# Preface

Since 2007, *NeoReviews™*, an online neonatology journal from the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), has published 4 to 10 continuing medical education questions per monthly issue. These questions refer to content from a review article and allow readers to assess their knowledge of the key aspects of the review. For this book, we selected approximately 1,200 questions that were published between 2007 and 2017 and remain relevant today. For each question, there is a short explanation of the correct answer with references, including the original article.

We envision that this book will be particularly helpful for neonatology fellows who are studying for the neonatal-perinatal medicine board examination, as the content closely correlates with the American Board of Pediatrics content specifications. It may also serve as a refresher and introduction to new topics for practicing neonatologists. In addition, we believe that this book is a valuable self-learning tool for pediatric residents, neonatal nurse practitioners, and neonatal nurses.

The *NeoReviews* Editorial Board aims to create a mix of content that encompasses core topics in neonatology as well as topics at the cutting edge of our field. To that end, some of the questions reference areas where knowledge is rapidly evolving; if readers find a question and answer that may be outdated, we encourage them to contact us so that we can update future editions.

We would like to acknowledge 2 people who crafted most of the original questions: Jayant Shenai, MD, FAAP, and Henry C. Lee, MD, FAAP, coauthor of this manual. We would also like to thank several people at the AAP who helped us get this book published: Carrie Peters, editor, professional/clinical publishing; Barrett Winston, senior manager, publishing acquisitions and business development; Jeff Mahony, director, professional and consumer publishing; and Joe Puskarz, director, journal publishing. We also thank Luann Zanzola and Sara Weissenborn, the past and current managing editors of *NeoReviews*.

Finally, we would like to dedicate this book to Alistair Philip, MD, FAAP, the editor in chief of *NeoReviews* from 2006 to 2017, who has been a wonderful editor, mentor, and friend; the field of neonatology has benefited tremendously from all his contributions.

Henry C. Lee, MD, FAAP
Santina A. Zanelli, MD, FAAP
Dara Brodsky, MD, FAAP

PART 1: QUESTIONS

# CARDIOLOGY

1. Differential cyanosis is defined as a difference in oxygen saturation of at least 5% or a difference in partial pressure of oxygen (Pao₂) of at least 20 mm Hg between the arm and the leg. If the upper extremity oxygen measurement is lower than the lower extremity oxygen measurement, the term reverse differential cyanosis is used. Of the following, the congenital heart disease most often associated with reverse differential cyanosis is:

A. Dextro-transposition of great arteries with coarctation of aorta or pulmonary hypertension
B. Ebstein anomaly of the tricuspid valve
C. Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve
D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
E. Truncus arteriosus

Source: Martin TC. Reverse differential cyanosis: a treatable newborn cardiac emergency. NeoReviews. 2011;12(5):e270-e273. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/12/5/e270. Accessed May 29, 2019

2. In newborns who have single-ventricle physiology, the proportions of venous return depend on how much blood flows to the pulmonary circulation through the ductus arteriosus compared with that entering the systemic circulation through the aorta. Ideally, the pulmonary blood flow (Qp) and systemic blood flow (Qs) should be balanced, leading to a Qp:Qs ratio of 1.0 to 1.7, which corresponds to an arterial oxygen saturation (Sao₂) of 75% to 85%. If the Sao₂ remains unacceptably high (&gt;90%), therapeutic measures to increase pulmonary vascular resistance and lower systemic vascular resistance are warranted. Of the following, the therapeutic measure most likely to improve systemic blood flow in newborns who have single-ventricle physiology is administration of:

A. Arginine-vasopressin
B. High-dose dopamine
C. Phosphodiesterase III inhibitor milrinone
D. Sodium bicarbonate
E. Supplemental oxygen

Source: Mastropietro CW, Tourner SP. Parallel circulations: managing single-ventricle physiology. NeoReviews. 2009;10(5):e239-e244. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/10/5/e239. Accessed May 29, 2019

3. The classic phenotype of hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) includes left ventricular hypoplasia associated with mitral stenosis/atresia, aortic atresia, coarctation of aorta, and an intact ventricular septum. Of the following, the most accurate statement regarding HLHS is that:

A. An intact interatrial septum is critical for survival.
B. Functional status of the right ventricle determines the approach to palliation.
C. HLHS accounts for approximately 25% of all cases of congenital heart disease.
D. Left ventricular communication with coronary sinusoids worsens the prognosis.
E. The size of the descending aorta is a risk factor for surgical palliation.

Source: Fricker FJ. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome: diagnosis and early management. NeoReviews. 2008;9(6):e253-e259. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/9/6/e253. Accessed May 29, 2019

4. You are asked to evaluate a 4-day-old term newborn for a cardiac arrhythmia. You review with medical students the normal findings on neonatal electrocardiography (ECG). Of the following, the most accurate statement regarding normal ECG findings in such a neonate is that the:

A. Corrected QT interval averages 470 ms
B. PR interval is measured best in lead I
C. QRS axis ranges from +55° to +200°
D. QRS duration ranges from 70 to 140 ms
E. T wave is usually negative in lead V₁

Source: Killen SAS, Fish FA. Fetal and neonatal arrhythmias. NeoReviews. 2008;9(6):e242-e252. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/9/6/e242. Accessed May 29, 2019

5. The transition from intrauterine to extrauterine life presents an abrupt change in cardiac workload and myocardial substrate delivery. The former is characterized by a decrease in right ventricular workload because of a decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance and by an increase in left ventricular workload because of an increase in systemic vascular resistance. The latter is characterized by a shift in myocardial substrate delivery from the fetal to the adult pattern. Of the following, the primary myocardial substrate used by the adult heart is:

A. Amino acids
B. Fatty acids
C. Glucose
D. Glycogen
E. Lactate

Source: Scholz TD, Segar JL. Cardiac metabolism in the fetus and newborn. NeoReviews. 2008;9(3):e109–e118. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/9/3/e109. Accessed May 29, 2019

6. The term *hypotension* can be defined simply as an abnormally low blood pressure. However, the definition of hypotension in neonates is compounded by uncertainties in establishing the lower limit of normal blood pressure below which treatment is required. Of the following, the most common approach to defining hypotension in neonates is based on:

A. Absolute threshold value of blood pressure below which an adverse outcome is likely
B. Extrapolation of data for blood pressure values from healthy neonates and young children
C. Level of blood pressure below which a disruption of important physiologic variables is likely
D. Randomized controlled trials investigating the optimal threshold value of blood pressure for treatment
E. Reference range of blood pressure values from a cohort of healthy neonates who have experienced no adverse outcomes

Source: Weindling AM, Subhedar NV. The definition of hypotension in very low-birthweight infants during the immediate neonatal period. NeoReviews. 2007;8(1):e32–e43. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/8/1/e32. Accessed May 29, 2019

7. Blood flow through an organ is proportional to the perfusion pressure divided by the vascular resistance. Of the following, the factor that causes the most significant change in blood flow with a minor alteration is:

A. Arterial pressure
B. Blood vessel diameter
C. Blood vessel length
D. Blood viscosity
E. Venous pressure

Source: Greisen G. Autoregulation of cerebral blood flow. NeoReviews. 2007;8(1):e22–e31. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/8/1/e22. Accessed May 29, 2019

8. When a newborn fails to achieve or sustain the normal decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance at birth, the result is hypoxemic respiratory failure or persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN). Of the following, the mediator most responsible for normal pulmonary vascular transition at birth is:

A. Asymmetric dimethylarginine
B. Endothelin-1
C. Leukotriene
D. Nitric oxide
E. Thromboxane

Source: Steinhorn RH, Farrow KN. Pulmonary hypertension in the neonate. NeoReviews. 2007;8(1):e14–e21. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/8/1/e14. Accessed May 29, 2019

9. Advocacy for universal newborn screening for critical congenital heart disease (CCHD) was driven by which of the following?

A. Academic research
B. Government
C. Industry
D. Parent advocacy
E. All of the above

Source: Govindaswami B, Jegatheesan P, Song D. Oxygen saturation screening for critical congenital heart disease. NeoReviews. 2012;13(12):e724–e731. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/13/12/e724. Accessed May 29, 2019

10. Which of the following is correct concerning the laboratory evaluation of cardiomyopathy?

A. An echocardiogram showing dilated cardiomyopathy rules out the need to do further genetic or metabolic testing.
B. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is characterized by hypertelorism, downward eye slanting, low-set ears, short stature, pulmonic stenosis (60% incidence), a web neck, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
C. Gene sequencing kits are available to aid in the diagnosis of cardiomyopathy whose sensitivity is so high that a negative test result invariably rules out the disease.
D. Mitochondrial disorders cause only a dilated and not a hypertrophic myocardopathy.
E. Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type 2) involves a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with an electrocardiogram (ECG) that most often shows a characteristic ECG with short PR intervals and biventricular hypertrophy.

Source: Wallis G, Fricker FJ. Neonatal cardiomyopathy. NeoReviews. 2012;13(12):e711–e723. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/13/12/e711. Accessed May 29, 2019

11. Evaluation of a fetus with a rapid heart rate by using pulsed-wave fetal Doppler imaging reveals atrial contractions that precede ventricular contractions. The atrial rate ranges between 180 and 240 beats per minute and seems to speed up and slow down. This most likely represents which of the following?

A. Atrial flutter
B. Ectopic atrial tachycardia
C. Premature atrial contractions
D. Second-degree atrioventricular block
E. Supraventricular tachycardia

Source: Pike JI, Greene EA. Fetal and neonatal supraventricular tachyarrhythmias. NeoReviews. 2012;13(10):e605–e614. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/13/10/e605. Accessed June 14, 2019

12. Expectant parents seeing the obstetrician for the first time early in pregnancy ask the clinician this question: "Are we at risk of having a child with congenital heart disease?" Which of the following is correct about detection of heart disease by using fetal echocardiography?

A. An older sibling with congenital heart disease is not considered a risk factor for recurrence.
B. Fetal hydrops is rarely (&lt; 1%) associated with fetal cardiac anomalies.
C. Maternal factors associated with greater risk for a fetus having congenital heart disease include diabetes mellitus, exposure to cardiac teratogens and/or viruses, congenital heart disease in the pregnant woman, and the presence of autoantibodies in the pregnant woman.
D. Most are detected in pregnancies with obvious risk factors.
E. Transabdominal imaging can be better than transvaginal imaging before 14 weeks' gestation.

Source: Co-Vu J, Ivsic T. Fetal echocardiography to diagnose fetal heart disease. NeoReviews. 2012;13(10):e590–e604. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/13/10/e590. Accessed June 14, 2019

Questions

13. Which of the following is correct about the outcome of patients with hypertension in the newborn period?

A. Nephrectomy should not be an option with multicystic or polycystic kidney disease.
B. Nephrogenesis is complete by 30 weeks' gestation.
C. Studies suggest that reduced nephron mass related to prematurity is a risk factor for the development of hypertension in adolescence and adulthood.
D. The patients least likely to have continued hypertension after the neonatal period are those who have an identifiable form of secondary hypertension, typically renal parenchymal or renovascular disease.
E. The vast majority of cases of hypertension in newborns do not resolve as these children get older.

Source: Dionne JM, Flynn JT. Hypertension in the neonate. NeoReviews. 2012;13(7):e401-e409. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/13/7/e401. Accessed June 14, 2019

14. A neonate with congenital diaphragmatic hernia is receiving mechanical ventilation and inhaled nitric oxide for persistent pulmonary hypertension. The patient is also hypotensive. Based on the current literature on vasopressin use for neonates with pulmonary hypertension, which of the following effects of vasopressin may be observed?

A. Hyponatremia may be seen in some cases.
B. Pulmonary arterial pressure will not decrease until high concentrations (&gt;1.2 U/kg/h) of vasopressin are infused.
C. The oxygenation index will likely increase.
D. There is likely to be higher sodium serum concentrations seen after vasopressin infusion.
E. Systemic blood pressure will most often decrease.

Source: Bondi DS, Ohler KH. Vasopressin and hemodynamic effects on the neonate. NeoReviews. 2017;18(8):e460-e471. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/18/8/e460. Accessed June 14, 2019

15. A male neonate born at 27-weeks' gestational age is now 10 weeks old and remains in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). He is receiving oral and gavage feedings and nasal cannula oxygen. He has had a complicated NICU course, with intraventricular hemorrhage and an episode of suspected necrotizing enterocolitis that was treated medically. Which of the following conditions has the most common nonrenal association with hypertension?

A. Bronchopulmonary dysplasia
B. Central line infection and sepsis
C. Intraventricular hemorrhage
D. Necrotizing enterocolitis
E. Retinopathy of prematurity

Source: Mistry K, Gupta C. Neonatal hypertension. NeoReviews. 2017;18(6):e357-e371. http://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/18/6/e357. Accessed June 14, 2019

16. Management of hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) has evolved over the last 3 decades. Of the following, the current approach to management of HLHS in most neonates is:

A. Blalock-Taussig shunt
B. Comfort care
C. Glenn shunt procedure
D. Neonatal heart transplant
E. Norwood palliation

Source: Fricker FJ. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome. NeoReviews. 2008;9(6):e253-e259. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/9/6/e253. Accessed June 14, 2019

17. Treatment for fetal tachycardia may be warranted if the tachycardia is sustained and the cardiac function is compromised. Of the following, the antiarrhythmic drug most effective in inducing a normal heart rhythm in the fetus with resistant atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia is:

A. Amiodarone
B. Flecainide
C. Procainamide
D. Sotalol
E. Verapamil

Source: Killen SAS, Fish FA. Fetal and neonatal arrhythmias. NeoReviews. 2008;9(6):e242–e252. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/9/6/e242. Accessed June 14, 2019

18. A 1-hour-old term female is having respiratory distress. She was born in meconium-stained amniotic fluid. Her oxygen saturation is low, and the saturation in the lower limbs is 10% lower than the saturation measured in the right wrist. You suspect possible persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN). Which of the following statements correctly describes the pathophysiologic nature of PPHN?

A. In PPHN, high pulmonary vasculature resistance decreases the blood flow to the lungs, and there is preferential blood flow to the systemic circulation, which is the path of least resistance.
B. In PPHN, the oxygen saturation is likely to remain at a consistent, stable level with very little change.
C. In PPHN, there is an excess induction of endothelial nitric oxide synthase, leading to an abundance of nitric oxide in the pulmonary vasculature.
D. In PPHN, there will be excessive shunting of deoxygenated blood that flows from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries.
E. The foramen ovale must be closed for PPHN to have clinical manifestations in the newborn.

Source: Lakshminrusimha S, Keszler M. Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn. NeoReviews. 2015;16(12):e680–e692. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/16/12/e680. Accessed June 14, 2019

19. You are considering steroid administration for a 27-weeks' gestational age neonate who remains hypotensive. Which of the following is correct regarding steroids and preterm neonates?

A. Both dexamethasone and hydrocortisone are associated with increased catecholamine metabolism.
B. Cortisol concentrations tend to be increased in preterm neonates who are receiving inotropic support.
C. Dexamethasone is preferred over hydrocortisone in extremely preterm neonates because of a safer profile regarding long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes.
D. Hydrocortisone downregulates angiotensin II receptors, leading to increased vascular resistance.
E. Hydrocortisone inhibits the expression of inducible nitric oxide synthase and vasodilatory prostaglandin action.

Source: Sahni M, Jain S. Hypotension in neonates. NeoReviews. 2016;17(10):e579–e589. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/17/10/e579. Accessed June 14, 2019

20. A pregnant woman at 20 weeks' gestation undergoes prenatal ultrasonography. The fetus is suspected of having congenital heart disease (CHD) and is referred for formal fetal echocardiography and counseling. Which of the following statements regarding CHD is correct?

A. Approximately 1 of 15 fetuses with CHD has a chromosomal abnormality.
B. CHD is more commonly found in trisomy 18 and trisomy 21 but is rarely found for trisomy 13.
C. DiGeorge syndrome is found in approximately 25% of patients with CHD.
D. The finding of a conotruncal heart defect is a risk factor for DiGeorge syndrome and may prompt further testing for that condition.
E. Ultrasonography at this gestational age is generally not specific enough for diagnosing CHD, and fetal echocardiography should be withheld until just before delivery.

Source: Chock V, Lee HC. Neurodevelopmental outcomes for infants born with congenital heart disease. NeoReviews. 2014;15(8):e344–e353. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/15/8/e344. Accessed June 14, 2019

21. A resuscitation team is present for the delivery of a term neonate with a prenatal diagnosis of hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS). Which of the following is correct regarding this condition and neurodevelopment?

A. Neonates with HLHS are at risk of developing gross or fine motor abnormalities, attention-deficit/hyperactivity problems, and/or special education needs.
B. Neonates with HLHS are most likely to have deficits of motor development, with 90% of patients having normal cognitive outcomes at school age but with 30% to 40% having motor difficulties.
C. Neurologic imaging is unlikely to be of use in this case because 99% of patients with HLHS have normal brain ultrasonographic and magnetic resonance imaging findings.
D. Several large studies concerning neonates with HLHS have demonstrated no differences in neurodevelopmental or medical outcomes whether the condition was diagnosed prenatally or after profound circulatory collapse after postnatal ductal closure.
E. The presence of a genetic polymorphism of apolipoprotein E in neonates with HLHS is a neuroprotective factor.

Source: Chock V, Lee HC. Neurodevelopmental outcomes for infants born with congenital heart disease. NeoReviews. 2014;15(8):e344-e353. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/15/8/e344. Accessed June 14, 2019

22. A female neonate born at 25-weeks' gestational age is now 4 weeks old. The nurse reports that the neonate has been hypertensive at the last 2 blood pressure measurements, and on further review, you note that the blood pressure has had an increasing trend over the past few days. A diagnostic evaluation is pursued, and no clear cause is found. Which of the following statements regarding treatment and prognosis is correct?

A. α- and β-adrenergic agonists are the most effective antihypertensive drugs in preterm neonates.
B. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors should be avoided in preterm neonates, those with acute renal failure, and those with hyperkalemia.
C. In observational studies, preterm neonates who receive antihypertensive medications in the initial neonatal intensive care unit hospital course have a strong likelihood (&gt;50%) of requiring lifelong antihypertensive therapy.
D. Nephrogenesis stops at approximately 24-weeks' gestational age, so subsequent postnatal therapies will have little clinical benefit in this population.
E. There is no indication or role for oral antihypertensive medications in the neonatal intensive care unit.

Source: Mistry K, Gupta C. Neonatal hypertension. NeoReviews. 2017;18(6):e357-e371. http://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/18/6/e357. Accessed June 14, 2019

23. A newborn with dextro-transposition of the great arteries (d-TGA) undergoes brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) before surgery. Which of the following is correct regarding imaging for congenital heart disease (CHD)?

A. Normal brain MRI results are highly specific for long-term development in CHD regardless of type, and follow-up evaluations of neurodevelopment for such patients are not necessary.
B. Approximately 75% to 90% of newborns with CHD demonstrate white matter injury on MRI or on autopsy postoperatively.
C. Brain MRI is more sensitive than ultrasonography for intraventricular hemorrhage but is overall less likely to detect infarction, periventricular leukomalacia, or evidence of hypoxia-ischemia.
D. In general, the use of brain MRI for d-TGA should be restricted to several weeks postoperatively and closer to the time of discharge because there are unlikely to be significant differences in pre- or postsurgical imaging results.
E. The most common abnormalities detected on presurgical MRI for patients with complex CHD are white matter injury and infarction.

Source: Chock V, Lee HC. Neurodevelopmental outcomes for infants born with congenital heart disease. NeoReviews. 2014;15(8):e344-e353. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/15/8/e344. Accessed June 14, 2019

24. A neonate with a prenatal diagnosis of hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is born at 38 weeks' gestation. Echocardiographic results soon after birth confirm the diagnosis and also more clearly delineate the mitral and aortic valve structure and function. The patient has mitral stenosis. Which of the following statements is true regarding prognosis and subtypes of HLHS?

A. Mitral stenosis is always associated with a ventricular septal defect.
B. The combination of mitral stenosis and aortic stenosis associated with HLHS is the rarest subtype, occurring in less than 10% of cases.
C. The subtype of mitral atresia and aortic atresia constitute approximately 75% of all hypoplastic left hearts.
D. When associated with aortic atresia, this subtype is at particularly high risk because of the presence of coronary-cameral fistulas in approximately one-half of such patients.
E. When mitral stenosis is combined with aortic stenosis, all cases result in fetal death.

Source: Moodley S, Tacy TA. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome: diagnosis, care and management from fetal life and beyond. NeoReviews. 2015;16(2):e109–e119. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/16/2/e109. Accessed June 14, 2019

25. A pregnant woman finds out that her neonate has hypoplastic left heart syndrome. The cardiologist and neonatologist meet with the parents at 28 weeks' gestation for further counseling and to discuss plans for clinical management. Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding management of hypoplastic left heart syndrome?

A. After birth, there is a goal to balance the parallel systemic and pulmonary circulations preoperatively to achieve a 1:1 pulmonary-to-systemic flow ratio.
B. If transplant is not performed after birth within the first 1 to 2 weeks, there is a 100% neonatal mortality rate.
C. Prostaglandin is contraindicated postnatally because of its effect on renal perfusion.
D. The consensus guidelines state that prenatal atrial decompression via femoral vessel catheterization with a balloon or stent be attempted at 34 weeks for patients who also have a ventricular septal defect.
E. The current standard of care for all patients with fetal detection before 32 weeks' gestation is to undergo prenatal intervention by means of aortic valve dilation in utero.

Source: Moodley S, Tacy TA. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome: diagnosis, care and management from fetal life and beyond. NeoReviews. 2015;16(2):e109–e119. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/16/2/e109. Accessed June 14, 2019

26. A 3-day-old 25-weeks' gestational age neonate has low blood pressure and is receiving a continuous infusion of dopamine. The neonate is suspected of having sepsis. Which of the following statements regarding dopamine is correct?

A. Dopamine at low doses (0.5–2.0 mcg/kg/min) acts on dopaminergic receptors.
B. Dopamine generally lowers the mean arterial pressure in neonates.
C. Dopamine has no chronotropic effect at any dose.
D. Dopamine is an endogenous inhibitor of norepinephrine.
E. Dopaminergic receptor stimulation in the kidney leads to renal vasoconstriction.

Source: Ruoss JL, McPherson C, DiNardo J. Inotrope and vasopressor support in neonates. NeoReviews. 2015;16(6):e351–e361. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/16/6/e351. Accessed June 15, 2019

27. The factors that influence vascular resistance are divided into the following categories: blood pressure, chemical (partial pressures of oxygen and carbon dioxide), metabolic, and neurogenic. Of the following, the most accurate statement regarding control of vascular resistance is:

A. Arterial/arteriolar vasoconstriction in response to increased luminal pressure is endothelium dependent.
B. Hypercapnia-induced vasodilation mediated through extracellular hydrogen ion concentration requires a basal level of nitric oxide.
C. Hypoxia-induced vasodilation is independent of an intact endothelium and nitric oxide production.

Smooth muscle cells of the arterial and arteriolar wall of the cerebral circulation contract in response to increased intravascular pressure, and the resultant vasoconstriction prevents excessive blood flow to the brain. Conversely, the same smooth muscle cells relax in response to decreased intravascular pressure, and the resultant vasodilation enhances blood flow to the brain. This phenomenon, which promotes maintenance of cerebral blood flow at a constant rate despite fluctuations in systemic blood pressure, is called cerebral autoregulation. Of the following, the most accurate statement regarding cerebral autoregulation in neonates is that:

A. Autoregulation in the human fetus develops much later in gestation than it does in the fetal lamb.
B. Autoregulation is active in preterm neonates treated with dopamine for systemic arterial hypotension.
C. Elevated partial pressure of carbon dioxide has no effect on cerebral autoregulation.
D. Loss or absence of autoregulation often precedes germ layer hemorrhage in preterm neonates.
E. The lower threshold for autoregulation in term neonates is believed to be $40\mathrm{mmHg}$ or higher.

Source: Greisen G. Autoregulation of cerebral blood flow. NeoReviews. 2007;8(1):e22–e31. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/8/1/e22. Accessed June 19, 2019

A. GENETICS AND INBORN ERRORS OF METABOLISM

1. When a maternally derived allele is silenced at a particular gene locus, such silencing is called maternal imprinting. Similarly, silencing of a paternally derived allele is called paternal imprinting. An imprinting error in the fetus can have serious health consequences. Gene imprinting errors can occur in association with artificial reproductive techniques. Of the following, the fetal condition most associated with a gene imprinting error during in vitro fertilization is:

A. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
B. Prader-Willi syndrome
C. Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1B
D. Silver-Russell syndrome
E. Transient neonatal diabetes

Source: Morley R, Saffery R, Hacking DF, Craig JM. Epigenetics and neonatology: the birth of a new era. NeoReviews. 2009;10(8):e387-e395. https://neoreviews.aappublications.org/content/10/8/e387. Accessed July 8, 2019

D. Sensation of posterior movement and relocation on gentle anterior traction

# CARDIOLOGY

1.  A. Dextro-transposition of great arteries with coarctation of aorta or pulmonary hypertension

This rare clinical finding of reverse differential cyanosis is most often associated with dextro-transposition of the great arteries along with either coarctation of the aorta/interrupted aortic arch or with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn.¹² In these conditions, the preductal partial pressure of oxygen (Pao₂) will be lower than the postductal Pao₂.

2.  C. Phosphodiesterase III inhibitor milrinone

Systemic afterload reducers such as the phosphodiesterase III inhibitor milrinone (0.375–0.75 mcg/kg/min) decrease systemic vascular resistance, which can lead to improved systemic blood flow.¹² Minimizing afterload may facilitate oxygen delivery to vital organs.

## References

1.  Barnea O, Austin EH, Richman B, Santamore WP. Balancing the circulation: theoretic optimization of pulmonary/systemic flow ratio in hypoplastic left heart syndrome. J Am Coll Cardiol. 1994;24(5):1376–1381

3.  B. Functional status of the right ventricle determines the approach to palliation.

Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) accounts for 7% to 9% of all neonates born with congenital heart defects. In HLHS, the right ventricle and tricuspid valve represent the systemic ventricle and atrioventricular valve, and their functional status determines the approach to palliation.¹ An unrestricted interatrial communication is critical to survival.

1.  Alsoufi B, Bennetts J, Verma S, Caldarone CA. New developments in the treatment of hypoplastic left heart syndrome. Pediatrics. 2007;119(1):109–117

4.  C. QRS axis ranges from +55° to +200°

In a term neonate, the QRS axis ranges from +55° to +200°, and the normal QRS duration, as measured in lead V₅, ranges from 20 to 80 ms. In the preterm newborn, the QRS axis ranges from +65° to +174°.

5.  B. Fatty acids

Before birth, the predominant substrates taken up and oxidized by the fetal heart are glucose and lactate.¹ Postnatally, there is a shift to the adult pattern of using primarily fatty acids to supply reducing equivalents to the mitochondrial electron transport chain.²

6.  E. Reference range of blood pressure values from a cohort of healthy neonates who have experienced no adverse outcomes

The most common approach of defining hypotension has been to define normality in a cohort of healthy preterm neonates by creating reference ranges for blood pressure on the basis of birth weight, gestational age, postnatal age, or a combination of the 3.¹ For a neonate of known gestation or birth weight, hypotension is defined as blood pressure less than the 3rd, 5th, or 10th percentile at any given postnatal age. ## 7. B. Blood vessel diameter

Large vessels (conduit arteries) and small vessels (intraparenchymatous arteries and arterioles) contribute about equally to vascular resistance, large arteries because of their length and small arteries and arterioles because of their small diameter. Even a minor change in diameter induces a significant change in resistance. For example, a 10% reduction in diameter results in a 35% increase in vascular resistance.

## 8. D. Nitric oxide

The primary endothelial products thought to be responsible for the pulmonary vascular changes during transition include nitric oxide and arachidonic acid metabolites. Nitric oxide production increases dramatically at the time of birth. Pulmonary expression of both endothelial nitric oxide synthase and its downstream target, soluble guanylate cyclase, increases during late gestation.¹

## 9. E. All of the above

Annamarie Saarinen led a group of mothers and families with neonates affected by congenital heart disease, some of whom did not survive infancy, and inspired the Advisory Committee on Heritable Disorders in Newborns and Children to add critical congenital heart disease (CCHD) to its list of disorders that receive universal screening before hospital discharge. By 2009-2011, several persuasive arguments had been made by pediatric cardiologists in the lay press and medical literature.¹² Stakeholders from affected families, governmental agencies, the March of Dimes, professional societies, industry, and others worked together to shape policy.

## 10. E. Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type 2) involves a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with an electrocardiogram (ECG) that most often shows a characteristic ECG with short PR intervals and biventricular hypertrophy.

Patients who have Pompe disease have a characteristic ECG with short PR intervals and biventricular hypertrophy. The ECGs of patients who have hypertrophic cardiomyopathy often show left atrial enlargement and high voltages representing biventricular hypertrophy.¹ Patients may also have concomitant preexcitation.

## 11. B. Ectopic atrial tachycardia

When an ectopic focus in the atria consistently depolarizes more quickly than the sinus node, the sinus node is suppressed, and the fetus develops an ectopic atrial tachycardia. Although the area of initial activation in the atria cannot be determined with routine fetal echocardiography, pulsed-wave fetal Doppler imaging can reveal an atrial contraction that precedes each ventricular contraction. In addition, ectopic atrial tachycardia can often be distinguished by the way it speeds ("warms") up and slows ("cools") down with atrial rates that usually range from 180 to 240 beats per minute.¹

The presence of certain factors will place a fetus at significantly higher risk of having congenital heart disease. These known risk factors include maternal, fetal, and familial components. Maternal risk factors

In persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN), ventilation-perfusion mismatch and extrapulmonary right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood across the patent foramen ovale and patent ductus arteriosus result in cyanosis. ## 19. E. Hydrocortisone inhibits the expression of inducible nitric oxide synthase and vasodilatory prostaglandin action.

Hydrocortisone exerts its cardiovascular action by means of the following mechanisms:

- Inhibition of the expression of inducible nitric oxide synthase and vasodilatory prostaglandin action¹,²
- Upregulation of cardiovascular adrenergic receptors, which can result in vasoconstriction, increased cardiac output, and increased blood pressure¹
- Upregulation of angiotensin II receptors and their second messenger systems, which play important roles in blood pressure regulation¹,²
- Inhibition of catecholamine metabolism and the release of vasoactive factors³
- Increase in the intracellular calcium concentration, leading to enhanced myocardial and vascular responsiveness to catecholamines³

## 25. A. After birth, there is a goal to balance the parallel systemic and pulmonary circulations preoperatively to achieve a 1:1 pulmonary-to-systemic flow ratio.

Patients with hypoplastic left heart syndrome are admitted to the intensive care unit for further assessment, monitoring, and initiation of prostaglandin therapy to maintain systemic output through ductus arteriosus patency. Balancing of the parallel systemic and pulmonary circulations is the major task preoperatively, with the goal of achieving a pulmonary-to-systemic flow ratio of 1:1. Although transplant is a potential option, surgical advancements and the lack of donor hearts with high waiting-list mortality has made transplant a less common choice.¹

26. A. Dopamine at low doses (0.5–2.0 mcg/kg/min) acts on dopaminergic receptors.

Dopamine is an endogenous sympathomimetic that potentiates release of norepinephrine in addition to having direct action on α, β, and dopaminergic receptors.¹ Potential effects may include α₁ receptor stimulation, leading to systemic vasoconstriction, and β₁ receptor stimulation, which increases cardiac output through positive inotropy (myocardial contractility) and chronotropy (heart rate). Dopaminergic receptor stimulation increases renal blood flow through renal vasodilation, change in tubular absorption, and positive inotropy.² The receptor effects of dopamine are dose dependent in children and adults, with a low dose (0.5–2.0 mcg/kg/min) acting on dopaminergic receptors, a medium dose (2–6 mcg/kg/min) acting on cardiac β₁ receptors, and a higher dose of greater than 6 to 10 mcg/kg/min acting on α₁ receptors.²

29. C. Milrinone has an inotropic effect by causing decreased breakdown of cyclic adenosine monophosphate.

Milrinone is a phosphodiesterase type 3 (PDE3) inhibitor with inotropic, inodilator (promotes myocardial contractility and produces vasodilation), and lusitropic (promotes myocardial relaxation) properties. The inotropic effect results from decreased breakdown of cyclic adenosine monophosphate by PDE3, perpetuating calcium influx into myocardial cells and resulting in myocardial contraction.¹⁻³

Norepinephrine is an endogenous catecholamine that increases systemic vascular resistance and cardiac output by activation of α₁,₂ and β₁ receptors. Norepinephrine constricts systemic vasculature to a greater degree than it constricts pulmonary vasculature.⁴ Dobutamine is a synthetic sympathomimetic amine that acts directly on α and β receptors without the release of norepinephrine.⁵

30. E. Prophylactic administration of hydrocortisone in association with concurrent indomethacin therapy has been associated with spontaneous intestinal perforation.

Corticosteroids aid in the management of hypotension by decreasing the breakdown of catecholamines, increasing calcium levels in myocardial cells, and upregulating adrenergic receptors.¹ Adverse effects of corticosteroids include hyperglycemia, gastric irritation, and fluid retention. Long-term exposure increases the risk of osteopenia and inhibits immune function and somatic growth. In considering the use of hydrocortisone in the setting of a normal cortisol level, a “normal” level in the setting of stress may indicate relative adrenal insufficiency, so it is likely that such a neonate will respond to hydrocortisone supplementation.

In a randomized clinical trial, neonates exposed to histologic chorioamnionitis had lower mortality when treated prophylactically with hydrocortisone soon after birth.² This trial was halted early because of the high incidence of spontaneous intestinal perforations in the treatment group. Subsequent analysis revealed that this complication occurred predominantly in the setting of concurrent indomethacin therapy.²

## 40. A. A typical course for patients is regression or resolution of ventricular hypertrophy, irrespective of therapy, at approximately 1 month of age.

The prognosis for neonates who have hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in association with maternal diabetes is generally excellent with the current state of neonatal care. Hemodynamic challenges frequently are associated with diastolic dysfunction and occasionally with systolic dysfunction. Even in neonates who have symptoms, the disease is self-limited, and recovery is typical after several weeks of supportive care. Way et al¹ described a series of 11 infants of mothers with diabetes who presented with congestive heart failure in the first week after birth and who were followed up until age 40 months. All patients were asymptomatic at approximately 1 month of age, and echocardiography revealed regression or complete resolution of the ventricular hypertrophy, irrespective of the therapy.

## 41. E. The preterm neonate may have relatively low systemic blood flow because of the structure of the preterm myocardium, which may be less able to overcome the increased systemic vascular resistance that occurs after birth.

At birth, the lower-pressure umbilical circulation is eliminated, resulting in increased systemic vascular resistance. Because of the structure of the preterm myocardium, there may be a lack of ability to overcome this increased resistance, leading to low systemic blood flow. Hence, neonates born at less than 30-weeks' gestation commonly have low systemic blood flow, which contributes to low blood pressure.¹

Positive pressure ventilation may contribute to decreased systemic blood flow by increasing the intrathoracic pressure and decreasing the venous return.² In both preterm and term neonates, chorioamnionitis can be associated with hypotension, which may be caused by the release of inflammatory mediators, such as interleukin-1 and tumor necrosis factor, which lead to peripheral vasodilation and increased vascular permeability.³

At normal levels of hemoglobin (15 g/dL), the presence of 3 to 5 g/dL of reduced hemoglobin results in 20% to 30% desaturation, and cyanosis is visible at oxygen saturation of approximately 70% to 80%. 46. A. Adding a view to include the left- and right-sided outflow tracts to the usual 4-chamber views at 20 weeks' gestation can improve the detection rate of cardiac anomalies from 60% to 90% if performed by a trained specialist.

Routine obstetric ultrasonography typically is performed at 20 weeks' gestation in low-risk pregnancies, usually including a 4-chamber view to display both atria, both ventricles, the atrial and ventricular septum, and the mitral and tricuspid valves. For a trained specialist, this view can demonstrate up to 60% of congenital heart defects. However, without the use of additional imaging views, the diagnosis of congenital heart defects affecting the aortic and pulmonary valves (eg, pulmonary and aortic valve stenosis), the great arteries (eg, transposition of the great arteries and truncus arteriosus), and the venous systems is nearly impossible. By adding a view to include the left- and right-sided outflow tracts, the detection rate improves to approximately 90% if performed by a trained specialist.

47. A. For neonates, the preferred initial therapy is oral propranolol.

Noonan syndrome is the most common cause of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in neonates and children younger than age 4 years. In hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, the mechanism of action of β-blockers, such as propranolol, includes slowing of the heart rate and prolongation of diastole, which allows for an increase in ventricular filling. Although it is commonly used for adults, verapamil is contraindicated in neonates. Medical therapy does not alter the prognosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and is primarily used for relief of symptoms. In the patient without symptoms who has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, medical therapy is controversial.

48. A. Choanal atresia

Choanal atresia is a blockage or narrowing of the nasal passage. Newborns are obligate nasal breathers, and bilateral choanal atresia or stenosis results in cyanosis and respiratory distress. Cyanosis is more intense at rest and improves when crying with the mouth open.

49. A. At moderate doses of 5 to 10 mcg/kg/min, dopamine predominantly increases cardiac contractility and heart rate by stimulating the cardiac β₁-, β₂-, and α₁-adrenergic and dopaminergic receptors.

Dopamine is the inotropic medication most commonly used for hypotension in neonates. It exerts a dose-dependent stimulation of the α- and β-adrenergic and dopaminergic receptors. Pharmacodynamic data on dose-related effects of dopamine in the neonate are limited. In adults and children, dopamine at low doses (2–4 mcg/kg/min) dilates renal and splanchnic vessels by its action on dopaminergic receptors. At moderate doses (5–10 mcg/kg/min), it predominantly increases cardiac contractility and heart rate by stimulating the cardiac β₁-, β₂-, and α₁-adrenergic and dopaminergic receptors. At high doses (≥ 10–20 mcg/kg/min), dopamine increases peripheral vascular resistance by stimulating vascular α₁ receptors.

For example, DiGeorge syndrome or 22q11.2 gene deletion is found in approximately 12% of neonates with CHD, particularly those with conotruncal lesions.² Neonates with 22q11.2 deletion are at increased risk for seizures, neurocognitive delay, autism, schizophrenia, and other social-interactive disorders.³

55. B. Doppler imaging pattern of the pulmonary venous flow

Determining the adequacy of the atrial communication is an important part of fetal assessment in hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS), with the potential need for fetal or immediate neonatal intervention in patients with a restrictive atrial septum. The actual size of the foramen ovale has not correlated well with the degree of left atrial hypertension after delivery. $^{1}$ A more reliable assessment is pulmonary vein flow patterns assessed with spectral Doppler ultrasonography. The pulmonary vein Doppler imaging pattern in the normal heart consists of forward flow into the left atrium during systole and early diastole, with either cessation of flow or a small amount of flow reversal during atrial contraction. In HLHS, pulmonary venous return is unable to pass through the stenotic or atretic mitral valve and seeks an alternate pathway, shunting from left to right through the foramen ovale. If this atrial communication is restrictive, left atrial hypertension ensues, and flow reversal with atrial contraction becomes more prominent in the pulmonary veins. $^{1-3}$

## 57. C. Patient factors such as genetic syndromes and low birth weight may have a larger effect than do operative factors in determining neurodevelopmental outcomes.

In the current era of surgical repair and preoperative and postoperative care, survival for hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) can be as high as 74% to 93%. With increasing survival rates, neurodevelopmental outcomes and quality of life have become more prominent as outcomes of concern. Multiple factors may contribute to the neurodevelopmental outcomes in patients with HLHS, including prenatal factors, such as ischemia and microcephaly, presumed to be secondary to altered cerebral blood flow, prematurity, cardiac anatomic factors, associated neurologic malformations, genetic conditions, postnatal chronic cyanosis, and surgical factors, including exposure to cardiopulmonary bypass and surgical technique. The significance of patient factors, such as genetic syndromes and low birth weight outweighs operative factors. $^{1-3}$

## 58. D. Neonates with premature atrial contractions or atrial bigeminy are usually treated with observation because the prognosis is excellent and the resolution of these usually occurs within the first 4 weeks after birth, often within a few days.

Several types of supraventricular tachyarrhythmias can occur in the fetus and neonate, including premature atrial contractions, ectopic atrial tachycardia, atrial flutter, and supraventricular tachycardia. $^{1,2}$ Neonates with premature atrial contractions or atrial bigeminy are treated with observation. The prognosis is excellent, with resolution usually occurring within the first 4 weeks after birth.

Multifocal or chaotic atrial tachycardia is diagnosed when there are 3 or more P-wave morphologies in the tachycardia. This rhythm may resemble atrial fibrillation. Ectopic atrial tachycardia can often be distinguished by the way it speeds up and slows down, with atrial rates that usually range from 180 to 240 beats per minute.

The rate of atrial flutter, if conducted 1:1, is usually 300 beats per minute but may conduct with 2:1 block at a rate of 200 beats per minute.

## 62. C. Possible negative effects of milrinone include systemic hypotension, tachycardia, tachyarrhythmias, and thrombocytopenia.

Milrinone is a phosphodiesterase type 3 inhibitor with inotropic, inodilator (promotes myocardial contractility and produces vasodilation), and lusitropic (promotes myocardial relaxation) properties. Cumulatively, milrinone increases cardiac output without an increase in myocardial oxygen demand, while decreasing afterload by decreasing systemic vascular resistance. The half-life of milrinone is 1.5 to 3.5 hours. The possible negative effects of milrinone include systemic hypotension, tachycardia, tachyarrhythmias, and thrombocytopenia.¹

Diagnoses such as 22q11 deletion syndrome or cri du chat del 5p and other microdeletions or duplications are commonly made using FISH. Subtelomeric FISH can also be used to assess for rearrangements in the telomere-associated repeat sequences at the distal ends of chromosomes. Such studies are especially useful in patients with multiple congenital anomalies and normal karyotype. A newer technique, multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification, is replacing FISH to detect genetic anomalies.¹ It requires a very small amount of DNA and can detect differences in a single nucleotide; therefore, it can detect small single-gene variations that may not be detected with FISH.

References

69. A. Although neonates with HCM of mothers with diabetes may appear edematous, they are actually obese, and diuretics could be counterproductive.

Therapy for neonates with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) includes:
- Maintenance fluids
- Mechanical ventilation if necessary
- Correction of hypoglycemia and hypomagnesemia
- Early diagnostic echocardiography and close follow-up
- Avoidance of inotropic agents
- Avoidance of diuretics unless there is objective evidence of fluid overload

70. D. Esmolol

Drugs to facilitate therapy for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy include β-blockers; short-acting β-blockers, such as esmolol, are preferable. Inotropic agents and diuretics are not typically recommended.

71. E. Ventilation of the lungs and an increase in oxygen tension lead to pulmonary vasodilation.

The transition from fetal to extrauterine life is associated with several events in circulation. Clamping of the umbilical cord removes the low-resistance placental circulation, increasing systemic arterial pressure. Various mechanisms lead to reduced pulmonary resistance and increased pulmonary blood flow. The most important stimulus to promote pulmonary vasodilation appears to be ventilation of the lungs and an increase in oxygen tension.¹ An 8-fold increase in pulmonary blood flow occurs, which raises left atrial pressure, closing the foramen ovale. Because the pulmonary vascular resistance decreases lower than systemic vascular resistance, flow reverses across the ductus arteriosus (from the aorta to the pulmonary artery, or left to right). The increase in arterial oxygen saturation leads to closure of the ductus arteriosus and ductus venosus.

References
1. Lakshminrusimha S, Steinhorn RH. Pulmonary vascular biology during neonatal transition. Clin Perinatol. 1999;26(3):601-619

72. E. Epinephrine has a nonselective α-agonist action and causes activation of both β₁- and β₂-adrenergic receptors, as well as increasing blood pressure and systemic blood flow by increasing both systemic vascular resistance and cardiac output.

Epinephrine is an endogenous catecholamine that is released by the adrenal gland in response to stressful stimulation. It has a potent nonselective α-agonist action and causes activation of both β₁- and β₂-adrenergic receptors.¹ Epinephrine increases blood pressure and systemic blood flow by increasing systemic vascular resistance and cardiac output. Epinephrine administered at low dosages (0.01–0.1 mcg/kg/min) stimulates β receptors, leading to enhanced myocardial contractility and peripheral vasodilation. At higher doses (&gt; 0.1 mcg/kg/min), additional stimulation of α receptors causes peripheral vasoconstriction and increased systemic vascular resistance.²

Pulmonary valve atresia is characterized by the absence of blood flow across the pulmonary valve as a result of a membrane-like structure in the region of the pulmonary valve. ## 77. C. If a patient with typical SVT has Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, the usual first-line medication is propranolol.

There are several drug choices for neonatal supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Sometimes 2 or more medications may be required. Each drug has an adverse effect profile that should be considered. β-Blockers might exacerbate reactive airway disease; amiodarone may cause hypothyroidism. Adenosine may be used for conversion of atrioventricular reentry tachycardia. Digoxin can be used for ectopic atrial tachycardia. Propranolol is the first-line treatment for typical SVT with WPW syndrome.

80. D. Preterm neonates are more susceptible to ischemia with low blood pressure and to hemorrhage with high blood pressure.

Cerebral autoregulation, in which arteries constrict in response to an increase in transmural pressure and dilate in response to a decrease in pressure, allows for an almost constant blood flow with a range of arterial blood pressures. This ability to autoregulate is immature in preterm neonates and occurs only over a narrow range of blood pressures. Hence, preterm neonates are particularly susceptible to ischemia with low blood pressure and to hemorrhage with high blood pressure.¹

81. E. Transposition of the great arteries with patent ductus arteriosus and coarctation of the aorta

Differential cyanosis occurs when the upper extremities are pink and the lower extremities are blue. It is usually caused by severe coarctation of the aorta or interrupted aortic arch in the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus, which supplies the lower extremities with desaturated blood from the patent ductus arteriosus.¹

Reverse differential cyanosis, with the upper extremities appearing cyanotic and the lower extremities appearing pink, occurs in the setting of transposition of the great arteries with a patent ductus arteriosus in the presence of severe coarctation of the aorta, interrupted aortic arch, or pulmonary hypertension.

86. E. The screening should be performed again 1 hour later.

In critical congenital heart disease screening conducted using pulse oximetry, preductal (right upper extremity) saturations are compared with postductal (lower extremity) saturations. A failed screening is when 1 of these findings occurs:

- The oxygen saturation value is less than 90%.
- Oxygen saturation is less than 95% in the right hand and foot on 3 measurements, each separated by 1 hour.
- The difference between pre- and postductal saturations is greater than 3% on 3 measurements, each separated by 1 hour.

87. A. Mean arterial pressure will generally increase with vasopressin use.

The primary role of vasopressin in the body is to regulate extracellular osmolality, and it is administered therapeutically for diabetes insipidus. Vasopressin also has vascular effects via stimulation of G protein-coupled V₁ₐ and V₂ receptors in the cardiovascular system. The V₁ₐ receptors located on vascular smooth muscle lead to vasoconstriction, whereas the V₂ receptors lead to vasodilatation. Vasoconstrictive effects predominate when vasopressin is used as an intravenous infusion, resulting in increased systemic vascular resistance and increased mean arterial blood pressure. Administration of vasopressin is thought to be especially useful in shock states when patients are likely to have low endogenous circulating arginine-vasopressin concentrations.

90. B. Echocardiography is the current standard for evaluation of fetal cardiac function and rhythm.

Echocardiographic tools, including 2-dimensional structural evaluation; M-mode analysis; and tissue, color, and pulsed-wave Doppler imaging, are all useful in fetal diagnosis and treatment. However, these modalities continue to have limitations in that the mechanical results of the arrhythmia are used to make assumptions about the underlying electrical activity.¹

Fetal electrocardiography, which allows for a more direct evaluation of fetal cardiac conduction, is still limited by poor data quality and interference from maternal signals.

Fetal magnetocardiography allows for acquisition of high-quality fetal cardiac signals, leading to a more specific and accurate arrhythmia diagnosis, but is limited in usefulness because of rare availability.²

## 94. A. Increases during the first days after birth

Blood pressure is low at birth and increases during the first few days. It also increases with increasing gestational age and birth weight. $^{1}$

Because blood pressure is a function of both blood flow and systemic vascular resistance, it is possible to have a low blood pressure with normal blood flow or a normal blood pressure with low blood flow. Thus, there is a weak relationship between mean blood pressure and left ventricular output. $^{2}$

## 96. C. Hyperdynamic precordial activity

The physical examination findings in hypoplastic left heart syndrome may vary with newborns who seemingly appear well at birth. Although there will be a complete admixture of systemic and pulmonary venous return, pulmonary blood flow relative to marginal systemic blood flow is increased, resulting in oxygen saturation greater than 85%, and cyanosis may be difficult to recognize at this level. Certain clues can increase suspicion of the presence of a critical heart lesion. Hyperdynamic precordial activity is a consistent finding that reflects right ventricular volume and pressure overload. Decrease in amplitude of peripheral pulses often is cited but typically is evident only after ductal constriction in a newborn with symptoms. The second heart sound is single if aortic atresia is present. A heart murmur of tricuspid valve regurgitation or increased pulmonary blood flow may be audible.

## 97. B. Carnitine palmitoyltransferase

The reaction catalyzed by long-chain acyl-CoA synthetase requires energy from adenosine triphosphate, which is hydrolyzed to adenosine monophosphate and pyrophosphate, and results in the formation of long-chain acyl-CoA synthetase. To gain access to the mitochondria, long-chain acyl-CoA synthetase reacts with carnitine at the mitochondrial outer membrane to form acylcarnitine in a reaction catalyzed by carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT I). Carnitine acyltranslocase then transfers acylcarnitine across the inner mitochondrial membrane where carnitine palmitoyltransferase II regenerates long-chain acyl-CoA synthetase and releases carnitine. CPT I is an important site of regulation of fatty acid oxidation by the fetal and newborn heart. $^{1}$

## 98. B. High vagal tone

Wandering atrial pacemaker, characterized by a change in P-wave axis and morphology, is due to a shift of the pacemaker from its usual location in the sinus node to other sites in the atrium and in the atrioventricular junction. This condition is a benign arrhythmia but generally is associated with high vagal tone. It may also accompany other bradyarrhythmias.¹

## 99. C. Subclavian artery to the ipsilateral pulmonary artery

For the placement of systemic-to-pulmonary shunts for conditions such as hypoplastic left heart syndrome, there is likely to be a diminutive or atretic aorta, necessitating both a shunt and the Norwood procedure. In the Norwood procedure, the main pulmonary artery trunk is transected from the branch pulmonary arteries and used to reconstruct the hypoplastic aortic arch, creating a new aorta. Because the size of the aorta in most patients who have hypoplastic right ventricles is adequate, they generally only require shunts. The most common shunt used in both patient populations is the modified Blalock-Taussig shunt, in which a graft is interposed between the subclavian or innominate artery and the ipsilateral pulmonary artery.¹ Pulmonary blood flow depends on this connection.

Reverse differential cyanosis is a rare clinical manifestation and is likely to indicate dextro-transposition of the great arteries along with either coarctation of the aorta or persistent pulmonary hypertension. Septostomy may be a further step if a restrictive patent foramen ovale is contributing to morbidity.

1. D. Incontinentia pigmenti

Incontinentia pigmenti is an X-linked dominant disorder. Males are affected by antenatal lethality, whereas females have a variable phenotype. Partial deletion of the gene IKBKG is found in most cases.¹ Newborns present at or shortly after birth with characteristic skin findings and variable ocular and neurologic abnormalities. Skin findings follow Blaschko lines, which correspond to embryonic mesodermal and epidermal cell migration pathways. Neonates present in the vesicular stage, which then can progress to subsequent verrucous, hyperpigmented, and hypopigmented stages. Skin biopsy specimens of vesicles will show spongiosis with eosinophils and dyskeratotic keratinocytes.

Large scalp lesions in patients with aplasia cutis congenita are at higher risk for several complications. An eschar can form over the dura at the peripheral borders of the lesion. As the eschar dries, it can pull away from the dura, thus leading to tears and significant hemorrhage.¹

## 8. C. Periorbital region

Slate gray nevi usually are seen over the lumbosacral region. Nevus of Ota, also known as *nevus fuscoceruleus ophthalmomaxillaris*, is a unilateral, patchy, blue to bluish-gray to brown patch of skin on the face. The distribution is that of either the first or the second divisions of the trigeminal nerve. The following areas often are affected: periorbital region, temple, forehead, malar region, and nose. The sclera, conjunctiva, cornea, and retina also can be affected.¹ The nevus of Ito (*nevus fuscoceruleus acromiodeltoideus*) is similar to the nevus of Ota but occurs in the following areas: shoulder, supraclavicular areas, sides of the neck, upper arm, scapulae, and deltoid.

## 9. B. Propranolol has a half-life of 3 to 6 hours and demonstrates a peak effect 1 to 4 hours after administration.

Propranolol is a β-blocker, blocking both β₁ and β₂ adrenergic receptors, and is highly lipophilic and undergoes extensive first-pass metabolism by the liver.¹ It has a half-life of 3 to 6 hours and demonstrates a peak effect at 1 to 4 hours after administration. The dose response is usually most pronounced after the first dose.

## 10. E. Vascular disruption

Fetus papyraceus is characterized by bilateral large stellate defects of truncal skin and sometimes the extremities.¹² Most cases occur as the result of a monochorionic twin gestation during which 1 twin dies during the first trimester. In these cases, an ischemic or thrombotic event is thought to be the cause.

## 11. E. Topical timolol 0.5% gel-forming solution can be used after tapering propranolol to prevent rebound.

Adverse effects of propranolol include bradycardia, hypotension, hypoglycemia, and bronchospasm. Although hypoglycemia is a potential adverse effect, routine glucose screening has not been deemed necessary. Many patients with PHACES syndrome have been treated successfully with propranolol.

Rebound after treatment course can occur.¹ Therefore, tapering is a common practice. However, propranolol that has been stopped more suddenly, perhaps because of illness or a period of decreased feeding, has appeared to be safe. A topical timolol gel-forming solution can be used to prevent rebound after tapering propranolol. Topical timolol also can be a treatment for some infantile hemangiomas, particularly those that are superficial.²

## 13. C. LEOPARD syndrome

Of the familial lentiginosis syndromes, LEOPARD syndrome is the most likely to manifest in the neonatal period. LEOPARD is an acronym for lentigines, electrocardiographic conduction defects, ocular hypertelorism, pulmonary stenosis, abnormal genitalia, retardation of growth, and deafness. Patients typically have 3 to 5 of these findings. Lentigines begin at birth or during the first few postnatal months and increase over time. This disorder and Noonan syndrome share mutations in PTPN11. LEOPARD syndrome can be autosomal dominant or sporadic in inheritance.¹

## 15. D. Relative contraindications include asthma and cardiogenic shock.

## 16. B. Nevus anemicus

Nevus anemicus appears as a pale macule or macules that coalesce into patches of varying sizes. There may be an irregular border. It is caused by decreased blood flow through the capillaries in the dermal papillae because of increased hypersensitivity of the blood vessels to catecholamines.¹

## 19. D. Small size (&lt; 2 cm)

Aplasia cutis congenita is a solitary scalp lesion in 70% to 75% of cases. It is usually close to the hair whorl and ranges in size from 0.5 to 2.0 cm, although some may be larger.¹ Larger defects are more likely to have underlying abnormalities and are at higher risk for complications. A ring of darker terminal hairs surrounding the defect is regarded as specific for neural tube defects. Membranous lesions and midline lesions also can be associated with neural tube defects.

## 20. B. Epidermolysis bullosa

Epidermolysis bullosa manifests at birth or shortly thereafter with varying degrees of blisters and erosions. Skin lesions that appear after birth may be limited to areas of recent mechanical trauma, such as the head and face, or may be more extensive. After the perinatal period, new blisters often are seen in sites prone to handling and friction, such as the hands, perineum, and back. Common areas of mucosal involvement include the lips and oral mucosa.¹

1.  C. Limit the glucose infusion

Good physiologic control and improved enteral and parenteral nutrition are the foundations of reducing the incidence and associated complications of hyperglycemia. Enhancing amino acid intake can directly counter catabolic conditions and promote endogenous insulin and insulinlike growth factor 1 secretion and their anabolic effects.¹ Intravenous glucose infusion rates should be limited to just the rate that produces normal glucose concentrations. Lipid infusions should be limited during hyperglycemia. Insulin therapy should be reserved as much as possible for severe hyperglycemia because the benefits of insulin in the setting of hyperglycemia in preterm neonates have not been demonstrated.²

### D. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a 46,XX female is congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). CAH is an autosomal recessive condition secondary to a defect in cortisol synthesis. A 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause of CAH and accounts for 95% of cases; however, 11-hydroxylase deficiency and 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency can also cause virilization of a female. The block in the production of cortisol leads to shunting of cortisol precursors toward the androgen pathway, which leads to virilization of the external genitalia.

In aromatase deficiency, patients are unable to convert androgen precursors to estrogen. Aromatase deficiency in the placenta leads to virilization of both the mother and the fetus. Maternal causes of androgen excess that can lead to virilization of a 46,XX newborn include virilizing adrenocortical tumors, ovarian tumors, or luteomas. Disorders of ovarian development in a 46,XX individual that can manifest as ambiguous genitalia include ovotesticular disorders of sexual development and 46,XX testicular disorders of sexual development.1, 2

References

Barbaro M, Wedell A, Nordenström A. Disorders of sex development. Semin Fetal Neonatal Med. 2011;16(2):119--127Lambert SM, Vilain EJ, Kolon TF. A practical approach to ambiguous genitalia in the newborn period. Urol Clin North Am. 2010;37(2):195--205

### A. Free thyroxine

Malnutrition, liver immaturity, and other complications of prematurity such as respiratory distress syndrome also lead to lower concentrations of thyroxine-binding globulin, which can lower total thyroxine concentrations.1 Therefore, many authors recommend measuring only free thyroxine in this population to assess thyroid hormone status.

### E. Müllerian duct remnants

Decreased 5α-reductase activity is a cause of undervirilization of genetic males and leads to varying degrees of ambiguity, ranging from a blind vaginal pouch to mild hypospadias with bifid scrotum.

Partial androgen resistance results in a spectrum of genital ambiguity. The androgen receptor is located on the X chromosome, and, therefore, transmission is X linked. Family members who have the same androgen receptor mutation can have different phenotypes, which makes partial androgen insensitivity syndrome challenging to diagnose. Mutations that lead to complete androgen insensitivity syndrome, however, result in normal female external genitalia. Müllerian structures such as the uterus typically are absent, and testes may be intra-abdominal or in the inguinal canal.1

### E. Thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibody

Maternal antibodies against the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor can cross the placenta and stimulate the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptors located on the epithelial cells of the fetal thyroid gland. This can lead to thyrotoxicosis.1, 2

### B. Propylthiouracil is the preferred drug in the first trimester, although it has been associated with minor birth defects, primarily face and neck cysts.

Antithyroid drugs in pregnancy are potentially teratogenic. Methimazole (a metabolite of carbimazole) use in pregnancy has been associated with choanal atresia, esophageal atresia, cutis aplasia, abdominal wall defects, eye anomalies, ventricular septal defects, and methimazole/carbimazole embryopathy in 2% to 4% of exposed children.1, 2, 3, 4 Therefore, propylthiouracil is the preferred drug in the first trimester. However, propylthiouracil exposure has also been associated with minor birth defects, primarily face and neck cysts, in 2% to 3% of cases.2

## 28. B. The initial noticeable symptoms of hypoglycemia that may indicate exhaustion of alternative fuel stores are often nonspecific, such as irritability, lethargy, or poor feeding.

When neonatal hypoglycemia results in clinical signs of brain injury, the temporal evolution is as follows:

- Low blood glucose levels are found, but the neonate does not have clinical signs because he or she is still able to draw on alternative fuel stores such as glycogen and fat.
- If untreated, the neonate exhausts alternative fuel stores and develops subtle clinical signs that are not specific to hypoglycemia, such as irritability, lethargy, and poor feeding. Hypoglycemia is not damaging at this stage.
- If untreated, the neonate develops obvious and severe clinical signs, such as seizures or coma. There may still be avoidance of damage if treated promptly.
- If not treated rapidly after the onset of these severe clinical signs, hypoglycemia becomes damaging and in severe cases results in cardiorespiratory arrest.

## 29. D. Impaired regulation of core temperature

Clinical findings in preterm neonates who are critically ill and in shock may include delay in capillary refill, worsening regulation of core temperature, apnea, tachypnea, and poor renal function with oliguria or anuria. Furthermore, patients can be hypotensive and tachycardic. Patients in shock secondary to adrenal insufficiency may also have hypoglycemia; however, hypoglycemia may be masked in neonates who are critically ill and receiving constant dextrose infusions.

## 30. B. Intracranial hemorrhage from hyperosmolarity

Hyperosmolarity, with osmotic shifts and risk of intracranial hemorrhage, is generally seen only with very rapid increases of plasma glucose concentrations to excessively high values, usually more than 500 mg/dL (27.8 mmol/L).¹

36. B. The development of the external male genitalia is dependent on the activity of dihydrotestosterone, which is converted from testosterone by the enzyme 5α-reductase.

Production of anti-Müllerian hormone by the Sertoli cells leads to involution of the Müllerian (female) internal ducts. The development of the external male genitalia is dependent on the activity of dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which is converted from testosterone by the enzyme 5α-reductase. DHT induces development of the penis from the genital tubercle and of the urethra from the urogenital sinus, as well as fusion of the labioscrotal folds to form the scrotum.

Phosphate deficiency is considered the earliest manifestation of poor bone mineralization. In this setting, TRP = (1-[(urine phosphorus × serum creatinine)/(serum phosphorus × urine creatinine)]) × 100 is greater than 95%.

Neonates with high TRP levels, low to normal parathyroid hormone levels, and hypophosphatemia will benefit from phosphorus supplementation.

40. D. In this scenario, it would be reasonable to investigate the cause of the hypoglycemia and to institute treatment to increase glucose levels.

41. D. The stimulus for cortisol synthesis starts in the hypothalamus with the release of corticotropin-releasing hormone.

The stimulus for synthesis of cortisol begins in the hypothalamus. The hypothalamus releases corticotropin-releasing hormone, which stimulates the pituitary to release adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). ACTH then stimulates the adrenal cortex, specifically the zona fasciculata, to synthesize and release cortisol. Cortisol has many varied effects systemically, which include maintenance of glucose homeostasis, alteration of inflammatory responses, regulation of hemodynamic stability in times of illness and stress, and maintenance of electrolyte balances.¹

42. D. Serum calcium levels are typically normal in neonates with metabolic bone disease.

Serum calcium levels are typically normal in neonates with metabolic bone disease because of the rapid response of the calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid glands. Preterm neonates with a chronic depletion of calcium, which can occur via medications such as glucocorticoids, diuretics, and methylxanthines, may develop secondary hyperparathyroidism. These patients also have hypophosphatemia but a low tubular reabsorption of phosphate. Serum calcium is not a sensitive marker in screening for metabolic bone disease of prematurity.

43. A. A chromosome analysis should be performed within the first 24 hours after birth, and the laboratory should be notified to expedite the results.

All patients with ambiguous genitalia require an urgent chromosome analysis as the initial investigation. Testing should be performed within the first 24 hours after birth, and the laboratory should be notified to expedite the results. A chromosomal microarray analysis is recommended to look for small deletions or duplications that may not be identified at routine karyotype testing. For patients with ambiguous genitalia and nonpalpable gonads, there should be a high suspicion of congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

## 44. B. Birth to a mother with autoimmune thyroid disease

## 45. B. Fetal pituitary luteinizing hormone

The critical period for external virilization of the genitalia is within the first 12 weeks of gestation. In the first trimester, testosterone production from the Leydig cells is driven by placental human chorionic gonadotropin. Fetal pituitary luteinizing hormone secretion increases during the second trimester and stimulates phallic enlargement and testicular descent.

## 47. D. Although diagnostic evaluation is performed, it will be important to maintain normal glucose levels to avoid brain injury because brain hypoglycemia will be exacerbated by a lack of ketone bodies or lactate.

In hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia, insulin secretion becomes dysregulated, driving glucose into insulin-sensitive tissues, such as skeletal muscle, liver, and adipose tissue. There is inhibition of glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, lipolysis, and ketogenesis, which prevents the generation of alternative energy substrates such as lactate and ketone bodies. The effects of hypoglycemia on the brain are further compounded by the lack of these alternative substrates for the brain to use. Hypoketotic hypofattyacidemia in the presence of hypoglycemia is the key metabolic milieu that predisposes the neonate to hypoglycemic brain injury. $^{1}$

## 49. E. T₄ sulfate levels will be at a peak and thereafter decrease.

In neonates born at 31 to 34 weeks, thyroxine (T₄) levels peak at 7 hours (125 nmol/L) and are approximately 20% greater than cord levels, whereas levels in neonates born at or before 27 weeks are static, approximately 60 nmol/L during this period. $^{1}$ Triiodothyronine levels in neonates born at 31 to 34 weeks increase 2-fold and peak at 7 hours (1.24 nmol/L), whereas in neonates born at or before 27 weeks, levels increase initially by approximately 60% at 1 hour (0.53 nmol/L) and decrease thereafter. For all gestational age groups, T₄ sulfate levels peak at postnatal day 7 and thereafter decrease. $^{2}$
