63. D. This patient has at least 1 major anomaly.

Congenital anomalies can be classified as major and minor on the basis of their medical and/or cosmetic effect. Major anomalies have a significant effect and are never considered part of normal variation. These include congenital heart disease, cleft lip and palate, ectrodactyly, holoprosencephaly, and so on. In contrast, minor anomalies do not have a medical effect but are uncommon in the general population (&lt; 4% of individuals). These include findings such as single palmar crease, ear tags and pits, lip pits, for example. Minor anomalies occur in 20%, 0.8%, and 0.5% of healthy newborns for 1, 2, and 3 minor anomalies, respectively. Although minor anomalies do not have a significant medical effect in isolation, the occurrence of 2 minor anomalies is associated with a 10% risk of major malformation. This risk increases to 20% if 3 anomalies are present.

Newborns with more than 1 anomaly are classified as follows $^{1,2}$:

- Association—describes anomalies occurring together more than would be expected by chance but with no underlying unifying cause (eg, VACTERL association)
- Deformation—anomalies secondary to external forces during development
- Disruption—growth arrest of a normally developing structure by an external force (eg, amniotic bands)
- Sequence—related anomalies secondary to a single major anomaly (eg, Pierre Robin sequence)
- Syndrome—anomalies occurring in a predictable manner and with a single cause (eg, trisomy 21)

Congenital anomalies can be classified as major or minor on the basis of their medical and/or cosmetic effect. Major anomalies have a significant effect and are never considered part of normal variation (eg, congenital heart disease, cleft lip and palate).

Minor anomalies do not have a medical effect (eg, single palmar crease, ear tags and pits) and occur in less than 4% of the general population. ## 65. B. Segments of sequence in a gene that are protein coding

Exons are the protein-coding sequences of the DNA and constitute approximately 1% to 2% of the human genome. Exons contain sequences of codons that are triplets of nucleotides, each encoding for a specific amino acid via transcription into a messenger RNA (mRNA) and translation into an amino acid sequence.

Introns are noncoding DNA regions that contain regulatory elements of mRNA and protein production.¹

Turner syndrome affects approximately 1 in 2,500 female live births, although most affected conceptions (99%) result in spontaneous abortion. ## 69. B. Identification of multinucleated cells of placental origin in maternal blood.

The discovery of multinucleated cells of placental origin was first described in the maternal circulation and lung tissue at maternal autopsy in 1893.¹ This was followed, much later, by the identification of fetal red blood cells in the maternal circulation in the 1950s. The existence of cell-free DNA in the circulation was first discovered in patients with cancer in the 1970s. In pregnant patients, the first discovery was the presence of the sex-determining region Y (SRY) gene in the maternal circulation. Fetal DNA in maternal blood was first isolated in 1989. However, it was not until 1997 that investigators demonstrated that the cell-free fetal DNA portion was relatively large and could be distinguished from the maternal cell-free DNA, thereby ushering in the era of noninvasive prenatal testing.²

## 71. A. CpG dinucleotide is the only dinucleotide that can be modified epigenetically.

Epigenetic gene regulation is the result of complex interactions among the DNA, the transcription machinery, and cofactors. Epigenetic mechanisms are critical to gene regulation and switch genes on or off on the basis of developmental stage, cell-specific needs, and environmental factors. The CpG dinucleotide is the only dinucleotide that can be modified epigenetically. The methylation of CpG dinucleotides present in a promoter region of the genome leads to gene silencing. In contrast, CpG dinucleotides present elsewhere in the genome are typically methylated at baseline and regulate promoter function, as well as transcription.¹,²

## 73. A. Fetal movement restriction

Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) encompasses a spectrum of hip abnormalities ranging from minor self-correcting abnormalities to congenital hip dislocation. The incidence of DDH ranges from 1% to 7% of newborns, varies by ethnicity, and affects girls 4 to 8 times more frequently than boys. It is unilateral in 63% of cases and more often occurs on the left side.

- Female sex (75.5% of cases)
- First pregnancy
- Oligohydramnios

## 74. A. Superoxide anion

Oxygen free radicals are highly chemically reactive and can cause functional and structural damage to cell components. Superoxide anion is the most abundant free radical. It is the precursor to most reactive oxygen species and mediates oxidative chain reactions. Superoxide dismutase leads to the dismutation of superoxide anion and produces hydrogen peroxide, which in turn is fully reduced to water by glutathione reductase or is partially reduced to hydroxyl radical. Hydroxyl radical is the strongest oxidant and leads to structural and functional cell damage. Superoxide anion can also react with nitric oxide to form peroxynitrite, a highly reactive compound.¹⁻³

1. C. In contrast to ABO incompatibility, many cases of NAIT occur during first pregnancies.

Neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia (NAIT) results from maternal production of antibodies directed against paternally derived antigens on the fetal platelets, most commonly the human platelet antigen (HPA)-1a. $^{1,2}$ In contrast to ABO or Rh incompatibility, NAIT occurs during a first pregnancy in approximately 50% of cases. An increase in NAIT severity is typically seen in the subsequent pregnancy, emphasizing the importance of accurate diagnosis of the index newborn. Treatment for newborns with severe NAIT includes random donor platelets; intravenous immunoglobulin; and, in severe cases, compatible HPA-1a-negative platelets, as well as washed maternal platelets. $^{2}$

Enterohepatic bilirubin circulation is increased in the newborn period because of both high β-glucuronidase activity and immature intestinal bacterial flora. β-Glucuronidase deconjugates bilirubin, allowing for its reabsorption in the intestine. $^{1}$

4. D. Prothrombin

The levels and function of coagulation proteins are developmentally regulated and are low in the term neonate, maturing over weeks to years to adult levels. $^{1}$ Fibrinogen, factor V, factor VIII, and von Willebrand factor are the only coagulation proteins that are within the adult range at birth. $^{2}$ Some factors, such as vitamin K-dependent factors, as well as factors XI and XII, prekallikrein, and high-molecular-weight kininogen, are low at birth (50% of adult levels) but mature rapidly postnatally, approaching adult levels by age 6 months. In contrast, prothrombin levels remain low throughout childhood. It is important to take into account these differences when interpreting screening coagulation tests in term and preterm neonates.

5. B. 7.3 mL/kg/min

The oxygen extraction ratio is defined as the ratio of oxygen consumption to oxygen delivery. In general, the body uses 15% to 33% of the oxygen delivered, yielding an oxygen extraction ratio of 0.15 to 0.33. Organ and cellular function will begin to be affected if the oxygen extraction ratio is 0.40 or greater. $^{1}$

The critical level of oxygen delivery below which metabolic demands are not met (oxygen consumption exceeds oxygen delivery) occurs at less than 7.3 mL/kg/min of oxygen in healthy young adults. $^{2,3}$

## 6. D. Hyperkalemia

Red blood cell (RBC) transfusions remain an important intervention in the care of neonates who are ill. In this population, RBC products are modified to account for the relative immune deficiency of the neonate. In most countries, leukoreduced and irradiated RBCs are used.¹ Leukoreduction reduces white blood cell counts by 99.9%,² whereas irradiation inactivates donor lymphocytes, thereby decreasing the risk of transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease. Using RBCs shortly after the irradiation procedure is recommended because of the risk of hyperkalemia. The process of irradiation leads to potassium leakage from the RBCs and decreases the shelf life of the product.³

## 8. C. Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP) to reduced NADP

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is a rate-limiting enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway of red blood cell (RBC) metabolism. It oxidizes glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconic acid and catalyzes NADP to its reduced form, NADPH, is critical for the maintenance of reduced forms of glutathione and thereby cellular defense against oxidative stress. The pentose phosphate pathway is the only source of NADPH for RBCs such that patients with G6PD deficiency have RBCs that are susceptible to hemolysis when exposed to oxidative stress.¹

## 9. E. Resistance to acid elution

Fetal hemoglobin (hemoglobin F [α₂γ₂]) is 34% of the total hemoglobin between 5 and 6 weeks of gestation, increasing to 50% by 16 weeks and 90% by 20 weeks.¹ Hemoglobin F differs from hemoglobin A (α₂β₂) in multiple ways. It has a much greater affinity for oxygen than does hemoglobin A because of decreased interaction with 2,3-disphosphoglycerate. Hemoglobin F can be oxidized to methemoglobin more readily than can hemoglobin A. Finally, it is resistant to acid elution, a property used to distinguish fetal cells from maternal cells in the Kleihauer-Betke test.²

Transient myeloproliferative disorder (TMD) affects approximately 10% of newborns with trisomy 21. The clinical presentation varies in severity from clinically asymptomatic to fulminant with hydrops to respiratory and cardiac failure. Hepatomegaly is the most common presenting sign, occurring in 50% of affected patients.¹ Other findings include splenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, respiratory failure, cardiac failure, and papulovesicular or pustular rash that typically involves the face. 11. D. In the PINT study, Kirpalani et al found that neonates in the restrictive group were more likely to avoid transfusion than were those in the liberal group, although most neonates in both groups received a transfusion.

Red blood cell transfusions are frequently needed when caring for extremely low-birth-weight (ELBW) neonates; however, consensus regarding optimal thresholds for transfusion is lacking. Several trials have investigated liberal versus restrictive transfusion thresholds in this population.

The Premature Infants in Need of Transfusion (PINT) study investigated the effect of restrictive versus liberal transfusion thresholds on mortality and short-term morbidity in 451 ELBW neonates.1 In this study, 451 neonates were randomly assigned to a low or a high transfusion threshold. Although most neonates in both groups received blood transfusions, 89% of neonates in the restrictive group received transfusions versus 95% in the liberal group (P = .037). There were no significant differences in mortality and short-term neonatal intensive care unit morbidities, including retinopathy of prematurity, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, or brain injury.1 However, at follow-up at age 18 to 21 months, children in the liberal group had improved mental developmental index at post hoc analysis.2

The Iowa trial investigated liberal versus restrictive transfusion guidelines in 100 preterm neonates with birth weights between 500 and 1,300 g.3 In this trial, there was no difference between groups in blood transfusion exposure, and neonates in the restrictive group were more likely to experience apnea, intraparenchymal brain hemorrhage, and periventricular leukomalacia.

12. E. Tpo levels are not as high in neonates with thrombocytopenia, particularly in neonates who are small for gestational age, compared with those in adults.

Thrombopoiesis, or platelet production, is different in neonates and adults. Neonates, particularly those who are small for gestational age, have lower thrombopoeitin (Tpo) levels compared with levels observed in children or adults. In addition, they have a higher number of circulating megakaryocyte progenitors. These megakaryocyte progenitors are structurally and functionally different from those in adults, with lower ploidy and size, as well as higher proliferative ability and sensitivity to Tpo.1,2 Despite all of these differences in thrombopoiesis, neonates achieve normal platelet counts because of the increased proliferative potential of the megakaryocyte progenitors.

13. D. This type of tumor is derived from mesenchymal cells and composed of masses of blood vessels that are irregular in arrangement and size.

Hemangiomas occur in 3% of neonates and are the most common tumors in this population. Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors that can occur anywhere in cutaneous, subcutaneous, and visceral locations, including the liver. Hepatic hemangiomas are derived from mesenchymal cells and composed of masses of blood vessels that are irregular in arrangement and size. They are more common in females and are cutaneous hemangiomas in approximately 50% of cases.1 Hepatic hemangiomas can also occur as part of a syndrome, including Klippel-Trenaunay-Weber or Osler-Rendu-Weber syndromes.

Neonates with hepatic hemangiomas can be asymptomatic or can present with abdominal distension and respiratory compromise or with cardiac failure, consumptive coagulopathy, or thrombocytopenia (Kasabach-Merritt syndrome). Hypothyroidism has also been described in association with hepatic hemangiomas and is secondary to high levels of type 3 iodothyronine deiodinase in the hemangioma.

Similar to hemangiomas located in other areas, hepatic hemangiomas undergo rapid proliferation followed by a slower resolution phase over years. Expectant conservative management is appropriate in most cases. $^{1,2}$

## 16. D. Laboratory phlebotomy losses are typically 15% to 30% of a neonate’s total blood volume in the first 6 weeks after birth.

Iatrogenic blood loss via phlebotomy losses is an important contributing factor in red blood cell (RBC) transfusion needs in extremely low-birth-weight neonates. Breastfeeding jaundice is secondary to insufficient intake of breast milk and is suspected in newborns with:

## 21. E. Prothrombin

Congenital deficiencies in factor (F) III (tissue factor [TF]) have not been described, presumably because they are lethal. TF is released after an injury to the vascular endothelium and is a potent initiator of the extrinsic coagulation pathway by forming a complex with FVII and directly or indirectly activating FX. Activated FX subsequently converts prothrombin (FII) to thrombin (FIIa) and initiates the common pathway of the coagulation cascade leading to fibrin formation.¹

## 22. A. A newer form of Epo, darbepoetin alfa, has a half-life that is 13- to 14-fold longer than that of rhEpo.

In preterm neonates, erythropoietin (Epo) is produced mainly in the liver, which is less sensitive to anemia than is the kidney, resulting in insufficient Epo production in this population. The use of recombinant human Epo (rhEpo) has been investigated as a means of reducing red blood cell transfusions in preterm neonates. Data suggest decreased transfusion needs in preterm neonates weighing less than 750 g at birth who received rhEpo for 2 weeks.¹ The administration of darbepoetin alfa, an analogue of rhEpo with a 13- to 14-fold longer half-life, resulted similarly in fewer transfusions than did rhEpo.² The risks and benefits of rhEpo continue to be investigated, with some studies indicating an increased risk of retinopathy of prematurity with higher cumulative doses of rhEpo³,⁴ and others finding neuroprotective effects.⁵,⁶

## 23. C. The patient can be monitored clinically, and a platelet count can be repeated the next morning.

Thrombocytopenia is a common problem, affecting 25% to 30% of all neonates admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit. Thrombocytopenia can be classified as mild (100,000–150,100/mcL), moderate (50,000–100,000/mcL), or severe (&lt; 50,000/mcL). The risk of bleeding increases with the severity of the thrombocytopenia:

- Minimal risk for platelet count 20,000 to 100,000/mcL
- Moderate risk for platelet count less than 20,000/mcL
- Severe risk for platelet count less than 5,000/mcL

Healthy neonates with mild to moderate thrombocytopenia can be monitored closely without additional investigation or intervention unless the thrombocytopenia persists for more than 5 to 7 days. A sepsis evaluation is recommended in neonates who are ill and have mild to moderate thrombocytopenia with no evidence of placental insufficiency.¹

## 24. C. Levels of urinary catecholamine metabolites, such as vanillylmandelic acid and homovanillic acid, are elevated in more than 90% of neonates with neuroblastoma and are detectable in random urine samples.

Neuroblastoma, the most common neonatal malignancy, originates in the adrenal medulla and anywhere along the sympathetic nervous system, with the liver and skin being the most common metastatic locations. Mutations in the anaplastic lymphoma gene are noted in 1% to 2% of cases.

Neonates with neuroblastoma may be asymptomatic or can present with an abdominal mass, hepatomegaly, and subcutaneous skin nodules (blueberry muffin baby).

---

<!-- Page 447 -->

Diagnostic investigations include imaging (ultrasonography, computed tomography, or magnetic resonance imaging), meta-iodobenzylguanidine scanning, and elevated urinary vanillylmandelic acid and homovanillic acid (elevated in 90% of cases). The diagnosis is confirmed by means of biopsy of the primary or metastatic tumor.

Neonates with a neuroblastoma, including those with liver, skin, and bone metastasis, have a favorable prognosis compared with that of neonates who present with a neuroblastoma later in life, with spontaneous regression observed in many cases. Because of these unique characteristics, neuroblastomas in the neonatal population have their own stage (4S).1,2

25. A. Bacterial or viral sepsis

In the evaluation of a neonate with thrombocytopenia, the following characteristics are important considerations in establishing a differential diagnosis:

• Ill appearance versus well appearance

• Timing of manifestation of the thrombocytopenia (early onset < 72 hours versus late onset ≥ 72 hours after birth)1

For neonates who have late-onset thrombocytopenia and appear ill, prompt evaluation for bacterial, fungal, and viral sepsis is recommended. Other causes include necrotizing enterocolitis and inborn errors of metabolism, such as propionic acidemia, isovaleric acidemia, methylmalonic acidemia, and Gaucher disease.

For neonates who appear well and have late-onset thrombocytopenia, drug-induced thrombocytopenia (heparin, antibiotics), thromboses, and Fanconi anemia should be considered in the differential diagnosis.2

26. C. Maternal hepcidin regulates iron status as a negative feedback inhibitor of iron absorption, and fetal hepcidin levels can alter maternal responses.

Eighty percent of fetal iron stores are accrued in the third trimester, and these accretion rates (1.6--2.0 mg/kg/d) are not affected by mild maternal anemia.1 Hepcidin is a key regulator of maternal--fetal iron metabolism. Maternal hepcidin exerts a negative effect on iron absorption and placental transfer, whereas fetal hepcidin can downregulate placental iron delivery if needs are met or in case of inflammation. With the 6-fold increase in iron absorption needs during pregnancy, a corresponding decrease in maternal hepcidin is noted with advancing pregnancy.2,3

Severe placental insufficiency with associated intrauterine growth restriction results in a decrease in placental iron transfer.4

27. A. Abnormally low fetal iron endowment increases the risk of poorer school performance, memory tasks, and behavioral problems.

Although maternal serum ferritin levels are positively linked to fetal iron stores, the treatment of mild iron deficiency anemia in pregnant women has not conclusively been shown to improve maternal or fetal iron status. Treatment does, however, lead to fetal benefits, such as decreased risk of low birth weight or preterm delivery.1

Decreased fetal iron stores have been linked to adverse neurocognitive outcomes later in life. Low fetal iron stores can occur with placental insufficiency, diabetes, severe psychological stressors, severe maternal obesity, and anemia of chronic illness with increased hepcidin levels resulting in decreased placental iron transfer.2,3 In addition, fetal conditions linked to low iron stores include fetal overgrowth, male sex, preterm birth, and multiple gestation.4

# 28. D. Photosensitization-induced cytotoxicity

Tin mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a competitive inhibitor of heme oxygenase, is emerging as a pharmacological option for the treatment of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia. One of the side effects of SnMP is photosensitization, so use of SnMP in conjunction with phototherapy is not recommended. $^{1}$ Animal studies indicate that in addition to SnMP inhibiting heme oxygenase, SnMP inhibits hemoprotein nitric oxide synthase $^{2}$ and may increase levels of inducible heme oxygenase. $^{3}$ These effects remain poorly understood. Furthermore, lack of data on the long-term effect of SnMP use has limited its use in the clinical setting in the United States.

32. E. TMD is a disease of megakaryocytic precursors, with mutagenesis occurring in immature myeloblast or megakaryoblast lineages.

Transient myeloproliferative disorder (TMD), or transient abnormal myelopoiesis, is an acute myeloproliferative disorder occurring in 10% of neonates with trisomy 21. It is characterized by the following:¹²:

- Mutagenesis of the immature myeloblast or megakaryoblast lineages
- Elevated bone marrow and peripheral blast cell count (&gt; 10%)
- Characteristically large blast cells with a high nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio, open chromatin with visible nucleoli, and basophilic cytoplasm with some peripheral bleb formation
- Expression of immature antigens (cluster of differentiation [CD]34, CD117) and megakaryocytic antigens (CD41, CD61) on blast cells as assessed with flow cytometry

33. C. Hb Constant Spring is clinically similar to β-thalassemia major and may require transfusions during infancy.

Hemoglobin (Hb) Constant Spring is an abnormal Hb caused by a mutation at position 142 in which glutamine (Gln) replaces a termination codon, thereby leading to an abnormally long and unstable Hb chain (α⁰, α142, Term → Gln). It is the most common nondeletional mutation associated with α-thalassemia and is more prevalent in Southeast Asia. Hb Constant Spring, when inherited with a cis-mutation (⁻/α⁰α), tends to be more severe than in the nondeletion form of HbH (⁻/α⁻). Patients with HbH-Constant Spring require more frequent and earlier transfusions.¹²

34. E. Hypoglycemia

Polycythemia is defined as a venous hematocrit value of 65% (0.65) or higher or a hemoglobin value higher than 22 g/dL (220 g/L).¹ It affects 0.4% to 5% of healthy neonates,¹ with an increased incidence noted in the following²:

- Neonates who are small for gestational age
- Neonates of mothers with diabetes
- Postterm neonates
- Recipient twins in twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome
- Neonates with chromosomal anomalies

Although many neonates with polycythemia have no symptoms, some neonates may demonstrate characteristic features as early as 2 hours after birth. Those include the following²,³:

- Neurological symptoms (irritability, jitteriness, tremors, seizures) in up to 60% of affected neonates
- Metabolic abnormalities, most commonly hypoglycemia (12%–40% of cases), followed by hypocalcemia (1%–11% of cases)

## 43. C. Neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia

Neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia (NAIT) should be considered in neonates who appear well but have early-onset (&lt; 72 hours after birth) moderate to severe thrombocytopenia (50,000-100,000/mcL and &lt; 50,000/mcL, respectively).[1] It occurs when maternal antibodies against fetal platelet antigen inherited from the father cross the placenta and lead to fetal platelet destruction. Most cases of NAIT (95%) are caused by 3 human platelet antigens (HPAs): HPA-1a, HPA-5b, and HPA-15b. HPA-1a causes 75% of NAIT cases in white neonates. HPA-1a incompatibility occurs in 1 in 350 pregnancies and results in thrombocytopenia in 1 in 1,000 to 1 in 1,500 affected pregnancies.[2]

Neonatal autoimmune thrombocytopenia is caused by maternal autoantibodies, most commonly in mothers with immune thrombocytopenic purpura or systemic lupus erythematosus. It occurs in 1 to 2 in 1,000 pregnancies and can be distinguished from NAIT by the presence of a low maternal platelet count.[3]

Inherited thrombocytopenias, including Bernard-Soulier and Wiskott-Aldrich syndromes, are rare disorders in which thrombocytopenia is the result of decreased production.[4]

44. E. The most common tumor of the kidney in the neonate is congenital mesoblastic nephroma, with cells predominantly composed of fibroblastic cells and confined to the renal capsule.

Most renal masses detected in the newborn period are secondary to malformations such as hydronephrosis and polycystic kidney disease.

Congenital mesoblastic nephroma, which occurs exclusively in the first 6 months after birth, is the most common neonatal renal tumor (75% of cases) and has the following characteristics¹,²:

- Mesenchymal tumor predominantly composed of fibroblastic cells
- Divided into 2 subtypes:
- Classical
- Cellular associated with translocation t(12;15) and increased risk of recurrence and metastases
- Confined to the renal capsule in most cases
- Nephrectomy alone is usually curative

Other renal tumors occurring in the neonatal period include the following:

- Wilms tumor (WT), or nephroblastoma, rarely manifests in neonates (0.2% of all cases) and is associated with a syndrome in 25% of cases (WT, aniridia, genitourinary tract abnormalities, intellectual disability [WAGR] syndrome; Denys-Drash syndrome; Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome; Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome). Mutations in WT1 11p13 and WT2 11p15 have been implicated in the pathogenesis of WT, but most patients do not have these mutations.³,⁴
- Rhabdoid tumor of the kidney, a very aggressive tumor, often manifests in advanced stages and has a high mortality rate.
- Clear cell carcinoma of the kidney is a very rare tumor with a better outcome in neonates than in older children.

45. C. Increased metabolic clearance of Epo

After birth, erythropoietin (Epo) levels decrease rapidly to very low levels, resulting in a decrease in reticulocytes and nucleated red blood cell counts within 5 to 7 days. There is evidence that low Epo concentrations in neonates with anemia should be viewed as physiological because of the following factors¹:

- Increased sensitivity of erythroid progenitors to Epo
- Decreased tissue oxygenation set point for Epo production
- Increased metabolic clearance of Epo
- Paracrine hormone effect of Epo in the liver
- Increased erythropoietic capacity as indicated by higher reticulocyte counts¹

46. B. For carriers with α-globin gene mutations, Asian individuals tend to have cis-mutations, whereas trans-mutations (on opposite sides of chromosome 16) are more likely to be seen in blacks.

α-Thalassemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in 1 or more of the 4 α-globin genes located on chromosome 16 and resulting in decreased α-globin production (α+) or complete absence of α-globin (α−). The severity of the disorder depends on the number of affected genes¹,²:

- α-Thalassemia carrier = 1 gene affected (-α/αα)
- α-Thalassemia trait = 2 genes affected. Two forms of α-thalassemia trait occur. Mutations on the same side of chromosome 16 (cis-mutation; −/αα) are more common in Asians. Mutations on opposite sides of chromosome 16 (trans-mutation; −α/−α) are more common in blacks.
- Hemoglobin (Hb) H disease = 3 genes affected with 2 distinct forms: (1) HbH (−/−α) and (2) HbH Constant Spring (−αᴳᴮ/−α), in which 1 of the affected genes has a mutation at position 142 in which glutamine replaces a termination codon thereby leading to an abnormally long and unstable Hb chain. Individuals with HbH Constant Spring have more severe clinical features than do those with HbH.
- If all 4 genes are affected (−/−), no α-globin chain is produced, resulting in Hb Bart production and hydrops fetalis.

## 52. A. Greater risk of mortality is associated with severe liver dysfunction, white blood cell count greater than 100 × 10³/mcL, and early age at presentation.

Transient myeloproliferative disorder (TMD) occurs in 10% of neonates with trisomy 21 and can manifest in utero as early as 26-weeks' gestational age. The prognosis of neonates with TMD diagnosed in utero is more severe than that of neonates receiving the diagnosis in the postnatal period, when spontaneous regression is observed in 80% of cases. Neonates with a prenatal diagnosis have a high risk of intrauterine death (30%), as well as neonatal (10%) and infant (18%) death. Postnatal mortality increases to 90% in neonates presenting with marked hepatomegaly, hyperechoic liver, and hydrops.¹

For neonates who survive an intrauterine manifestation of the disease or who receive the diagnosis in the postnatal period, higher initial leukocyte and blast counts correlate with an increased risk of hepatic, cardiac, and respiratory dysfunction. Treatment with cytarabine and/or rasburicase, exchange transfusion or leukopheresis, and hyperhydration are reserved for neonates with life-threatening complications, including heart and respiratory failure, coagulopathy, and blast cell count greater than 100 × 10³/mcL. Overall, 77% of patients with a postnatal diagnosis of TMD survive to age 3 years.²

Twenty percent to 25% of neonates with TMD will develop acute megakaryoblastic leukemia, typically before the age of 4 or 5 years.

## 55. C. Immature platelet fraction test

Thrombocytopenia is common in neonates admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit and can result from increased platelet destruction or decreased platelet production.

The only way to assess platelet production directly is via a bone marrow biopsy. Although this is the gold standard test in adults, the procedure is not typically performed in neonates because of technical difficulties. Therefore, techniques to assess platelet production indirectly, including the measurement of thrombopoietin levels, circulating megakaryocyte progenitors, and reticulated platelet percentages (RP%s), have been investigated. Of those techniques, the immature platelet test (IPF), which measures the RP% equivalent, is the only test currently available for clinical use. IPF levels are high in disorders of increased platelet destruction and low in disorders of decreased production. However, the use of IPF testing in the neonatal population requires more study to determine normative values and potential clinical utility.¹⁻³

## 56. D. Prenatal diagnosis of TMD can be challenging because some ultrasonographic findings associated with TMD are nonspecific and can be associated with congenital infections.

Transient myeloproliferative disorder (TMD) can manifest prenatally (as early as 26-weeks’ gestational age) and postnatally.

Neonates with prenatal presentation have a worse prognosis, with high prenatal and postnatal mortality. The prenatal diagnosis is challenging because many of the ultrasonographic findings are nonspecific and are also seen with fetal infections. In these cases, limited data indicate that intrauterine fetal blood transfusion may be a therapeutic option in neonates with anemia and thrombocytopenia.¹

Most neonates with postnatal presentations (80%) will experience spontaneous regression without medical intervention. Therefore, chemotherapy with cytarabine or exchange transfusion is considered only in neonates with life-threatening complications.²

Although the presence of mutations in GATA1 may be necessary for the development of TMD, the mutations are not found before 25-weeks’ gestational age. In addition, there is no consensus on the treatment of neonates without symptoms with GATA1 mutation (silent TMD).

58. A. Because sacrococcygeal tumors are highly vascular, larger tumors in the fetus may lead to high-output cardiac failure and anemia.

Teratomas are the most common tumors seen in neonates and are typically diagnosed with routine prenatal ultrasonography. Most teratomas are isolated and benign and occur in the sacrococcygeal and mediastinal area.

Sacrococcygeal teratomas (SCTs) are the most common form of neonatal teratoma (35%–60% of cases) and have a marked female predominance (4:1). They are highly vascular tumors that can be associated with high-output cardiac failure, anemia, and hydrops when large enough. Thirty percent of SCTs are mature, 10% have yolk sac tumor elements, and 60% are immature. The risk of malignancy increases with age and is less than 10% at birth compared with 75% after age 1 year.¹²

59. C. Sickle cell anemia is caused by homozygous HbSS or by coinheritance of HbS with another β-globin variant.

Sickle cell anemia (hemoglobin [Hb]S) is the most common hemoglobinopathy in the United States. A single base mutation of adenine to thymine results in the replacement of glutamic acid at codon 6 to valine on the β-globin gene (α₂β₂ᵗⱼˡᵉᵒˣˠˢᵗ). The mutation is more common in descendants from Africa, Central and South America, the Middle East, India, and the Mediterranean. Sickle cell trait occurs in 1 in 12 blacks, whereas sickle cell disease affects 1 in 500 blacks compared with 1 in 36,000 Hispanic Americans.¹²

Sickle cell anemia occurs when both genes are affected (homozygous state, HbSS), whereas sickle cell trait occurs when 1 gene is affected (HbAS). HbSS accounts for 60% to 70% of sickle cell disease, whereas the remaining cases are caused by coinheritance of HbS with another β-globin variant, including the following:

- HbC, leading to HbSC disease
- β-thalassemia, leading to sickle cell-β⁰-thalassemia or sickle cell-β⁺-thalassemia

Because this β-globin gene mutation does not affect the production of HbF (α₂δ₂), neonates typically do not have symptoms. Symptoms begin several months after birth and coincide with a decrease in HbF and an increase in HbS levels. Swelling of the hands and feet (dactylitis) is often the first manifestation of sickle cell anemia but does not occur in the neonatal period. HbSS and sickle cell-β⁰-thalassemia have the most severe phenotypes, whereas HbSC and sickle cell-β⁺-thalassemia have a milder phenotype.³⁴

60. D. Preservative and additive solutions are added to the RBC component to reduce hemolysis and extend storage to approximately 35 to 42 days.

Red blood cell (RBC) transfusions are often necessary to treat extremely low-birth-weight neonates with anemia. The process of RBC collection and storage is important to consider because of metabolic changes that occur.

After separation from platelet-rich plasma, preservatives (CPD, CP2D, CPDA-1) and additives (AS-1, AS-3, AS-5) are added to store the RBCs for a maximum of 35 to 42 days. Stored RBC units have a goal hematocrit of 55% to 65%. Multiple metabolic changes occur during storage, including the following:

- Decreased adenosine triphosphate
- Decreased 2,3-diphosphoglycerate, resulting in increased oxygen affinity and decreased tissue oxygen delivery
- Oxidative changes
- Potassium accumulation

Before transfusion, RBC units are irradiated to prevent transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease and undergo leukoreduction to decrease transmission of cytomegalovirus.³

Epidemiological studies have identified multiple risk factors associated with severe neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia. ## 62. E. TMD occurs in up to 10% of patients with Down syndrome.

Transient myeloproliferative disorder (TMD) occurs in 10% of neonates with trisomy 21 and requires 2 genetic abnormalities: (1) trisomy of the ERG gene on chromosome 21 and (2) a GATA1 gene mutation. It can occur in neonates with complete or partial trisomy 21, as well as mosaicism for trisomy 21.¹

Most neonates present in the postnatal period (&gt;95%). Prenatal onset of TMD can occur and may manifest as severe hepatomegaly with or without splenomegaly, hydrops, thrombocytopenia, and anemia. However, fetuses with known trisomy 21 are more likely to develop hydrops for reasons other than TMD.²

## 63. A. Cyclical changes in bilirubin concentration in the first 2 months after birth that require intermittent phototherapy

Review of data from the USA Kernicterus Registry indicates that neonates with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency can exhibit 5 distinct patterns of bilirubin increase¹:

- Slow postnatal increase in bilirubin levels (&lt; 95th percentile) during the first week, which resolves with a maturing bilirubin elimination system
- Predischarge total serum bilirubin (TSB) level less than the 75th percentile, with exacerbation by starvation, dehydration, unrecognized sepsis, or being late preterm and progression to a TSB level greater than the 95th percentile
- Early-onset hyperbilirubinemia: TSB level greater than the 75th percentile with rapid increase (&gt;0.2 mg/dL/h) and good response to timely intensive phototherapy
- Prolonged unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (&gt;2 weeks of age)
- Dramatic, acute-onset excessive hyperbilirubinemia with TSB level increase greater than 1 mg/dL/h, often concurrent with the patterns just described

## 69. D. Normal saline

Partial exchange transfusion is a therapeutic option in neonates with severe, symptomatic polycythemia. Term neonates reach their Hb nadir at approximately 8 weeks after birth, with an average Hb concentration of 11.2 g/dL (112 g/L).¹

Anemia of prematurity is a result of both physiological factors (decreased erythropoietin and erythropoiesis, shortened erythrocyte life span) and nonphysiological, potentially modifiable, factors. These nonphysiological factors include blood loss secondary to laboratory testing and pathological conditions such as sepsis, inadequate nutrition, and hemorrhages. Studies indicate that blood loss is the greatest contributor to anemia of prematurity.¹

## 72. E. Prothrombin time

Vitamin K deficiency syndromes are 1 of the most common causes of bleeding in healthy newborns and can manifest in the first 24 hours after birth (early onset), between 1 and 7 days after birth (classic), or 1 to 8 weeks after birth (late).

Coagulation studies reveal a markedly prolonged prothrombin time in excess of the partial thromboplastin time. Fibrinogen, D dimer, platelet count, and platelet function analyzer are unaffected.¹

## 73. C. Random donor platelets

The first line of treatment for neonates suspected of having neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia (NAIT) is the administration of random donor platelets. Studies indicate that a large proportion of neonates with NAIT respond to random donor platelet transfusions.¹ The administration of intravenous immunoglobulin is also recommended.² In refractory cases, the administration of matched platelets may be necessary. This can be achieved as follows:

- Transfusion of washed and concentrated maternal platelets
- Presumed matched donor platelets (human platelet antigen [HPA]1b1b and HPA5a5a negative)
- Random donor-matched platelets³,⁴

Clinical trials investigating the efficacy of recombinant erythropoietin (rEpo) as a treatment for anemia of prematurity have yielded variable results largely because of significant variations in the doses of rEpo used (ranging from 70 to 5,000 U/kg) and the duration of treatment (from 2 weeks to several months).¹⁻³

1. C. Hyperimmunoglobulin D syndrome

Hyperimmunoglobulin D syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the mevalonate kinase gene located on chromosome 12q24.¹² Infants with hyperimmunoglobulin D syndrome typically present by 6 months of age with episodic fevers that are triggered by immunizations or stressful events and last several days.³ Affected infants also can have a maculopapular rash, vomiting, diarrhea, edema, arthritis, and oral ulcers during these episodes.³ Laboratory findings include an elevated white blood cell count and anemia. Treatment with 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl coenzyme A reductase inhibitors, tumor necrosis factor α inhibitors, or interleukin-1 inhibitors has been successful in some patients. A severe form of hyperimmunoglobulin D syndrome is mevalonic aciduria.

2. B. Hepatitis B vaccine administration is delayed compared with that in term neonates.

In general, preterm neonates who are medically stable should receive vaccinations at the same chronological age as do term neonates. One exception to this rule is that neonates born less than 2,000 g to women who are hepatitis B surface antigen negative should receive the first hepatitis B vaccine either at 1 month of age or at the time of hospital discharge, whichever occurs first.¹

The vaccine dose should not be reduced for preterm neonates nor should the dose be divided into aliquots. The optimal administration site in preterm neonates who receive intramuscular vaccines is the anterolateral area of the thigh. Many large studies have found that vaccine administration does not increase the risk for sudden infant death syndrome or autism in term or preterm neonates.

3. A. HNA-1a

Alloimmune neonatal neutropenia (ANN) occurs when the neonate inherits a human neutrophil antigen (HNA) from the father that is distinct from those of the mother. In utero, the foreign fetal neutrophil antigens enter the maternal circulation, inducing the maternal production of immunoglobulin G antibodies that are then passed back to the fetus and can destroy fetal neutrophils. The degree of fetal neutropenia depends on several factors,¹⁻³ including the:

- Amount of maternal antibodies in the fetal circulation
- Subclass of maternal antibodies
- Fetal reticuloendothelial phagocytic function
- Fetal bone marrow response to produce neutrophils

Many different types of antigenic targets have been implicated in patients with ANN. In the United States, approximately 50% of affected neonates have antibodies that bind to the HNA-1a, HNA-1b, or HNA-2a types.⁴

4. D. Antiphospholipid antibody

Neonates born to women with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can have neonatal lupus syndrome if there is transplacental transfer of the antinuclear antibodies anti-Sjögren syndrome A (SSA/Ro) and anti-Sjögren syndrome B (SSB/La). Common clinical manifestations of this syndrome¹ include the following:

- Rash (papulosquamous erythematous lesions with central clearing associated with a fine scale, most commonly involving the face and scalp, as well as other areas)
- Thrombocytopenia
- Direct hyperbilirubinemia
- Mildly elevated liver function test results

Less common manifestations include anemia, neutropenia, central nervous system vasculitis, bradyarrhythmias, myocarditis, glomerulonephritis, pneumonitis, cerebral dysgenesis, rhizomelia, and optic nerve hypoplasia.

Approximately 30% of women with SLE also have antiphospholipid antibodies. Transplacental transfer of these antibodies can lead to intrauterine growth restriction and preterm birth. Affected neonates are also at greater risk for neonatal thromboses, particularly if there are other risk factors for thromboses.² In this scenario, the neonate does not have any classic findings of neonatal lupus syndrome but does have findings that are consistent with acquisition of antiphospholipid antibodies.

5. B. By 30 weeks' gestational age, the bone marrow has become the exclusive site for B-cell maturation. In humans, the fetal liver contains pre-B cells as early as 7 weeks' gestation and immature B cells that express surface immunoglobulin (sIg)M by 9 weeks' gestation.¹ The bone marrow contains pre-B cells by 12 weeks' gestation with expression of sIgA, sIgG, and sIgD. Plasma cells are initially found at 20 weeks' gestation. By 22 weeks' gestation, fetuses have an amount of B cells in the spleen, bone marrow, and peripheral blood similar to that in adults.² By 30 weeks' gestation, the bone marrow becomes the only site for B-cell maturation, and B cells are no longer found in the liver. After birth, the number of B cells increases, with a peak at 3 to 4 months of age, decreasing to adult levels by age 6 to 7 years.³

6. E. Defects in the recombination activating gene RAG1 or RAG2 result in the failure of T-cell receptor generation.

T-cell development is a complicated process, and the developmental pathway is susceptible to many molecular defects with distinct effects, such as the following¹,²:

- Deficiency in adenosine deaminase or adenylate kinase → excess of toxic metabolites in lymphoid cells → apoptosis of lymphoid precursors located in the bone marrow and thymus
- Defects in the cytokine signal transduction pathway (eg, Janus kinase 3) → failure of lymphocyte development and T-cell differentiation in the thymus
- Defects in the recombination activating gene RAG1 or RAG2 → failure to develop T-cell receptors
- Defects in the DNA repair enzymes (part of V(D)J recombination) → failure to develop T-cell receptors
- Defects in the major histocompatibility complex class II → T-cell death because of inappropriate T-cell receptor mediated survival signals
- Deletion of 22q11.2 or deletion in Forkhead box N1 → T-cell lymphopenia as a result of abnormal development of the thymus

Lymphatic vessels are found in almost all parts of the human body except the brain, the anterior chamber of the eye, the bone marrow, and the part of the spleen containing red pulp.¹ The development of the

## 8. E. The development of the stratum corneum begins between 32 and 34 weeks of gestation.

Preterm neonates have deficits in every part of their immune system. Skin keratinization is delayed in neonates born preterm because the development of the stratum corneum begins between 32 and 34 weeks of gestation and matures within 2 weeks after birth. Preterm neonates have decreased complement activity, lower neutrophil stores, and decreased neutrophil adhesion. This population also has decreased activity of CD4 and CD8 T cells, as well as decreased maternal transfer of immunoglobulin G that occurs in the third trimester. All neonates have a decrease in gastric acidity that occurs after birth, inhibiting the immune ability of the stomach.

## 9. D. Glomerulonephritis

Primary infantile systemic lupus erythematosus is uncommon and primarily involves the renal and pulmonary systems, with manifestations such as pneumonitis, pulmonary hemorrhage, pulmonary capillaritis, glomerulonephritis, and nephrotic syndrome.¹² Neonates with this primary form require aggressive immunosuppression.

Common clinical findings in neonates with neonatal lupus erythematosus include thrombocytopenia, erythematous rash with central clearing, direct hyperbilirubinemia, and abnormal liver function test results. Affected neonates can also have multiple organ involvement, including glomerulonephritis, nephrotic syndrome, pneumonitis, anemia, and abnormal cerebral development.

## 10. B. An important aspect of interpreting screening results is that preterm newborns are expected to have a higher false-positive rate than are term newborns.

Newborn screening can be used to diagnose severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) by measuring the T-cell receptor excision circles (TRECs) by using polymerase chain reaction. If there is a low amount of TRECs, the integrity of the DNA is determined by measuring beta-actin levels. If the TREC amount is low and there is a normal amount of beta-actin, the result is abnormal and confirmation with flow cytometry is required to quantify the lymphocyte subsets. This approach to diagnosing SCID can be used even if the genetic cause is unknown.¹

The presence of maternal T cells in the newborn does not affect the results because these peripherally expanded cells have low TREC levels.

Preterm newborns have an increased false-positive rate of screening results for SCID compared with that of term newborns, so preterm newborns with a low TREC amount and normal beta-actin level should undergo repeat TREC screening closer to a postmenstrual age of 40 weeks' gestation.²

## 13. C. Preterm neonates have lower serum IgG concentrations, with lower nadirs that occur sooner after delivery.

Immunoglobulin (Ig) G is actively transferred from the pregnant woman to the fetus by means of receptor-mediated endocytosis across the placenta. Because this process is active, fetal IgG concentrations may be higher than those in pregnant women. Preterm neonates are deficient in IgG because most of the IgG transfer occurs during the late second trimester and throughout the third trimester.¹ After birth, IgG is catabolized, and concentrations in both term and preterm neonates decrease to a nadir between 3 and 5 months of age. The preterm neonate usually has a lower nadir that occurs at an earlier chronological age.

## 14. C. She will be at increased risk of pneumonia due to adenovirus, cytomegalovirus, and respiratory syncytial virus.

Severe combined immunodeficiency is a rare disease that causes recurrent severe infections as a result of deficient or poorly functioning T cells. This disease occurs more often in males. Patients are at increased risk of the following:¹⁻⁵

- Pneumonia due to adenovirus, cytomegalovirus, *Pneumocystis jirovecii*, or respiratory syncytial virus
- Chronic viral diarrhea leading to failure to thrive
- Systemic illness after immunization with a live attenuated vaccine (eg, chronic rotavirus diarrhea can occur after administration of live oral rotavirus vaccine)³,⁴
- Episodic rash, liver dysfunction, and diarrhea

If affected newborns are untreated, death during infancy or early childhood is very likely.

## 15. B. Cardiocyte apoptosis

Congenital heart block occurs in 1% to 2% of neonates born to women with antinuclear Sjögren syndrome A/Ro and antinuclear Sjögren syndrome B/La antibodies.¹ The mechanism for the conduction injury associated with these maternal antibodies starts with cardiocyte apoptosis, which is a normal part of fetal cardiac development.²,³ The maternal antibodies then bind to the surface of the cardiocytes, attracting macrophages to the site.²,⁵ The subsequent secretion of several fibrosis-promoting factors leads to irreversible fibrosis of the fetal cardiac conduction pathways.²,³

# 16. D. Pregnancy-induced hypertension

The most common cause of neutropenia in neonates during the first postnatal week is decreased neutrophil production secondary to pregnancy-induced hypertension. $^{1,2}$  Thus, in neonates who appear well but have neutropenia (neutrophil count  $&lt; 1.0 \times 10^{3} / \mathrm{mcL}$ $[1.0 \times 10^{9} / \mathrm{L}]$ ) who are born to women with this condition, further evaluation is usually considered only if neutropenia persists beyond 5 to 7 days.

Other causes of neonatal neutropenia include the following:

- Decreased neutrophil production

- Bone marrow failure such as Kostmann syndrome and Shwachman-Diamond syndrome
- Maternal conditions such as diabetes mellitus
Some viral infections

- Increased neutrophil destruction

- Immune-mediated processes such as alloimmune neonatal neutropenia or congenital autoimmune neutropenia
- Microbial infections

- Increased margination of neutrophils

- Drug-induced neutropenia
Some infections
- Idiopathic neutropenia

# 17. C. Migratory maculopapular skin rash

Chronic infantile neurological cutaneous and articular syndrome, also known as neonatal-onset multisystem inflammatory disease, has 3 common clinical manifestations $^{1,2}$ :

1. Chronic aseptic meningitis (lumbar puncture demonstrates prominent neutrophilia)
2. Rash (urticarial, migratory, maculopapular—usually noted at birth)
3. Metaphyseal skeletal dysplasia (usually involving long bones and large joints, seen in  $50\%$  of affected infants within the first few months after birth)

Periodic fevers, ocular involvement (conjunctivitis, uveitis, or papilledema), progressive hearing loss, and dysmorphic features (frontal bossing and saddle nose) also often occur.

# 18. B. For patients with adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency, polyethylene-glycosylated ADA enzyme replacement can help partially to restore the infant's immune system before transplant.

Definitive treatment of severe combined immunodeficiency is a hematopoietic stem cell transplant to replace the infant's abnormal immune system with healthy cells. $^{1,2}$  If patients are not severely immunocompromised, pretransplant chemotherapy is beneficial because it helps to open up sites within the bone marrow for donor cells to be deposited and also reduces the risk of graft rejection. $^{3}$  Outcomes are better if the donor is matched to the patient's human leukocyte antigen $^{2}$  and if the transplant occurs early in life, before any infections occur. $^{4}$  Before transplant, enzyme replacement for patients with ADA deficiency can partially restore the infant's immune system. $^{5}$  Retrovirus-mediated gene therapy is being investigated as a possible alternative to stem cell transplants for patients with ADA deficiency.

# 19. C. Rotavirus is a common pathogen, with most children infected by 3 years of age, with outbreaks in NICUs having been reported.

Rotavirus is a common pathogen that infects almost all children by 3 years of age.¹ Outbreaks of rotavirus infection have occurred in neonatal intensive care units (NICUs), and there have been reports of a temporal association with necrotizing enterocolitis.¹ A tetravalent rhesus-based rotavirus vaccine used in 1998 was associated with an increased risk of intussusception and was withdrawn.² Currently, there are 2 vaccines available in the United States: a human-bovine reassortant vaccine and a monovalent, live attenuated vaccine that are not associated with an increased risk of intussusception. Since 2006, rotavirus immunization in the United States has decreased neonatal hospitalizations by an estimated 1.5 million.³

Both types of vaccines are associated with shedding in stool, raising concerns for possible rotavirus transmission via the fecal-oral route.² Because of this risk, most NICUs withhold the rotavirus vaccine until discharge, with the first dose recommended between 42 and 104 days.⁴ This approach has led to delayed or missed rotavirus immunizations in preterm neonates, prompting some NICUs to vaccinate preterm neonates during their NICU stay.⁵

# 20. D. Platelet-endothelial cell adhesion molecule

Numerous molecules are involved in the process of neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissues. The first step (neutrophil rolling with binding to and release from inflamed endothelium) is mediated by selectin ligands (L-selectin on neutrophils and E- or P-selectin on endothelial cells).¹ Neutrophils are then able to attach to the endothelium through the binding of neutrophil beta₂ or leukocyte integrins (eg, leukocyte function-associated antigen-1) to receptors on the endothelial cells (eg, intercellular adhesion molecule-1).² Platelet-endothelial cell adhesion molecules are important for the transendothelial migration of neutrophils during the final step.

Neonatal monocytes ingest and destroy bacteria, similar to the way in which adult monocytes do. 22. D. Pertussis mortality is highest in neonates and infants younger than 6 months, particularly for the youngest who are infected.

The incidence of pertussis infection has been increasing, with the highest rate occurring in neonates and infants younger than 1 year of age. This increase is partly because of waning immunity in adults, as well as delays in diagnosis because of atypical symptoms in adults (chronic cough that is not consistent with the classic whooping episodes). Infants receive the first pertussis vaccine at 2 months' chronological age and thus are unprotected from pertussis for an extended period, leading to increased mortality in neonates and infants younger than 6 months of age who are infected. Preterm neonates are particularly vulnerable and have higher rates of hospitalizations and need for intensive care.

23. C. The age of a neonate determines antibody response more than does the neonate's gestational age; therefore, vaccinations within the first few days after delivery will generally produce a poor immune response.

The amount of antibody response that occurs after immunizations is determined by a neonate's chronological age rather than the neonate's gestational age. Thus, the timing of vaccinations should not be corrected for gestational age, and most vaccination schedules start at 2 months of age.

Marginal zone B cells are the primary responders for encapsulated organisms; these cells are restricted to the spleen, and very few are present at birth. The humoral immune response to encapsulated bacteria (eg, Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae) is delayed past the time of birth. The naive nature of the adaptive immune system at birth also inhibits neonates from mounting an adequate immune response to foreign antigens.

24. A. Antimicrobial lactoferrin

Azurophilic granules contain myeloperoxidase, proteolytic enzymes (eg, cathepsins, elastase), and antimicrobial proteins (eg, defensins and bactericidal permeability increasing proteins). In contrast, the smaller specific granules contain bacteria-destroying compounds such as lactoferrin, lysozyme, and complement fragment receptors. The content in azurophilic granules assists with intracellular killing of bacteria, whereas the content of specific granules is important for extracellular killing. $^{1}$

25. B. Cysteine

Chemokines are cytokines that are chemotactic. These small proteins contain 4 cysteine residues that are critical for the disulfide covalent bonding necessary to form their secondary structure. Chemokines assist with migration of cells to sites of injury or infection.

## 26. C. Hyperimmune globulin infusions

Some studies investigating hyperimmune globulin infusions suggest a possible benefit of preventing sepsis in very low-birth-weight neonates, and clinical trials with antistaphylococcal immunoglobulins are ongoing.¹,²

Pasteurized donor human milk does not decrease the risk of infections in neonates; this lack of immunologic benefit is likely related to the processing or pasteurization process of banked human milk.³,⁴

Four trials examined the benefit of granulocyte transfusions administered in neonates with sepsis and neutropenia. Although none of these trials showed an improvement in survival, a meta-analysis of these studies concluded that the data were insufficient to recommend or refute the use of granulocyte transfusions.⁵

Administration of myeloid colony-stimulating factors, such as granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, does not decrease mortality in neonates with sepsis.⁶ A large randomized controlled trial assessed the early postnatal use of granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor as prophylaxis for reduction of sepsis in extremely preterm neonates (PROGRAMS trial).⁷ Although this stimulating factor led to an improvement in neutropenia, there was no reduction in sepsis or mortality.⁷

Immunization with T-cell-dependent protein antigens is ineffective in preterm and term neonates because the neonatal antibody response is weak early in life.

## 27. E. Thrombocytopenia

There are 3 main clinical manifestations of neonatal lupus syndrome:

- Rash (erythematous lesions with central pallor)
- Thrombocytopenia
- Direct hyperbilirubinemia with mild transaminitis

These clinical findings typically resolve over time as maternal autoantibodies disappear from the neonatal circulation. Neonatal lupus syndrome can also involve other organs such as the heart (eg, heart block, myocarditis, endocarditis), kidneys (eg, glomerulonephritis, nephrotic syndrome), lungs (pneumonitis, pulmonary hemorrhage), and brain (eg, cerebral dysmaturation or dysgenesis). Some of these manifestations may have long-term effects.

## 28. B. No symptoms

Although neonates with autoimmune neutropenia of infancy have primary neutropenia as a result of autoantibodies (similar to immune thrombocytopenic purpura), neonates with neonatal autoimmune neutropenia acquire maternal autoantibodies during gestation that destroy fetal neutrophils.¹,²

Autoimmune neutropenia of infancy leads to neutropenia associated with minor infections (eg, otitis media, respiratory tract infections, gastroenteritis, cellulitis) and typically resolves by 4 years of age.³ In contrast, neonates with neonatal alloimmune neutropenia have transient neutropenia that resolves within a few months of age, and affected patients usually have no symptoms.

## 29. B. Drug-induced neutropenia

Neutropenia occurs in approximately 8% of neonates admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit.¹ The mechanisms for this hematologic abnormality include the following:

- Decreased neutrophil production as a result of inherited neutropenias, viral infections, and maternal conditions such as pregnancy-induced hypertension²,³
- Increased neutrophil destruction as a result of immune-mediated disorders and bacterial infections⁴
- Increased neutrophil margination in the microvascular endothelium as a result of medications

## 30. A. Apnea before administration of vaccines

Mild and transient episodes of apnea and bradycardia can occur in preterm neonates after immunization with the following vaccines: Haemophilus influenzae type b, inactivated poliovirus, hepatitis B virus, and pneumococcal conjugate.¹ Recent studies suggest that although whole-cell pertussis vaccine might be associated with apnea, this risk decreases with the use of acellular pertussis vaccine.² The most significant factor associated with postimmunization apnea is apnea occurring before vaccine administration.³ Neonates with a high score on the Score for Neonatal Acute Physiology at 12 hours of age, a younger age (younger than 67 days), and a lower birth weight (&lt; 2,000 g) were also at greater risk for postimmunization apnea.³

## 31. A. Elevated C-reactive protein levels

The laboratory findings in patients with mevalonic aciduria include elevated levels of inflammatory markers (eg, C-reactive protein), increased white blood cell counts, and anemia; these findings typically become more severe during acute episodes.¹ In contrast to other organic acid defects, mevalonic aciduria is not associated with acidosis, hypoglycemia, ketosis, or hyperammonemia.² Concentrations of mevalonic acid in the plasma, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid of affected patients are increased.

## 32. E. Organism coated by immunoglobulin G

The efficiency of phagocytosis increases when the target is opsonized by a specific immunoglobulin G, which helps to neutralize phagocytic inhibitors (eg, capsular polysaccharide) and makes the bacterial surface more hydrophobic and, thus, more easily ingested.¹ Phagocytosis is even more effective if the organism surface is also coated by complement component 3, as well as immunoglobulin G.¹

## 33. A. Apneic events associated with acellular pertussis vaccination have not been shown consistently, and recent reports suggest that apnea is more likely related to the infant's clinical status.

Globally, studies have found lower immunization rates in neonates born preterm, particularly in extremely low-birth-weight neonates. In studies from the United States and Canada, this lower rate was most significant at 2 months of age and persisted at 6 months of age, with improvement by age 12 months.¹² Part of this delay is the erroneous belief that preterm neonates are unable to tolerate or respond to vaccinations.³

Preterm infants have an increased risk of apnea after the 2-month immunizations, particularly if these episodes occurred preimmunization;⁴ 4-month immunizations have not been associated with an increased risk of apnea.⁵ This potential risk of postimmunization apnea should not lead to a delay in vaccination. Cardiorespiratory events have been implicated most frequently after the whole-cell pertussis vaccine, leading to a delay in pertussis vaccination or mandatory monitoring after vaccination.⁶ Studies have found that this association is lower if the acellular pertussis preparation is used and might be more related to the patient's clinical status rather than the vaccine itself.⁷

## 34. C. Follicular B2 cells provide the adaptive immune response against thymus-dependent antigens.

In mammals, there are 3 major B-cell subsets with distinct functions:

- Follicular B2 cells provide the adaptive immune response against thymus-dependent antigens; they are responsible for creating high-affinity antibodies that are highly specific to antigens.¹
- B1 cells are found primarily in the peritoneal and pleural cavities; they are part of the innate immune response against thymus-independent antigens and create low-affinity antibodies with broad antigen specificity.² They are the predominant type of B cell in the fetus, with approximately 90% of the total cord blood B cells consisting of CD5+ B cells.
- Marginal zone B cells are found primarily in the spleen; they are part of the innate immune response against thymus-independent antigens and create low-affinity antibodies with broad antigen specificity.²

## 35. D. Infants younger than 31 weeks' gestational age have decreased antibody titers to whole-cell pertussis vaccine compared with that of term infants.

A preterm infant's humoral response and antibody titers after vaccinations vary with the type of vaccine.¹ Postimmunization antibody response correlates directly with birth gestational age, chronological age, and birth weight.² For example, infants younger than 31 weeks' gestational age have decreased antibody titers to whole-cell pertussis vaccine compared with that of term infants,³ and preterm infants also have decreased titers after immunization to *Haemophilus influenzae* type b.⁴ In contrast, preterm infants have an adequate antibody response to the hepatitis B vaccine.³

## 36. A. Cytokines in the thymus transmit growth and differentiation signals that help generate a specific T-cell receptor for each T cell.

During fetal hematopoiesis, T-cell precursors develop in the fetal liver and then in the bone marrow. These precursors then migrate to the thymus where cytokines transmit growth and differentiation signals to help generate a specific T-cell receptor for each T cell. The T-cell receptor locus contains many V, D, and J gene segments. Recombination-activating genes and DNA repair enzymes (eg, DNA ligase) then rearrange the gene segments. As a result, a new linear T-cell receptor locus is created, leading to an extremely diverse group of T-cell receptors that can respond to a large group of antigens. Along with this new T-cell receptor, T-cell receptor excision circles are also created. Molecular defects can occur at any of these steps and lead to severe combined immunodeficiency disorder. $^{1,2}$

## 37. E. X-linked agammaglobulinemia is characterized by near absence of all immunoglobulins.

Abnormalities in the development of B cells lead to multiple different immunodeficiencies. Almost complete absence of all immunoglobulins causes the severe immunodeficiency known as X-linked agammaglobulinemia. This occurs when there are mutations in the Bruton tyrosine kinase gene, which prevents pre-B cells from developing into immature B cells. $^{1}$ This arrest in B-cell development prevents B-cell differentiation and thereby antibody production in response to microbes. $^{1}$ Infants with X-linked agammaglobulinemia are protected from severe infections in the first few months after birth because of transplacental acquisition of maternal antibodies.

X-linked hyper IgM syndrome is a group of disorders caused by CD40 ligand mutations that lead to abnormalities in the immunoglobulin class-switch recombination. Affected patients have high or normal IgM levels and low IgG, IgA, and IgE levels. $^{2}$

Infants with common variable immunodeficiency have decreased serum IgG concentrations and reduced switched memory B cells, leading to an inadequate response to vaccines and decreased ability to switch immunoglobulin classes. $^{3}$

3. E. 2 to 3 days after developing sepsis
C-reactive protein (CRP) is an acute phase protein used in the evaluation of sepsis in neonates. When sepsis occurs, CRP concentrations are initially increased in less than one-fifth of neonates with infection. Twenty-four hours after an infant develops symptoms consistent with sepsis, levels of this protein are significantly elevated, with peak concentrations occurring 2 to 3 days after infection onset. Therefore, antibiotic therapy should lead to a decrease in inflammation and, correspondingly, the CRP concentrations should decrease; if this does not occur, the neonate may not be responding to antibiotics, perhaps because the pathogen is not sensitive to the antibiotic regimen.¹

4. C. *Escherichia coli*
Because intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis for group B *Streptococcus* has become standard, the incidence of early-onset sepsis caused by gram-negative organisms has increased. *Escherichia coli* is the most common gram-negative organism that causes early-onset sepsis in preterm neonates.¹⁻³ The pathogenesis of early-onset sepsis is most often attributable to ascending colonization in the setting of rupture of membranes. This can then lead to intra-amniotic fetal infection or fetal colonization at the time of delivery. Early-onset neonatal sepsis caused by *Listeria monocytogenes* is unique because it is spread hematogenously across the placenta.

5. D. Soft-tissue swelling

In newborns with osteomyelitis, the soft-tissue swelling around the involved bone is the first abnormality to manifest at radiography. As the infection progresses, necrosis within the bone is apparent. Radiographic evidence of bone destruction appears at approximately 7 to 10 days from the onset of the infection, earlier than it does in older children. If the adjacent joint is involved, joint swelling and a widened joint space can be visible.

6. D. This finding may also be associated with histologically visible lesions on the surface of the umbilical cord of wedge-shaped, microabscesses containing yeast, hyphae, and neutrophils.

Invasive Candida disease in a neonate is uncommon. Because affected neonates have similar clinical findings, unlike neonates with bacterial infections, umbilical cord pathological assessment is helpful in diagnosing Candida infection. The pathological findings described in this vignette are consistent with Candida infection. Grossly, the infected umbilical cord demonstrates cream-colored 2- to 3-mm macules. Histological findings of the umbilical cord of a neonate with invasive Candida disease will demonstrate pathognomonic wedge-shaped microabscesses containing yeast, hyphae, and neutrophils.

7. E. The time to positivity for the blood culture was 14 hours after the culture was obtained.

Several factors can help in distinguishing between a true coagulase-negative Staphylococcus species infection and contamination. A true infection is more likely in the following scenarios¹:

- Blood cultures from a peripheral site and central line both positive for the same organism
- Greater than 50 colony-forming units/mL
- Repeat blood culture positive for the same organism but obtained before antibiotics
- Time to positive blood culture of less than 15 hours
- Elevated inflammatory markers, such as C-reactive protein
- Clinical symptoms consistent with sepsis

Changes in care practices in neonatal intensive care units can affect the rate of central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs) significantly. There are 3 main approaches to decrease the CLABSI rate¹,²:

1. Promote hand hygiene
2. Optimize insertion, use, and removal of the central line, including the following:

- Criteria for line insertion and removal
- A dedicated team for line insertion
- Checklists for insertion procedure and monitoring of the line

- A maximal sterile barrier during placement, with use of mask, hat, sterile gown, sterile gloves, and sterile drapes

- Interval guidelines for tubing changes: the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention currently recommends line changes every 96 hours for most fluids except for lipid-containing lines that should be changed every 24 hours, as well as administration of blood products that requires a line change with each infusion³

11. C. The incidence of early-onset sepsis for very low-birth-weight newborns in the United States is 10 per 1,000 live births in recent years.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defines neonatal early-onset sepsis (EOS) as a positive blood or cerebrospinal fluid culture within the first 7 days after birth.¹ The definition of EOS in very low-birth-weight newborns is a positive culture within the first 72 hours after birth.² This definition encompasses a shorter period in preterm newborns because an infection in this population after 72 hours can be attributable to instrumentation or nosocomial flora rather than perinatal acquisition.² In recent years, the incidence of EOS for very low-birth-weight newborns in the United States has been 10 per 1,000 live births.³

12. D. Over the past 20 years, cases of early-onset neonatal group B Streptococcus infection have decreased in the United States because of intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis.

Group B Streptococcus and Escherichia coli are the 2 most common causes of neonatal meningitis, accounting for two-thirds of proven cases. As a result of increasing antimicrobial resistance to these 2 pathogens, current initial antibiotic treatment in neonates suspected of having sepsis or meningitis should include ampicillin and gentamicin. A third-generation cephalosporin should be considered if there is high risk of gram-negative bacilli infection (eg, maternal intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis). This empiric treatment should be modified based on organism sensitivity. No vaccines currently are approved during pregnancy to prevent meningitis.

13. D. Intrauterine and intrapartum transmission are the most common routes of acquisition of HCV in children.

Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection is a major cause of chronic liver disease. Intrauterine and intrapartum transmission are the most common routes of acquisition of HCV in children. Pregnant women who acquire HCV infection usually have no symptoms. HCV RNA has been found in human milk at extremely low levels, so breastfeeding is not contraindicated in women infected with HCV. At present, there is no medication available to reduce the perinatal transmission of HCV.

## 14. D. Intravenous acyclovir is recommended for severe infections.

Intravenous acyclovir is the drug of choice for pregnant women with severe varicella infections, whereas oral acyclovir is recommended for routine infections. For pregnant women with zoster infection, acyclovir is recommended only if the lesions are severe or painful. Acyclovir is most effective if therapy for the pregnant woman is initiated within 1 day of the onset of varicella symptoms or within 3 days of zoster lesions.¹ There are insufficient studies examining the use of the antiviral foscarnet for use in pregnant women with varicella. For pregnant women who are not infected and not immune, the varicella vaccine should be administered postpartum, even in breastfeeding women.²

## 16. E. Varicella-zoster virus

Precautions for airborne organisms are needed to prevent the transmission of varicella-zoster virus, measles, and pulmonary tuberculosis. These pathogens can spread over long distances, so the patient should be placed in a private airflow room, and health care providers should use a respirator (eg, fit-tested N-95 or powered air-purifying respirators).¹

For respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) or multidrug-resistant organisms such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus that are spread by contact, health care workers should wear a gown and gloves (and possibly a mask for RSV) to prevent transmission.¹ Because pertussis spreads via respiratory droplets over short distances, hospital personnel should use a mask for protection.¹ Personnel caring for a neonate with adenovirus need to use contact and droplet precautions, which include gloves, gown, and mask.¹

## 17. B. 36 hours

Kumar and associates retrospectively studied the time to positivity of neonatal blood cultures in 215 neonates with 404 noncontaminated positive blood cultures.¹ They found that 90% of cultures were positive by 36 hours, 93% of cultures were positive by 48 hours, and 98.5% were positive by 60 hours.¹ The negative predictive values were 99.7% and 99.8% at 36 and 48 hours, respectively.¹ The authors summarized that a 36-hour period of observation of blood cultures is adequate to rule out sepsis in neonates without symptoms.¹

## 18. C. Transmission frequency of Toxoplasma during pregnancy increases with advancing gestation.

More than 80% of pregnant women in the United States are susceptible to an acute infection with Toxoplasma gondii. Women can acquire the parasite by ingesting oocysts present in the feces of infected cats and contaminated soil, cat litter, water, or garden vegetables. Kittens are more likely to contain oocysts than are adult cats. Alternatively, women can become infected by ingesting pseudocysts in undercooked meat. Although most pregnant women who are infected have no symptoms, approximately 15% present with a flu-like illness with lymphadenopathy. The transmission rate is highest if the maternal infection

## 21. D. One mechanism of GBS meningitis is transcellular, whereby the bacteria penetrate through the blood-brain barrier cells without any intercellular involvement or disruption of tight junctions.

There are 3 ways that bacteria can penetrate the blood-brain barrier¹:

- Transcellular: bacterial penetration through the blood-brain barrier cells
- Paracellular: bacterial penetration between the blood-brain barrier cells
- Trojan horse mechanism: bacterial penetration by transmigration of infected phagocytes

Animal and human studies have shown that group B *Streptococcus* (GBS), *Escherichia coli*, and *Listeria monocytogenes* can penetrate the blood-brain barrier by means of the transcellular approach.

*L monocytogenes* can also cause meningitis by means of the Trojan horse mechanism.

22. E. The goal of HCV treatment is undetectable viral RNA in the blood approximately 6 months after discontinuation of interferon therapies and approximately 3 months after discontinuation of direct-acting antivirals.

The goal of hepatitis C virus (HCV) treatment is to decrease serum viral RNA to undetectable levels in the blood approximately 6 months after discontinuation of interferon therapies and approximately 3 months after discontinuation of direct-acting antivirals. Direct-acting antivirals are administered orally. Women of reproductive age who are HCV positive should be treated for HCV before pregnancy because antiviral therapy is not currently recommended in pregnant women because of lack of efficacy and limited safety data.¹ Ribavirin use in pregnant women who are HCV positive has teratogenic effects.² Children with hepatitis C infection can receive pegylated interferon with ribavirin, with the length of treatment ranging from 24 to 48 weeks, depending on the genotype.¹

23. B. Escherichia coli

Skull osteomyelitis occurs in neonates after an iatrogenic injury, such as complications of a cephalohematoma or after use of a fetal scalp electrode.
