24. A. Breast

Clinical manifestations of a methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection in the neonate include pustulosis, cellulitis, abscess, and invasive disease (eg, osteomyelitis, arthritis, pneumonia, meningitis).¹ Pustulosis involves a collection of pus with lesions that are less than 1 cm in diameter, and an abscess is a collection of pus of 1 cm in diameter or more. The breast is the most common site for abscess formation in neonatal MRSA infections, whereas pustulosis can involve any part of the skin.

25. E. VariZIG is recommended in any patients who are immunocompromised and not immune.

After a patient is exposed to varicella, the administration of varicella-zoster immune globulin (VariZIG) is effective at preventing varicella infection and is recommended in the following scenarios¹:

- Any person who is immunocompromised and not immune
- Newborns born to women with symptoms of a varicella virus infection 5 days before delivery and until 2 days after delivery
- Hospitalized preterm newborns born younger than 28-weeks’ gestational age or with birth weight less than 1,000 g

VariZIG significantly decreases the mortality rate of newborns at high risk for varicella infection. Of note, newborns cannot receive the varicella-zoster vaccine.

## 31. C. Gestational immaturity

Candida is the third most common pathogen responsible for sepsis beyond 72 hours of age in very low-birth-weight neonates. Young gestational age and low birth weight are the 2 most significant risk factors for acquiring a Candida infection in the neonate who is hospitalized. Other risk factors are endotracheal intubation, central venous catheter use, parenteral nutrition, and medications such as corticosteroids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

## 32. D. Reasons that coagulase-negative staphylococci may be common in CLABSIs include that they are practically a universal colonizer of skin in neonates in the neonatal intensive care unit and are also further selected by resistance to most antibiotics routinely administered to these neonates.

The most common organism that contributes to central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs) in neonates is coagulase-negative staphylococci. This organism colonizes the skin of almost all patients in the neonatal intensive care unit and is resistant to most antibiotics. Other common microbes are enterococci, Candida, and gram-negative organisms. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and methicillin-sensitive S aureus are prevalent in 1% to 5% and 20% to 30% of healthy adults in the United States, respectively. These gram-positive organisms produce compounds that help them adhere to catheter surfaces. In contrast, gram-negative organisms contribute to less than 10% of CLABSIs in neonates.

## 33. A. Hand hygiene before and after every patient contact

Direct or indirect contact is the primary transmission route of pathogens in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). The most effective method of preventing a nosocomial infection in this environment is to ensure that clinical care providers practice meticulous hand hygiene before and after every patient interaction. Other strategies that can decrease nosocomial infections in the NICU include:

- Removal of all jewelry distal to the elbows¹,²
- Wearing masks to avoid contact with respiratory secretions

Studies have not found that surgical scrubbing before entry into the NICU affects the nosocomial infection rate.³ Similarly, there is no evidence that universally wearing gloves for all patient contact decreases the rate of nosocomial infections, and 1 study suggests that this practice may be associated with poor hand hygiene between uses of gloves.⁴

## 35. D. Liver

Congenital tuberculosis (TB) is rare and occurs when the pregnant woman has recently acquired TB either immediately before the pregnancy or during the pregnancy. A pregnant woman with TB can infect the fetus by means of hematogenous spread across the placenta and into the umbilical vein. Blood flow from the umbilical vein then enters the liver, which is the first organ infected with bacteria.

38. E. Tachycardia in the absence of external stimuli and hypothermia

The systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is a dysregulation in the normal physiological state evident by alterations in vital signs and laboratory results.¹ The adult definition of SIRS has been modified for application in term neonates and consists of the following:

- Abnormal temperature defined as greater than 38.5°C or less than 36°C
- Tachycardia or bradycardia without any other explanation
- Tachypnea or acute need for mechanical ventilation
- Leukocytosis, leukopenia, or greater than 10% immature neutrophils

Diagnosis requires the presence of at least 2 of these 4 findings, and 1 of these must be an abnormal temperature or white blood cell count. Challenges arise when using this definition in preterm neonates because preterm neonates have unique physiological characteristics.²

- Lower incidence of severe infections and decreased mortality with shortened length of stay in low-resource settings

Strong evidence is lacking for the use of skin-to-skin care in neonates who are hospitalized and whose condition is unstable.

40. E. Using a multivariable model that takes into account prior probability of sepsis on the basis of multiple variables, including maternal factors, can help to reduce the number of newborns evaluated and empirically treated for EOS.

Multivariable risk models for early-onset sepsis (EOS) are available that begin with the prior probability of sepsis and account for both maternal risk factors known at the time of birth and for the newborn clinical condition from birth through 12 hours of age. Use of clinical algorithms based on such models can help to reduce the number of newborns evaluated and empirically treated for EOS.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the American Academy of Pediatrics recommend that providers should determine the newborn risk assessment for EOS by using maternal and neonatal factors.¹⁻³ One group of authors examined the use of a multivariable model to determine EOS probability on the basis of known risks.⁴ Combining risks, such as length of rupture of membranes, maternal fever, and clinical findings in the newborn, led to a reduction in the number of newborns evaluated and empirically treated for EOS.⁴ The approach of using 1 variable, such as rupture of members more than 18 hours, is less effective because it does not account for interactions among risk factors. Single components of the complete blood cell count or C-reactive protein level are also poor predictors of EOS.

42. C. EOS in newborns is mostly caused by rupture of membranes, with ascending colonization leading to intra-amniotic infection.

Early-onset sepsis (EOS) occurs in newborns after rupture of membranes, with ascending colonization leading to intra-amniotic infection. Newborn colonization at the time of delivery can also lead to neonatal infection. Although group B Streptococcus is the most common organism that leads to EOS in term newborns, preterm newborns are most likely to have EOS as a result of Escherichia coli. 43. C. Nonculture tests of cerebrospinal fluid, such as latex agglutination, polymerase chain reaction, microarray, or immunochromatography, may be helpful in cases of previous antibiotic treatment.

The neonate described in this vignette has symptoms that might be consistent with meningitis. When meningitis is suspected in a neonate, the cerebrospinal fluid should be tested as early as possible (ideally, before starting antibiotics). A neonate with bacterial meningitis might have cerebrospinal fluid results that show polymorphonuclear pleocytosis, low glucose concentration, increased protein concentration, and positive culture result.

Nonculture cerebrospinal fluid testing may be helpful if earlier identification of organisms is needed, antibiotics were previously administered, or there is a diagnosis of intraventricular hemorrhage. Options for this type of testing include latex agglutination, polymerase chain reaction, microarray, or immunochromatography. The loop-mediated isothermal amplification method is a promising test that amplifies DNA at isothermic temperatures.

44. E. There is a positive correlation between HCV viral load and risk of perinatal transmission, with pregnant women with a higher HCV RNA load more likely to transmit the virus than are women with low or no viremia.

The most common route of hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection in neonates is mother-to-neonate vertical transmission. The transmission rate from a pregnant woman who is HCV positive to the fetus is between 7% and 15%. The risk of transmission is greatest in the following situations:

- High maternal HCV viral load³
- High HCV RNA load, even if the pregnant woman has low viremia³
- Maternal coinfection with HIV (increased risk by 3- to 5-fold)⁴; this risk decreases significantly, and might even be protective, if the pregnant woman is receiving highly active antiretroviral therapy⁴
- Female neonate⁵

Factors that are unlikely to affect the risk of HCV mother-to-neonate transmission are:

- Prolonged rupture of membranes or use of fetal scalp electrodes⁶
- Mode of delivery⁵
- Genotype of the virus³

## 45. D. Occupations with exposure to children

In the United States, congenital cytomegalovirus occurs in approximately 40,000 neonates per year. This infection is found most commonly in women with the following characteristics:

- Young age
- Unmarried status
- Race other than white
- High exposure to young children (eg, occupation in childcare)

## 46. A. Bilirubin toxicity

Third-generation cephalosporins can lead to adverse effects, including phlebitis, fever, gastrointestinal symptoms such as emesis and diarrhea, elevated liver function test results, and cholelithiasis. More serious adverse effects include seizure activity, hemolytic anemia, and bone marrow suppression with thrombocytopenia and leukopenia.¹ Ceftriaxone can displace bilirubin from albumin and, thus, is not recommended during the first postnatal week.²

## 47. A. Although a report that is structured as a clinical-pathological correlation can provide the physician with useful information, some situations may benefit from further communication between pathologist and neonatologist.

A pathologist can provide the neonatologist with useful information about the pathological nature of the placenta. In some cases, it may be beneficial for the pathologist to communicate with the neonatologist. During the assessment of the severity of placental inflammation, the pathologist's standard practice is to use the nomenclature and classification system established in 2003 by the Perinatal Section of the Society for Pediatric Pathology.¹ This approach helps to standardize the pathologist's report, but it is not intended to guide the neonatologist in management decisions such as the need to start antibiotics.

48. A. 16 to 20 weeks

The fetus of a pregnant woman with primary varicella infection can become infected during periods of maternal viremia, with the greatest risk occurring between 8 and 20 weeks' gestation. Transmission of varicella to the fetus during this period can lead to fetal demise or congenital varicella syndrome.

49. A. Femur

The most common site of neonatal osteomyelitis is the metaphysis of long bones. The most frequently involved long bones are the femur and tibia followed by the humerus and the fibula.

50. A. Hepatomegaly

Almost 80% of newborns with congenital syphilis have symptoms at birth,1 with symptoms typically developing between weeks 3 and 14 after birth. There is a wide spectrum of clinical findings, with early clinical manifestations consisting of the following1:

Hepatosplenomegaly (hepatomegaly is present in almost all affected newborns)Rash (maculopapular desquamating diffuse lesions or vesiculobullous lesions involving the palms and soles, also known as pemphigus syphiliticus)Rhinitis (highly infectious nasal fluid)JaundicePseudoparalysisNephrotic syndrome (as early as 2 to 3 months of age)Hematologic manifestations, such as an elevated or low white blood cell count and/or low platelet countCentral nervous system abnormalities, such as meningitis, hydrocephalus, or seizuresOsteochondritis (usually involving the long bones and ribs)

Stigmas of this early disease lead to late congenital syphilis, with findings such as Hutchinson teeth, saddle nose deformity, retinal and corneal abnormalities, neurodevelopmental abnormalities, and joint abnormalities.1

51. B. Hepatosplenomegaly

Congenital tuberculosis results from hematogenous spread from the placenta into the umbilical vein, resulting in a primary lesion in the fetal liver or fetal lung. Congenital tuberculosis can also be acquired by ingestion or aspiration of infected amniotic fluid, resulting in gastrointestinal or pulmonary disease, respectively. Affected neonates typically present during the second or third postnatal week. The most common clinical manifestations are as follows1,2:

Hepatosplenomegaly (76%)Respiratory distress (72%)Fever (48%)Lymphadenopathy (38%)Irritability or lethargy (21%)Ear discharge (17%)Skin papules (14%)

## 54. A. Almost all children with perinatally acquired HCV have no symptoms.

Almost all children with perinatally acquired hepatitis C virus (HCV) have no symptoms. Mother-to-neonate vertical transmission of HCV leads to 3 possible outcomes¹:

1. Acute resolving infection (~20%): children have spontaneous viral clearance
2. Chronic asymptomatic infection (50%): children have intermittent viremia with normal liver function test results and typically no hepatomegaly
3. Chronic active infection (~30%): children have persistent viremia, abnormal liver function test results (frequently), and sometimes hepatomegaly; disease in affected children progresses slowly, with a 1% to 2% risk for cirrhosis during childhood²

## 56. C. Oxacillin and gentamicin

After cultures are obtained in a neonate suspected of having osteomyelitis, antimicrobial therapy should be started as soon as possible. The combination of oxacillin or nafcillin with an aminoglycoside (eg, gentamicin or tobramycin) can be used as first-line treatment until the culture results are known. If there is a concern for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, vancomycin can be added to the regimen or can replace oxacillin.

59. D. Maternal immunoglobulin G antibodies correlate with lower fetal infection rate.

Approximately 60% of adults in the United States are seropositive for parvovirus. Among occupational groups, schoolteachers have the highest rate of infection.¹ Pregnant women are equally as susceptible to parvovirus as any other adult. Maternal immunoglobulin G antibodies correlate with a lower infection risk.² If a pregnant woman contracts parvovirus infection, the greatest risk of transmission occurs during the first and second trimesters, with a fetal infection risk of 33%.³ Clinical manifestations of parvovirus in the infected fetus include severe anemia, congestive heart failure, possible hydrops, ascites, pleural effusions, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and ventriculomegaly. # 62. C. Elevated lipocalin 2 level in the cerebrospinal fluid

Researchers have investigated whether cerebrospinal biomarkers can be helpful in distinguishing between bacterial and viral meningitis in neonates. Specifically, neonates with bacterial meningitis had higher lipocalin 2 levels, higher lactate concentrations, and higher C-reactive protein levels than did neonates with viral meningitis. However, the clinical utility of these biomarkers is still uncertain because studies have examined a small number of patients and inconsistent assays have been used.

Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus is a gram-positive organism with more than 30 different species, including the following:

- Staphylococcus epidermidis: most predominant species, occurring in almost  $75\%$  of isolates
- S lugdunensis: associated with endocarditis and sepsis
- Staphylococcus saprophyticus: found in the genitourinary tract

Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus is currently the most common organism associated with nosocomial infections, contributing to  $30\%$  of central line infections hospital-wide, as reported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention National Healthcare Safety Network.2

# 64. B. Antibiotic use is associated with fungal infections, particularly candidiasis.

Although antibiotic use has few immediate adverse effects, exposure to a prolonged course of antibiotics has significant long-term risks in neonates, including the following:

- Alteration of the intestinal microbiome with development of resistant organisms
- Increased risk of Candida infections among preterm neonates, particularly with use of third-generation cephalosporins in very low-birth-weight neonates
- Increased risk of necrotizing enterocolitis in very low-birth-weight neonates
- Increased risk of late-onset sepsis in very low-birth-weight neonates
- Increased mortality in very low-birth-weight neonates

66. D. In the United States, most newborns with early-onset GBS sepsis have capsular polysaccharide serotypes Ia, Ib, II, III, and V.

Approximately 20% to 30% of women are colonized with group B Streptococcus (GBS). 70. D. If this patient had received antibiotic treatment within the past several days before the culture was obtained, there may be reduced levels of bacteremia, leading to a false-negative culture.

The sensitivity of a blood culture for diagnosing a bloodstream infection depends on the blood volume obtained, with a minimum of 0.5 mL required for detection of bacteremia.¹,² A general rule is that a blood volume of 1 mL should be sent for culture in a neonate, which will result in a sensitivity of 95%.³ If a neonate receives antibiotics within 4 days of the bacteremia, a false-negative culture is possible because

## 72. E. The temperature is 40°C; the heart rate and respiratory rate are normal; and there is an elevated leukocyte count, with 25% immature neutrophils.

A diagnosis of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) in a neonate requires evidence of physiological and/or laboratory abnormalities.¹ Four categories need to be assessed:

1. Low or high temperature
2. Leukopenia, leukocytosis, or more than 10% immature neutrophils
3. Bradycardia or tachycardia
4. Tachypnea or need for mechanical ventilation without a specific abnormality

The diagnosis of SIRS requires abnormalities in 2 of these categories, and 1 of these needs to be an abnormality in temperature or white blood cell count.¹ Thus, the neonate who has an elevated temperature (40°C) and an elevated leukocyte count meets the criteria for SIRS.

## 73. C. For health care providers, hand hygiene can be performed with chlorhexidine gluconate soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer before and after patient contact, after bodily fluid exposure, and before starting a sterile task.

Research has shown that central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs) in the neonate who is hospitalized can be significantly decreased, even in patients at risk who are of young gestational age and very low birth weight.¹,² Appropriate hand hygiene is 1 of the most effective methods of decreasing the risk of CLABSIs in this population. Hand hygiene with chlorhexidine gluconate soap and water or alcohol-based liquids is effective at decreasing the amount of microbes and viruses on the hands of hospital personnel. Alcohol-based liquids are less irritating to the skin, but soap and water is better at cleaning hands that are visibly soiled. Chlorhexidine soap and water are better at eradicating Clostridium difficile.

### 75. E. Transient hepatic dysfunction

The use of fluconazole prophylaxis in very low-birth-weight neonates has been associated with very few side effects. ### 76. E. Use of a third-generation cephalosporin should be considered in a neonate born to a mother who received intrapartum group B Streptococcus prophylaxis.

Empiric therapy for presumed neonatal meningitis should be based on the likely organisms, which is determined by chronological age and risk factors. For neonates younger than 1 month of age, a combination of ampicillin and an aminoglycoside is recommended to cover the most common organisms in this population: group B Streptococcus (GBS), Escherichia coli, and Listeria monocytogenes. For neonates born to women who received intrapartum prophylaxis for GBS or if a gram-negative organism is likely, a third-generation cephalosporin should be considered. Once an organism is identified, the antibiotic regimen can be modified based on susceptibility. For an antibiotic-resistant organism, a repeat lumbar puncture may be warranted to document spinal fluid sterility. Although a 21-day antibiotic regimen is used to treat meningitis, there are no well-controlled trials that support this common practice.

### 77. A. Acute chorioamnionitis is associated with preterm birth, with studies reporting the presence of acute chorioamnionitis in 30% to 75% of preterm births.

Acute chorioamnionitis is found in 30% to 75% of preterm births.^{1-4} The pathological finding of acute inflammation of the placenta and umbilical cord is a marker of infection. The most common route of acquisition is by an ascending route of microorganisms from the cervicovaginal tract into the amniotic

---

<!-- Page 491 -->

Infectious Diseases

cavity. Microbes can also enter hematogenously from the maternal circulation (eg, after dental procedures), by local entry into the uterus from the peritoneum and pelvic regions, by entry into the amniotic sac as a result of a procedure or trauma, or by direct entry into the fetal circulation after an umbilical cord transfusion. These latter mechanisms do not require the rupture of membranes.

## 78. B. Neonates exposed to HCV and infected with HCV should receive hepatitis A and hepatitis B immunizations.

The diagnosis of hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection in a neonate with intrauterine HCV exposure is challenging because maternal immunoglobulin G antibodies can persist in the neonate's circulation for as long as 18 months. To avoid false-positive anti-HCV immunoglobulin G antibody results, a neonate who is born to a mother with HCV infection should undergo antibody testing at or after 18 months of age.[1,2] For children who have positive antibodies at that age, HCV RNA testing after age 3 years is helpful to confirm chronic active infection.[2] Alternatively, HCV RNA testing can be performed in the first year after birth; although the ideal timing for RNA testing is not known, most experts suggest testing between 1 and 2 months of age.[2] Neonates exposed to HCV and infected with HCV should receive hepatitis A and hepatitis B immunizations because a second cause of infectious hepatitis can increase morbidity and mortality.[1]

## 79. B. Neonates born to mothers with symptoms of varicella 5 days before delivery to 2 days after delivery have a higher fatality rate because of insufficient maternal antibody production and intrauterine transfer.

The risk of a neonate having congenital varicella disease is 24% if the mother was infected with varicella-zoster virus within 21 days of delivery. The neonatal mortality rate is greatest if the mother has symptoms of varicella 5 days before delivery to 2 days after delivery because there is insufficient maternal antibody production and intrauterine transfer to the fetus. Pneumonia is the most common cause of death in neonates with congenital varicella infection. The typical varicella rash consists of vesicles that develop into pustules; bullous or hemorrhagic lesions are less common.

## 80. D. Maternal GBS colonization

Early-onset sepsis as a result of group B *Streptococcus* (GBS) is acquired by means of intrauterine colonization or colonization during vaginal delivery. Without intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis, approximately one-half of the neonates born to mothers who are GBS positive are colonized with GBS, with only a small percentage (1% to 2%) of neonates who are colonized developing invasive GBS disease. Although there are many factors that increase the risk of neonatal GBS disease, the greatest risk factor for neonatal GBS disease is maternal GBS colonization.

## 83. B. Most newborn TB arises from transmission from household contacts.

Congenital tuberculosis (TB) is rare because it is difficult for the tubercle bacillus to cross the placenta. Instead, most neonates acquire TB by transmission from infected household contacts.

Pregnancy is not associated with an increased risk of TB. However, because pregnancy symptoms are similar to a TB infection, there might be a delay in diagnosing it.¹ TB is not associated with an increased risk of pregnancy complications. Extrapulmonary TB is rare in pregnancy.

## 84. D. Lumbar puncture is always required in late-onset sepsis.

It is important to perform lumbar puncture in neonates suspected of having late-onset sepsis (LOS) because up to 25% of neonates with LOS have meningitis and as many as one-half of neonates with meningitis have a negative blood culture.¹,² Ideally, the lumbar puncture should be performed before starting antibiotics but can be deferred if the neonate has hemodynamic instability, thrombocytopenia, or coagulation abnormalities.³ Interpretation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) results can be challenging in neonates because there is a high risk for traumatic lumbar puncture (39.5%) and there is variability in normal cytological and biochemical values.⁴ Studies have found that various methods for adjusting CSF white blood cell counts on the basis of CSF red blood cell counts in traumatic lumbar puncture did not improve the ability to diagnose meningitis and the sensitivity was decreased.⁵

## 88. A. Candida albicans

# 8. A. Bronchopulmonary sequestration

The most common congenital lung masses are bronchopulmonary sequestration (BPS), congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM), and congenital lobar emphysema. It may be difficult to distinguish these masses prenatally. Bronchopulmonary sequestration is a solid lesion that occurs more commonly in the left lower chest or upper abdomen. As described in this vignette, BPS is typically wedge-shaped with a systemic arterial blood supply.¹ Typically, CPAMs can be either macrocystic (more common) or microcystic and located anywhere in either lung.² Congenital lobar emphysema consists of hyperinflated lung tissue that can appear similar to microcystic congenital pulmonary airway malformations but usually has a predisposition for the upper lobes.³

## 10. A. Chromosomal translocation

During preimplantation genetic testing, cells can be examined by fluorescent in situ hybridization to assess for a chromosomal imbalance. Polymerase chain reaction or targeted gene sequencing can assess for a single gene abnormality. Testing for human compatibility leukocyte antigen and sex selection for an X-linked abnormality is also available.

## 11. B. Chronic TTTS is almost exclusively restricted to twins with monochorionic diamniotic placentation.

More than 80% of monochorionic diamniotic twin gestations have shared vessels within the chorionic villous tree.¹⁻³ These connections can be superficial on the surface of the chorionic plate or unidirectional (ie, arteriovenous) and deep in the placental cotyledons. The deep anastomoses are the largest contributor to the development of twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS). Marginal or velamentous umbilical cord insertions or a single umbilical artery increase the severity of TTTS.⁴

Donor twins are more likely than recipient twins to have a chorionic magistral blood vessel pattern, which is a pattern of large-sized vessels with minimal branching that extend from the site of cord insertion to the periphery of the placenta without significant change in vessel diameter. Donor twins are at greater risk of becoming wrapped in the amnion if there is severe oligohydramnios or anhydramnios and may appear "stuck" to the uterine wall or placenta.

## 12. C. O-negative blood concentrated to a hematocrit between 75% and 80% should be used.

Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling and intrauterine transfusion are typically recommended when the fetal hematocrit is less than 30% with a goal hematocrit between 40% and 50%. O-negative blood concentrated to a hematocrit between 75% and 80% is used to minimize the total blood volume and prevent hydrops caused by cardiac overload. One method to calculate the transfusion volume is to use the following formula:

$$
\text{Transfusion volume} = \frac{\text{hemoglobin (goal)} - \text{hemoglobin (fetal)} \times \text{fetoplacental blood volume}}{\text{hemoglobin (donor)} - \text{hemoglobin (goal)}}
$$

The reference range for fetoplacental blood volume is between 90 and 120 mL/kg.

More commonly, birth centers use the approach described by Giannina et al² that estimates the volume of the transfusion based on the fetal weight.

Administration of prophylactic antibiotics to the pregnant woman prior to percutaneous umbilical blood sampling has not been shown to be beneficial.

2. Giannina G, Moise KJ Jr, Dorman K. A simple method to estimate volume for fetal intravascular transfusions. Fetal Diagn Ther. 1998;13(2):94-97

## 13. A. Blood volume increases.

A pregnant woman undergoes several physiological changes, including the following:

- Heart rate increases by 10% to 20%.
- Stroke volume increases by 30%.
- Cardiac output increases by 30% to 50%.
- Total blood volume increases by 20% to 50%.
- Systemic vascular resistance decreases by 20%.

Even though their total blood volume increases, pregnant women have relative anemia because the red blood cell volume increases at a lower rate.

## 14. E. Glutathione S-transferase alpha

Women with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy have serum bile acid levels that are greater than 12 μmol/L. Affected patients also have increased levels of alkaline phosphatase, bilirubin, cholesterol, γ-glutamyl transpeptidase, liver transaminases, and glutathione S-transferase alpha. Glutathione S-transferase alpha levels have been shown to correlate with serum bile acid levels.

## 15. C. Preterm delivery is a common outcome in women with preeclampsia; however, in women with late-onset preeclampsia, approximately 25% of the preterm births are thought to be iatrogenic.

A pregnant woman is diagnosed with preeclampsia if she has hypertension that develops after 20 weeks' gestation and proteinuria. Affected women have a higher incidence of having a preterm delivery as a result of maternal or fetal complications. However, in women with late-onset preeclampsia, approximately 25% of the preterm births are thought to be iatrogenic.

Late preterm neonates who are born to women with preeclampsia are at increased risk of being admitted to a neonatal intensive care unit and have a greater risk of respiratory distress syndrome.¹⁻³ Women with preeclampsia have higher levels of the soluble vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-1 (also called sFlt-1); data are conflicting about whether this is associated with an increased risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia.²,⁴,⁵

## 16. A. If there is shoulder dystocia resulting in birth injury, the brachial plexus is the most common site of injury.

Neonates born to women with diabetes mellitus who are large for gestational age have an increased risk of shoulder dystocia. This risk correlates with fetal weight—a newborn who weighs more than 4,000 g has a risk of 5% to 7% of shoulder dystocia. Fortunately, most neonates with shoulder dystocia do not have any complications; if a complication does occur, a brachial plexus injury is the most common type of injury, followed by fracture of the clavicle or humerus.¹

While fetuses born to women with diabetes have a normal lean body mass, they have higher fat deposited in their abdominal and shoulder tissues. The greater difference in the chest to head and shoulder to head ratios, which is difficult to predict prenatally, places the neonate at increased risk for shoulder dystocia.

Unfortunately, methadone still has risks when used during pregnancy, including increased risk of preterm delivery, newborns small for gestational age, and neonatal abstinence syndrome, which requires longer medical treatment than exposure to traditional opiates. Buprenorphine is considered a relatively safe option for treating opioid addition during pregnancy, as studies have found that newborns have shorter hospitalizations, lower peak abstinence scores, and lower maximal dose of morphine compared with neonates exposed to methadone in utero.¹

## 18. E. Surfactant deficiency

The woman described in this vignette has findings that are most consistent with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy. Studies have found that fetuses of affected women also have elevated bile acid levels in cord serum and meconium. Neonates born to women with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy are at increased risk of surfactant deficiency, bile acid pneumonia, and meconium aspiration syndrome.¹

Newborns born to women with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy are not at increased risk for cholestasis, rash, hepatitis, or sepsis.

## 19. D. Selenium

Women with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy have lower levels of selenium. Women from Finland and Chile have diets that are low in selenium, which might explain the reason for the higher incidence of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy in these populations.

## 20. A. If there are artery-to-vein anastomoses present, they are likely to be deep with both donor-to-recipient and recipient-to-donor communication coexisting, with the net flow favoring donor to recipient.

The pathophysiology of twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) in monochorionic diamniotic twin gestations is not completely understood. The current explanation is that the shared placenta consists of deep artery-to-vein anastomoses in both directions with a net flow that favors the donor-to-recipient direction. The frequency of artery-to-artery anastomoses is typically lower in pregnancies complicated by TTTS than in non-TTTS pregnancies, suggesting a protective effect.¹,²

A peripheral cord insertion increases the likelihood of TTTS and typically involves the donor twin.¹

Although either twin can develop hydrops if there is TTTS, fetal demise in the donor twin is more common.³

## 22. D. Placental hypoperfusion and ischemia

Pregnant women with preeclampsia have shallow placental implantation with abnormal placental vascular development.¹,² The shallow cytotrophoblast invasion leads to increased placental vascular resistance and placental hypoperfusion. The hypoperfusion triggers a cascade of growth factors that further exacerbates placental hypoperfusion and leads to endothelial dysfunction.³,⁴

23. A. Humans and apes have the highest levels of plasma progesterone detected at the time of birth.

Progesterone is the primary hormone that establishes and maintains a human pregnancy. While pregnant rodents have increased progesterone levels because of increased ovary production, pregnant primates rely on the placenta to increase progesterone levels. At the time of birth, progesterone levels decrease dramatically in most mammals except for humans and apes, who actually achieve peak progesterone levels at that time. In some animals, the impairment of progesterone receptor function during pregnancy results in delayed delivery beyond term.

24. C. The rate of fetal malformation is 2 to 4 times higher in pregnant women with type 1 and type 2 diabetes compared with the general population.

Major fetal malformations in pregnant women with diabetes are most likely if the woman had poor glucose control prior to conception and during the first trimester. $^{1-4}$ The most common types of malformations in this population involve the cardiovascular, neurological, and urinary systems. The rate of fetal malformation is 2 to 4 times higher in pregnant women with type 1 and type 2 diabetes compared with the general population. $^{2-6}$ Depending on the study, the fetal malformation rate has been found to be the same or slightly higher in pregnant women with gestational diabetes compared with the general population.

25. D. Persistently positive test results for the combination of anticardiolipin, anti- $\beta_{2}$ glycoprotein 1, and lupus anticoagulant antibodies place the patient at greater risk of thrombotic events and pregnancy morbidity than a positive test result for just one of the antibodies.

The diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome is based on having at least one clinical finding and at least one laboratory finding. The abnormal laboratory findings include the following:

- Elevated serum or plasma immunoglobulin (Ig) M or IgG anticardiolipin antibody titers determined by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) on 2 or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart
- Elevated serum or plasma IgM or IgG anti- $\beta_{2}$ glycoprotein antibody titers determined by ELISA on 2 or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart
- Increased plasma lupus anticoagulant test on 2 or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart

If all 3 antibodies are elevated, the pregnant patient is at greater risk of thromboses and pregnancy-related morbidities. $^{2}$

## 26. B. Chronic hypertension

Chronic hypertension is the maternal risk factor with the highest likelihood ratio (LR) for the development of preeclampsia (LR = 12.5).¹ The second highest LR is antiphospholipid syndrome (LR = 9.7), followed by prior history of preeclampsia (LR = 7), diabetes (LR = 3.5), twin gestation (LR = 3), nulliparity (LR = 3), and obesity (LR = 2.5).¹ Maternal black race is associated with a LR of 1.5. Additional detection methods, however, are needed, as these maternal risk factors only identify about 30% of women who develop preeclampsia.²

## 27. A. Absence of the echolucent clear space between the uterus and placenta is an ultrasonographic finding that suggests the presence of placenta accreta.

Placenta accreta, placenta increta, and placenta percreta are abnormal forms of placentation in which the chorionic villi of the placenta attach abnormally to the uterus. Although an abnormal placentation is a clinical diagnosis, there are several ultrasonographic findings that are suggestive of an abnormal placentation, including¹,²

- Absence of the echolucent clear space between the uterus and placenta
- Thin hyperechoic space between the serosa of the uterus and the maternal bladder wall
- Appearance of placental lacunae with or without high-velocity flow
- Abnormal color Doppler flow at the interface between the myometrium and the maternal bladder

Magnetic resonance imaging has similar sensitivity compared with ultrasonography in the diagnosis of abnormal placentation, but it may be useful for distinguishing placenta accreta, the least invasive form, from placenta percreta, the most invasive form.³

Maternal corticosteroid administration has no effect on placenta implantation.

30. E. Unlike in normal pregnancies, women who go on to have preeclampsia are noted to have an incomplete remodeling of the spiral arteries in the placenta.

Although the precise pathogenesis of preeclampsia is still unknown, the disease process requires the following 2 features:

- Early disruption in the remodeling of the spiral arteries within the placenta, with an increase in stiffness of these vessels¹
- A systemic antiangiogenic response in the pregnant woman

While the vascular disruption is thought to occur early in gestation, the maternal clinical manifestations of preeclampsia are not observed until after 20 weeks' gestation. The late clinical findings are thought to result, in part, from increased microparticles that are released from the syncytiotrophoblast into the maternal circulation as the pregnancy progresses.²,³ Pregnant women with preeclampsia also have higher amounts of antiangiogenic factors, such as the soluble membrane receptor for vascular endothelial growth factor called Fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 or sFLT-1,⁴,⁵ that probably contributes to the maternal clinical findings.

34. E. The main concern is that dilation of the aortic root could lead to dissection and aortic rupture. 36. C. Deep venous thrombosis

Antiphospholipid syndrome in nonpregnant human adults leads to venous thromboses such as

- Superficial thrombosis
- Deep venous thrombosis
- Pulmonary embolism
- Mesenteric, portal, intracranial, and retinal thrombosis

Affected patients can also have arterial thromboses such as ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, or renal and adrenal artery thrombosis. Less commonly, multiple microvascular thromboses can occur, potentially leading to cardiopulmonary failure.

Non-thrombotic complications of APS include cardiac valvular disease, hemolytic anemia, livedo reticularis, and thrombocytopenia.

37. C. Location of the liver

The fetal magnetic resonance imaging described in this vignette is most consistent with a left-sided congenital diaphragmatic hernia. The location of the fetal liver has been shown to be predictive of postnatal survival.¹-³ Albanese et al found that an intra-abdominal location of the fetal liver was associated with 93% survival and 19% need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) compared with an intra-thoracic liver location that was associated with 43% survival and 53% need for ECMO.⁴

46. C. Lacunae or small spaces first form within the syncytial layer and then expand and join to form a lacunar network that later develops into the intervillous space within the placenta.

During a normal pregnancy, the blastocyst implants into the endometrium and then differentiates into 2 layers, the outer syncytiotrophoblast layer and the inner cytotrophoblast layer. Between 8 to 13 days post-coitus, small spaces called lacunae form within the syncytiotrophoblast layer that expand and form a lacunar network. This lacunar system later develops into the intervillous space within the placenta that contains maternal blood. Cytotrophoblast cells invade the syncytial columns that remain after the lacunae develop and become the placental villi that contain fetal vessels.

47. C. If a pregnant woman does have a change in the vaginal microbial community, it usually is from one type of Lactobacillus-dominant community to another.

The vaginal microbiome of pregnant women has decreased species richness, less diversity, and more stable microbial communities compared with nonpregnant women.¹² If a pregnant woman does have a change in the vaginal microbial community, it usually is from one type of Lactobacillus-dominant community to another.² Studies suggest that over-suppression of vaginal microbial communities may correlate with adverse pregnancy outcomes such as preterm birth, but further studies are needed to understand this association.³

48. C. Stromal histiocytes, called Hofbauer cells, are found in placental villi.

With advancing gestation, the placental villous network becomes more elaborate. The larger primary villi contain muscular arteries with thick walls that branch into secondary and tertiary villi with a greater number of small vessels. While stromal histiocytes, also known as Hofbauer cells, are found in placental villi of a normal placenta, lymphocytes and plasma cells are abnormal findings suggesting chronic inflammation. The space between the villi contains maternal blood that flows freely around the villi, allowing for exchange of gas and nutrients with the intravillous vessels.

49. C. Stage III

In 1999, Quintero et al described an ultrasonographic staging system to predict the hemodynamic effect on the fetuses with twin-twin transfusion syndrome.¹ There are 5 stages with increasing severity.

- Stage I: oligohydramnios/polyhydramnios, visible donor bladder
- Stage II: oligohydramnios/polyhydramnios, donor bladder not visible
- Stage III: oligohydramnios/polyhydramnios, abnormal umbilical Doppler flow (donor with absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in umbilical arteries, recipient with pulsatile flow in umbilical vein, and/or recipient with reversal of flow in the ductus venosus)
- Stage IV: oligohydramnios/polyhydramnios and hydrops in either the donor or recipient
- Stage V: oligohydramnios/polyhydramnios and demise (impending or actual) in one or both twins The ultrasonographic findings described in this vignette are most consistent with stage III.

# 50. C. Low birth weight, slow growth in infancy, excessive growth in childhood

In 1992, Hales and Barker described the thrifty hypothesis that proposed that a fetal environment associated with poor fetal growth leads to an adaptive response that might have long-term consequences.¹⁻³ Potential long-term outcomes include increased risk for hypertension, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes mellitus type 2 during adulthood.⁴ Based on more recent data, studies suggest that the most unfavorable growth patterns for the development of coronary artery disease later in life are low birth weight, slow growth in infancy, and excessive growth in childhood.⁴⁻⁶

# 51. B. For nearly all women with type 2 diabetes mellitus, insulin is necessary in pregnancy, often with increased dosage requirements.

Insulin is required for all pregnant women with type 1 diabetes mellitus and for almost all women with type 2 diabetes mellitus. In contrast with nonpregnant women with diabetes, it is recommended that pregnant women with diabetes check their blood glucose 4 times a day for maximal glucose control. This maintenance of glucose control is critical, as poor control preconception and during the first trimester increases the risk of congenital anomalies and poor control later in pregnancy increases the risk of neonatal morbidities. Fetal echocardiography should be obtained in all women with type 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus at approximately 22 weeks' gestation because of the increased risk of structural heart disease.

# 52. D. Is more likely to have thrombocytopenia that usually resolves by 10 days of age

Neonates born to women with preeclampsia are more likely to have transient thrombocytopenia after birth that typically resolves by 10 days of age. In most cases, the thrombocytopenia is not severe and is more common in neonates who also are growth-restricted.¹ The pathophysiology of the thrombocytopenia is probably attributable to several factors, such as decreased platelet production following fetal hypoxia, platelet sequestration in small vessels, and platelet destruction within the placenta.²,³ Transient neutropenia is also a common hematologic abnormality in neonates born to women with preeclampsia, particularly in neonates with growth restriction.

# 53. B. Most of the valvular lesions seen in pregnancy are acquired from rheumatic fever.

Pregnant women can have congenital or acquired valvular disease; rheumatic fever is the most common cause of acquired valvular disease. Mitral valve stenosis is the most common valvar issue that occurs in pregnant women. Stenosis of the mitral or aortic valve requires close monitoring and possible treatment with anticoagulation medications.¹

54. B. Gastrointestinal obstruction

Fetal magnetic resonance imaging is superior to ultrasonography for the early detection of gastrointestinal obstruction and renal cysts. Ultrasonography can diagnose most other abdominal anomalies, such as abdominal wall defect, hydronephrosis, meconium peritonitis, and microcolon.

55. E. The placenta in women with GDM tends to be significantly larger than those in women without GDM.

The placenta of women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) tends to be significantly larger than those in women without GDM, $^{1,2}$ and histologic findings of chorangiosis is a prominent finding. $^{1}$ Neonates born to women with GDM tend to be larger, and preliminary data suggest that this is more common when the mothers have obesity.

56. A. Cytomegalovirus

In the United States, the most common cause of chronic infectious villositis results from a cytomegalovirus or Treponema pallidum infection. Occasionally, chronic villositis is caused by herpes simplex virus, varicella-zoster virus, or poxviruses.

During the transition to extrauterine life, fluid within the airways moves to the adjacent perialveolar tissue. $^{1}$ Complete liquid clearance can take several hours. $^{1,2}$ During this time, the lung is filled with an excessive amount of fetal lung liquid, which is associated with increased pressures within the pulmonary interstitium $^{2}$ and greater tissue expansion of the chest wall. $^{3}$

58. D. Increased observation, either as inpatient or outpatient

The management of pregnant women with preeclampsia focuses on decreasing maternal and neonatal morbidity by achieving control of blood pressures, preventing seizures, and determining the ideal timing of delivery. If a woman has preeclampsia without severe features, the obstetrician will monitor the woman's blood pressure more closely, along with regular assessment of laboratory data, fetal growth, and amniotic fluid volume. ## 60. A. Angiogenic factors

The precise pathophysiology of preeclampsia is unknown but is thought to consist of poor placentation with a decreased uteroplacental blood supply. The subsequent placental hypoxia leads to a release of inflammatory, oxidative stress and antiangiogenic mediators, resulting in a systemic inflammatory response with clinical manifestations later in pregnancy.¹ Studies have found high concentrations of antiangiogenic factors (eg, soluble endoglin, soluble vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-1 or sFlt-1) and lower concentrations of angiogenic factors (eg, placental growth factor, vascular endothelial growth factor) during the second trimester of pregnant women who later develop preeclampsia.²,³ Quantification of these compounds holds promise for the early diagnosis of preeclampsia prior to the development of symptoms to allow for earlier medical interventions.

## 61. D. The primary cause of fetal overgrowth in pregnancies in women with diabetes is fetal hyperinsulinemia.

The most common fetal complication in pregnant women with diabetes is fetal overgrowth occurring in the last trimester. The term large for gestational age is defined as a neonate with a birth weight above the 90th percentile, but a stricter definition has also been used (&gt;97.7th percentile above the mean birth weight). If a neonate's birth weight is greater than 4,000 g, the term macrosomia is used, although large for gestational age and macrosomia are often used interchangeably. The excessive fetal growth associated with maternal diabetes is attributable to fetal hyperinsulinemia in response to intrauterine hyperglycemia.¹,² Although affected neonates have greater amounts of adipose tissue and organomegaly, their head size is typically appropriate for age.

Predicting the birth weight in fetuses of women with diabetes is important, as neonates with high birth weights have an increased risk for birth-related injuries. However, the ability of ultrasonography to predict birth weights greater than 4,000 g is lower than the predictability for typical birth weights.³

## 62. B. Persistent APS-associated antibodies may be associated with a risk of autism spectrum and developmental disorders.

Data have shown that neonates born to women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) have a greater risk of preterm birth (16%) and being born small for gestational age (11%). The lupus anticoagulant was detectable in 4% of neonates born to mothers with APS compared with anticardiolipin antibodies and anti-β₂ glycoprotein antibodies, which were detectable in 16% and 18% of neonates, respectively; these antibodies persisted during the first 6 months after birth.³ Follow-up studies have found an increased risk of neurodevelopmental issues, such as autism spectrum and developmental disorders.⁴ Although neonatal thromboses can occur, most affected neonates also have another risk factor for thromboses, such as a central line catheter, sepsis, or perinatal depression.⁵

63. B. Due to the potential for maternal hemorrhage in a delivery with placenta accreta, a planned cesarean delivery and hysterectomy is typically required.

Pregnancies complicated by placenta accreta, increta, or percreta are at high risk for partial placental separation at the time of delivery with associated risk of severe maternal hemorrhage. As a result, a planned hysterectomy after delivery is usually recommended.¹² To avoid the risk of maternal hemorrhage with advancing gestational age, most women with this diagnosis are delivered between 34 and 35 weeks' gestation.³⁴ Neonatal morbidity is not affected by the type of placental invasion.⁵

64. B. As early as 1990, a meta-analysis by Keirse showed a beneficial effect of 17-hydroxyprogesterone on reducing preterm birth with a pooled odds ratio of 0.50.

Initial studies examining the potential of progesterone administration to prevent preterm birth in pregnant women were conflicting. One meta-analysis published by Keirse in 1990 showed a positive benefit.¹ The author found that 17-hydroxyprogesterone led to a reduction in preterm birth with a pooled odds ratio of 0.5 (CI 0.3-0.85) in pregnant women with a prior preterm birth.¹ In contrast, intramuscular 17-OH progesterone administration had no effect on preterm birth rate in a randomized controlled trial of 168 active women in the military.²

In 2003, the Maternal-Fetal Medicine Units Network reported evidence for the use of progesterone based on results from a randomized controlled trial of 310 women.³ The authors found that women who received weekly intramuscular 17-OH progesterone starting between 16 and 20 weeks' gestation until 36 weeks' gestation had a reduction in the risk of delivery at

- Less than 37 weeks' gestation (decrease from 54.9% to 36.3%, relative risk 0.66, CI 0.54-0.81)
- Less than 35 weeks' gestation (decrease from 30.7% to 20.6%, relative risk 0.67, CI 0.48-0.93)
- Less than 32 weeks' gestation (decrease from 19.6% to 11.4%, relative risk 0.58, CI 0.37-0.91)³

65. A. A model of reduced uterine perfusion pressure has been studied in rats as well as other animals; reduced uterine perfusion pressure has been found to cause proteinuria, hypertension, impaired renal function, and fetal growth restriction, although reduced trophoblast invasion does not occur.

Researchers have had difficulty finding an animal model that mimics all the manifestations of preeclampsia in humans. Although models in nonhuman primates are most similar to preeclampsia in humans, mice and rat models are more commonly used because of increased availability and lower cost. A pregnant rat model of reduced uterine perfusion pressure following surgical narrowing of the aorta causes proteinuria, hypertension, impaired renal function, and fetal growth restriction, but reduced trophoblast invasion does not occur.¹⁻³ Models of overexpression of antiangiogenic factors in pregnant rats⁴ and mice⁵ have also led to hypertension, proteinuria, and renal injury, although progression to eclampsia does not occur.

Immune models for preeclampsia are based on the observation that inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin (IL)-10 are markedly decreased in women with preeclampsia. Pregnant baboons that received monoclonal antibodies directed at IL-10 had abnormal trophoblast invasion with elevated maternal mean blood pressures but did not exhibit proteinuria, abnormal liver enzyme levels, or thrombocytopenia.⁶ One model of placental maldevelopment involved administration of doxycycline to pregnant rats that led to a decrease in trophoblast invasion and lighter placental mass.⁷

## 66. E. Pruritus

The most common initial clinical manifestation of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is pruritus. The itching typically involves the palmar and plantar areas but can also be more extensive. The other potential manifestations listed are not typically found in this disease.

## 67. E. The preterm gastrointestinal tract tends to have abnormal bacterial colonization with less diversification and a greater number of pathogenic bacteria.

Research shows that many placentas of healthy pregnant women are colonized with bacteria. This knowledge has implications for intrauterine colonization of the fetus. Indeed, sequencing techniques suggest that amniotic fluid is also colonized with microbes that could play a role in the development of the gut microbiome. A recent study analyzed the microbiota in the meconium of neonates within 48 hours after birth and found that the organisms were more similar to amniotic fluid flora compared with the microbes in the oral and vaginal cavities.¹

The type and number of placental microbes, as well as the effect on amniotic fluid bacteria, might play a role in preterm births by inciting a fetoplacental inflammatory response. Contrary to normal fetal gut development where the interaction between toll-like receptors and commensal bacteria downregulates inflammation, the preterm neonate is likely to have a gastrointestinal tract with increased immunoreactivity.² The preterm gastrointestinal tract tends to have abnormal bacterial colonization with less diversification³ and a greater number of pathogenic bacteria.⁴ This might have implications later in life, as one study found that a low intestinal microbial diversity at age 1 month was associated with immunoglobulin E-associated eczema later in life.⁵

## 69. D. Facilitated diffusion

While gases are transferred across the placenta by simple diffusion, glucose is transferred by facilitated diffusion with the assistance of GLUT3 and GLUT1 hexose transporters. Active transport allows for the transfer of amino acids from maternal to fetal circulation, which is against the concentration gradient. Water is transferred across the placenta by bulk flow, while immunoglobulins move across the placenta by endocytosis/exocytosis.

## 70. C. Infiltration of lymphocytes, histiocytes, and sometimes plasma cells into placental villi, often leading to villose agglutination

In addition to the infiltration of lymphocytes, histiocytes, and sometimes plasma cells into placental villi, chronic villositis is typically multifocal and is often found in TORCH syndrome.

## 71. E. Photocoagulate the placental anastomoses using laser energy to interrupt the placental hemodynamic imbalance.

The gold-standard approach to progressive or severe twin-twin transfusion syndrome is to perform the fetoscopic laser occlusion of chorioangiopagous placental vessels (FLOC) procedure. This technique consists of photocoagulation of the placental anastomoses using laser energy to disrupt the placental hemodynamic imbalance.[1,2] Essentially, this procedure converts the placenta from a monochorionic to dichorionic type, although some connections are likely still present.[3,4] FLOC has been shown to be more effective than serial amnioreduction with higher survival rates and lower morbidities.[1]

## 72. E. The most common complication encountered during fetal blood sampling and transfusion is fetal bradycardia, which is reported to occur in 7% to 52% of procedures but is usually self-limited.

Depending on the report, the risk of fetal bradycardia can vary between 7% to 52% post-periumbilical blood sampling procedure. ## 73. C. May decrease the risk of placental abruption

Magnesium sulfate administration to pregnant women during labor has been shown to decrease the risk of eclampsia by 58% and reduce the risk of placental abruption (relative risk 0.67, CI 0.45-0.89). However, it does not alter maternal morbidity or rate of cesarean delivery. For women with preeclampsia with severe features, magnesium sulfate is also recommended in the immediate postpartum period. Studies show that administration of magnesium sulfate to pregnant women does not affect neonatal morbidities.

## 75. A. Congenital heart disease such as ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, and atrial septal defect

Monochorionic diamniotic twins can have ischemic-related injuries associated with twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS). These include the following:

- Brain injuries such as white matter infarction, intraventricular hemorrhage, and porencephaly¹,²
- Renal injuries such as renal cortical necrosis
- Intestinal atresia
- Cutis aplasia
- Limb necrosis

All monochorionic diamniotic twins are at increased risk for structural heart disease, such as ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, and atrial septal defect. Studies have found a 7% risk of congenital heart disease in monochorionic diamniotic twins³ compared with the baseline risk of 0.5% in healthy singleton pregnancies.⁴ If TTTS is also present, the risk of structural heart disease is even higher.⁴ The pathogenesis of the overall increased risk of heart disease in monochorionic diamniotic twins is poorly understood but probably relates to fluctuations in flow to the fetuses, alterations in angiogenic factors, unequal placental sharing, and inherent genetic factors.

## 76. C. Fetal energy demands for tissue growth are greatest during the third trimester in humans, including fat deposition.

Fetal energy demands for tissue growth and fat deposition are highest during the last trimester in human pregnancies. One theory of parturition is that it begins when fetal metabolic needs exceed the maternal supply. In support of this theory, population studies in the Netherlands have shown that in times of famine, when maternal supply is low, there was a consistent and significant reduction in the average gestational length by 4 days.¹

After birth, the human newborn weighs 50% more than the predicted neonate to mother ratio.² Primates other than humans are almost fully developed at term gestation, accounting for the large head size compared to the body; this contrasts with the human brain that is initially relatively small but continues to grow rapidly after delivery.³

Women with abnormal placenta invasion (ie, accreta, increta, percreta) are at increased risk of partial placental separation with significant hemorrhage.¹² A planned cesarean delivery between 35 and 36 weeks' gestation is recommended in women with abnormal placental invasion, as it has been shown to decrease the risk of maternal hemorrhage.¹² Maternal morbidity is likely to be reduced by arranging the delivery in a tertiary care center, with ready availability of obstetricians, anesthesiologists, gynecologic oncologists, interventional radiologists, and other specialists.³

81. D. There have been at least 2 randomized controlled trials showing that vaginal progesterone is associated with a significant reduction in the risk of preterm delivery in women with shortened cervix. After studies found that progesterone decreased the risk of preterm delivery in women with a prior preterm birth, researchers then examined the effect of progesterone on women with a shortened transvaginal cervical length, as this is a strong risk factor for preterm birth. In 2005, 250 women with a shortened cervix were randomized to receive vaginal progesterone or placebo starting at 20 to 25 weeks' gestation until delivery or 34 weeks' gestation.¹ The group who received progesterone had a significantly lower rate of preterm birth (19% vs 34%; relative risk, 0.56; 95% CI 0.36–0.86), even without a prior history of preterm delivery.¹ In 2011, another trial randomized 458 women with a shortened cervix to receive vaginal progesterone or placebo between 20 and 24 weeks' gestation until delivery or 37 weeks' gestation and found a similar reduction in preterm birth, independent of prior history of preterm delivery.² Both of these studies were double-blinded. The optimal dose and route of progesterone administration are still being investigated.

82. D. One approach to generating trophoblast cell lines from stem cells is by disaggregating and culturing embryonic stem cells without substances that maintain their pluripotency.

Human embryonic stem cells can be used to generate trophoblast using 3 models.

- Generating trophoblast cell lines by disaggregating and culturing embryonic stem cells without substances that maintain their pluripotency.¹ Trophoblast cells form on the outer layer, which is similar to their location in the placenta.
- Knocking down genes in human and mouse embryonic stem cells that are important for maintaining pluripotency; this approach causes these stem cells to differentiate into trophoblasts.²
- Treating human embryonic stem cells with transforming growth factor beta, such as BMP4 or BMP10, causing them to differentiate into trophoblast cells.³,⁴

The most common pregnancy-specific complication of APS is preeclampsia, occurring in as many as 50% of affected pregnancies. Approximately one-third of pregnancies affected by APS are associated with preterm birth, and approximately 20% lead to intrauterine growth restriction. Affected women often have a history of recurrent first-trimester pregnancy loss, with second and third trimester fetal demise also occurring.

85. B. Both donor and recipient twins are at risk for hypertension and should have blood pressures monitored closely.

In pregnancies complicated by twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), donor twins are more likely to have growth restrictions with anemia and recipient twins are more likely to be large for gestational age with polycythemia. In the immediate newborn period, both neonates should be assessed for cardiovascular strain. Approximately 62% of affected twins are also at higher risk for hypertension at age 2 years as a result of intrauterine cardiovascular and renal adaptations to TTTS. Donor twins are also at increased risk for renal tubular apoptosis.

87. E. Up to 50% of women with gestational diabetes mellitus will develop type 2 diabetes mellitus later in life.

Pregnant women have decreased insulin sensitivity in the liver and peripheral tissues with advancing gestational age; correspondingly, insulin secretion increases to maintain euglycemia. Gestational diabetes mellitus develops if the increase in insulin secretion is inadequate, resulting in hyperglycemia. Gestational diabetes occurs in approximately 4% to 6% of all pregnancies.[1,2] The prevalence of gestational diabetes has been increasing over the past 20 years because the incidence of obesity has increased and detection methods have improved.[3] Most women with gestational diabetes are diagnosed at the time of routine glucose screening, which occurs between 24 and 28 weeks' gestation. Up to 50% of women with gestational diabetes mellitus will develop type 2 diabetes mellitus later in life.[4,5]

As noted in the answer, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers should be avoided during pregnancy because of teratogenic effects in the first trimester, and increased risk of retinopathy, hypotension, and renal dysfunction, when exposure occurs in the second and third trimesters.

It is safe to administer adenosine during pregnancy and prescribe antibiotic prophylaxis for pregnant women with cardiac lesions. Because unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin do not cross the placenta, they are safe to prescribe during pregnancy. However, warfarin does cross the placenta and is not recommended for anticoagulation during pregnancy.

89. C. Prenatal and postnatal prophylaxis with anti-D antibody are highly effective in preventing sensitization and subsequent hemolysis and hydrops.

If a fetus has Rh-group antigens C, c, D, E, e, or Kell and the pregnant woman is negative for these antigens, the pregnant woman can produce antibodies (usually immunoglobulin G) that cross the placenta to bind to and destroy fetal red blood cells. Rh-D-specific immunoglobulin prophylaxis with anti-D antibody (eg, RhoGAM) is now given to all pregnant women with Rh-negative blood type (independent of middle cerebral artery blood flow velocity and ultrasonographic findings).¹ This has significantly decreased the risk of Rh alloimmunization. However, a pregnant woman with Rh-negative blood type is still at risk for hemolysis in the fetus and newborn if anti-D antibodies are missed or if maternal antibodies are produced against other paternal antigens.

92. B. Estrogen and progesterone affect T-cell switching toward the Th2 phenotype.

Estrogen and progesterone influence the switch of T cells from the Th1 to the Th2 state.¹ As a result, pregnant women have a lower sensitivity to Th1-mediated antiviral infections and increased sensitivity to Th2-mediated hypersensitivity reactions. It is thought that pregnant women who have obesity make this transition from Th1 to Th2 earlier than pregnant women who do not have obesity.²

# 93. E. Preeclampsia with severe features may contribute to the neonate developing adult disease such as hypertension.

Women with preeclampsia with severe features have a greater risk of having a preterm birth, which contributes to neonatal morbidities. $^{1,2}$  Fetal death is twice as likely in women with severe disease compared with women with non-severe disease (11.5% vs 5.4%). $^{3}$  Preeclampsia with severe features is an extremely common cause of intrauterine growth restriction $^{4}$  with neutropenia occurring in approximately 40% to 50% of affected neonates. $^{1,2}$  In a prospective study of women with preeclampsia, preterm neonates born between 23 and 32 weeks' gestation had a greater risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (odds ratio, 2.96). $^{2,5}$  Studies suggest that the diagnosis of preeclampsia with severe features may affect the neonate in the long term, increasing the risk of adult diseases such as hypertension, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease. $^{6}$

# 94. C. In African Americans, an association between a single nucleotide polymorphism in the IL-6 receptor gene and preterm birth has been described.

The process of parturition is extremely complex and involves genetic influences of both the pregnant woman and the fetus. # 95. A. Catastrophic APS is a subset of APS in which neonates with antiphospholipid antibodies have a rapid presentation of thrombosis, arterial occlusion, or microthrombi in 3 or more organs.

Neonates born to women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) are exposed to antiphospholipid antibodies during gestation. However, these antibodies are insufficient to lead to neonatal disease; instead, large vessel thrombosis is found in neonates born to women with APS if the neonate has another prothrombotic risk factor (eg, central vascular catheter, sepsis, perinatal depression, prematurity, inherited prothrombotic genetic disorder). $^{1,2}$

Catastrophic APS occurs in a subgroup of patients with APS. In this type, neonates with antiphospholipid antibodies have a rapid presentation of thrombosis, arterial occlusion, or microthrombi in 3 or more organs. $^{3}$  Further studies are needed to explain why some neonates develop this form of APS.

# 101. C. Delivery is recommended between 34% and 36% weeks' gestation if the woman has poor in-hospital glycemic control.

Pregnant women with well-controlled pregestational or gestational diabetes mellitus should be managed expectantly until 39 weeks' gestation. In women with poorly controlled diabetes, delivery is recommended between 34% and 36% weeks' gestation if the woman has poor in-hospital glycemic control or fetal testing results are abnormal. If delivery prior to 37 weeks' gestation is anticipated, women with gestational diabetes mellitus should be given corticosteroids to decrease the risk of respiratory distress syndrome; the administration of corticosteroids to women with pregestational diabetes mellitus is less clear and the current recommendation is to provide corticosteroids if the delivery is expected to be before 34 weeks' gestation.

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) defines macrosomia as an estimated fetal weight exceeding 4,500 g in neonates born to women who have a diagnosis of pregestational or gestational diabetes mellitus. Studies show that induction of labor for pregnant women with diabetes with macrosomic fetuses does not decrease the risk of birth trauma. The most recent ACOG Practice Bulletin about the delivery approach for fetal macrosomia states that

- "With an estimated fetal weight of greater than 4,500 g, a prolonged second stage of labor or arrest of descent in the second stage is an indication for cesarean delivery."
- "Barring unusual circumstances, cesarean delivery should be performed for midpelvic arrest of the fetus with suspected macrosomia."

# 102. A. There are higher rates of subnormal growth at 12 and 18 months' corrected age with significantly lower head circumference percentiles at 18 months' corrected age.

There have only been a few studies examining the growth outcomes in infants born to women with preeclampsia. One cohort study compared infant growth in very low-birth-weight infants born to normotensive women (n=46) and women with preeclampsia (n=40). Data showed that infants born to women with preeclampsia had greater rates of poor growth at 12 and 18 months' corrected age with significantly lower head circumference percentiles at 18 months' corrected age. Data about long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes in this population are inconsistent.

Studies have not found that infants born to women with preeclampsia are at increased risk for severe intraventricular hemorrhage or periventricular leukomalacia, with some data suggesting a possible lower risk.[2,3]

Term infants born to women with preeclampsia might be at higher risk for encephalopathy, which is possibly attributable to a greater fetal inflammatory response in these infants.

## 103. B. Teenagers and women older than 35 years

In the United States, teenagers and women older than 35 years have the highest proportion of neonates born late preterm. In the teenage population, this might be attributable to adverse circumstances such as low socioeconomic status and limited education. Older women are at greater risk for hypertension and diabetes mellitus, which might contribute to the higher rate of preterm birth.

## 104. C. Placental blood flow is significantly reduced in pregnant women who use tobacco.

Among pregnant women, the most common licit substance of abuse is tobacco, which has been shown to significantly decrease placental blood flow. Alcohol is the most common teratogenic substance of abuse and can also lead to preterm birth and low birth weight. Because of these potential adverse outcomes, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends that pregnant women should not drink any amount of alcohol during pregnancy. Amphetamine use during pregnancy is also associated with preterm birth and low birth weight. Use of tobacco, alcohol, and amphetamines during pregnancy can change maternal physiology and also have a direct effect on the uterus, placenta, and fetal brain.

## 105. D. Symptoms typically occur in the first week postpartum.

Psychosis occurs in approximately 1 to 3 per 1,000 postpartum women. It typically manifests during the first week after delivery and usually requires emergency hospitalization because it evolves rapidly. Women with postpartum psychosis can have delusions, mood swings ranging from euphoria to depression, hallucinations, insomnia, and/or confusion. Limited data suggest that prophylactic treatment in women at high risk can prevent this disorder, but further studies are warranted.

## 106. B. In the 2013 executive summary from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, one part of the definition for preeclampsia is that the systolic blood pressure be equal to or greater than $140\mathrm{mmHg}$ at 2 distinct times at least 4 hours apart.

In 2013, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists defined preeclampsia as new-onset hypertension after 20 completed weeks' gestation with a systolic blood pressure equal to or greater than $140\mathrm{mmHg}$ and/or a diastolic pressure equal to or greater than $90\mathrm{mmHg}$ measured on 2 distinct occasions at least 4 hours apart. To be given this diagnosis, patients also need to have proteinuria, which was defined as equal to or greater than $300\mathrm{mg}/24$ hours or a protein-creatinine ratio equal to or greater than $0.3\mathrm{mg/dL}$. A diagnosis of intrauterine growth restriction is not a criterion for the diagnosis of preeclampsia. Most cases of preeclampsia are diagnosed after 20 weeks' gestation.

Preeclampsia with severe features requires a systolic blood pressure equal to or greater than $160\mathrm{mmHg}$ or diastolic pressure greater than $110\mathrm{mmHg}$ measured on 2 distinct occasions at least 4 hours apart or other clinical findings such as thrombocytopenia, persistent abdominal pain, liver or renal dysfunction, pulmonary edema, cerebral disturbances, or visual changes.

There is a higher incidence of genomic imprinting disorders, such as Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and Angelman syndrome, in neonates who were conceived by assisted reproductive technology.¹ This is thought to be due to changes in pH and serum concentrations in the in vitro cultures and manipulation of in vitro cultured embryos. Intracytoplasmic sperm injection is the most common assisted reproductive technology associated with genomic imprinting disorders.

## 110. A. Exceptionally large placentas are associated with adverse outcomes.

Women who have obesity tend to have placentas that are larger than average for gestational age. Neonates with placentas that are extremely large or neonates that are large relative to their placentas have a greater risk of adverse outcomes.¹ Placental efficiency is the ratio of fetal to placental weight, and this varies during gestation.² A decrease in placental efficiency is associated with an increased risk for adult-onset cardiovascular disease.³

## 111. D. The diagnosis of TTTS is made solely based on ultrasonographic criteria.

The diagnosis of twin-twin transfusion syndrome is based on amniotic fluid discordance with the donor having oligohydramnios and the recipient having polyhydramnios in monochorionic diamniotic pregnancies.

The lambda sign, also called the twin peak sign, represents a chorion extending between the intertwin membrane layers, which is found in dichorionic pregnancies and absent in monochorionic pregnancies.¹

David Barker and colleagues were the first to report that poor nutrition during fetal life and early infancy was associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease during adulthood.
