## 113. B. Chronic chorioamnionitis

The patient described in this vignette has a diagnosis that is most likely consistent with chronic chorioamnionitis. In this disease, there is a patchy infiltration of lymphocytes in the chorion on the fetal side. It is often accompanied by chronic villositis and chronic deciduitis. Some cases may be attributable to an infection.

## 114. B. Major malformations occur in 6% to 12% of neonates born to women with type 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus, with the initial injury occurring by the seventh week of gestation.

Major congenital malformations are the main cause of perinatal mortality in women with type 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus.¹ They occur in 6% to 12% of these pregnancies with the initial injury occurring by the seventh week of gestation.¹ Structural heart disease is the most common malformation with a 5-fold increase in ventricular septal defects and transposition of the great arteries. Abnormalities of the central nervous system and skeletal system are the next most common malformations. In contrast to neonates born to women with type 1 or type 2 diabetes, neonates born to women with gestational diabetes are not at increased risk for major malformations, as the onset of maternal disease occurs after the period of organogenesis.²

## 118. C. Dehydroepiandrosterone

The human placenta plays a variety of roles in the production and transfer of hormones. There are 3 general categories of hormones involved during gestation.

- Hormones that are produced by the pregnant woman that act on the placenta and can be transferred to the fetus (eg, thyroid hormone, oxytocin, estrogen)
- Hormones that are produced by the fetus, altered by the placenta, and then transferred to the fetus or the pregnant woman (eg, dehydroepiandrosterone)
- Hormones that are produced by the placenta and transferred to the pregnant woman and/or fetus (eg, insulinlike growth factor type 2, which is transferred to the fetus, and human chorionic gonadotropin, which is transferred to the pregnant woman)

## 119. E. Primary causes of maternal mortality during pregnancy include cardiomyopathy, pulmonary hypertension, aortic dissection, and myocardial infarction.

An atrial septal defect is one of the most common cardiac defects found in pregnant women. If a woman has a coarctation of the aorta, the Valsalva maneuver should be discouraged during the second stage of labor. Because most pregnant women with a history of tetralogy of Fallot or a patent ductus arteriosus have already had a complete repair of their lesion, the pregnancy is well-tolerated.

Although the incidence of cardiac disease in pregnancy women is low (approximately 4%), morbidity is as high as 34%. The most common causes of mortality in pregnant women are cardiomyopathy, pulmonary hypertension, aortic dissection, and myocardial infarction.

## 120. C. Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling and platelet transfusion may be of benefit in this fetus if the fetus has antibodies that react with the paternal human platelet antigen.

If a pregnant woman who has negative test results for the human platelet antigen has a fetus that has positive test results for the human platelet antigen (inherited from the father), maternal platelet antibodies can cross into the fetus and lead to intrauterine thrombocytopenia. In a future pregnancy, prenatal treatment initiated at 12 or 20 weeks' gestation with intravenous immunoglobulin with or without prednisone has been clearly shown to be of benefit when sensitization is known to exist. Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling and platelet transfusions may help to treat fetal thrombocytopenia and minimize the risk of an intracranial hemorrhage.

## 122. D. Teratoma

The most common causes of a fetal neck mass are teratoma and cystic hygroma. Teratomas are typically solid but may have a cystic component. The mass is usually midline and is well circumscribed. Cystic hygromas are multi-septated masses with a cystic appearance and are more often located in the posterior neck. $^{1,2}$ They typically invade adjacent structures within the mouth or superior anterior mediastinum.

## 123. C. Stage III

In 1999, Quintero et al described an ultrasonographic staging system to predict the hemodynamic effect on the fetuses with twin-twin transfusion syndrome. $^{1}$ There are 5 stages with increasing severity.

- Stage I: oligohydramnios/polyhydramnios, visible donor bladder
- Stage II: oligohydramnios/polyhydramnios, donor bladder not visible
- Stage III: oligohydramnios/polyhydramnios, abnormal umbilical Doppler flow (donor with absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in umbilical arteries, recipient with pulsatile flow in umbilical vein, and/or recipient with reversal of flow in the ductus venosus)
- Stage IV: oligohydramnios/polyhydramnios and hydrops in either the donor or recipient
- Stage V: oligohydramnios/polyhydramnios and demise (impending or actual) in one or both twins

The ultrasonographic findings in the patient described in this vignette are most consistent with stage III.

1. Quintero RA, Morales WJ, Allen MH, Bornick PW, Johnson PK, Kruger M. Staging of twin-twin transfusion syndrome. J Perinatol. 1999;19(8 Pt 1):550-555

## 124. A. Candida albicans

The histopathology of the umbilical cord lesions described in this vignette is most consistent with an infection by Candida species. Although Candida albicans is the most common type of species in this scenario, other species have been described, such as Candida parapsilosis. Regardless of the type of Candida species, the infected umbilical cord typically has visible pinpoint yellow-white nodules, which are consistent with subamnionic microabscesses by histology. Necrotizing funisitis might also be apparent by histopathology.

## 128. E. Preeclampsia

Hypertension during pregnancy is defined as a systolic blood pressure equal to or greater than 140 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure equal to or greater than 90 mm Hg noted twice with at least 4 hours between measurements.¹ Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy can be classified as follows¹:

- Chronic hypertension: hypertension prior to pregnancy, before 20 weeks’ gestation or persisting beyond 12 weeks’ postpartum
- Gestational hypertension: hypertension after 20 completed weeks’ gestation
- Preeclampsia: new-onset of hypertension after 20 completed weeks’ gestation + proteinuria (≥ 0.3 g/24 h or a protein-creatinine ratio ≥ 0.3 mg/dL)
- Preeclampsia with severe features: systolic blood pressure equal to or greater than 160 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure equal to or greater than 110 mm Hg noted twice with at least 4 hours between measurements OR severe proteinuria (≥ 5 g/24 h) OR severe abdominal pain, abnormal liver function results, worsening renal insufficiency, pulmonary edema, thrombocytopenia, pulmonary edema, or new-onset visual changes² (note: proteinuria is not required.)

1. B. In adult cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), studies have demonstrated that chest compressions without rescue breathing can significantly reduce the time to return of spontaneous circulation and can increase survival.

Animal and human studies in adults have shown that uninterrupted chest compressions, as well as systemic vasoconstrictors, such as epinephrine, can enhance diastolic blood pressure during CPR. These studies have demonstrated that continuous chest compressions without rescue breathing significantly reduce the time to return of spontaneous circulation and increase survival.¹,² Guidelines for adults and children (but not the neonatal population) recommend that bystander CPR be performed without rescue breaths and that in lone-rescuer advanced CPR, chest compressions should be uninterrupted for the first few minutes.³ After a secure airway has been established, continuous chest compressions with asynchronous ventilations are recommended.³,⁴

2. B. Caspases

Mitochondria play a role in brain injury after asphyxia. Leakage from the electron transport chain in impaired mitochondria is the primary source of oxygen free radicals after hypoxic-ischemic injury.¹

Release of cytochrome c from mitochondria induces neuronal apoptosis through activation of a proteolytic cascade, including caspases that cleave proteins that are vital for cell survival. Apoptosis can also be induced via release of mitochondrial proteins, a caspase-independent pathway.

5. C. Increasing functional residual capacity, decreasing resistance, increasing lung compliance.

As a preterm neonate takes its first breaths after delivery, more air will enter than leave the lungs, thereby creating the functional residual capacity. 8. C. Randomized studies begin as high-quality evidence but may be downgraded because of methodological quality.

Randomized studies begin as high quality but may be downgraded for methodological quality, whereas observational or cohort studies begin as low quality and can be further downgraded or upgraded, depending on methodological quality or positive outcome effect.

Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) is an emerging consensus process that rates quality of evidence and strength of recommendations along with values and preferences.¹,² In brief, GRADE classifies quality of evidence as follows: high quality (there is high confidence in the estimate of effect as reported in a synthesis of the literature), moderate quality (there is moderate confidence, but there may be differences from a further elucidated truth), low quality (there is low confidence in the estimate of the effect, which may be substantially different from the true effect), and very low quality (it is possible that the estimate of effect is substantially different from the true effect). The quality of a body of evidence involves consideration of 5 unique domains: the risk of bias for each outcome as reported across relevant studies (methodological quality), as well as the directness of evidence (such as whether the population studied is the same as that for which the guideline will be used), heterogeneity of the results of individual studies, precision of effect estimates, and risk of publication bias.

References

9. A. If the neonate presents with poor tone and inadequate breathing efforts, the initial steps of resuscitation can be completed under the radiant warmer and positive-pressure ventilation provided if the neonate is not breathing or has a heart rate less than 100 beats per minute.

The Neonatal Resuscitation Program is the education program that translates the 2015 American Academy of Pediatrics/American Heart Association neonatal resuscitation guidelines, which is based on a review of the evidence by the International Liaison Committee on Resuscitation.¹

In the scenario where the neonate is born through meconium-stained amniotic fluid and is vigorous with good respiratory effort and muscle tone, the neonate may stay with the mother to receive the initial steps of newborn care. However, if the neonate presents with poor muscle tone and inadequate breathing efforts, the initial steps of resuscitation should be completed under the radiant warmer. Positive-pressure ventilation should be initiated if the neonate is not breathing or the heart rate is less than 100/min after the initial steps are completed.

10. A. A Cochrane meta-analysis has concluded that plastic wraps or bags are effective at reducing heat loss in neonates born younger than 28-weeks' gestational age.

Occlusive wraps, made of polyethylene or similar material, are a useful component of thermal management for preterm neonates at birth. A Cochrane meta-analysis reviewed several studies on plastic wraps or bags and found a benefit of increased temperature.¹ For the outcome of prevention of hypothermia, a number needed to treat of 4 was estimated. In general, no serious harm has been found from use of plastic wraps.

The temperature of a fetus is 0.9°F (0.5°C) above the maternal temperature. However, within a few minutes after birth, the neonatal core temperature will decrease.¹ Preterm neonates may have an initial appropriate response to a decrease in environmental temperatures; however, the effect is limited, and there is a high risk for hypothermia. The World Health Organization recommends that the newborn axillary temperature be maintained between 97.7°F and 99.5°F (36.5°C and 37.5°C).²

12. E. One rationale for this ratio is the higher physiological heart rate of 120 to 160 beats per minute and breathing rates of 40 to 60 per minute in neonates.

The neonatal section of the International Liaison Committee on Resuscitation continues to recommend a 3:1 ratio of compressions to ventilation, with 90 compressions and 30 breaths per minute to achieve 120 events per minute.¹,² The rationale is based on the higher physiological heart rate of 120 to 160 per minute and breathing rates of 40 to 60 per minute in neonates compared with those in older patients. Another reason for this strategy is that bradycardia or cardiac arrest in neonates is usually caused by hypoxia rather than primary cardiac compromise. Therefore, providing ventilation is more likely to be beneficial than is providing chest compressions.

15. D. Heat loss via conduction occurs when neonates are in direct contact with cold surfaces.

Heat loss occurs by means of 4 mechanisms that are all relevant for the risk of hypothermia in preterm neonates¹:

1. Evaporation: amniotic fluid covering the skin exposed to the relatively nonhumidified air in the delivery room leads to evaporation
2. Conduction: direct contact between the neonate and the surrounding environment and objects, such as cold blankets
3. Convection: the gradient between the temperature of the skin of the neonate and movement of ambient air, such as when the neonate is moved from the mother to a resuscitation table
4. Radiation: the gradient between the skin and surrounding surfaces not touching the neonate

References

1. Knobel R, Holditch-Davis D. Thermoregulation and heat loss prevention after birth and during neonatal intensive-care unit stabilization of extremely low-birthweight infants. J Obstet Gynecol Neonatal Nurs. 2007;36(3):280-287

Signs of intrapartum asphyxia include signs of fetal distress (passage of thick meconium, fetal heart tracing abnormalities, severe obstetric adverse events such as uterus rupture or placental abruption); neonatal depression as indicated by low Apgar scores; prolonged need for resuscitation; and, perhaps most importantly, significant metabolic acidosis measured by means of umbilical cord blood gas analysis (pH &lt; 7.0–7.05 and base deficit &gt;12–16 mEq/L).¹

## 26. C. Infant mortality

A Cochrane review of randomized or quasi-randomized studies enrolling a total of 1,302 newborns and comparing room air versus 100% oxygen for neonatal resuscitation was published in 2005.¹ No individual study found a significant difference in mortality between groups; however, pooled analysis showed a benefit of reduced mortality in the group receiving room air. No significant differences were seen for the outcomes of neurological development or hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.

### References

1. Tan A, Schulze A, O'Donnell CPF, Davis PG. Air versus oxygen for resuscitation of infants at birth. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2005;2(2):CD002273

## 27. C. Moderate hypothermia

In several randomized controlled trials, moderate hypothermia (goal temperatures ranging from 33.5°C to 35.0°C) decreased mortality and reduced hypoxic-ischemic brain injury when initiated within 6 hours after injury for neonates with moderate or severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.¹,²

## 28. B. Establish effective ventilation

Most newborns need no interventions or assistance during the transition of the birth process. However, an estimated 10% of newborns may benefit from help in establishing effective ventilation; this is considered the most critical step of neonatal resuscitation.¹

## 29. B. A response to cold external temperature involves stimulation of sympathetic pathways, which induces a surge in thyroid-stimulating hormone that leads to thyroxine and triiodothyronine release.

A neonate's initial response to cool external temperatures involves stimulation of skin thermoreceptors leading to nonshivering thermogenesis. Stimulation of sympathetic pathways induces thyrotropin release that then leads to release of thyroxine and triiodothyronine. Triiodothyronine causes upregulation of the protein thermogenin, which causes uncoupling of mitochondrial oxidation and phosphorylation. Thermogenin and norepinephrine act on brown fat to initiate chemical thermogenesis.¹

### References

1. Ringer SA. Core concepts: thermoregulation in the newborn; part 1—basic mechanisms. NeoReviews. 2013;14(4):e161–e167

## 30. C. Positive end-expiratory pressure

Neonates who breathe spontaneously can generate fairly high transpulmonary pressures immediately after birth.¹ However, the use of high pressures with manual positive-pressure ventilation can increase the risk of lung injury.² Increasing the time over which pressure is applied may help to minimize injury. Applying positive end-expiratory pressure will help to maintain pressure on the airways throughout the respiratory cycle.

There is no uniformity in the consent process for video recording for clinical care in the delivery room. Parental consent may not be required for video recording for quality assurance purposes at some sites. $^{1,2}$ Because birth and delivery room resuscitation are not always predictable regarding timing, a retrospective consent process may be an option when appropriate. $^{3,4}$ Staff members' consent may be appropriate on certain occasions, such as in research studies. $^{5,6}$ The intended use and management of the videos, such as for research and/or quality assurance, will guide the decisions surrounding appropriate requirements and strategies for consent. ## 34. A. Preterm neonates can maintain core temperatures in only a narrow range of environmental temperatures.

Preterm neonates are at a high risk for hypothermia because they can maintain core temperatures in only a narrow range of environmental temperatures. Also, their ratio of skin surface to body weight is almost 4 times that of adults, whereas term neonates have a ratio 3 times that of adults. This larger skin surface area leads to more heat loss. Preterm neonates' sweat glands are not functional, and vasodilation is inefficient. $^{1}$

35. B. Help the newborn form a sufficient functional residual capacity and large enough tidal volume
Very preterm newborns have a pliable and unstable chest wall and underdeveloped respiratory muscles, creating a challenge in forming effective functional residual capacity. The most important first step in aiding the transition to effective breathing is to help the newborn form and maintain sufficient functional residual capacity and tidal volume. 38. E. Untreated hypothermia eventually leads to altered physiological characteristics and may cause seizure activity or even death.
Temperature regulation is linked to oxygen consumption and glucose use.¹² Cold stress leads to increased oxygen consumption, tissue hypoxia, and metabolic acidosis. Metabolic acidosis can then inhibit surfactant formation. Norepinephrine released from brown fat can lead to systemic vasoconstriction, which leads to pulmonary vasoconstriction, and can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues. Heat loss can contribute to dehydration and fluid electrolyte imbalance. Untreated hypothermia may eventually lead to altered physiological characteristics and seizure activity and, in some cases, may be a factor in increasing the risk for mortality.

42. B. Glutamate

When cell membrane functions fail, excitatory amino acids, primarily glutamate, accumulate in the extracellular space because of increased release and impaired uptake.¹ The secondary neurotoxic cascade is initiated as the accumulation of glutamate leads to overactivation of neuronal receptors, including the N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor, which leads to an excessive influx of calcium. An increase in intracellular calcium concentration leads to activation of cell-degrading enzymes such as lipases, proteases, phospholipases, and endonucleases.

References

1. McLean C, Ferriero D. Mechanisms of hypoxic-ischemic injury in the term infant. Semin Perinatol. 2004;28(6):425-432

43. B. Diastolic blood pressure

In experimental models of adult ventricular fibrillation cardiac arrest to determine the effectiveness of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, aortic diastolic blood pressure or coronary perfusion pressure are the most reliable measurements.¹⁻⁴ A hypoxic heart that is depleted of energy substrate requires reestablishment of myocardial perfusion with oxygenated blood. During cardiac compressions, blood pumped out of the heart will take the path of least resistance. In the scenario of asphyxia in which there is vasodilation and no or minimal diastolic blood pressure, the blood pumped by compressions will preferentially flow through the aorta and the periphery rather than into the narrow-diameter coronary arteries that have higher resistance.

## 8. D. Protease

Cerebral tissue hypoxia results in decreased production of adenosine triphosphate and phosphocreatine, which leads to cell membrane depolarization and influx of intracellular calcium. This influx in intracellular calcium results in the activation of multiple downstream pathways including¹,²

- Endonuclease activation that results in nuclear injury
- Protease activation leading to cytoskeleton disruption
- Protease and phospholipase activation that results in free radical production and activation of the apoptotic pathways
- Nitric oxide synthase activation
- An increase in excitatory neurotransmitter (glutamate) release

## 9. C. Myotonic dystrophy

Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is an autosomal dominant disorder that can present in the newborn period with hypotonia, respiratory distress, poor feeding, clubfoot, and eyelid ptosis. The physical examination may reveal bitemporal wasting, a masklike facies, and a tented upper lip. The prenatal history may be significant for a history of decreased fetal movement, polyhydramnios, and breech positioning.

Myotonic dystrophy type 1 is caused by expansion of trinucleotide CTG repeats in the noncoding region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) gene on chromosome 19. A trinucleotide repeat size greater than 34 is unstable, resulting in possible expansion during female germline cell division, a process known as anticipation. A CTG repeat length between 37 and 50 is considered a premutation state, and individuals in this category are asymptomatic or have very subtle clinical features.

The diagnosis of myotonic dystrophy is confirmed by the detection of a CTG repeat length greater than 50, and the length of the CTG repeats determines disease severity.¹,²

- Mild DM1 (50–150 repeats)
- Classic DM1 (100–1,000 repeats)
- Congenital DM1 (&gt;1,000 repeats)

# 10. C. Morphine

Neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) is the result of the abrupt discontinuation of chronic fetal exposure to substances used or abused by the mother during pregnancy. NAS most commonly follows opioid exposure, but polydrug use can lead to a more severe presentation. It is a generalized multisystem disorder with central nervous system, autonomic nervous system, and gastrointestinal system symptomatology.

The mainstay of therapy for neonates with NAS is centered on nonpharmacological measures and family-focused care. For newborns with opioid withdrawal and who require pharmacological intervention, morphine has been shown to be more effective than paregoric alone or paregoric and diazepam. In addition, the use of paregoric is not recommended because most preparations contain alcohol, benzoic acid, and camphor. The use of phenobarbital as a first-line therapy for a newborn with opioid withdrawal is not indicated. Similarly, diazepam contains sodium benzoate, which may displace bilirubin, is poorly metabolized by neonates, and should not be used in the treatment of NAS.¹

## References

1. Jansson LM, Patrick SW. Neonatal abstinence syndrome. *Pediatr Clin North Am.* 2019;66(2):353-367

# 11. D. Shoulder dystocia

Perinatal brachial plexus palsy is a peripheral nerve injury that increases in incidence with increasing birth weight.

- 0.9 per 1,000 for newborns weighing less than 4,000 g
- 1.8 per 1,000 for newborns weighing 4,000 to 4,500 g
- 2.6 per 1,000 for newborns weighing more than 4,500 g¹

Perinatal brachial plexus palsy is commonly associated with traumatic birth, but not always, and can lead to significant long-term disability. Risk factors include the following:

- Maternal factors: excessive weight gain, maternal short stature, maternal diabetes, uterine abnormalities, and history of a previous pregnancy complicated by shoulder dystocia
- Fetal factors: fetal macrosomia, as discussed above
- Parturitional factors: shoulder dystocia, prolonged labor, assisted delivery, breech delivery, and post-term delivery

Among these risk factors, shoulder dystocia is the most common, occurring in 45% of newborns.²

# 12. A. Beals syndrome

Beals syndrome, or congenital contractural arachnodactyly, is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in the FBN2 gene on chromosome 5. Affected neonates can present with features also seen in newborns who have Marfan syndrome, including

- Crumpled ears
- Dolichostenomelia (long arms, hands, legs, and feet)
- Arachnodactyly
- Chest wall deformities

Other common features unique to Beals syndrome include the following:¹,²

- Joint contractures of the fingers, elbows, and knees; this can be associated with motor delays.
- Scoliosis.
- High-arched palate.
- Mitral valve prolapse with or without regurgitation.

## 14. D. Limb clonus

Movement abnormalities due to seizures are difficult to ascertain in the neonatal period because of incomplete brain myelination. Neonatal seizures typically present as focal clonic, focal tonic, generalized tonic, myoclonic, and subtle seizures. In general, abnormal movement caused by seizures is stereotypical and cannot be stopped.

There are multiple types of nonepileptic movement disorders to consider as part of the differential diagnosis of abnormal movements in the neonatal period.¹ These can be interrupted with repositioning or arousal and include the following:

- Jittery movements: very rapid, short duration tremulous movements usually involving multiple extremities
- Limb clonus: rapid and short duration jerking movement, typically restricted to one joint as in the clinical vignette described
- Benign sleep myoclonus: rapid jerking movements randomly affecting the extremities, trunk, and face, and resolving with arousal

## 15. A. A base deficit greater than 14 mEq/L would increase the probability of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.

Therapeutic hypothermia has been shown to be neuroprotective in term and near-term neonates with moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE).¹ Eligibility for therapeutic hypothermia is determined in a 2-step process.²

- The presence of biological evidence of a hypoxic-ischemic event around the time of delivery. While criteria vary slightly between trials,²,³ the determination of a hypoxic-ischemic insult can be ascertained by the presence of metabolic acidosis at birth, a low 10-minute Apgar score, or continued need for resuscitation at 10 minutes after birth. Looking specifically at base deficit, Wayenberg demonstrated that a base deficit greater than 14 mEq/L (14 mmol/L) had a sensitivity of 73% and a specificity of 82% for predicting moderate to severe HIE with a likelihood ratio of 4.1.⁴
- The presence of moderate or severe encephalopathy based on neurological examination, indicating that the hypoxic-ischemic event was prolonged enough to cause brain injury.

16. A. An infant exposed to SSRIs may have increased pain tolerance with decreased physiological response and crying in response to stimuli such as heel sticks.

Exposure to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in utero has been associated with the following:

- A small increase in the risk of neurological anomalies in some studies, mostly driven by exposure to fluoxetine and paroxetine.¹,²
- The occurrence of neonatal adaptation syndrome with symptoms such as hypertonia, tremors, jitteriness, feeding issues, difficulty sleeping, and respiratory distress. Symptoms are typically mild, resolve within 2 to 6 days, and respond well to nonpharmacological measures including skin-to-skin care.³
- Altered neurobehavior and motor development in the early postnatal period.⁴
- Altered pain response with increased pain tolerance as demonstrated by decreased physiological response and crying in response to stimuli such as heel sticks. There are no long-term data to support an effect of SSRI exposure on response to pain in later life.⁵
- Decreased fetal head growth and higher fetal weight gain compared with fetuses of pregnant women with depression but not taking SSRIs.⁶

Neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) is global problem, with reports of rapidly increasing incidence in developed and developing countries. In the United States, a 3-fold increase in NAS occurred between 2000 and 2009, and the rate of NAS has continued to increase since then, outpacing projections. - Erratic responses to succinylcholine

Therefore, close monitoring before, during, and after anesthesia, as delineated in the Myotonic Dystrophy Foundation anesthesia guidelines, is critical to decrease these risks.²

## 19. D. The Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers is a brief screening tool administered to the parents at the 18- and 24-month well-child visits to identify children at high risk of having ASD.

Children born preterm are at increased risk of developing autism spectrum disorder (ASD).¹ On average, ASD is not diagnosed until after age 4 years, although research indicates that diagnosis at age 2 years is feasible, valid, and stable.²³ Earlier diagnosis is possible using screening tools such as the Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (M-CHAT). The M-CHAT is brief and can be administered to parents of children between 18 months and 24 months at high risk for ASD.⁴

The following deviations in development have been proposed by the American Academy of Neurology and Child Neurology Society as absolute red flags for possible ASD:

- No babbling, pointing, or use of nonverbal gestures by 12 months
- No single words by 16 months
- No 2-word spontaneous phrases by 24 months
- Loss of language or social skills at any age⁵

## 20. B. Children who achieve head control by 9 months of age and who are sitting by 2 years of age, and have suppression of primitive reflexes by 18 to 24 months of age, are more likely to achieve eventual ambulation than those who do not achieve those milestones.

The risk of cerebral palsy (CP) increases with decreasing gestational age (GA) at birth, with an incidence between 15% and 20% among neonates born at fewer than 25 weeks’ GA.¹ Cerebral palsy is classified from 1 to 5 in order of increasing severity using the Gross Motor Function Classification System.²

Most preterm neonates with CP will be able to walk, either independently (58%) or with assistance (11%).³ Children who will ultimately be able to ambulate are more likely to have achieved the following:

- Head control by 9 months of age
- Sitting by 2 years of age
- Suppression of primitive reflexes by 18 to 24 months of age⁴⁵

The most common form of CP in children born preterm is spastic diplegia (&gt;75% of cases). Most children with spastic diplegia will be able to walk (with or without assistance), perform independent care, and have bowel-bladder control. However, about one-third of these children will have cognitive impairments. Those with spastic hemiplegia have a higher risk of cognitive and learning impairments (two-thirds of children) but are typically able to walk by age 3 years. More than 50% of children with the dystonic forms have normal intelligence but have problems with speech and articulation, movement control, drooling, and swallowing.

## 21. B. Newborns in the prenatal surgery group in the MOMS trial had increased urological complications compared with the postnatal intervention group.

Myelomeningocele are neural tube defects that occur with an incidence of about 2.0 per 1,000 births.¹ The care of neonates with myelomeningocele includes the following:

- Defect closure, prenatally or postnatally
- Surveillance and treatment of hydrocephalus
- Long-term multidisciplinary care

The Management of Myelomeningocele Study trial was designed to compare outcomes of prenatal and postnatal surgery in children with myelomeningocele.² This randomized, multicenter trial was stopped early because of a significant decrease in the need for cerebrospinal fluid shunting in the prenatal intervention group (65% vs 92%, P &lt; .001). At 12 months, children who underwent prenatal surgery had decreased hindbrain herniation. At 30 months, more children in the prenatal surgery group were able to walk. The risks of prenatal surgery for myelomeningocele include maternal morbidity, preterm birth, and increased urological complications.³,⁴

Prenatal surgery may be considered if the following inclusion criteria from the MOMS trial are met:

- Singleton pregnancy
- Spinal level between T1 and S1
- Normal karyotype
- Presence of an Arnold-Chiari malformation type II²

## 22. E. Lower margin below 5 μV and upper margin below 10 μV

Amplitude-integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) allows for continuous and noninvasive brain monitoring at the bedside. Advantages over full montage electroencephalography (EEG) include that it does not require an EEG technician for lead placement, and bedside clinicians with no neurophysiology background can interpret the aEEG with appropriate training.

Several classification systems for the interpretation of the aEEG background activity have been developed. The basic classification developed by al Naqeeb and colleagues¹ distinguishes 3 patterns based on voltage assessment.

- Normal: lower margin above 5 μV and upper margin above 10 μV
- Moderately abnormal: lower margin below 5 μV and upper margin above 10 μV
- Suppressed: lower margin below 5 μV and upper margin below 10 μV

This classification is helpful in evaluating neonates with encephalopathy.

More applicable to all neonates is the 5-pattern classification developed by Hellström-Westas and colleagues.²

- Continuous activity: lower amplitude of 5 to 7 μV (up to 10 μV); maximum amplitude of 10 to 25 μV (up to 50 μV)
- Discontinuous activity: variable lower border variable (&lt;5 μV with maximum amplitude &gt;10 μV), leading to a wider bandwidth
- Burst suppression: discontinuous background with minimum amplitude without variability (0–2 μV) and bursts with amplitude &gt;25 μV. Two types of burst suppression pattern are distinguished: positive burst suppression (≥100 bursts per hour) and negative burst suppression (&lt;100 bursts per hour)
- Low-voltage pattern: continuous background pattern of very low amplitude of about 5 μV
- Flat or isoelectric tracing: extremely low background amplitude (significantly below 5 μV)

## 23. E. Hypothermia reduces calcium influx into neuronal cells, potentially reducing the degree of mitochondrial dysfunction.

Therapeutic hypothermia has been shown to be neuroprotective in term and near-term neonates with moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.¹ The beneficial effects of therapeutic hypothermia are due to its effect on multiple cellular and metabolic pathways involved in the pathogenesis of hypoxic-ischemic brain injury.² These mechanisms include the following:

- Decrease in the tissue metabolic demand, including cerebral metabolic rate
- Decrease in ionic perturbation with decreased intracellular calcium influx and mitochondrial dysfunction, and thereby neurotoxicity
- Decreased free radical production
- Attenuation of the proinflammatory cascade activation, including reduction in STAT 3 expression
- Enhanced RBM3 protein expression, a protein with antiapoptotic and cell proliferation functions

## 24. B. Focal tonic seizure

Neonatal seizures can be differentiated from nonepileptic abnormal movements of the newborn because of their stereotypical nature and the fact that they cannot be stopped with repositioning or arousal.

Neonatal seizures are classified as follows:

- Focal (multifocal) clonic seizures, characterized by slow (0.5–2.0 per second) rhythmic jerking of an extremity, or twitching of the face. These are classically associated with a seizure on electroencephalogram (EEG).
- Focal tonic seizures, characterized by stereotypical, slowly evolving stiffening and posturing of an extremity, or asymmetrical posturing of the trunk and neck, with or without associated eye deviation. These are classically associated with a seizure on EEG.
- Generalized tonic seizures, characterized by whole-body stiffening with upper and lower extremities extension. These are not typically associated with rhythmic discharge on EEG and may represent a brainstem release phenomenon.
- Myoclonic seizures, characterized by rapid, single jerks of a limb and/or trunk. They can be distinguished from benign sleep myoclonus by their persistence and lack of correlation with sleep.
- Subtle seizures (motor or autonomic), characterized by stereotyped episodes of eye deviation and nystagmus, chewing movements, rhythmic tongue thrusting, swimming movements of the arms, or bicycling movements of the legs. Autonomic signs include tachycardia, apnea, and abrupt changes in blood pressure. The presence of an EEG correlate is inconsistent.

## 25. E. The randomized trials for therapeutic hypothermia employed either a combination of head and body cooling or whole-body cooling alone, with core temperatures typically a degree lower in the whole-body cooling trials.

Several large randomized controlled trials have demonstrated that therapeutic hypothermia is effective in improving the outcomes of newborns (≥35 or ≥36 weeks' gestation) with moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.¹

Eligibility for therapeutic hypothermia was determined in a 2-step process for all these trials.²

- Biological evidence of a hypoxic-ischemic event around the time of delivery. While criteria varied slightly between trials,² all included a surrogate of impaired placental gas exchange (metabolic acidosis at birth, a low 10-minute Apgar score, or continued need for resuscitation at 10 minutes after birth).
- Presence of moderate or severe encephalopathy based on neurological examination with half of the trials using an amplitude-integrated electroencephalogram to confirm moderate or severe encephalopathy.

In all cases, therapeutic hypothermia was achieved via either whole-body cooling or selective head cooling with mild systemic cooling. Core temperatures (rectal or esophageal) were 1° lower in the total body cooling trials compared to the selective head cooling trials. All trials maintained hypothermia for a total duration of 72 hours, followed by a slow rewarming period.²³

## 26. D. Reduced white matter in the premotor, sensorimotor, and temporal cortices and reduced gray matter volumes in the sensorimotor and mid-temporal cortices have been associated with poor cognitive outcomes.

Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a powerful tool to predict the neurodevelopmental consequences of prematurity. Conventional and advanced MRI sequences can be used in this population. Conventional imaging sequences include T1- and T2-weighed images and are useful to

- Determine and classify white matter abnormalities. The presence of moderate to severe white matter abnormalities and asymmetrical myelination of the posterior limb of the internal capsule are strong risk factors of adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes.¹²
- Identify and classify cerebellar hemorrhages.
- Investigate cerebral and cerebellar growth and development. Advanced imaging sequences include
- Volumetric and surface-based morphometry to investigate macrostructural brain development. Using these techniques, investigators determined that reduced white matter volumes in the premotor, sensorimotor, and temporal cortices and reduced gray matter volumes in the sensorimotor and mid-temporal cortices were associated with poor cognitive outcomes.³
- Diffusion tensor imaging and measurement of fractional anisotropy (FA) to investigate the microstructural integrity of the brain. Fractional anisotropy increases with advancing development, and lower FA values have been shown to correlate with motor and cognitive outcomes.⁴⁵

## 27. B. Mechanical ventilation in neonates is associated with an increase in cortisol and catecholamine levels.

Mechanical ventilation, sometimes for prolonged periods, is necessary in the care of sick preterm and term neonates. While the use of mechanical ventilation is associated with an increase in cortisol and catecholamine levels, the routine use of narcotic sedation is not recommended for the following reasons:

- The use of advanced modes of ventilation has greatly decreased the risk of asynchronous respiratory effort with subsequent compromised gas exchange and increased stress responses.
- The preemptive use of morphine in mechanically ventilated neonates has not been shown to lead to a measurable analgesic effect.
- The randomized controlled NEOPAIN trial reported no beneficial effect of preemptive morphine infusions with an increased risk of intraventricular hemorrhage in preterm neonates born at 27 to 29 weeks' gestation. Neonates receiving additional morphine doses required longer mechanical ventilation support.¹
- A Cochrane review determined that preemptive opioid sedation did not result in any differences in mortality, duration of mechanical ventilation, or short- and long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes.

## 28. A. Her glial fibrillary acidic protein levels were likely to be elevated during the first 2 days after delivery.

Multiple biomarkers of neonatal hypoxic brain injury have been studied, including the following:

- Protein S100β. Elevated S100β levels are seen in the cord blood or first urine of neonates with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) compared with control participants. A cord blood level greater than 2.02 mcg/L has a sensitivity of 87% and a specificity of 88% for predicting the moderate or severe HIE.¹
- Neuron-specific enolase (NSE). Elevated serum NSE levels (&gt;40 mcg/L) between 4 hours and 48 hours after birth are predictive of neonates with moderate to severe HIE.²
- Umbilical cord interleukin 6 (IL-6). Elevated IL-6 levels in the neonate but not the mother correlate with the severity of HIE as well as with 2-year neurodevelopmental outcomes.³
- Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). GFAP level is elevated after HIE and serum levels 0.15 ng/mL or greater on neonatal intensive care unit admission have been shown to be predictive of abnormal brain magnetic resonance imaging findings.⁴
- Brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF). Neonates with HIE have higher BDNF level in cord plasma.⁵

## 29. B. Even if this patient had a normal hearing screening result in the NICU, the patient is at risk for delayed-onset or progressive hearing loss and will require repeat testing.

Neonates born preterm have an increased risk of neurodevelopmental impairments, emphasizing the need for careful follow-up after neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) discharge to detect problems early, implement timely interventions, and optimize outcomes. Recommendations specific to the neurodevelopmental monitoring in the NICU population include the following:

- Recognition of the increased risk of cerebral palsy, including preterm neonates with a history of normal head ultrasounds (4% risk).¹
- Recognition of neonates at higher risk of developing seizures, including those with a history of intraventricular hemorrhage (10% risk),² periventricular leukomalacia (18% risk),³ or moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (29%-35% risk).⁴
- Close monitoring for shunt malfunction in neonates with a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. In addition, neonates should be monitored for the development of late ventriculomegaly and hydrocephalus and need for post-discharge shunt placement.
- Emphasizing the importance of ophthalmology follow-up for preterm neonates with or without retinopathy of prematurity.
- Ongoing surveillance for the development of hearing impairments. The goals of universal hearing screening programs are 3-fold: (1) screen all neonates for hearing loss by 1 month of age; (2) perform diagnostic audiological evaluations by 3 months of age; and (3) enroll eligible infants in early intervention no later than 6 months after birth. Risk indicators associated with hearing loss include NICU stay longer than 5 days, exposure to ototoxic medications, hyperbilirubinemia with bilirubin level greater than 20 mg/dL, in utero infection (cytomegalovirus, Zika, rubella, syphilis, toxoplasmosis), and craniofacial anomalies involving the ear and/or temporal bone. Some risk

Neonates with risk factors, such as the neonate described in the vignette, should have repeat diagnostic audiology assessment by 24 to 30 months of age. ## 30. C. If this neonate has hypoxic-ischemic brain injury, there is likely to be an increased synaptic release of glutamate and over-activation of glutamate neuronal receptors.

The pathogenesis of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) results from an interruption of the metabolic substrates necessary for brain metabolism, particularly oxygen and glucose. It evolves in 2 phases.¹

- The first phase includes immediate cell death due to necrosis as a result of interruption of substrates delivery.
- The second phase is characterized by the complex activation of several intracellular pathways including
- Excitotoxicity, characterized by increased synaptic release of glutamate with over-activation of glutamate neuronal receptors
- Free radical production leading to increase in oxidative stress, and neuronal injury
- Activation of inflammatory cascades

Therapeutic hypothermia is effective in improving the outcomes of neonates with moderate to severe HIE because it targets many of these mechanisms resulting in decreased secondary cell death, or apoptosis.²

Exposure to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) has been associated with alterations in neurobehavior and development. A meta-analysis of observational studies demonstrated an increased risk of ASD with a pooled crude odds ratio of 1.91 (95% CI, 1.13-3.47).¹ This association was replicated in a prospective study of 376 children.² However, the data remain conflicting with 2 additional studies finding no association between SSRI exposure and ASD.³,⁴ In the study from Clements and colleagues, an increased risk of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in children exposed to SSRIs was noted.⁴

32. B. In contrast to having central nervous system causes of hypotonia, neonates with peripheral nerve disorders do not usually show improvement in their muscle strength or tone.

An approach focusing on anatomical-clinical correlation is recommended for the systematic evaluation of the hypotonic newborn. Localization between upper motor neuron (central) and lower motor neuron (peripheral), while not perfect, is helpful in narrowing the differential diagnosis and directing diagnostic testing.¹²

Hypotonia due to peripheral nerve disorders is characterized by the following distinguishing features³:

- Weakness (distal greater than proximal)
- Muscle atrophy
- Possible contractures; may be as extensive as arthrogryposis multiplex congenita
- Possible muscle fasciculations because of denervated muscle fibers (less common than seen with anterior horn cell disorders)
- Diminished or absent reflexes
- Normal or increased protein level on cerebrospinal fluid studies
- Normal creatine kinase level
- Decreased motor nerve conduction velocity

In contrast to having central nervous system causes of hypotonia, neonates with peripheral nerve disorders do not usually show improvement in their muscle strength or tone. Peripheral disorders are classified as generalized or focal (ie, brachial plexus injury). Generalized neuropathies include

- Hereditary motor and sensory neuropathies (eg, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease).
- Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathies. Familial dysautonomia (or Riley-Day syndrome) is the best described of these neuropathies.
- Acquired demyelinating neuropathies, which rarely present in the neonatal period.

## 34. A. Hydrocephalus

Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by the expansion of trinucleotide CTG repeats in the noncoding region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) gene on chromosome 19. The prenatal care of women with DM1 or with a family history of DM1 should be provided by a maternal-fetal medicine specialist due to the increased risk associated with fetal DM1 including higher rates of¹

- Spontaneous abortions
- Preterm labor
- Preeclampsia
- Spontaneous premature rupture of membranes
- Peripartum hemorrhage

In a pregnant woman with a family history of DM1 or with grip myotonia, the following findings would increase the suspicion of DM1 in the fetus²:

- Polyhydramnios (secondary to swallowing difficulties)
- Ventriculomegaly or hydrocephalus
- Talipes equinovarus
- Decreased fetal movements

## 35. A. Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibody assay

Transient neonatal myasthenia gravis (TNMG) affects 10% to 20% of newborns born to mothers with myasthenia gravis. Transient neonatal myasthenia gravis is caused by the transplacental passage of antibodies against the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (AChR, 85% of cases) or against the muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSKR, 15% of cases), causing neuromuscular junction blockade in the newborn.¹

In an asymptomatic mother, the diagnosis of TNMG may be missed; therefore, TNMG should remain on the differential diagnosis of a newborn presenting with generalized hypotonia and poor suck between 3 and 72 hours after birth. Other clinical findings suggestive of TNMG include weak cry, facial diplegia or paresis, and swallowing difficulties, as well as, in some cases, respiratory distress and ptosis.² In this situation, the concomitant measurement of anti-AChR and anti-MuSKR antibodies in both mother and newborn is diagnostic.

## 36. D. Timing of initiation of cooling

The neuroprotective effects of therapeutic hypothermia are dependent on several factors including timing of initiation of cooling as well as depth and duration of cooling. Among those, the timing of initiation of cooling is the most important. Preclinical data support a loss of neuroprotection if cooling is delayed by longer than 6 hours. Further, the degree of neuroprotection decreases with delays of cooling onset by longer than a few hours after the hypoxic-ischemic insult.¹

## 37. C. Oligodendrocyte progenitor cell

The primary cellular target in periventricular white matter injury or periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is the pre-myelinating oligodendrocyte (PreOLs). These PreOLs, which are present at high concentration in the periventricular region between 23 weeks' gestation and 32 weeks' gestation, are particularly susceptible to hypoxia-ischemia, free radical injury, excitotoxicity, and inflammation, all factors implicated in the pathogenesis of PVL.¹⁻³

38. B. Children with this disorder usually do not have problems with early milestone acquisition.

Developmental coordination disorder (DCD), a milder form of motor disability than cerebral palsy, is defined as "an impairment of motor performance sufficient to produce functional performance deficits not explicable by the child's age or intellect, or by other diagnosable neurological or psychiatric disorder."¹

The incidence of DCD is higher among children born with a birth weight less than 1,000 g (5%–50%, with most studies reporting a 30% incidence) compared with children born with normal birth weight (2%).²³ Other risk factors of DCD include male sex, prolonged rupture of membranes, retinopathy of prematurity, and postnatal steroid exposure.⁴⁵

Children with DCD have an increased risk of cognitive and academic difficulties, behavioral problems, and social isolation.

39. E. Referral to a specialist familiar with ASD should occur; these may include developmental and behavioral pediatricians, pediatric neurologists, or child and adolescent psychiatrists.

Children born preterm, with a low birth weight, or with neonatal medical complexity have an increased risk of having autism spectrum disorder (ASD). In a prospective study with rigorous diagnosis of ASD, children born preterm were found to have a prevalence of ASD of 5%, 3 times that of the general population.¹ Therefore, screening for ASD using tools such as the Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (M-CHAT), is recommended in the follow-up care of these high-risk children. The M-CHAT is a short screening tool administered to parents at the 18- and 24-month visits.²

If a child is suspected of having ASD, referral to a specialist should occur as soon as possible to ensure accurate and prompt diagnosis as well as institution of appropriate educational and developmental interventions.

For children younger than 3 years at diagnosis, services are available through the state early intervention system. If they are older than 3 years, an individualized education program can be implemented through the public school system. Additional therapy services may also be available through the child's insurance.

40. E. To date, there have been no randomized clinical trials that have evaluated the effect of maintaining blood glucose concentration at designated levels after neonatal asphyxia.

Hypoxic-ischemic brain injury is the result of substrate delivery interruption including oxygen and glucose. An important aspect of the post-injury care of these neonates is to maintain adequate substrate delivery to support recovery. Studies indicate that both hypoglycemia (particularly early after the insult) and hyperglycemia are associated with poor outcomes in neonates with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). However, to date there have been no randomized clinical trials that have evaluated the effect of maintaining blood glucose concentration at designated levels after neonatal HIE.¹⁻⁴

## 41. B. Collagen 1A1 gene

Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) type II is due to a sporadic mutation in the collagen 1A1 gene resulting in abnormal collagen fibrils in type I collagen.

Fetuses with OI type II have an increased risk of preterm birth and low birth weight. Clinically, OI type II is characterized by

- Short stature of prenatal onset
- Short and broad long bones with bowing
- Deep blue sclera
- Small nose with low nasal bridge, which may appear beaked
- Wormian skull
- Respiratory failure due to abnormal ribs with small chest and lung hypoplasia
- Cerebral cortex abnormalities including neuronal migration defects

Most fetuses with OI type II die in the neonatal period.¹

## 43. A. Initial arm and hand involvement in PBPP may affect subsequent cortical development even after full recovery of innervation.

Perinatal brachial plexus palsy (PBPP) is a peripheral nerve injury that is commonly associated with traumatic birth, but not always. Despite improvements in prenatal care, the rate of PBPP has remained stable over the past 3 decades, which may be due in part to an increase in population birth weights. Upper lesions (C5, C6, and ±C7) are more common than lower lesions (C8 and T1) or total lesions (C5–T1).

While the rates of recovery are high (historically reported to be as high as 90%), this may be an overestimate and more recent systematic reviews highlighted the persistence of residual deficits in 20% to 30% of patients.¹,² Lower lesions are more likely to result in long-term impairment than upper lesions (66% vs 21%).³ The recovery of biceps function within the first month after birth predicts full recovery of function by age 2.⁴ If the recovery in biceps function is delayed to 2 to 3 months after birth, full recovery is unlikely. Likewise, poor recovery beyond 3 months is predictive of long-term neurological deficits.⁴,⁵ One of the reasons for poor motor outcomes in some children with PBPP is suboptimal cortical development due to prolonged paralysis at a critical period of brain development.⁶

## 44. A. Chorioretinal lacunae

Aicardi syndrome is a rare disorder occurring in 1 in 100,000 live births¹ and characterized by the triad of agenesis of the corpus callosum, infantile spasms, and chorioretinal lacunae.² Aicardi syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder that predominantly affects females and males with a 46,XXY karyotype.³

## 45. A. Core temperature is most stable and within the desired range when using whole-body cooling mattress with servo control.

Therapeutic hypothermia is standard of care for the treatment of neonates with moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy and is provided as whole-body or selective head cooling. Methods of effective whole-body cooling include servo-controlled cooling mattresses, ice bags, gloves filled with ice, and laminar flow cooling devices. In selective head cooling, active cooling is applied only to the cranium but does result in mild systemic cooling.¹

Core temperature (either esophageal or rectal) has been shown to be most stable when using a servo-controlled cooling mattress. In contrast, the use of water-filled gloves resulted in the least stable temperature maintenance of all the methods tested.

Most of the randomized controlled trials investigating therapeutic hypothermia aimed for a core temperature between 33°C to 34°C and 34°C to 35°C for 72 hours, followed by a slow rewarming phase, with a rewarming rate no faster than 0.5°C per hour.²

## 46. A. Benign neonatal seizure

Two types of benign neonatal seizure syndrome have been described.

- Benign familial neonatal convulsions, which are characterized by a family history of seizures in the neonatal period that spontaneously resolve after a few days or weeks.
- Benign neonatal seizures, which are characterized by onset of seizures between 4 days and 6 days after birth (fifth day fits) with no family history of seizures in the neonatal period.

In both cases, seizures are typically focal clonic and respond well to antiseizure medication. In addition, the neurological examination reveals normal findings, the background electroencephalographic finding is normal, and there are no risk factors for seizures. Antiseizure medications can typically be discontinued after a few weeks or months.¹,²

## 47. E. The onset of opiate withdrawal is 24 to 72 hours following birth but can appear as late as 5 to 7 days after delivery.

Neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) is a multisystem disorder caused by the abrupt discontinuation of chronic fetal exposure to substances used or abused by the pregnant woman during pregnancy. It most commonly follows opioid exposure, but polydrug use can lead to a more severe presentation.¹

Chronic opioid use or abuse during pregnancy results in NAS in about 60% of exposed newborns with onset of symptoms typically between 24 hours and 72 hours after birth. It is important to recognize that a delayed presentation can occur, up to 5 to 7 days after birth.²,³

---

<!-- Page 555 -->

Neurology

The clinical presentation of NAS is variable and includes the following clinical features:

- Neuro-irritability: hypertonia, tremors, hyperreflexia, irritability and restlessness, high-pitched cry, poor sleep, and seizures (rare)
- Autonomic instability: yawning, nasal stuffiness, tachypnea, sweating, sneezing, fever, and skin mottling
- Gastrointestinal disturbances: diarrhea with possible diaper rash with skin excoriation, vomiting, poor feeding, and poor weight gain

In mothers on medication-assisted therapy and with no history of polydrug use, breastfeeding should be promoted and has been shown to be beneficial for both mother and baby.⁴

Toxicology testing is an important tool for the diagnosis of NAS and the recognition of other substance exposures. Cord and meconium drug testing are more sensitive than urine drug testing.⁵

## 48. D. Nemaline myopathy

Nemaline myopathy is one of the most common forms of congenital myopathy and occurs in 1 in 50,000 births. Pathogenic mutation in several genes have been identified (11 to date), most of them encoding sarcomeric thin filament proteins.¹,²

Newborns affected by nemaline myopathy present in the neonatal period with²

- Severe muscle weakness affecting the face, neck, and proximal limb muscles
- Hypotonia
- Dilated cardiomyopathy
- Arthrogyposis multiplex congenita
- Absent deep tendon reflexes

There may also be a history of poor fetal movement and polyhydramnios prenatally. Creatine kinase levels are typically normal. On muscle biopsy, characteristic nemaline rodlike inclusion bodies are seen throughout muscle fibers on modified Gomori trichome staining.

## 49. B. Distribution of oligodendrocyte progenitors

Pre-myelinating oligodendrocyte progenitors (preOLs), which peak in the white matter between 23 weeks' gestation and 32 weeks' gestation, are the primary cellular target in periventricular white matter injury (PWMI). Pre-myelinating oligodendrocytes are more susceptible than more mature cells to oxidative stress, which results from hypoxic-ischemic insults as well as infection/inflammation.¹⁻³ The risk of PWMI declines with the differentiation of preOLs into immature OLs starting at 30 to 32 weeks' postconceptional age and corresponds to the initiation of myelination of human periventricular white matter.

## 50. E. Non-cystic diffuse white matter injury

While cerebral ultrasonography is reliable in the detection of intracranial hemorrhages and cystic periventricular white matter injury (PWMI), it is not sensitive for the detection of diffuse PWMI. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the imaging technique of choice to detect non-cystic diffuse PWMI. For optimal assessment of the periventricular white matter, a combination of conventional MRI sequences

## 51. E. The Sarnat classification scale codifies the neurological examination of a neonate into 6 domains.

The Sarnat score is used in clinical practice to codify the neurological examination and assess the degree of encephalopathy in neonates with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. It was originally published in 1976 by Sarnat and Sarnat¹ and later modified to include scoring on a scale from 1 to 3 in 6 domains of the neurological examination.² The 6 domains included in the modified Sarnat score include the following:

- Level of consciousness
- Activity
- Posture
- Tone
- Primitive reflexes
- Autonomic dysfunction of the pupils, heart rate, and respirations

In most studies, abnormalities in 3 of the 6 domains define moderate to severe encephalopathy.

## 52. E. Negative burst suppression

Amplitude-integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) is used for continuous and noninvasive bedside monitoring of brain activity in sick neonates. The interpretation of the aEEG background activity is an important step when assessing the severity of encephalopathy in a newborn with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy such as the newborn described in the vignette. Several classification systems have been developed for the classification of aEEG background patterns.

Al Naqeeb and colleagues¹ developed a basic classification system based on voltage assessment as follows:

- Normal: lower margin above 5 μV and upper margin above 10 μV
- Moderately abnormal: lower margin below 5 μV and upper margin above 10 μV
- Suppressed: lower margin below 5 μV and upper margin below 10 μV

Hellström-Westas and colleagues² developed a classification system that includes 5 aEEG background patterns as follows:

- Continuous activity: lower amplitude of 5 to 7 μV (up to 10 μV); maximum amplitude of 10 to 25 μV (up to 50 μV)
- Discontinuous activity: variable lower border variable (&lt;5 μV with maximum amplitude &gt;10 μV), leading to a wider bandwidth
- Burst suppression: discontinuous background with minimum amplitude without variability (0–2 μV) and bursts with amplitude &gt;25 μV. Two types of burst suppression pattern are distinguished: positive burst suppression (≥100 bursts per hour) and negative burst suppression (&lt;100 bursts per hour)
- Low-voltage pattern: continuous background pattern of very low amplitude of about 5 μV
- Flat or isoelectric tracing: extremely low background amplitude (significantly below 5 μV)

53. C. According to the meta-analysis, there appears to be a larger degree of improvement in outcomes for neonates who have moderate encephalopathy compared to that seen for neonates who have severe encephalopathy.

Therapeutic hypothermia for neonatal moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy has been shown to be neuroprotective in multiple randomized trials.¹,² Eligibility criteria, while slightly different between the trials, all included a 2-step process for inclusion.

- Biological evidence of a hypoxic-ischemic event, including metabolic acidosis at birth, low 10-minute Apgar score, or continued need for resuscitation at 10 minutes after birth
- Evidence of moderate or severe encephalopathy based on neurological examination

Methods to provide therapeutic hypothermia include the following:

- Whole-body cooling with goal core temperature of 33°C to 34°C
- Selective head cooling with mild systemic cooling with goal core temperature of 34°C to 35°C

In all trials, therapeutic hypothermia was maintained for 72 hours, followed by a slow rewarming phase, with a rewarming rate no faster than 0.5°C per hour.²

Several meta-analyses found that therapeutic hypothermia is associated with improvement in death or major neurodevelopmental disability, mortality, and major neurodevelopmental disability in survivors at 18 to 24 months with a number needed to treat to prevent one death or major disability between 5 and 7.¹,³ While outcomes appear to be improved regardless of the severity of encephalopathy, the degree of neuroprotection is greater in neonates with moderate encephalopathy compared to those with severe encephalopathy.³

## 54. C. Meconium drug screening

Toxicology screening is an important aspect of the treatment of newborns with neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS). Urine drug screening of neonates has limited utility because it will detect only drugs recently used or abused by the mother, resulting in a high false-negative rate. The use of meconium and neonatal hair for drug testing was found to be more sensitive for the detection of opioid and cocaine exposure when compared with a structured maternal interview. While neonatal hair analysis had a sensitivity of 100% for cocaine and 80% for opiate detection, it also had a high false-positive rate for cocaine (13%) and for opiate (20%). In contrast, meconium drug screening had a sensitivity of 87% for cocaine and 77% for opiate detection and no false-positive results for cocaine exposure. In this study, a structured maternal interview was found to have a low sensitivity for the detection of opioid and cocaine exposure.

## 55. E. The finding of WMA at term equivalent postmenstrual age has been associated with motor, cognitive, language, and executive function delays.

White matter abnormalities (WMA) are the most common cause of brain injury in preterm neonates. They are best assessed using brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and the pattern of WMA includes parenchymal lesions, punctate hyperintensities, and diffuse excessive high signal intensity (DEHSI). Of note, assessment of gray matter injury is typically performed at the same time, as it is commonly associated with WMA.

Parenchymal lesions identified at term equivalent postmenstrual age (TEA) include the following:

- Cystic or diffuse periventricular white matter injury (or periventricular leukomalacia)
- Parenchymal hemorrhage
- Infarction
- White matter loss

The presence of parenchymal lesions on brain MRI at term equivalent age is predictive of cerebral palsy at 18 to 21 months with sensitivities between 71% and 100%. The sensitivity remains good at 31 months (87%).

---

<!-- Page 558 -->

Answers

Punctate white matter hyperintensities are also predictive of adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm neonates in a manner that is dependent on

- The number of lesions. The presence of 6 or more lesions is strongly associated with abnormal motor development.³
- The location of the lesions. Lesions in the corona that radiate above the posterior limb of the internal capsule, but not those anterior or posterior, are highly specific for predicting motor disability at 3 to 5 years.⁴
- The timing of the lesions. Punctate hyperintensities identified prior to TEA are not predictive of long-term outcomes.⁵

The presence of DEHSI on brain MRI should be interpreted with caution, particularly when imaged on a 3 Tesla scanner, as this finding may be transient and to date no consistent association with adverse neurodevelopmental outcome has been identified.⁶

Several standardized scoring systems have been developed to quantify the degree of white matter injury identified on brain MRI using conventional magnetic resonance sequences in preterm neonates.⁷,⁸

Heel sticks are one of the most common procedures performed in neonates and have been shown to be more painful than venipunctures.¹ The use of local anesthetics such as EMLA (2.5% lidocaine, 2.5% prilocaine mixture) has not been shown to decrease pain scores secondary to heel lancing.² Nonpharmacological interventions such as nonnutritive sucking, swaddling/facilitated tucking, skin-to-skin care, and rocking/holding have been shown to be helpful in decreasing the newborn's response to acute procedural pain. The use of oral sucrose has also been shown to reduce pain behaviors in preterm and term neonates.³

57. D. Preterm newborns with high S100β levels have higher mortality rates than those who are of otherwise similar weight and gestational age without high S100β levels.

Multiple biomarkers of preterm brain injury have been studied, including protein S100β. This protein is primarily produced by astrocytes and is rapidly released into the bloodstream with blood-brain barrier disruptions.¹ Reference ranges for protein S100β are available for preterm and term neonates. Protein S100β can be measured in many biological fluids including urine, blood, cerebrospinal fluid, saliva, amniotic fluid, and human milk.²

In preterm neonates, elevated S100β levels in the urine are associated with a higher risk of mortality.³ Further, urine S100β concentration at birth has been shown to be higher in preterm neonates who go on to develop an intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), with the highest concentration observed in neonates who later develop severe IVH.⁴

## 58. E. Smooth philtrum

The early recognition of fetal alcohol syndrome is important to improve the long-term outcomes of children with gestational alcohol exposure. In the neonatal period, newborns affected by fetal alcohol syndrome may present with a history of intrauterine growth restriction and a small-for-gestational age birth weight, microcephaly, and the following characteristic facial dysmorphic features:

- Short palpebral fissures
- Smooth philtrum
- Thin vermillion border of the upper lip¹⁻³

## 59. D. The neuroprotective mechanism of EPO may result from the prevention of N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor activation that can occur after hypoxic-ischemic injury.

Erythropoietin (EPO), an endogenous glycoprotein induced by hypoxia hematopoiesis, has been shown to be neuroprotective.¹⁻⁴ The activation of neuronal EPO receptors is neuroprotective via several mechanisms including the following:

- Prevention of N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor activation secondary to hypoxia-ischemia
- Increases expression of antiapoptotic proteins
- Decreased excitotoxicity
- Decreasing apoptosis
- Decreased peroxynitrite production and oxidative stress
- Decreased inflammatory cytokines⁴,⁵

There are a high number of neuronal EPO receptors in the developing human brain.⁶ Recombinant EPO administered systematically has been shown to cross the blood-brain barrier after hypoxia-ischemia.⁷

- Is implemented from birth
- Encompasses a system's approach to care incorporating the neonate, the family, and the environment of care perspectives

At 1 year of age, children with early hypoglycemia also have a 5-fold increase of having a low neuromotor function score.¹

## 62. E. The NICHD whole-body cooling trial patients have been assessed at 6 to 7 years of age, and the direction of the effect favors the hypothermia group for the primary outcome of death or IQ less than 70.

Therapeutic hypothermia for neonatal moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy has been shown to be neuroprotective at 18 to 21 months in multiple randomized trials. Several meta-analyses of these trials found that therapeutic hypothermia is associated with improvement in death or major neurodevelopmental disability, mortality, and major neurodevelopmental disability in survivors at 18 to 24 months with a number needed to treat to prevent one death or major disability between 5 and 7.¹⁻³

Longer-term outcome data at early school age are now also available from the CoolCap and National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD) whole-body cooling trials.

In the CoolCap trial, 45.9% of the neonates enrolled in the trial were evaluated at 7 to 8 years of age. Results from this trial indirectly supported a sustained effect of therapeutic hypothermia on outcomes with a strong correlation between outcomes at 18 months and 7 to 8 years.⁴

The follow-up rate at 6 to 7 years was 91% in the NICHD whole-body cooling trial. In this trial, while the primary outcome of death or IQ less than 70 decreased from 62% in the control group to 47% in the therapeutic hypothermia group, it did not reach statistical significance. There was a significant decrease in the secondary outcome of death from 44% to 28% (P = .04) in the control group and the therapeutic hypothermia group, respectively. In this trial, a low 10-minute Apgar score (&lt;3) was associated with increased risk of death or severe disability (76%, 82%, and 80% for Apgar score of 0, 1, or 2 at 10 minutes, respectively). This association between a low 10-minute Apgar score and outcome persisted at the 6- to 7-year follow-up.⁵

## 63. A. Gastrointestinal dysfunction can be seen along the entire gastrointestinal tract, as smooth and skeletal muscle may be involved.

Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by the expansion of trinucleotide CTG repeats in the noncoding region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) gene on chromosome 19. It is classified as congenital myotonic dystrophy (CMD) and childhood myotonic dystrophy (ChMD).

Myotonic dystrophy type 1 is a multisystem disorder that can affect the respiratory, cardiac, gastrointestinal, musculoskeletal, endocrine, ocular, and auditory systems as follows:

- Patients with CMD can present with respiratory distress at birth secondary to muscle weakness. They are also at increased risk of aspiration and pneumonia. Other respiratory dysfunction affecting patients with DM1 include orthopnea, dyspnea, snoring, and daytime sleepiness.
- Arrhythmias can occur and are the leading cause of death in adulthood. This is an uncommon complication in childhood.
- Gastrointestinal dysfunction can be seen along the entire gastrointestinal tract. This may include poor oral skills and need for gastrostomy tube in the neonatal period, risk of aspiration, abdominal discomfort, bloating, constipation, diarrhea, and fecal incontinence.
- Newborns with CMD are typically hypotonic at birth. Weakness is more common in those who have CMD than those who have ChMD. Hypotonia and weakness improve with time such that most patients attain independent ambulation. Dysphagia, dysarthria, ptosis, and decreased facial expression can be long-term problems due to persistent jaw and facial muscle weakness.
- Patients with DM1 should be monitored for the development of hypothyroidism, hyperparathyroidism, estradiol insufficiency, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, and insulin resistance. These typically develop in adulthood.
- Ophthalmologic complications can occur and include ptosis, weakness of eyelid closure, strabismus, and cataract (in adults).
- Otitis infections are frequent during infancy, and the need for surgical intervention is common.

## 64. B. Meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials showed that therapeutic hypothermia is associated with improvement in the combined outcome of death or major neurodevelopmental disability, mortality, major neurodevelopmental disability in survivors, and cerebral palsy.

Multiple large randomized trials have investigated the effects of therapeutic hypothermia on neurodevelopmental outcomes after neonatal moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). Trial results were consistently in favor of therapeutic hypothermia, and, importantly, none of the trials showed that patients who received hypothermia were more likely to have severe disability.

Meta-analyses of these trials have shown that therapeutic hypothermia is associated with improvement in the following outcomes at 18 to 24 months:

- Death or major neurodevelopmental disability
- Mortality
- Major neurodevelopmental disability in survivors

The number needed to treat to prevent 1 death or major disability is between 5 and 7. $^{1,2}$

School-age outcomes, available from some of the larger trials, support a strong correlation between 18 to 24 months and 6 to 8 years outcomes. $^{3}$

## 65. B. Dejerine-Sottas disease

Dejerine-Sottas disease is a severe hereditary motor and sensory demyelinating neuropathy that is characterized by the following:

- Presentation before age 2 with hypotonia or delayed motor development. Affected patients can present in the neonatal period with hypotonia, arthrogryposis, foot deformities, and respiratory distress often requiring mechanical ventilation support. In addition, there may be a prenatal history of decreased fetal movements, intrauterine growth restriction, and polyhydramnios.¹
- Areflexia on neurological examination.
- Markedly decreased nerve conduction velocity (&lt;12 m/s).
- Significant decrease in myelinated fiber density, thin myelin sheaths, and onion bulb formation on nerve biopsy. This distinguishes Dejerine-Sottas disease from congenital hypo-myelinating neuropathy where complete absence of peripheral nerve myelin is observed along with absence of myelin degeneration evidence such as onion bulb formation.²

Along with congenital hypo-myelinating neuropathy, Dejerine-Sottas disease is currently thought to be part of a broader disease spectrum of congenital myelinopathies. The most common mutations identified in these patients are myelin protein zero, peripheral myelin protein 22, and early growth response 2 mutations.³⁻⁸
