## 66. D. Seizures usually have an appearance of a gradual buildup and decline in frequency and an amplitude that includes repetitive spikes, sharp waves, or a single sinusoidal pattern that lasts 5 to 10 seconds.

Seizures on amplitude-integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) will appear as simultaneous and rapid increases in minimal and maximal amplitudes often preceded by a short period of depressed activity. Seizures detected on aEEG should always be confirmed with a conventional electroencephalogram (EEG). Features characteristic of seizure activity on EEG include the following:

- Gradual buildup and decline in frequency and amplitude
- Presence of repetitive spikes, sharp waves, or a single sinusoidal pattern that lasts 5 to 10 seconds¹

Most neonatal seizures (78%) localize to the centrotemporal area and, therefore, can be detected by aEEG. Seizures that are brief (&lt;30 seconds) are not detected by aEEG.²,³ Finally, it is important to distinguish seizures from artefacts using time-frequency analysis and video recording.⁴,⁵

67. A. As one-third of patients may develop latex allergy, precaution to use non-latex gloves should be taken.

Myelomeningocele are neural tube defects that occur with an incidence of about 2.0 per 1,000 births.¹ The care of newborns with myelomeningocele includes defect closure, surveillance and treatment of hydrocephalus, and coordinated, long-term multidisciplinary care.

Defect closure may occur prenatally in some cases or postnatally. Postnatal closure should occur within 72 hours after birth. Antibiotics are recommended preoperatively to prevent infections. Postoperatively, the development of rapidly progressive hydrocephalus is indicated for 3 to 10 days depending on the level of concern. Overall, 56% to 86% of neonates with myelomeningocele will eventually require a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt.²,³ In some patients, placement of a VP shunt at the same time as the myelomeningocele repair may be indicated.³ When caring for these patients, it is important to use non-latex gloves, as 33% of patients with myelomeningocele develop a latex allergy.⁴ Of note, the preterm delivery of newborns with myelomeningocele to avoid prolonged amniotic fluid exposure has not been shown to consistently improve functional outcomes.

68. C. Diffusion tensor imaging

Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is the most common form of brain injury and cause of neurodevelopmental impairments in neonates born preterm. There are 2 forms of PVL, cystic and diffuse.

- Cystic PVL (cPVL) is characterized by the presence of focal cystic necrotic lesions in the periventricular white matter and can easily be identified on cranial ultrasound. The incidence of cPVL has been decreasing over the past several years and occurs among less than 5% of preterm neonates born at less than 32 weeks’ gestational age.¹
- Diffuse PVL represents the most common form of brain injury observed in neonates born preterm. Studies indicate that diffuse PVL occurs in 17% to 25% of neonates born at less than 32 weeks’ gestational age when imaged using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) at term corrected age.¹,² Diffuse PVL is not reliably detected on cranial ultrasound. Brain MRI, particularly T2-weighed imaging, is the imaging technique of choice for the identification of diffuse PVL. Advanced MRI sequences, such as diffusion tension imaging, have been shown to be particularly sensitive in the detection of diffuse PVL.³,⁴ However, caution should be exercised when only diffuse excessive high signal intensity (DEHSI) is seen on brain image (particularly when imaged on a 3 Tesla scanner), as this finding may be transient and to date no association with adverse neurodevelopmental outcome has been identified.⁵

69. C. Smaller hemorrhage size has been found to have less effect on long-term outcomes.

Cerebellar hemorrhages (CBHs) are now recognized as an important pattern of brain injury in preterm neonates. It is best identified by brain magnetic resonance imaging, as cranial ultrasonography, even when adding the posterior fossa and mastoid views, has been shown to underestimate the presence of CBH.¹

Cerebellar injury is associated with neurodevelopmental impairments in the motor, cognitive, and behavioral domains.²,³ Limperopoulos and colleagues found that preterm neonates with isolated CBH on term equivalent age had neurodevelopmental impairments in 66% of cases compared with 5% in age-matched control participants. Those included (isolated CBH vs controls).³

## 70. B. Due to the complex factors that affect pharmacokinetics in a patient with ECMO, dosing of analgesic and sedative drugs in this patient may be difficult to predict.

Sedation and analgesia is typically required during extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) to prevent unintentional decannulation. In general, higher doses of pain and sedation medications are required in neonates receiving ECMO. Multiple factors influence drug pharmacokinetics during ECMO such that predicting appropriate dosing is challenging.

Some factors result in need to decrease the drug doses including

- Increased volume of distribution because of the ECMO circuit
- Binding/sequestration of drugs in the circuit (up to 40% for lorazepam and up to 50% for morphine)¹
- Hemofiltration of small molecules

Others result in need to decrease drug doses.²

- Decreased drug clearance due to renal and hepatic injury
- Immature organ function in neonates
- Active drug metabolites

## 71. A. Biceps function

Perinatal brachial plexus palsy is a peripheral nerve injury that can lead to long-term neurological impairments. While the rates of recovery have been historically reported to be high (90%), recent systematic reviews indicate that residual deficits occur in 20% to 30% of patients,¹,² with lower lesions being more likely to result in long-term impairment than upper lesions (66% vs 21%).¹

The recovery of biceps function within the first month after birth predicts full recovery of function by age 2. However, if the recovery in biceps function is delayed to 2 to 3 months after birth, full recovery is much less likely. Recovery of biceps function beyond 3 months is associated with long-term deficits.³

## 72. A. Activin receptors are highly expressed in neuronal cells, and preterm newborns with high serum activin A levels have higher risk of developing IVH.

Several biomarkers of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) have been studied including

- Protein S100β, a protein produced by astrocytes and rapidly released into the blood after blood-brain barrier disruptions. Urine and blood concentrations of protein S100β are elevated at birth in infants who later develop IVH, with the levels correlating to the degree of injury.¹

- Activin, a trophic factor highly expressed in neurons. Activin levels are elevated shortly after birth in neonates who develop IVH.²
- Erythropoietin (EPO). In a prospective study, elevated cord EPO levels were shown to be predictive of the development of IVH, even after correcting for gestational age.³
- Chemokine ligand 18 (CCL18). Low cord levels of CCL18 have been associated with increased risk of IVH as well as cerebral palsy.⁴
- Brain type creatine phosphokinase (CPK-BB). Early increase in CPK-BB concentration has been shown to be associated with IVH.⁵
- Interleukin 6 (IL-6) and C-reactive protein (CRP). In asymptomatic pregnant women at risk of preterm delivery, elevated IL-6 and CRP levels were associated with increased IVH risk in their preterm newborn.⁶

## 73. A. Allopurinol is an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, which is a source of superoxide.

Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, has been shown to be neuroprotective in animal studies.¹⁻³ It has also been shown to decrease death or severe disability in one randomized controlled trial of 60 neonates with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.⁴ Current interest has been focused on the prenatal use of allopurinol. Preclinical data indicate that maternal treatment with allopurinol results in decreased superoxide production and hippocampal injury in fetal lambs exposed to intermittent cord occlusion.¹,⁵ Data in humans are somewhat limited, with one randomized controlled trial demonstrating decreased S100β levels in neonates born to mothers treated with allopurinol.⁶ A larger trial of prenatal allopurinol administration did not show a decrease in neuronal damage markers, with potential benefit restricted to girls.⁷ A 5-year follow-up study did not demonstrate a benefit of prenatal allopurinol administration on long-term neurodevelopmental and behavioral outcomes.⁸

## 74. B. IBAIP uses observations of the infant's behavioral interactions with parents after discharge from the nursery.

Developmental care is centered on individualized care based on infant behavior and cues, and multiple programs have been developed to better assess and understand the competencies of an individual infant. These programs encompass preparation for discharge and transition to home.

---

<!-- Page 566 -->

Answers

The Newborn Individualized Developmental Care and Assessment Program (NIDCAP) is a family-centered program implemented from birth that assesses the needs of the newborn based on the observation of behavioral cues prior to, during, and after interventions. Decisions on adjustments to care are based on these observations and after discussion with staff and family. The program supports parents' involvement and facilitates discharge preparation.¹

The Infant Behavioral Assessment and Intervention Program (IBAIP) is a program based on the same theory as NIDCAP but, in addition, includes 6 to 8 home visits after neonatal intensive care unit discharge. In the home setting, IBAIP professionals can support families in understanding how their infant handles environmental information and assist parents in making adjustments to promote neurobehavioral organization and self-regulatory competence.²

The Mother-Infant Transaction Program (MITP) is also designed to support parents in interpreting behavioral cues in their infant and to respond appropriately. It is implemented 1 week before discharge and continues for 3 months after discharge with 4 home visits.³

## 75. B. Care in the neonatal intensive care unit for more than 5 days, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, craniofacial anomalies, assisted ventilation, and hyperbilirubinemia requiring exchange transfusion are some factors that increase risk of hearing loss.

Hearing impairment occurs in 2% to 4% of neonates admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) for more than 5 days (a 10-fold increased risk).¹,²

Risk factors for hearing impairment include very low birth weight, NICU stay greater than 5 days, ototoxic medications, history of exchange transfusion, history of TORCH infection, history of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, craniofacial anomalies, culture-positive meningitis, and congenital syndromes associated with hearing loss. On average, significant hearing loss is diagnosed at age 14 months.¹ Early identification and treatment is key to improving outcomes.¹⁻⁴ Despite that, only about 62% of neonates with hearing loss are enrolled in early intervention.³

## 76. D. Renal cysts

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder due to a mutation in one of the peroxyn (PEX) genes resulting in the intracellular accumulation of very long chain fatty acids. It represents a severe form of peroxisome biogenesis disorders that also include adrenoleukodystrophy, infantile Refsum disease, and rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata.¹ Patients affected by Zellweger syndrome typically present in the neonatal period with the following:

- Characteristic facial features (high forehead, large fontanelles with wide sutures, epicanthus, shallow orbital bridge, and anteverted nares)
- Abnormal retinal pigmentation
- Marked hypotonia
- Poor feeding
- Hepatomegaly and hepatic dysfunction
- Renal cysts
- Shortened proximal limbs
- Chondrodysplasia punctata

The presence of cortical malformations of the peri-sylvian and peri-rolandic regions, hypomyelination, and subependymal germinolytic cysts on brain image are highly suggestive of Zellweger syndrome.

Agenesis of the corpus callosum can also occur but, in contrast to Aicardi syndrome, is not a requirement for the diagnosis of Zellweger syndrome.²

77. E. There is a decrease of oxygen and glucose in proportion to the degree of asphyxia, which is associated with a switch from aerobic to anaerobic metabolism.

In the neonatal period, the brain utilizes 70% or more of the glucose produced by the liver. Exposure to hypoxic-ischemic stress leads to a switch from aerobic to anaerobic metabolism and in turn decreases glucose delivery in proportion to the degree of asphyxia. Because of the limited energy stores in neonates as well as an immature counter-regulatory response, this results in hypoglycemia.

Studies indicate that both hypoglycemia (particularly early after the insult) and hyperglycemia are associated with poor outcomes in newborns with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). However, there are no randomized clinical trials to guide clinicians as to what the optimal glucose level target should be in newborns affected by HIE.¹⁻⁴

80. C. Rewarming should take place at a rate not greater than 0.5°C per hour.

Therapeutic hypothermia for the treatment of moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy occurs in 4 distinct phases.¹,²

---

<!-- Page 568 -->

Answers

1. An induction phase during which the core temperature is rapidly decreased to the goal temperature.
2. A maintenance phase during which core temperature is tightly maintained between 33°C to 34°C (whole-body cooling) and 34°C to 35°C (selective head cooling) for a duration of 72 hours. The use of sedation during cooling should be strongly considered, particularly in infants with agitation or excessive shivering, as this may lead to increased metabolic demand.
3. A rewarming phase during which the core temperature is slowly increased. Rewarming rates of 0.5°C or less per hour are recommended to avoid temperature overshoot and rebound seizures. During the rewarming phase, neonates should be monitored for hypotension.
4. A normothermia phase to prevent hyperthermia.

## 81. A. Children in a comprehensive early behavioral intervention program have shown improvements in IQ, adaptive skills, and diagnostic status.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is more common in children born preterm.¹ In a prospective study with rigorous diagnosis of ASD, low birth weight infants (&lt;2,000 g) were found to have prevalence of ASD of 5%, 3 times that of the general population.²

In children younger than 3 years at the time of diagnosis, services are available through the state early intervention system. Early developmental behavioral interventions that are family centered and include parent training, behavioral therapy, speech therapy, and occupational therapy have been shown to result in improvements in IQ, adaptive skills, and diagnostic status after 2 years.³ All toddlers with ASD improve with early intervention, with the highest benefits seen in those with higher cognitive scores pre-intervention.⁴

## 82. B. aEEG uses single EEG channels to show EEG amplitude as a compressed trend.

The amplitude-integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) is generated from the raw EEG signal using the following steps:

- The signal is amplified.
- A narrow filter (&lt;2 Hz and &gt;15 Hz) is applied. This greatly minimizes artefacts including muscle activity, and environmental electrical interference.
- The signal is rectified (negative voltages are converted to positive values; peak-to-peak amplitudes are measured and weighed toward alpha frequencies).
- The signal is smoothed, plotted on a semilogarithmic scale to emphasize lower voltage activity, and displayed on a logarithmic scale between 10 and 100 μV.
- Finally, the signal is viewed in a highly compressed timescale (6 cm/h), which allows for optimal assessment of trends in cerebral activity.¹,²

The most commonly used electrode placements include central (C3–C4), central-parietal (C3–P3 and C4–P4), and parietal (P3–P4) derivations. Placement of electrodes in the frontal region should be avoided because of decreased sensitivity to seizure detection.³

83. B. The finding of these lesions at term postmenstrual gestation (such as in this infant) is more worrisome than if it was found prior to term postmenstrual age, because of the associated risk of adverse neurodevelopmental outcome.

Punctate white matter hyperintensities are one of the patterns of white matter abnormalities that can be identified on brain magnetic resonance imaging in preterm infants. These lesions are predictive of adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes depending on the number, location, and timing of lesions. Studies indicate that the presence of 6 or more lesions is strongly associated with abnormal motor development.¹ The location of the lesions is also very important to consider, with lesions in the corona radiate above the posterior limb of the internal capsule being highly specific of motor disability at 3 to 5 years.² Finally, punctate hyperintensities identified prior to term equivalent postmenstrual age have not been shown to be predictive of long-term outcomes.³

86. C. Lack of a normal aEEG background, abnormal neurological examination finding, and MRI findings consistent with HIE.

A hypoxic-ischemic insult may be suspected in children with neonatal encephalopathy if

- There is a perinatal history consistent with hypoxia-ischemia (ie, placental abruption, uterine rupture, prolonged fetal bradycardia).
- A metabolic acidosis is present in cord blood or early baby blood gas assessments.

A brain magnetic resonance imaging study with a pattern of injury consistent with a hypoxic-ischemic insult confirms the diagnosis.

In neonates with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, the following findings are helpful to consider when assessing the risk of adverse long-term outcomes:

- A 10-minute Apgar score less than 3 is associated with a high risk of early neonatal death with an adjusted relative risk of 359·4 (95% CI, 277·3–465·9).¹
- A persistently abnormal neurological examination finding beyond 72 hours after birth is associated with increased risk of death or disability with an adjusted odds ratio of 18.61 (95% CI, 5.37–64.49) compared with neonates who improved in fewer than 24 hours after birth.²
- A persistently abnormal amplitude-integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) background beyond 72 hours after birth. In contrast, a very abnormal aEEG during the first 24 to 48 hours that normalizes after 48 hours is a good prognostic sign.³

# 87. C. Greater concentration of chloride in the neuron

Seizures are common in the neonatal period because of the excitation/inhibition imbalance characteristic of the newborn brain, largely due to delay in the maturation of inhibitory γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptors. In the mature brain, GABA receptor activation results in a net influx of chloride into the cell, resulting in decreased cellular membrane resting potential and thereby inhibition of action potentials. In contrast, the immature brain is characterized by higher intraneuronal chloride concentration; therefore, GABA receptor-mediated inhibition is diminished or may even have a net excitatory effect. This developmental asynchrony in excitatory and inhibitory systems in the brain may explain why neonatal seizures have an incomplete response to medications that act via GABAergic mechanisms such as phenobarbital and benzodiazepines.¹,²

# 88. B. Germinal matrix vulnerability

Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is a common complication of preterm birth, and severe IVH has been shown to adversely affect the outcomes of preterm neonates.

In preterm neonates, IVH originates in the germinal matrix, a highly vascular structure located in the caudothalamic groove and overlying the caudate nucleus. The germinal matrix is a site of active cellular production. Early in pregnancy, neurons are produced and migrate to the cortex. Between 23 and 32 weeks’ gestation, glial cells are produced in the germinal matrix. As the need for cellular production decreases with advancing gestation, the germinal matrix involutes, with almost complete involution by 36 weeks’ gestation.

The development of IVH is multifactorial and involves anatomical as well as physiological factors. First, the germinal matrix lies within an arterial end zone and is directly connected to the deep galenic venous system. In addition to the tenuous capillary integrity and vulnerability to hypoxia-ischemia, extravascular factors such as poor vascular support and increased fibrinolytic activity further increase the risk of bleeding. Physiological instability after birth and in the setting of limited ability to autoregulate cerebral blood flow further compounds the problem.¹,²

# 89. C. Morphine

Nonpharmacological measures and family-focused care are the cornerstone of therapy for neonates affected by neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS). For newborns with opioid withdrawal who require pharmacological intervention, treatment with an opioid (most commonly morphine or methadone) is the recommended first-line treatment of choice.¹⁻³ In a Cochrane review, the use of opioid as first-line pharmacological therapy for newborns with NAS due to opioid withdrawal was associated with improved resolution of symptoms and decreased likelihood of needing a second agent compared with phenobarbitone or diazepam.⁴

# 90. A. Congenital disorder of glycosylation

Congenital disorders of glycosylation are autosomal recessive disorders secondary to abnormal synthesis of N-linked oligosaccharides. These oligosaccharides are critical for synthesis of glycoproteins and glycolipids.

Affected neonates may present with microcephaly and hypotonia. Physical examination may reveal the following:

- Abnormal distribution of fat (most prominently in the suprapubic, iliac, and buttock regions)
- Inverted nipples
- Strabismus

Cardiomyopathy, protein-losing enteropathy, hypoglycemia, coagulopathy, and seizures may also occur. Brain imaging, if performed, may demonstrate progressive atrophy.¹

# 91. B. Corticospinal pathway

Prenatal ultrasonographic techniques are used to document neural development (normal and abnormal) or damage. Newer techniques, such as 3- and 4-dimensional ultrasonography, can allow further exploration of the neuromaturation of the fetus. Using these techniques, the presence of active abduction of the thumb indicates intact upper motor control and corticospinal pathways. In contrast, fetuses with severe brain damage cannot open their hands spontaneously, and active abduction of the thumb is not seen.¹

# 92. E. 2 to 4 weeks of age

Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is the most common form of brain injury and cause of neurodevelopmental impairments in neonates born preterm. There are 2 forms of PVL.

- Cystic PVL (cPVL) is characterized by the presence of focal cystic necrotic lesions in the periventricular white matter and can easily be identified on cranial ultrasound, typically at 2 to 4 weeks of age. The incidence of cPVL has been decreasing over the past several years and occurs among fewer than 5% of neonates born at less than 32 weeks' gestational age.¹
- Diffuse PVL represents the most common form of brain injury observed in neonates born preterm. Studies indicate that diffuse PVL occurs in 17% to 25% of neonates born at less than 32 weeks' gestational age when imaged using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) at term corrected age.¹² Diffuse PVL is not reliably detected on cranial ultrasound, and brain MRI, particularly T2-weighed imaging, is the imaging technique of choice for the identification of diffuse PVL.³

# 93. D. Melatonin has been shown to reduce the extent of neutrophil migration in animal models of hypoxic-ischemic brain injury.

Melatonin is a hormone with multiple cellular effects, some of which target known mechanisms of hypoxia-ischemia-induced brain injury. These effects include

- Decreased free radical injury via scavenging hydroxyl radical and peroxynitrite, and reducing superoxide production.¹²
- Anti-inflammatory activity with decreased neutrophil migration, decreased macrophage-activated microglia activation, and decreased proinflammatory cytokine production such as interleukin 2 and interleukin 6.³⁴

In newborns with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, melatonin administration within 6 hours after birth decreased levels of malonaldehyde, a product of lipid peroxidation.⁵

# 94. B. Cervical nerve root 6

Perinatal brachial plexus palsy (PBPP) is classified according to the location of the nerve injury as follows:

- Upper lesion (C5, C6, and ±C7), characterized by poor shoulder function and variable hand function. Erb palsy is an upper trunk lesion (C5 and C6) resulting in the "waiter's tip" posture, with shoulder adduction and internal rotation, elbow extension, forearm pronation, and wrist flexion.
- Lower lesion (C8 and T1), characterized by good shoulder function and poor hand function. Klumpke palsy is a lower trunk lesion (C8 and T1) affecting wrist and finger flexors as well as intrinsic hand muscles. Horner syndrome occurs alongside lower lesions when the sympathetic fibers of T1 are injured.
- Total lesion (C5-T1), characterized by poor function in the entire arm and accounting for 18% of all PBPP cases. $^{1,2}$

# 95. E. EDS type VII (arthrochalasis)

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) represents a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by joint laxity, skin abnormalities, and skeletal changes, as well as cardiovascular and ophthalmologic abnormalities. Among EDS, types VIIA and VIIB (arthrochalasis) are the most likely to be recognized in the newborn period.

Affected newborns may present with

- Bilateral hip dislocations
- Congenital patellar dislocations with hyperextension of the knees
- Hypotonia secondary to excessive joint laxity

A history of breech in presentation may also be present.

EDS types VIIA and VIIB are autosomal dominant disorders caused by mutations in exon 6 of the COL1A1 or COL1A2 gene. $^{1}$

# 96. C. Fatty acid ethyl ester

The early recognition of fetal alcohol syndrome is important to improve the long-term outcomes of children with gestational alcohol exposure. However, because of maternal underreporting, affected children may have significant delays in diagnosis. As such, methods to detect fetal alcohol exposure are actively being investigated. Among those, the most promising is the detection of fatty acid ethyl esters (FAEEs). While they are present in the meconium of neonates born to mothers who abstain or mothers with poorly controlled diabetes and glycosuria, FAEEs are more prevalent among the meconium of neonates born to mothers with problematic drinking. In addition, a FAEE value greater 600 ng has a sensitivity of 100% and a specificity of 98.4% for exogenous alcohol exposure in utero. $^{1-3}$

## 97. B. Chromatin aggregation

Following a hypoxic-ischemic insult, both necrotic and apoptotic cell death occur.

Necrotic cell death is characterized by

- Passive cell swelling
- Rapid energy loss with subsequent disruption of internal homeostasis and lysis of the nucleus, organelles, and plasma cell membranes
- Release of intracellular components with resultant local inflammatory response

Apoptotic (programmed) cell death occurs in the days to weeks following the hypoxic-ischemic insult. It is characterized by $^{1,2}$

- Cell shrinkage
- Coarse chromatin aggregation and nuclear DNA fragmentation
- Nuclear pyknosis
- Extrusion of membrane bound cytoplasmic fragments (or apoptotic bodies)

## References

1. Wyllie AH, Kerr JFR, Currie AR. Cell death: the significance of apoptosis. Int Rev Cytol. 1980;68:251-306

## 98. A. The Creating Opportunities for Parent Empowerment program, based on the theory of self-regulation and control, is designed to help parents interpret their babies and has been shown to reduce length of stay.

Developmentally supportive interventions and family-centered care are important aspects in the care of preterm neonates admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). Developmental care is centered on individualized care based on newborn behavior and cues, and multiple programs incorporating these concepts have been developed.

The Newborn Individualized Developmental Care and Assessment Program (NIDCAP) is a family-centered program that is implemented from birth and assesses the needs of the newborn based on the observation of behavioral cues prior to, during, and after interventions. Decisions on adjustments to care are based on these observations and after discussion with staff and family. Nurseries can obtain a NIDCAP certification after staff training and a standardized examination process. $^{1}$

The Infant Behavioral Assessment and Intervention Program (IBAIP) is a program based on the same theory as NIDCAP but, in addition, includes 6 to 8 home visits after NICU discharge. In the home setting, IBAIP providers can support families in understanding how their infant handles environmental information and assist parents in making adjustments to promote neurobehavioral organization and self-regulatory competence. $^{2}$

The Creating Opportunities for Parent Empowerment (COPE) program is based on the theory of self-regulation and control. It utilizes standardized information material designed to help parents learn about infant behavior, respond in a supportive manner, and facilitate their infant's development. The COPE program has been shown to reduce length of stay. $^{3}$

Couplet care is based on the concept coupling the care of the baby with that of the postpartum mother.

## 99. C. The parents are likely to be of Ashkenazi Jewish background.

The neonate described in the vignette has features suggestive of familial dysautonomia or Riley-Day syndrome. This hereditary and autonomic neuropathy type 3 is characterized by

- Ashkenazi Jewish parents. Familial dysautonomia almost always occurs in Ashkenazi Jewish parents with a carrier frequency of 1 in 36 and an incidence of 1 in 3,700 live births in this population. $^{1}$
- Feeding difficulty with recurrent aspiration, nasal cry, jerky limb movements, hypotonia, and episodes of marked irritability with retrocollis and opisthotonos. $^{2,3}$

On examination, corneal reflexes are absent, deep tendon reflexes are decreased, and there is absent fungiform papillae, lack of axonal flare after intradermal histamine, and defective lacrimation. $^{4}$

## 100. C. Children who do not require a shunt as infants are more likely to have higher achievement in education than those children who had shunts, with children who require shunt revision more likely to have lower achievement.

Most neonates with myelomeningocele survive and about 56% to 86% will require ventriculoperitoneal shunt placement.¹,² Mortality after initial repair is most commonly secondary to Arnold-Chiari malformation type II progression and shunt malfunction. Shunt malfunction is a common problem within the first year and is important to recognize in a timely fashion. Patients may present with headache, vomiting, and lethargy or with subtler signs such as deteriorating school performance, worsening urological function, or worsening lower extremity function.³ Brain imaging is not always helpful, emphasizing the need for a high index of suspicion for shunt malfunction diagnosis in patients with a myelomeningocele.

The long-term outcomes of patients with myelomeningoceles are as follows:

- 47% of patients are able to ambulate in the community.
- 80% of patients achieve social urinary continence, with 85% requiring intermittent catheterization.
- Of men, 12% to 75% have erectile dysfunction.
- Of patients, 70% to 75% have a normal IQ.
- 60% of patients have a learning disability.

Patients who do not need a shunt are more likely to have higher achievement in education than those children who had shunts, particularly those who required shunt revisions.¹,⁴

## 101. D. The degree of placental transfer for SSRIs is dependent on the molecular weight, plasma protein binding, and pharmacokinetics of the medication.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) increase serotonin (5-HT) levels by blocking the serotonin transporter. All SSRIs can cross the placenta to a variable degree dependent on their molecular weight, plasma protein binding, and pharmacokinetics.¹

They can also cross the blood-brain barrier² and, therefore, can affect fetal 5-HT levels. Activin A, a neuroprotein expressed after acute neuronal damage that may have a role in neuroprotection, is elevated in the amniotic fluid and cord blood of neonates born to mothers on SSRIs.³ However, whether this indicates neuroprotection or direct neuronal damage from SSRIs remains unclear at this time.

102. B. The clinical and EEG findings corresponding to each stage are not necessarily specific to the etiology of HIE but are manifestations of cerebral dysfunction that may occur with any newborn encephalopathy.

Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is categorized in 3 stages of increasing severity as delineated by Sarnat and Sarnat. The Sarnat classification score was developed with 21 neonates more than 36 weeks' gestation with HIE. These neonates were followed by serial neurological examinations, electroencephalogram (EEG) for the first 6 days after birth, as well as follow-up at 12 months after birth. Results from this study indicated that neonates with stage 1 (mild) encephalopathy or stage 2 (moderate) encephalopathy for less than 5 days had a good early childhood prognosis. The EEG correlated with the degree of encephalopathy on neurological examination but was not specific to hypoxia-ischemia as the cause of the encephalopathy.¹

103. E. The most common location of a myelomeningocele is lumbosacral but can be at any spinal segment. Myelomeningoceles are secondary to a failure of primary neurulation and occur most commonly in the lumbosacral region. 105. C. Muscle weakness of the diaphragm, abdominal, and intercostal muscles can lead to poor forced vital capacity.

Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by the expansion of trinucleotide CTG repeats in the noncoding region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) gene on chromosome 19.

In the pediatric population, DM1 is classified as congenital myotonic dystrophy (CMD, onset of symptoms at birth) and childhood myotonic dystrophy (ChMD, onset of symptoms between 1 and 10 years). Newborns with CMD present in the neonatal period with hypotonia, respiratory distress, poor feeding, talipes equinovarus, and eyelid ptosis.¹

Respiratory distress in the newborn period is caused by muscle weakness of the diaphragm, intercostal, and abdominal muscles, leading to decreased forced vital capacity. In addition, weakness of inspiratory, expiratory, and facial muscles results in poor cough effort and impairment in secretion clearing with high risk for aspiration and pneumonia. Most newborns requiring mechanical ventilation support in the newborn period can wean off their support. The mean duration of respiratory support is 26 weeks, and the 1-year mortality among infants with CMD requiring mechanical ventilation for more than 30 days is 25%.²

# 106. E. Sleep-wake cycles

The use of bedside amplitude-integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) monitoring has been shown to be helpful in predicting later neurological outcomes in term neonates with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.

Severely abnormal background patterns such as burst suppression on flat tracing or continuous low-voltage patterns without recovery at 24 hours predict poor outcomes with sensitivities of 91% to 95%, positive predictive values of 86% to 88%, and negative predictive values of 91% to 96%.¹⁻³

The timing of background pattern recovery is another important prognostic factor. Neonates with severely abnormal background patterns, including burst suppression, continuous low voltage, and flat tracing, but who recover to a normal background pattern within 48 hours after birth have a better prognosis, particularly those with earlier recovery of the aEEG background pattern.⁴ Similarly, earlier emergence of sleep-wake cycles is a good prognostic sign. Presence or absence of sleep-wake cycle at 36 hours after birth was found to correctly predict neurodevelopmental outcomes at a median age of 19 months in 82% of patients.⁵

# 107. A. Care that emphasizes behavioral individuality

The Newborn Individualized Developmental Care and Assessment Program (NIDCAP) is a family-centered program that aims to support the newborn's development through coordinated, multidisciplinary care, based on the systematic observation of behavioral cues prior to, during, and after caregiving. From these observations, developmentally appropriate and individualized care plans are formulated and may include interventions such as

- Modification of the environment of care wherever possible to decrease stress
- Adjustment of timing of nursing and medical interventions
- Family support
- Coordination of developmental care

The program is instituted from birth, and all care plan decisions occur after inclusive discussions with staff and family.¹

# 108. C. Hypothermia

Therapeutic hypothermia is the only approved therapy for the treatment of moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy in neonates more than 35 to 36 weeks' gestational age. Therapeutic hypothermia has been studied in multiple large randomized trials that all showed a beneficial effect on 18- to 21-month neurodevelopmental outcomes. Meta-analyses of these trials indicate that therapeutic hypothermia is associated with decreased death or major neurodevelopmental disability, mortality, and major neurodevelopmental disability in survivors at 18 to 24 months. The number needed to treat to prevent 1 death or major disability is between 5 and 7.¹,² School-age outcomes, available from some of the CoolCap and the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development whole-body cooling trial, support a sustained benefit of therapeutic hypothermia at 6- to 8-year outcomes.³

## 109. A. Clinical examination

Perinatal brachial plexus palsy is a peripheral nerve injury that can lead to long-term neurological impairments in 20% to 30% of patients.¹² Lesions to the lower trunk (C8 and T1) are more likely to result in long-term neurological impairment than lesions to the upper trunk (C5, C6, and ±C7): 66% of cases and 21% of cases, respectively.¹

The clinical assessment of function recovery, particularly that of biceps function,³ is critical in the decision to proceed with surgery for determination of the location and extent of the lesion as well as reconstruction of the brachial plexus. Typically, decisions to proceed with microsurgery over continued observation begin around 2 months after birth.⁴⁻⁶

## 110. B. Cases that developed in utero have been described.

Acute inflammatory demyelinating neuropathy (AIDP), also known as Guillain-Barré syndrome, is an acquired demyelinating neuropathy and is rare in the neonatal period. It is important to distinguish acquired demyelinating neuropathy from inherited peripheral neuropathy because of different treatment options. Clues that an acquired demyelinating neuropathy is present include the absence of family history, a negative genetic workup, the presence of inflammation on nerve biopsy, and asymmetrical neurophysiological findings. The spontaneous resolution of symptoms confirms the diagnosis.¹

Neonates affected by AIDP may present with generalized hypotonia, progressive weakness, bulbar dysfunction, and respiratory distress. The neurological examination is significant for hyporeflexia. Prenatal onset of AIDP has been described with decreased fetal movements. In some cases, a triggering event in the mother can be identified, but not always. The disease typically resolves in less than 8 weeks.²⁻⁶

## 111. A. Appropriate personnel should be available, the infant can be fed 30 to 45 minutes prior to the MRI, magnetic resonance-compatible monitoring equipment should be placed, and the infant should be swaddled to minimize motion.

Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is an important tool in the diagnosis and monitoring of brain injury in term and preterm neonates. While most MRIs are performed at term equivalent postmenstrual age, MRIs can be safely performed in the preterm population. For preterm and term neonates and infants, MRI can be performed without sedation in most cases. The following general guidelines should be considered when performing brain MRI in the neonatal population:

- Adequate personnel must be available for preparation, transport, and monitoring. This should include personnel skilled in airway management for neonates requiring respiratory support or who are not medically stable.

Answers

- Preparation of the newborn should begin 30 to 45 minutes prior to scan time and includes connection to magnetic resonance-compatible equipment for continuous in scanner monitoring, removal of any metal-containing objects, placement of earmuffs, and plan for newborn swaddling. If available, the use of a vacuum bag is helpful to secure the newborn in place.
- Neonates do not have to be NPO (nil per os, or nothing by mouth) for the procedure. In fact, feeding 20 to 30 minutes prior to the scan may be helpful in the successful completion of an MRI study without sedation.¹,²

## 112. A. A combination of atropine, fentanyl, and vecuronium can be administered.

The American Academy of Pediatrics has issued a policy statement recommending that all newborns receive analgesic premedication for endotracheal intubation with the exception of emergent intubations.¹ Most commonly, premedication for endotracheal intubation includes a rapid-acting analgesic (fentanyl, slow infusion), a vagolytic (atropine), and a short duration muscle relaxant.² This type of combination has been shown to decrease both time to intubation and number of intubation attempts.³ If the plan is to intubate for surfactant administration followed by rapid extubation, the use of a muscle relaxant should be omitted. For this situation, shorter acting drugs such as propofol or remifentanil are under investigation.⁴

Multiple agents are currently being investigated for the treatment of neonatal hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. Those include

- Erythropoietin (prevents N-methyl-D-aspartate [NMDA] receptor activation and decreases free radical toxicity and inflammation)

- Allopurinol (inhibits xanthine oxidase and superoxide radical production)

## 114. B. External granular layer

Cerebellar development is prolonged beginning at 4 weeks' gestation and completing several weeks after birth. Because of this extended developmental period, the cerebellum is susceptible to a wide range of insults that, in addition to injury, may lead to abnormal cerebellar development. The external granular layer is particularly vulnerable to injury because it is relatively under-vascularized, and developmental events originating in the external granular cell layer occur over an extended period.¹,²

## 115. A. Colpocephaly

Agenesis of the corpus callosum occurs in 1 in 4,000 live births,¹ and the incidence increases to 2.3% among developmentally disabled populations.² Agenesis of the corpus callosum is associated with other brain malformations in 50% to 70% of patients²,³ and can be part of more than 100 syndromes, more prominently Aicardi syndrome and Zellweger syndrome.⁴

Agenesis of the corpus callosum can also occur in isolation. Complete agenesis of the corpus callosum results in the formation of the Probst bundle (secondary to the fibers that were destined to connect the 2 hemispheres traversing in anterior-posterior direction) and colpocephaly (enlargement of the occipital horns of the lateral ventricle).

## 116. B. Phenobarbital has lower protein binding and fewer interactions with other medications.

While phenobarbital is used more commonly than phenytoin, both antiseizure medications are equally effective in the treatment of neonatal seizures.¹ Disadvantages of phenytoin over phenobarbital include the following:

- Difficulties in maintaining therapeutic levels after transition to oral phenytoin.
- Higher protein binding of phenytoin and increased risk of drug-drug interactions.
- Risk of irritation and tissue injury with extravasation due to poor solubility at neutral pH and precipitation in solutions containing dextrose. This problem is greatly mitigated by the use of fosphenytoin.
- Possible bradycardia with rapid injections.

One advantage of phenytoin over phenobarbital is that it is less likely to cause sedation.

Both drugs are metabolized in the liver.²

## 117. A. Elevated cord blood concentrations of S100β have been linked to moderate or severe HIE.

In a neonate with moderate hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), the following biomarker profile is expected:

- Elevated S100β protein levels in cord blood or urine. Studies indicate that a protein S100β concentration greater than 2.02 mcg/L in cord blood has a sensitivity of 87% and a specificity of 88% for predicting the moderate or severe HIE.¹
- Elevated serum levels of neuron-specific enolase (&gt;40 mcg/L) between 4 hours and 48 hours after birth.²
- Elevated interleukin 6 levels in cord blood. Interleukin 6 levels in cord blood have been shown correlate with the severity of HIE as well as with the 2-year neurodevelopmental outcomes.³
- Elevated glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), a cytoskeletal filament protein specific to astrocytes and released into the bloodstream after astrocyte death. Serum levels of GFAP 0.15 ng/mL or higher on neonatal intensive care unit admission have been shown to be predictive of abnormal brain magnetic resonance imaging findings.⁴
- Elevated brain-derived neurotrophic factor in cord plasma.⁵

118. A. Although SSRI use has been associated with Arnold-Chiari malformations type I, because of the nature of studies, it is difficult to interpret whether SSRI exposure itself increases that risk or that another factor linked to higher likelihood of SSRI use plays the larger role.

In utero exposure to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) has been associated with a small increase in the risk of neurological anomalies in some studies, mostly driven by exposure to fluoxetine and paroxetine.¹

In a Bayesian analysis, Reefhuis and colleagues found an increased risk of anencephaly with paroxetine (odds ratio [OR] 3.2, 95% CI, 1.6–6.2) and an increased risk of craniosynostosis with fluoxetine (OR 1.9, 95% CI, 1.1–3.0). In this study, the use of sertraline was not associated with an increased risk of congenital malformations.²

In a population-based study, Bérard and colleagues found that the use of both sertraline and non-sertraline SSRIs led to an increased risk of craniosynostosis.³

Another study indicated that the use of SSRIs also increased the risk of Arnold-Chiari malformation type I in the newborn when compared to babies born to mothers with no history of depression or SSRI use (18% vs 2%, P = .003). In this cohort study, the duration of exposure was found to be a factor.⁴

Overall, studies do not distinguish between the effect of depression and that of SSRI exposure.

Because the absolute risk of neurological malformation is small, discontinuation of SSRI therapy in a pregnant woman with depression and well-controlled symptoms on SSRIs is not recommended.

119. E. Sonic hedgehog gene signaling inhibition

The teratogenic effects of alcohol in the brain are mediated by multiple mechanisms including

- Alcohol is an agonist to the γ-amino butyric acid A receptor and an antagonist to the N-methyl-D-aspartic acid receptor, leading to apoptosis.¹
- Increased free radical production with subsequent lipid peroxidation and cell death.²
- Increased nitric oxide production resulting in peroxynitrite production.²
- Alcohol affects pathways important in central nervous system organization and neuronal cell migration.³,⁴
- Inhibition of the sonic hedgehog gene signaling, which plays a critical role in early morphogenesis of the limb and midline brain structures.⁵

120. B. Cryptorchidism is present in nearly all affected males.

Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) should be considered in the differential diagnosis of neonates presenting with hypotonia. The hypotonia improves by age 2 to 3. Other clinical features of PWS in the neonatal period include lethargy, decreased spontaneous movement, weak cry, and feeding difficulties.

The following physical examination findings may also raise the suspicion for PWS:

- Hypogonadism and cryptorchidism (80%–90% of affected males)
- Characteristic facial features including dolichocephaly, narrowed bifrontal diameter, almond-shaped palpebral fissures, and narrow nasal bridge

Deletions are most common (65%–75% of cases), followed by maternal uniparental disomy in 20% to 30% of patients and imprinting defects in 1% to 3% of patients.¹,²

## 121. B. Cerebral palsy is a clinical description and lacks specific pathological or radiographic features, with some neonates with CP having a normal brain magnetic resonance imaging scan.

Cerebral palsy (CP) is a clinical description of disorders related to movement and motor abnormalities that are nonprogressive in nature and secondary to injury to the developing fetal or infant brain. Cerebral palsy is associated with impairments in cognitive, communication, and social functioning.

The prevalence of CP ranges from 1.5 to 2.5 per 1,000 live births in the United States.¹,² The incidence of CP is higher among those born preterm, with the highest incidence seen among neonates born at less than 25 weeks' gestation (15%–20%).³,⁴ While preterm birth is a risk factor for CP, 50% of all cases of CP occur in term neonates.⁵

A diagnosis of CP is typically not formally made until age 2, but early signs such as abnormal tone, feeding issues, early hand preference, prominent fisting, asymmetrical crawling, persistence of primitive reflexes, ankle clonus, and scissoring of legs may raise the suspicion of CP earlier.⁶

## 122. A. Neonates with mild encephalopathy have been shown to have more behavioral problems such as anxiety, depression, and attention regulation, compared with control participants.

Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is categorized in 3 stages of increasing severity as delineated by Sarnat and Sarnat.¹ Neonates with mild encephalopathy or moderate encephalopathy lasting less than 5 days have improved outcomes compared with those with prolonged moderate encephalopathy or those with severe encephalopathy. In a meta-analysis, adverse outcomes were observed in 0%, 32%, and 100% of neonates with mild, moderate, and severe encephalopathy score, respectively.²

Importantly, while neonates with mild encephalopathy do not have severe neurodevelopmental disabilities, they are at increased risk of the following adverse outcomes compared with control participants:

- Lower mean (SD) IQ scores (99 [17] vs 109 [12])³
- Increased rates of behavioral problems at 9 to 10 years of age such as anxiety, depression, attention regulation, and thought problems⁴

## 123. B. Glycine

The N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor is an ionotropic glutamate receptor that is overexpressed in the immature brain. It is the predominant mediator of excitotoxicity in the developing brain. N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor activity is regulated by several binding sites.¹

- A neurotransmitter (glutamate or NMDA) binding site. Agonist binding to this site leads to channel opening and intracellular calcium influx.
- A co-agonist (coactivator) glycine binding site.
- An open-channel blocker MK-801 binding site.
- A inhibitory voltage-dependent magnesium-binding site. The immature NMDA receptor is less likely to be blocked by magnesium than more mature channels.
- A inhibitory divalent cation site that binds zinc.
- A polyamine binding site.

## 124. E. Transient neonatal myasthenia gravis

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder affecting the neuromuscular junction and resulting in weakness and fatigability of striated muscles. There are 3 clinical manifestations of myasthenia gravis in childhood.¹

- Juvenile myasthenia gravis, which occurs in late infancy and childhood. It is the most common form of myasthenia gravis in childhood but remains rare, representing approximately 10% of all cases of myasthenia gravis in Western populations. It is caused by antibodies passing against the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (AChR, 85% of cases) or against the muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSKR, 15% of cases).
- Congenital myasthenia gravis, a rare familial form of myasthenia gravis that is not associated with antibodies.
- Transient neonatal myasthenia gravis, which affects 10% to 20% of newborns of mothers with myasthenia gravis. Transient neonatal myasthenia gravis is due to the transplacental passage of anti-AChR or anti-MuSKR with resultant neuromuscular junction blockade in the newborn.²

## 125. D. The 2011 study by Pinto-Martin and colleagues found an autism prevalence of 5% among a preterm cohort of neonates less than 2,000 g birth weight.

Neonates born preterm, with a low birth weight, or with neonatal medical complexity have an increased risk of having autism spectrum disorder (ASD). In a prospective study with rigorous diagnosis of ASD, Pinto-Martin and colleagues found that neonates with a birth weight less than 2,000 g have prevalence of ASD of 5%, 3 times that of the general population.¹ Because of this increased risk, screening for ASD using tools such as the Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers is at the 18- and 24-month visits for these high-risk children.²

## 126. B. Atypical behaviors may be present, such as stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, insistence on sameness, and highly restricted or fixed interests.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) occurs in 1 in 68 children and is 5 times more common in boys. The prevalence of ASD has been increasing over the past several decades, from 6.7 per 1,000 children in 2000 to 14.7 per 1,000 children in 2010.¹

Autism spectrum disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by²

- Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction including difficulties with social-emotional reciprocity, nonverbal communication, and relationships such as interactive play with peers.
- Presence of restricted, repetitive patterns of atypical behavior, interests, or activities. These may include repetitive, stereotypical motor movements, insistence on sameness, highly restricted or fixated interests, and hyperreactivity or hyporeactivity to sensory input.

- Symptoms that are present in early childhood and impair daily functioning.

The average age of diagnosis of ASD is 4 years; however, earlier behavioral markers may be noted in infants as young as 12 months. The following deviations in development have been proposed by the American Academy of Neurology and Child Neurology Society as absolute red flags for a possible ASD diagnosis:

- No babbling, pointing, or use of nonverbal gestures by 12 months
- No single words by 16 months
- No 2-word spontaneous phrases by 24 months
- Loss of language or social skills at any age

## 127. A. Abnormal neurological examination findings

The incidence of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy has decreased over the past several decades, occurring in 1.5 per 1,000 live term births in developed countries. About 25% of survivors are at risk of adverse developmental outcomes including motor deficits, memory impairment, visual motor or visual perceptive dysfunction, hyperactivity, and learning disabilities. The risk of impairment increases with the degree of encephalopathy. In the first few days after birth, an abnormal neurological examination finding is the single most useful predictor that a brain insult has occurred in the perinatal period.

## 128. C. The latent phase following an initial ischemic insult lasts 6 to 15 hours.

The pathogenesis of brain injury following neonatal hypoxia-ischemia is complex and is characterized by overlapping phases of injury that evolve over time.

- The initial (primary) phase of injury is due to the abrupt interruption of substrates delivery (oxygen and glucose) to the brain, resulting in necrotic cell death.
- This initial phase of injury is followed by a latent phase that lasts between 6 hours and 15 hours. This period represents a therapeutic window during which the institution therapies to mitigate further injury can be implemented, including therapeutic hypothermia.
- The secondary phase of neuronal injury is characterized by apoptotic cell death, with most of the burden of neuronal injury and death occurring during this phase. Multiple mechanisms are involved during the secondary phase including excitotoxicity, free radical production, and activation of inflammatory cascades.

## 129. D. Opening of the hands

Head instability is essential to motor behavior during the first 2 postnatal months. At that stage, if manual support to the neck and spine is provided, one will observe the following:

- Diversification of facial expressions
- Decrease in the flexor of the upper extremities with opening of the hands
- Intentional reaching and grasping of an object
- Temporary disappearance of the Moro and grasp reflexes

This supported state has been described as the liberated state and can be observed in newborns as young as 2 weeks. A positive liberated state provides supportive evidence of the integrity of the upper (corticospinal) system.

## 131. D. Intrauterine growth restriction

Preterm birth is an important risk factor for cerebral palsy (CP), with more preterm neonates being at higher risk of CP: 10.4% to 12.1% at 22 to 26 weeks' gestation compared with 3.3% to 7.8% at 27 to 32 weeks' gestation.¹ In addition, a history of abnormal head ultrasonographic findings increased the risk of CP. Of note, the presence of periventricular leukomalacia or intraparenchymal hemorrhage increases the risk of CP regardless of the degree of prematurity.² In preterm neonates, additional risk factors include exposure to postnatal steroids, need for high-frequency ventilation, prolonged mechanical ventilation, pneumothorax, male sex, sepsis, necrotizing enterocolitis, African American race, and low socioeconomic status.³,⁴

While preterm birth is a significant risk factor for CP, 50% of all cases of CP occur in term neonates.⁵ In this population, risk factors include

- Maternal factors: chorioamnionitis, maternal intellectual disability, hypothyroidism, and severe proteinuria
- Neonate factors: ischemic stroke, neonatal encephalopathy, noncentral nervous system malformations, cerebral dysgenesis, 5-minute Apgar score 3 or less, intrauterine growth restriction, birth weight less than 2,000 g, and severe hyperbilirubinemia

## 132. C. There may be increased muscle tone, tremors, jitteriness, difficulty sleeping, or respiratory distress.

Neonatal adaptation syndrome can occur in newborns exposed to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in utero. Affected newborns may present with hypertonia, tremors, jitteriness, feeding issues, difficulty sleeping, and respiratory distress.¹

Neonatal adaptation syndrome occurs in 22% to 49% of newborns exposed to SSRIs.²,³ Symptoms are typically mild and resolve within 2 to 6 days. In a study from Forsberg and colleagues, only 3% of exposed neonates were classified as having severe symptoms with a Finnegan score greater than 8.² In another study, 12.3% of exposed neonates were classified as having severe symptoms.³ There is no benefit of SRRI discontinuation for the last 2 weeks of pregnancy.⁴

In general, affected neonates respond well to nonpharmacological measures including skin-to-skin care, swaddling, and feeding on demand. Breastfeeding has been shown to decrease neonatal adaption syndrome symptoms.⁵

## 133. B. Erb palsy

Neonatal brachial plexus palsy occurs in 0.3 to 3.0 per 1,000 live births and is classified into 4 anatomical groups based on neurological findings at 2 to 3 weeks of age.¹

- Group I: lesion level C5-C6 with paralysis of shoulder and biceps
- Group II: lesion level C5-C7 with paralysis of shoulder, biceps, and forearm extensors
- Group III: lesion level C5-T1 with complete paralysis of limb
- Group IV: lesion level C5-T1 with complete paralysis of limb with Horner syndrome

Erb palsy is an upper trunk lesion (group I) resulting in the "waiter's tip" posture, with shoulder adduction and internal rotation, elbow extension, forearm pronation, and wrist flexion. On the affected side, the Moro reflex is absent but the grasp reflex is present. It is the most common form of neonatal brachial plexus injury, representing greater than 50% of all cases.²

## 134. E. Symptomatic patent ductus arteriosus

Near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) allows for the continuous, noninvasive bedside monitoring of cerebral tissue oxygenation 2.5 to 3.0 cm below the sensor. For neonates, NIRS monitoring has been used to study cerebral autoregulation, predict outcomes in preterm neonates, for the perioperative treatment of neonates with complex congenital heart diseases, and for neonates on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation.

For preterm neonates, NIRS monitoring has been shown to be helpful in the prediction of intraventricular hemorrhage.¹ Further, it can be used to monitor preterm neonates with hemodynamically significant patent ductus arteriosus.²

## 135. D. The disease is caused by a CTG repeat within the 3' untranslated region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase gene on chromosome 19q13.

Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by the expansion of trinucleotide CTG repeats in the noncoding region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) gene on chromosome 19. Myotonic dystrophy type 1 is classified as congenital myotonic dystrophy (CMD, onset of symptoms at birth) and childhood myotonic dystrophy (onset of symptoms between 1 years and 10 years of age), and adult DM1 (diagnosis after 10 years). The prevalence of DM1 is 1 in 6,000 to 1 in 8,000, with CMD representing 10% to 30% of all DM1 cases. Pediatric mortality rates are between 17% and 41%, with the most common cause of death being respiratory failure. Most infants requiring mechanical ventilation support in the newborn period will wean off their support with a mean duration of respiratory support of 26 weeks. The 1-year mortality among infants with CMD requiring mechanical ventilation for more than 30 days is 25% and 30% if the need for mechanical support is greater than 90 days.¹,²

## 136. E. Release of apoptosis-triggering caspase proteins

The pathophysiology of hypoxic-ischemic brain injury is complex and occurs in multiple phases including a primary energy failure phase, a latent period, and a secondary energy failure phase. The severity of the secondary energy failure phase is variable and depends on the degree of primary failure. The pathways activated during the secondary energy failure phase include$^{1,2}$

- Activation of microglia and inflammatory response
- Caspases release and activation of apoptotic pathways
- Decreased growth factors and protein synthesis
- Further accumulation of excitotoxic neurotransmitters

## 137. A. Enhanced gray-white matter signal contrast

The prenatal diagnosis of agenesis of the corpus callosum using ultrasound is difficult and is inferred from the failure to visualize the cavum septum pellucidum between 18 and 20 weeks' gestation. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the imaging technique of choice, allowing for the visualization of the corpus callosum by 20 weeks' gestation. Fetal MRI performed between 20 and 23 weeks' gestation will also detect other overt brain anomalies such as hydrocephalus but may miss migrational or myelination defects. A repeat fetal MRI between 28 and 34 weeks is helpful to diagnose these subtler lesions prenatally, because of enhanced gray-white matter differentiation and development of cortical gyration.$^{1,2}$

## 139. D. Opiate

Neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) most commonly follows in utero chronic opioid use or abuse (heroin, methadone, morphine, oxycodone, codeine, and/or buprenorphine). ## 140. A. Finnegan scoring system

Multiple scoring systems are available for the evaluation of neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) severity. Among those, the Finnegan scoring system is the most studied and the most widely used.$^{1}$ The Finnegan scoring system scores 20 items in 4 categories: neurological, state, respiratory, and gastrointestinal. In general, a score of 8 or greater indicates more severe NAS and is used by some as an indication for pharmacological treatment initiation. Of note, the Eat, Sleep, Console approach, which focuses on the functional effect of NAS on the neonate, has been gaining ground and has led to significant decreases in the need for pharmacological interventions.$^{2}$

## 141. D. Ischemia-reperfusion injury

Cerebellar hemorrhage is increasingly recognized as an important form of brain injury in preterm neonates. Cranial ultrasonographic studies using the mastoid views indicate higher incidence of cerebellar hemorrhage than previously thought, 19% among preterm neonates less than 750 g at birth.¹ The most common locations of hemorrhage are the primary and secondary germinal matrices in the deep subependymal and superficial subpial regions. Ischemia-reperfusion mechanisms also appear to play a role, with frequent microscopic hemorrhagic lesions in under-vascularized areas identified on pathology studies.

## 142. A. Diffuse non-cystic myelination disturbance is the predominant form of white matter injury.

Periventricular white matter injury (PWMI) is in large part due to injury to the pre-myelinating oligodendrocyte progenitors. Periventricular white matter injury includes a spectrum of injury most often classified as focal cystic lesions (also known as cystic periventricular leukomalacia, cPVL) or diffuse lesions.¹,²

Focal cystic PWMI (or cPVL) is characterized by symmetrical lesions adjacent to the anterior and posterior horns of the lateral ventricles, most commonly in the frontal and parietal-occipital periventricular white matter. These cystic lesions are readily detected by cranial ultrasonography. In contrast, diffuse PWMI can be missed on cranial ultrasound, and brain magnetic resonance imaging is the diagnostic study of choice. Studies indicate that the incidence of focal cystic PWMI has decreased, accounting for less than 5% of cases of PWMI.³⁻⁶

## 144. D. Righting reaction

With birth, the newborn experiences the effects of gravity for the first time. The full righting reaction is one of the major counter-gravity responses that a newborn will demonstrate when placed in the upright position. With tactile stimulation of the soles and activation of extensor muscles, a newborn can actively sustain his/her body weight for a few seconds. This is a brainstem response that evolves in a caudo-cephalic fashion, restricted to the lower extremities around 28 weeks' gestational age and reaching the head between 38 and 40 weeks' gestational age.¹,²

Hypercalcemic hypercalciuria can cause renal calcifications in preterm neonates because of the following:

- Hyperparathyroidism
- Hypophosphatasia

## 7. D. Number of glomeruli

The glomerular filtration rate (GFR) depends mostly on the number of glomeruli, which increases in utero until approximately 35 to 36 weeks’ gestation. Once the total number of glomeruli is attained, the GFR increases relative to renal mass and changes in renal hemodynamics. Renal growth and development are affected by intrauterine growth restriction, maternal hypertension, and postnatal illness, which can have long-term effects on renal function.

## 8. D. Oligohydramnios may indicate a more severe abnormality that may require emergent intervention postnatally.

Nonrenal prenatal findings can help to determine the cause of the prenatal hydronephrosis:

- Hydroureter without a distended bladder → possible obstruction at the ureterovesicular junction
- Hydroureter with a distended bladder → possible obstruction of the urethra

The finding of oligohydramnios, indicating a significant decrease in urine output, is associated with a more severe renal abnormality that might require emergent intervention postnatally.

## 9. D. Restrict fluid intake to a total volume equal to insensible losses plus urine output replacement.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) is managed supportively in neonates. If a prerenal cause is suspected, normal saline boluses can be administered. However, if there is no increase in urine output or decrease in serum creatinine after the boluses, additional boluses are not recommended because of the risk of fluid overload, pulmonary edema, and anasarca. If a neonate becomes hypotensive, vasoactive agents are recommended. If there is a high chance that the AKI is related to intrinsic renal disease, the best fluid management strategy is to restrict fluid intake to a total volume equal to insensible water losses plus urine output replacement. Maximal parenteral nutrition should be provided. Monitoring for associated electrolyte abnormalities (eg, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, hyperphosphatemia) is also important because corrections may be needed.

## 10. A. Chronic exposure to catecholamines leads to a decreased number of cardiac β-adrenergic receptors.

In response to cardiac failure, compensatory mechanisms include an increase in adrenal epinephrine secretion and release of neural norepinephrine. This leads to increased sympathetic tone, with an associated increase in heart rate, contractility, and cardiac output. However, chronic sympathetic stimulation can have deleterious effects, such as direct toxicity to the myocardium and a decrease in the number of β-adrenergic receptors in the heart because of tachyphylaxis. There can also be a decrease in

## 13. E. Spironolactone

Loop diuretics (eg, bumetanide and furosemide) and thiazide diuretics (eg, hydrochlorothiazide and metolazone) need to be delivered to the renal tubular lumen to exert their pharmacological effect. In contrast, aldosterone antagonists (eg, spironolactone) compete with aldosterone and bind to receptors on the cortical collecting tubule cells.

## 14. D. Production of fetal urine begins at 9-weeks' gestational age, and the fetal bladder is visible by ultrasonography starting at 13-weeks' gestational age.

Fetal ultrasonography is extremely useful for the detection of major renal anomalies. The fetus begins to produce urine at 9-weeks' gestational age, and the fetal bladder is visible by ultrasonography at 13-weeks' gestational age. By 20-weeks' gestational age, 90% of the amniotic fluid is composed of fetal urine. Fetal ultrasonography can detect fetal kidneys at 12-weeks' gestational age, with distinction of the renal cortex and medulla being evident by 25-weeks' gestational age. Fetal hydronephrosis can be identified at 18- to 22-weeks' gestational age, usually by means of routine fetal screening. The finding of severe fetal hydronephrosis during the third trimester is more predictive of a renal or urinary tract anomaly.¹

## 16. B. Collecting duct

Each part of the nephron plays a different role in water regulation. In the proximal renal convoluted tubule, sodium is actively transported across the tubule wall, and water passively follows. In the loop of Henle and distal convoluted tubules, there is active reabsorption of solutes, but these sections are mostly impermeable to water. Hypotonic urine then enters the collecting duct where most of the reabsorption of water is tightly regulated by arginine vasopressin or antidiuretic hormone.

17. A. In kidneys affected by MCDK disease, there is essentially no normally differentiated renal epithelium.

Multicystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK) disease is the most severe form of renal cystic dysplasia, with almost completely undifferentiated renal epithelium as a result of limited ureteric bud branching.¹ Normally, there are approximately 300,000 to 1,000,000 nephrons in a neonatal kidney; however, in MCDK disease, there are fewer than 300,000 nephrons. The most common form of MCDK disease is unilateral, which is associated with a good prognosis²; however, if there is bilateral involvement, the outcome is poor.

18. B. High mean airway pressures in neonates receiving ventilation have been associated with AKI, possibly because of impaired venous return and decreased cardiac output.

The causes of acute kidney injury (AKI) in neonates can be classified into 3 categories: prerenal, intrinsic, or postrenal.

The primary prerenal cause is renal hypoperfusion as a result of the following:

- Hypovolemia from decreased fluid intake, excessive fluid losses, or third spacing with decreased intravascular volume
- Decreased cardiac output (eg, high mean airway pressures from the ventilator, impairing venous return)¹
- Medications that decrease afferent arteriole dilatation (eg, ibuprofen, indomethacin)
- Medications that block efferent arteriole constriction (eg, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors)
- Increased abdominal pressure resulting in compartment syndrome

Any of these prerenal causes of AKI can lead to intrinsic renal injury. Intrinsic injury can also result from interstitial nephritis, cortical necrosis after severe perinatal hypoxic-ischemic injury, or a direct effect of nephrotoxic medications (eg, aminoglycosides, amphotericin B, intravenous contrast material), particularly in neonates of lower birth weight.²

Postrenal causes of AKI involve obstruction of the flow of urine. Causes include prenatal abnormalities, such as posterior urethral valves or obstruction at the ureteropelvic junction, whereas postnatal causes include urethral strictures, trauma after catheterization, or abdominal masses.

19. C. 36 weeks

By 8 weeks' gestation, the first nephron is formed, and fetal urine production begins. At 20 weeks' gestation, urine production is established, and approximately one-third of the full complement of nephrons has developed.¹ At 36 weeks' gestation, the number of nephrons is the same as that in adults.¹ Preterm neonates born younger than 36-weeks' gestational age are still in the process of nephrogenesis, and exposure to medications can affect the development of their kidneys, including nephron numbers.²,³

## 21. D. May help to explain the inconsistent response of neonates to diuretic therapy but currently lack clinical relevance

Pharmacogenomics is a new field that seeks to individualize drug treatment on the basis of a patient’s specific genotype. At present, the clinical applicability of this approach is minimal because of lack of availability of genotype testing, inconsistent correlation of a patient’s genotype to a response, and limited data. However, pharmacogenomics has the potential to explain the variability in patient responses to medications, such as the inconsistent response of neonates to diuretic therapy.

## 22. E. Basolateral Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase

In addition to affecting renal hemodynamics and tubular function, catecholamines regulate the Na⁺/K⁺-adenosinetriphosphatase (ATPase) enzyme on the basolateral membrane of the renal tubule.¹ This enzyme is involved in renal solute transport, leading to increased sodium absorption. Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase enzyme activity increases in response to α- and β-adrenergic receptor stimulation and decreases in response to dopamine receptor stimulation.¹

## 23. D. Diagnosed by means of fetal ultrasonography with large fluid-filled renal cysts observed by 20 weeks’ gestation

Multcystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK) disease is diagnosed by means of fetal ultrasonography with echogenic kidneys containing multiple large cysts that are visible by 20 weeks’ gestation.¹ This is in contrast to polycystic kidney disease in which cysts are not visible until later in gestation. While MCDK disease is usually unilateral, bilateral involvement can occur. The underlying cause of MCDK disease is varied and has been associated with many genetic mutations. In contrast, autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease is attributed to mutations in a single gene, the PKHD1 gene, which is located on chromosome 6p21.

Patients with mild MCKD disease do not usually develop hypertension. However, chronic renal failure occurs in 12% to 50% of affected patients, even if only 1 kidney is involved.¹ Previous reports indicated an increased risk of Wilms tumor in the affected kidney, leading to routine nephrectomies in patients with MCKD disease. However, studies found that this risk is minimal, and some centers now monitor patients periodically with ultrasonography instead of performing routine surgery.²

Vesicoureteral reflux can also lead to fetal hydronephrosis. Less frequent causes include collagen disorders, neurological impairment, malignancy, and prune-belly syndrome.

## 26. E. Angiotensin II stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete aldosterone.

In response to a decrease in renal blood flow, renin levels increase, which leads to increased production of angiotensin II. Angiotensin II has several functions, including the following:

- Increase in water and salt reabsorption in the renal tubules¹
- Vasoconstriction of systemic and renal arterioles²
- Stimulation of the adrenal cortex to produce aldosterone, further increasing sodium reabsorption in renal tubules and nonrenal sites³
- Increase in glomerular filtration⁴
- Possible vascular smooth muscle cell and myocardial hypertrophy⁵

## 28. D. Distal tubule

Thiazide diuretics block the apical sodium chloride transporter in the distal convoluted tubule, the collecting tubule, and the early part of the collecting duct.¹² However, because the distal tubule is responsible for only 5% to 10% of renal tubular reabsorption, thiazide diuretics are not as effective as loop diuretics. 30. A. Perform renal ultrasonography in 3 to 6 weeks

Neonates with a prenatal diagnosis of mild hydronephrosis have a low risk of urinary tract infection, and most affected patients have spontaneous resolution of their hydronephrosis. Postnatal renal ultrasonography at 3 to 6 weeks of age is helpful to determine whether additional imaging is needed.

31. B. Decreased afferent arteriole stretch leading to stimulation of renal baroreceptors

The kidneys increase renin secretion in response to a decrease in afferent arteriole stretch or pressure; this leads to a stimulation of renal baroreceptors. $^{1,2}$ In addition, other mechanisms of increased renin secretion include the following:

- Increased renal sympathetic activity and stimulation of the renal $\beta_{1}$ adrenergic receptors $^{1,2}$
- Decreased sodium chloride transport to the macula densa $^{1,2}$

Neonates can have nephrocalcinosis with normal urinary and serum calcium levels if primary or secondary hyperoxaluria is present. Primary hyperoxaluria has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern that leads to excessive calcium oxalate renal deposits. In its most severe form, primary hyperoxaluria occurs in 3- to 4-month-olds who present with failure to thrive, seizures, and renal failure. $^{1}$ Secondary hyperoxaluria can occur in newborns with short bowel syndrome and malabsorption.
