33. A. Bladder exstrophy

There are 3 general categories of the bladder exstrophy-epispadias complex (BEEC)$^{1,2}$:

1. Classic bladder exstrophy: This is the most common type of BEEC, occurring in 60% of cases. Affected patients have an exposed, inside out bladder and a visible dorsal urethra at the lower part of the abdominal wall. The external genitalia are involved in all affected patients, and an inguinal hernia is present in most patients.
2. Epispadias: This mild phenotype is present in 30% of cases. Affected patients have an open urethral plate and an abnormal urethral location. Affected males have an ectopic meatal opening or a mucosal strip on the dorsal side of the penis, and affected females have a urethral cleft.
3. Cloacal exstrophy: Patients with this type (10% of cases) are most severely affected and present with bladder and large intestine extrusion, along with abnormalities of the anus, genitalia, and colon.

## 34. A. Hypercalciuria

Patients with type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA), also known as distal RTA, have decreased acid secretion into the distal tubule. Typical laboratory findings associated with this disorder include the following¹,²:

- Hypokalemia: potassium replaces hydrogen as a cation in the urine
- Hypocitraturia: citrate is reabsorbed to create bicarbonate
- Hypercalciuria: possibly caused by increased calcium secretion from bone to serve as a buffer and increased delivery of sodium to the distal tubule with associated increase in calcium renal excretion
- High urine pH with hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap

## 35. D. Plasma flow rate

The hallmark of prerenal failure in the development of decreased glomerular filtration is decreased plasma flow rate to the kidneys. This is caused by either volume contraction or decreased cardiac output. If these conditions are treated, renal perfusion can be restored, and normal renal function can return. However, if volume replacement is inadequate or cardiac output remains low, prerenal failure will persist, potentially leading to renal injury.

## 36. A. Accompanied by oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia in severe cases

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is caused by a mutation on the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 6p21. The diagnosis can be made prenatally by fetal ultrasonography with multiple small renal cysts visible after 20 weeks’ gestation and large, echogenic kidneys. In severe cases, oligohydramnios, the Potter phenotype, and pulmonary hypoplasia can occur.¹ Postnatally, in addition to polycystic renal findings, neonates with ARPKD have hepatic fibrosis with some degree of biliary dysgenesis.² If patients survive the neonatal period, long-term complications such as chronic renal insufficiency, growth failure, hyponatremia, and severe hypertension (associated with low plasma renin concentrations) can occur.³

## 37. E. Patients with the VACTERL association can have renal involvement of varying severity, including hydronephrosis, ectopic kidneys, renal agenesis, and renal dysplasia.

The VACTERL association is associated with at least 3 of the following findings: vertebral abnormalities, anal atresia, esophageal atresia or tracheoesophageal fistula, renal abnormalities, and limb anomalies.¹ The renal abnormalities can vary and include hydronephrosis, ectopic kidneys, renal agenesis, and renal dysplasia.¹

There is some overlap between the clinical findings of VACTERL and Holt-Oram syndrome (caused by a mutation in the transcription factor TBX5) and those of Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome (caused by a mutation in the DHCR7 gene).²

## 38. D. Preterm neonates have an impaired renal ability to reabsorb sodium and water.

After birth, preterm neonates have an increase in creatinine levels in the first few days, with neonates of younger gestational age having the most significant increase.¹ This increase in creatinine begins to decrease gradually after 4 days.¹ Preterm neonates have an impaired renal ability to reabsorb sodium and water, which corresponds to the large diuresis in this population during the first week after birth.² This is associated with a lower maximum urine osmolality of 500 mOsm/L (500 mmol/kg) in preterm neonates compared with a maximum urine osmolality of 800 mOsm/L (800 mmol/kg) in term neonates.² Preterm neonates also have a lower glomerular filtration rate than do term neonates, with both preterm and term neonates reaching adult levels at approximately 1 year of age.²

39. C. For patients with antenatal hydronephrosis, the most common obstructive process is ureteropelvic junction obstruction.

An obstruction at the ureteropelvic junction is the most common cause for congenital obstruction involving the urinary tract and occurs in 1 in 500 to 1,500 births. $^{1,2}$

In general, the severity of the hydronephrosis correlates with an increased risk for an underlying renal anomaly, $^{3}$ as well as increased risk for a urinary tract infection. $^{4}$ In addition, there is a greater risk of urinary tract infection in females with hydronephrosis. $^{5}$ Newborns with low-grade hydronephrosis are unlikely to require postnatal surgical intervention (&lt; 10% of affected newborns) compared with newborns with high-grade hydronephrosis who are more likely to need surgical intervention (&gt; 50% risk). $^{5,6}$

40. A. ACE inhibitors block the pathway that converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors block the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. Use of ACE inhibitors significantly reduces dysfunction of the left ventricle and mortality in adults with heart failure. $^{1}$ By decreasing systemic vascular resistance (ie, decreasing afterload), left ventricular function and cardiac output improve. ACE inhibitors also have the potential of reversing left ventricular hypertrophy if used long term. $^{2}$ By preventing the breakdown of bradykinin, ACE inhibitors lead to an increase in bradykinin, $^{3}$ which causes a cough in 5% to 35% of patients. $^{4}$

The use of ACE inhibitors in neonates and infants could lead to renal injury, so monitoring of renal function is necessary in this population. This effect is not dose dependent and is more common in preterm neonates. $^{5,6}$ A study conducted by the Pediatric Heart Network in 230 infants with single-ventricle physiology found that the use of enalapril did not improve survival, somatic growth, or ventricular function in the first year. $^{7}$ However, this study had several limitations (eg, small sample size, intervention occurring after surgery), so further data are needed to be certain of lack of effect.

Angiotensin II serves as a renal growth factor and plays an important role in renal development.¹ Pregnant rats that were fed a protein-restricted diet had pups with a suppressed fetal renin-angiotensin system (RAS) and abnormal renal development.²,³ Transgenic or knockout animals that lacked genes within the RAS had severe impairment of nephrogenesis.⁴

## 42. E. The serum creatinine level will normally increase during the first days after birth before gradually decreasing.

In preterm neonates, the serum creatinine level will normally increase during the first days after birth before gradually decreasing.¹ The younger the neonate's birth gestational age, the greater the increase in creatinine.¹ The neonate's creatinine level at birth reflects maternal creatinine levels and is not helpful in assessing renal function. After this period, creatinine levels correlate with the patient's glomerular filtration rate, but this level is not a sensitive test for the diagnosis of acute kidney injury in children.² Protein intake should not be restricted in neonates with acute kidney injury.

## 43. E. Transient dilation is less common with severe antenatal hydronephrosis.

Most patients (41%–88%) with a prenatal diagnosis of mild hydronephrosis have a transient nonobstructive dilation that has no clinical significance.¹ Neonates with unilateral mild to moderate hydronephrosis do not require imaging in the newborn period; instead, a renal ultrasound is recommended at 3 to 6 weeks after discharge.

Neonates with severe antenatal hydronephrosis are at increased risk of persistent dilation, with greater risk of urinary tract infections, need for surgery, or development of chronic kidney disease.¹ Affected neonates require evaluation prior to discharge.

Although neonates with a diagnosis of severe antenatal hydronephrosis should be treated with prophylactic antibiotics, neonates with mild antenatal hydronephrosis only require antibiotics if there are other abnormalities such as ureterocele, bladder abnormalities, hydroureter, or urinary obstruction.¹

## 44. D. Spironolactone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist, decreasing sodium reabsorption and preventing potassium loss.

There are several agents to treat heart failure in adults that act by inhibiting different steps in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone pathway. A renin inhibitor prevents angiotensinogen from being converted into angiotensin I. For example, aliskiren treats heart failure by blocking plasma renin activity.¹ Inhibitors of angiotensin-converting enzyme block the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II.

Spironolactone acts downstream as a competitive aldosterone receptor antagonist, leading to a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium loss. In addition, this corticosteroid decreases both the turnover of extracellular matrix, a critical factor in cardiac remodeling, and myocardial collagen levels.² If spironolactone is used concomitantly with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, patients are at risk for hyperkalemia.³ Eplerenone, another mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist, is more selective than is spironolactone.⁴

Angiotensin receptor blockers competitively block the angiotensin I receptor.

## 45. D. Recent data suggest that even mild forms of congenital kidney disease that are benign during childhood may progress to end-stage renal disease in adulthood.

There are 5 progressive stages of chronic kidney disease, with stages 1 to 4 accounting for most childhood cases. $^{1,2}$ The final stage, stage 5, is end-stage renal disease and has a low prevalence in children. $^{1,2}$ Chronic kidney disease has a broad effect on life, affecting a child's growth, nutrition, and social development. Recent data suggest that even mild forms of congenital kidney disease that are benign during childhood may progress to end-stage renal disease in adulthood. $^{3}$ However, of all patients with end-stage renal failure, only $2\%$ are children. $^{1,2}$ The life expectancy of a child who starts dialysis is 20 years from the initiation of dialysis. $^{1}$

## 46. A. Distal renal tubular acidosis

Patients in the neonatal intensive care unit can develop normocalcemic hypercalciuric nephrocalcinosis as a result of 1 of the following causes:

## 47. B. Decreased serum bicarbonate

Type 2 renal tubular acidosis (RTA), also known as proximal RTA, results from a decrease in bicarbonate resorption in the proximal tubule. The high urinary loss of bicarbonate is associated with a high urine pH and leads to a decrease in serum bicarbonate with associated metabolic acidosis. $^{1}$

## 49. E. Ureteric bud

The pronephros develops and then regresses by 4 weeks' gestation. This is followed by the development of the mesonephros that gives rise to the mesonephric tubule and duct. The mesonephric duct (also known as the Wolffian duct) then forms into the ureteric bud, which branches and differentiates into the collecting ducts, renal pelvis, and ureter. At the same time, the metanephric mesenchyme is formed and ultimately differentiates into the nephrons. Renal agenesis is due to the failure of development of the ureteric bud. A schematic of the normal development of the kidney is shown in the figure. $^{1}$

1.  B. Alveolar/capillary hypoplasia

Classic (or "old") bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) from the pre-surfactant era is characterized by structural damage of normal pulmonary structures from mechanical ventilation and oxygen toxicity with airway squamous metaplasia, alveolar septal fibrosis, airway smooth muscle hypertrophy, and marked inflammation.¹

In contrast, a disruption of normal alveolar and vascular development with subsequent diffuse alveolar/capillary hypoplasia is the hallmark of new BPD. This reduction in alveolar development leads to clinically significant loss of surface area for gas exchange. Airway injury, inflammation, and fibrosis are usually milder in new versus old BPD.²³

2.  A. Commitment of the family

Lung transplantation may be a therapeutic option to prolong survival in neonates with inherited disorders of surfactant metabolism. The decision to proceed with lung transplantation is a complex one and includes the following considerations:

- Specific molecular defect
- Degree of illness and anticipated disease trajectory
- Absence of extrapulmonary organ dysfunction
- Ability to transport and remain near a pediatric lung transplant center
- The desire and commitment of the family

This final criterion is the most important factor in the decision to proceed with lung transplantation for an inherited disorder of surfactant metabolism.¹²

3.  C. Positive end-expiratory pressure

Functional residual capacity (FRC) represents the lung volume at the end of normal tidal ventilation and is determined by the balance between outward stretch of the thorax and inward recoil of the lung. Functional residual capacity is critical for oxygenation and must be optimized to improve oxygenation. In preterm neonates, the judicious use of positive end-expiratory pressure is most effective in establishing and maintaining FRC.¹²

4.  E. Volume-targeted ventilation

In volume-targeted ventilation modes, the peak inflating pressure required to deliver the targeted volume is dependent on lung compliance and, therefore, is higher when lung compliance is poor and decreases with improvement in lung compliance. This permits consistent tidal volume delivery at the lowest pressure and thereby avoids injurious overdistention. A Cochrane systematic review showed a decrease in death and bronchopulmonary dysplasia (typical risk reduction of 0.73, 95% CI, 0.57–0.93) with volume-targeted ventilation versus pressure-limited ventilation.¹

5.  C. Promoting adsorption and spreading of surfactant

Surfactant, a surface-active substance produced in type II pneumocytes, decreases surface tension proportionally to alveolar size to prevent alveolar collapse at end expiration. The composition of surfactant, a mixture of phospholipids and protein, is critical to its function. Lipids are the most abundant component of surfactant (90%) and include phospholipids (saturated and unsaturated

phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylglycerol, and others) and neutral lipids. Saturated phosphatidylcholine (dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine) represents 50% of surfactant and is the principal lipid responsible for the formation of the lipid monolayer and thereby reduction in surface tension. Surfactant also contains 4 surfactant proteins (SPs), 2 hydrophobic (SP-B and SP-C) and 2 hydrophilic (SP-A and SP-D). Surfactant protein B and SP-C are critical to the optimal dynamic behavior and function of surfactant and facilitate absorption and spreading of the phospholipid monolayer. Surfactant protein A and SP-D are collectins and are part of the host innate system. Surfactant protein A helps regulate surfactant expression and uptake, while SP-D regulates surfactant reuptake and recycling.¹

## 6. E. Ventilator dependence at 36 weeks' postmenstrual age

Permissive hypercapnia is a ventilation strategy used to decrease ventilator-induced injury in preterm neonates. Three randomized controlled trials (RCTs) have been published investigating the benefits of permissive hypercapnia strategies in preterm neonates.

The first trial, a pilot trial in 49 preterm neonates, demonstrated a decreased need for mechanical ventilation in the intervention group.¹ The largest trial included 220 neonates with a birth weight of 501 to 1,000 g and demonstrated a decrease in ventilatory support at 36 weeks in the permissive hypercapnia group (1% vs 16%, P &lt; .01) with no adverse effect on severe intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), periventricular leukomalacia (PVL), or survival without neurodevelopmental impairments at 18 to 22 months.² The third RCT had higher Paco₂ targets and did not show benefits of permissive hypercapnia in 65 very preterm neonates.³ Finally, a Cochrane review including 2 of the trials concluded there was no difference in the incidence of death, chronic lung disease at 36 weeks' postmenstrual age, severe IVH, or PVL.⁴ This conclusion was supported by a recent multicenter RCT in 359 neonates 23 to 28 weeks' gestation comparing Paco₂ targets of 55 to 65 mm Hg (days 1-3), 60 to 70 mm Hg (days 4-6), and 65 to 75 mm Hg (days 7-14) in the high target group versus Paco₂ targets of 40 to 50 mm Hg (days 1-3), 45 to 55 mm Hg (days 4-6), and 50 to 60 mm Hg (days 7-14) in the control group.⁵

## 7. A. Frameshift mutation (121ins2)

Surfactant protein B is critical to surfactant function and facilitates the adsorption of surfactant lipids to the air-liquid interface. Surfactant protein B is encoded by the SFTPB gene on chromosome 2. The most common mutation in individuals of Northern European descent is the frameshift mutation (121ins2). This mutation accounts for 60% to 70% of all the SFTPB alleles mutants identified to date.¹,²

Surfactant protein B deficiency is a severe autosomal recessive disorder characterized by respiratory distress of variable severity and diffuse lung disease on chest radiograph at birth. Progressive worsening of the respiratory status with possible transient improvement is typical. Death from respiratory failure most commonly occurs between 3 and 6 months of age. Lung transplantation is currently the only effective treatment option.³,⁴

# 8. E. Larger preterm neonates (&gt;1,000 g birth weight)

The use of inhaled nitric oxide (iNO) in preterm neonates has been studied in multiple randomized controlled trials (RCTs). Kinsella and colleagues investigated the use of iNO in 793 preterm neonates with respiratory failure. They found no difference in the incidence of death or bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) in the overall cohort. However, for neonates with birth weight greater than 1,000 g, iNO decreased the incidence of death or BPD from 59.6% to 29.8%.¹

Van Meurs and colleagues found a similar effect in a post hoc analyses of their RCT in 420 preterm neonates with respiratory failure. In this trial, iNO also decreased the rate of death or BPD among neonates greater than 1,000 g at birth (50% vs 69%, P = .03).²

# 9. C. Impaired alveolar development

Classic bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is due to injury to the immature lung from in utero infection and postnatal mechanical ventilation with high pressures and oxygen concentration. It is characterized by marked parenchymal and airway inflammation as well as airway squamous metaplasia, alveolar septal fibrosis, and airway smooth muscle hypertrophy.¹,²

In contrast, new BPD is secondary to the resuscitation of extremely immature lungs with subsequent disruption of normal alveolar and vascular development. The hallmark of new BPD is diffuse alveolar/capillary hypoplasia. It is characterized by less smooth muscle hypertrophy and fibrosis and less large and small airway metaplasia than "old" BPD.³,⁴

# 10. B. Blockage of adenosine receptors

Caffeine is an effective treatment for apnea of prematurity resulting in

- Stimulation of the medullary respiratory center
- Increased sensitivity to carbon dioxide
- Improved diaphragmatic contractility and airway function

Caffeine exerts its effects primarily via antagonism of adenosine A1 and A2 receptors in the brain. Secondary mechanisms include inhibition of phosphodiesterase with increase in cyclic adenosine monophosphate as well and intracellular calcium release. These mechanisms are likely less important in the neonatal population because they require very high caffeine concentrations.¹,² In animal models, upregulation of the γ-amino butyric acid receptor has also been shown to be a mechanism of action of caffeine.³

# 11. D. Annexin A1 synthesis

Glucocorticoids have been shown to prevent or decrease the severity of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) most likely secondary to their anti-inflammatory effect. This anti-inflammatory effect is primarily mediated by annexin A1 synthesis, resulting in decreased phospholipid A2 expression and thereby decreased production of prostaglandins, thromboxanes, prostacyclins, and leukotrienes. Other mechanisms of action of glucocorticoids include

- Suppression of cyclooxygenase 1 and 2
- Modulation of transcription and post-transcription regulation of surfactant components
- Stimulation of antioxidant production
- Enhanced adrenergic activity¹,²

## 12. B. It is secreted into the proximal tubule lumen and performs its action in the thick ascending loop of Henle, where it inhibits the reabsorption of sodium and chloride.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that exerts its action on the thick ascending loop of Henle where most tubular sodium is reabsorbed. Because loop diuretics are highly protein bound, they are minimally filtered at the glomerular level and are carried to the proximal tubule, where they are excreted into the lumen by organic acid pumps. Decreased renal blood flow and secretory processes reduce drug delivery and the diuretic effects of loop diuretics in preterm infants. Once secreted in the lumen, loop diuretics inhibit the reabsorption of sodium and chloride by binding to the sodium-potassium-chloride transporter. Another effect of furosemide is increase in prostaglandin production with subsequent vasodilatation and increase in renal blood flow.[1,2]

## 13. E. Reduction in births past 41 weeks' gestation

Meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS) is diagnosed in neonates with respiratory distress born through meconium-stained amniotic fluid and for whom symptoms cannot be otherwise explained. MAS is characterized by hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis. While the incidence of meconium-stained amniotic fluid is 8% to 10% of term deliveries, MAS occurs in 1.5% of neonates born after 37 weeks' gestation. This represents a significant decrease from 5.7% in 1990. This decrease in the incidence of MAS is largely due to a marked decrease in the number of births occurring after 41 weeks' gestation.[1-3]

## 14. B. Gas volume

Given the small size of neonatal patients, a key parameter of the evaluation of a new ventilator for use in neonates is to understand how the delivered gas volume is measured and adjusted. Ventilators designed for general use often measure the delivered gas volume at the ventilator exit port, not at the airway opening. With this type of ventilator, the delivered volume can be grossly overestimated and underestimated despite applied correction to estimate circuit losses. $^{1}$

## 15. A. Attenuates hyperoxia-induced lung interstitial fibrosis

Therapeutic hypercapnia is performed by adding carbon dioxide to inspired gases to induce hypercapnia and differs from permissive hypercapnia, which occurs in the setting of a ventilated patient being managed with low minute ventilation. Unlike permissive hypercapnia, therapeutic hypercapnia allows for the independent investigation of hypercapnic acidosis. In experimental models, therapeutic hypercapnia has been shown to

- Attenuate measures of lung injury in models of high tidal volume-induced and endotoxin-induced lung injury.[1,2]
- Attenuate hyperoxia-induced fibrosis in neonatal mice.[3]
- Decrease neutrophil influx and inflammation.[1,2]
- Alter neutrophil adherence to pulmonary endothelial cells by decreasing the expression of intercellular adhesion molecule 1 as well as the chemoattractant interleukin 8.[4]
- Decrease tumor necrosis factor α secretions in macrophages.[5]

## 16. B. Infants who are born small for gestational age are more likely to have episodes of intermittent hypoxemia (IH).

Intermittent hypoxemia is characterized by brief episodes of hemoglobin oxygen saturation (Spo₂) drops and is most commonly defined as Spo₂ drops below 80%. Intermittent hypoxemia is common in preterm infants and is inversely correlated to gestational age and birth weight. It occurs in 50% of moderately preterm infants and 97% of extremely preterm infants. Infants born small for gestational age are at increased risk of IH. The natural progression of IH is characterized by a low incidence in the first week after birth followed by progressive increase between weeks 2 and 3 with IH peaking between 4 and 5 weeks after birth. Intermittent hypoxemia events then plateau or start to decrease during weeks 6 to 10 after birth.¹⁻⁴

## 17. D. Edi trigger is the minimum increase in electrical activity from the preceding trough that triggers the ventilator to designate the increase in electrical activity as a breath.

Noninvasive ventilation (NIV) neurally adjusted ventilatory assist (NAVA) allows for the synchronization of NIV to the electrical activity of the diaphragm (Edi), as measured via a specialized NAVA catheter placed in the distal esophagus. The Edi peak corresponds to the neural inspiratory effort, or respiratory drive, while the Edi minimum is a measure of the tonic activity of the diaphragm, an estimate of the effort needed to prevent alveolar de-recruitment at end expiration. The Edi trigger corresponds to the minimum increase in electrical activity from the preceding baseline that will trigger the ventilator. It is set by the clinician to recognize strong Edi signals as breaths and distinguish them from background noise.¹

## 18. A. Avoiding extreme flexion or extension of the neck and considering prone positioning

Apnea of prematurity (AOP) is common and is inversely correlated to gestational age. It affects almost all neonates less than 28 weeks' gestation and about 20% of neonates at 34 weeks' gestation.¹ Apnea of prematurity can persist beyond term and up to 44 weeks' gestation in some neonates.²,³

Some preventative measures have been shown to decrease the burden of AOP in preterm neonates. These include

- Avoidance of extreme flexion or extension of neck to maintain the patency of the upper airway⁴
- Maintenance of a stable thermal environment, as temperature fluctuations have been shown to result in apnea⁵
- Careful attention to the maintenance of nasal patency, including judicious nasal suctioning, use of heated humidified air, and use of appropriately sized nasal cannula
- Maintaining oxygen saturation within an appropriate target range (ie, 88%-94%), because of the hypoxic ventilatory depression present in preterm neonates

# 19. C. Pulmonary hypoplasia can occur in the saccular and alveolar stages.

Congenital lung abnormalities can occur throughout the 5 stages of lung development as follows:

- Embryonic stage (0–7 weeks): tracheal and pulmonary agenesis
- Pseudoglandular stage (7–17 weeks): congenital pulmonary airway malformations, bronchopulmonary sequestrations (intralobar or extralobar), congenital lobar emphysema, and congenital diaphragmatic hernia
- Canalicular stage (16 to 23–27 weeks): pulmonary hypoplasia
- Saccular stage (24–28 to 36–38 weeks) and alveolar stage (approximately 36 weeks–2 years): pulmonary hypoplasia, alveolar capillary dysplasia, and congenital lobar emphysema¹⁻³

# 20. C. In contrast to pneumonia, radiographic findings will usually clear after 24 hours.

Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a common cause of neonatal respiratory distress, caused by a delay in fetal lung fluid clearance, and is characterized by the following clinical features:

- Onset of symptoms shortly after birth (minutes to hours)
- Tachypnea associated with nasal flaring, grunting, and retractions (intercostal, subcostal, and suprasternal)
- Supplemental oxygen need typically less than 0.40

Symptoms typically resolve within 72 hours of birth.

Fluid in the interlobar fissure, bilateral edema, prominent pulmonary vasculature with increased perihilar markings, and lung hyperinflation are classic radiographic findings of TTN. These findings classically clear after 24 hours.¹,²

## 23. D. 1989

Kurt von Neergaard is credited with making the first observation that the retractile force of the lung is dependent on the surface tension in the alveoli and that lowering surface tension could improve respiratory mechanics and should be studied in newborns. In the 1950s, several investigators elucidated the role of the alveolar lining layer in mediating surface tension, and the term pulmonary surfactant was coined by John Clements. In 1959, Avery and Mead made the observation that the lungs of neonates who died of hyaline membrane disease did not contain foam in their airway. This seminal discovery led to the understanding of surfactant deficiency as the cause of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Fujiwara and colleagues were the first to successfully treat preterm neonates with RDS with a modified natural surfactant. Surfactant was approved for the treatment of RDS by the US Food and Drug Administration in 1989.¹,²

## 25. E. 1994

Antenatal steroid administration to pregnant women with threatened delivery is now considered the single most effective intervention to decrease mortality and morbidity among neonates born preterm. The first randomized controlled trial of antenatal betamethasone for preterm delivery was performed by Liggins and Howie in 1972.¹ This trial was followed by several other trials that all consistently demonstrated significant benefits of antenatal steroid in preterm neonates as young as 24 weeks’ gestation. In these trials as well as later observational studies, antenatal steroid administration resulted in decreased mortality and morbidity including respiratory distress syndrome and intraventricular hemorrhage.²–⁴

Despite mounting evidence, it was not until 1994 that the National Institutes of Health recommended the use of antenatal steroids for women with threatened delivery between 24 and 34 weeks’ gestation.⁵

# 26. E. Tricuspid regurgitant jet velocity

Early echocardiography is an important tool in the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension (PH) in preterm neonates with severe respiratory distress syndrome and requiring high levels of ventilator support. Preterm neonates with PH may have the following echocardiographic findings:

- Right atrial enlargement
- Right ventricular hypertrophy
- Right ventricular dilation
- Pulmonary artery dilation
- Septal flattening

These qualitative findings have overall poor predictive value. The most utilized finding is the tricuspid regurgitant jet velocity to estimate systolic pulmonary artery pressures (sPAP). Studies indicate that sPAP correctly identifies PH in 79% of patients but is poor in the prediction of PH severity. Further, sPAP cannot be consistently obtained (only in about 61% of cases).¹

# 27. C. Compared to hydrocortisone, dexamethasone is 25 to 50 times more potent.

The use of glucocorticoids, and particularly dexamethasone, has been extensively studied for the treatment and prevention of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) in preterm infants. Dexamethasone, a long-acting steroid with a half-life of 36 to 54 hours, has almost exclusive glucocorticoid effects with minimal mineralocorticoid effects. It is 25 to 50 times more potent than hydrocortisone and has been shown to improve pulmonary function, facilitate extubation, and decrease the incidence of BPD among preterm infants. However, it is associated with many adverse effects preventing its routine use. Those include hyperglycemia, hypertension, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, growth failure, gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation, and chronic suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. Most concerning are the long-term adverse effects of dexamethasone use on neurodevelopmental outcomes.¹,²

Two recent meta-analyses of systemic corticosteroids for the prevention of BPD in preterm infants concluded that dexamethasone reduces the risk of BPD but that there is uncertainty with regard to optimal agent and treatment regimens, including when, how much, and for how long.³,⁴ Hydrocortisone is an attractive alternative to dexamethasone because relative adrenal insufficiency is common in preterm infants. In the PREMILOC trial, low-dose hydrocortisone, administered during the first 10 postnatal days, resulted in increased rate of survival without BPD (51% vs 60%, P = .04) in 523 preterm neonates less than 28 weeks' gestation.⁵ While there was no overall increase in sepsis rate, subgroup analysis indicated an increased risk of sepsis in infants 24 to 25 weeks' gestation. There was no effect on neurodevelopmental outcomes at age 2 years.⁶

28. C. The recent addition of spironolactone to the infant's therapy, resulting in competition for the same binding sites on the sodium-potassium-chloride channel.

Furosemide resistance can occur via multiple mechanisms including

- Distal tubular cell hypertrophy in response to chronic increase in sodium concentrations delivered to the distal tubule. The addition of a thiazide diuretic, 0.5 to 1.0 hour prior to furosemide administration, will inhibit distal tubule sodium reabsorption.
- Altered furosemide oral absorption.
- Concomitant use of nonsteroidal drugs that inhibit prostaglandins and blunt the response to loop diuretics.
- Decreased delivery to the thick ascending loop of Henle (ie, hypoalbuminemia, decreased renal blood flow).

29. B. When a neonate is breathing supplemental oxygen, the sigmoidal hemoglobin-oxygen relationship is less consistent at higher oxygen saturations, with the $\mathrm{Pao}_2$ being higher than expected.

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve describes the relationship between arterial oxygen saturation $(\mathrm{Sao}_2)$ and arterial partial pressure of oxygen $(\mathrm{Pao}_2)$. The predictable relation between $\mathrm{Pao}_2$ and $\mathrm{Sao}_2$ is lost at high oxygen saturations when supplemental oxygen is used. Under these circumstances, $\mathrm{Pao}_2$ may be higher than anticipated and increase in dissolved free oxygen. Free radical production will also occur. Therefore, measurements of $\mathrm{Pao}_2$ should be performed to avoid hyperoxia, along with avoiding high $\mathrm{Sao}_2$ levels in neonates requiring supplemental oxygen. $^1$

30. B. Chorioamnionitis can induce lung maturation and decrease respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), but it may also lead to symptoms of diffuse pneumonia presenting as respiratory distress.

Preterm neonates born at less than 30 weeks' gestation are often exposed (50% of patients) to chorioamnionitis, which may be clinically unrecognized. $^{1}$ The resultant inflammation can result in decrease in the incidence of RDS by promoting lung maturation primarily via increased amounts of surfactant. $^{2}$ Interestingly, while growth-restricted neonates experience chronic stress, a decrease in the incidence of RDS among this population has not been observed. This is presumably secondary to other underlying mechanisms such as variable degrees of lung hypoplasia and/or lung structural abnormalities as contributing causes of respiratory distress. $^{3}$

On the flip side, chorioamnionitis and the subsequent inflammation can present as diffuse pneumonia that may clinically mimic RDS but respond poorly to exogenous surfactant. $^{4,5}$

31. C. The point at which the NAVA level is at a plateau phase in which the peak inspiratory pressure and tidal volumes do not increase further, as a result of downregulation of electrical activity of the diaphragm (Edi)

Noninvasive ventilation (NIV) neurally adjusted ventilatory assist (NAVA) allows for the synchronization of NIV to the electrical activity of the diaphragm (Edi), as measured via a specialized NAVA catheter placed in the distal esophagus. When using NAVA ventilation modes, it is important to understand the following terminology:

---

<!-- Page 610 -->

Answers

- The Edi peak: a measure of the neural inspiratory effort, or respiratory drive
- The Edi minimum: a measure of the tonic activity of the diaphragm, or the effort to prevent alveolar de-recruitment at end expiration
- The Edi trigger: the minimum increase in electrical activity from the preceding baseline that will trigger the ventilator (set by the clinician to recognize strong Edi signals as breath and distinguish them from background noise)
- NAVA level: a conversion factor that converts the Edi signal into a proportional pressure

When initiating NAVA ventilation, it is important to titrate the NAVA level to achieve optimal respiratory unloading. Respiratory unloading is achieved once a plateau phase is reached, where additional titration of the NAVA level does not result in further increases in peak inspiratory pressures and tidal volume. Increases in NAVA levels beyond this breaking point result in downregulation of Edi.¹

## 32. C. Nasal intermittent positive pressure ventilation may have benefit in reducing extubation failure compared with CPAP.

Nasal intermittent positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) is a method of noninvasive respiratory support that combines continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with ventilator breaths. It can be synchronized (SNIPPV) or non-synchronized (NIPPV). Initial trials indicated that SNIPPV reduced the risk of extubation failure by 33% compared with CPAP alone with a number needed to treat of 3.¹⁻⁴ A Cochrane review that included 5 trials using SNIPPV, 2 trials using NIPPV, and 1 trial using both methods concluded that NIPPV decreased extubation failure and need for reintubation within 48 hours to 1 week with no effect on bronchopulmonary dysplasia or mortality.⁵

## 33. C. Using a longer inflation time

Establishment and maintenance of functional residual capacity (FRC) is critical to successful transition and effective ventilation at birth. Several methods have been shown to be effective in helping preterm neonates establish FRC after birth, including

- Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and positive end-expiratory pressure have been shown to facilitate lung recruitment, reduce atelectotrauma, and promote lung liquid resorption.¹
- Sustained inflation (SI) strategies where a prolonged inflation time is used to establish FRC has been studied in both experimental models and neonates. A meta-analyses including 4 randomized controlled trials concluded that SI decreases the need for mechanical ventilation at 72 hours but does not affect bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) or death. In addition, an increase in the number of neonates requiring treatment for patent ductus arteriosus was noted.² A recent Cochrane review of SI versus standard inflation concluded that SI does not decrease mortality, need for intubation, need for or duration of respiratory support, or BPD.³ More concerning, a recent large randomized controlled trial was stopped early due to excess mortality in the SI group.⁴ At this time the effects of SI on respiratory outcomes in preterm neonates require further study and the use of SI is not recommended in routine clinical practice.

## 34. D. Lucinactant (Surfaxin)

Third-generation surfactants are synthetic surfactants containing proteins capable of mimicking the properties of surfactant protein (SP) B and SP-C. Two such surfactants have been developed: recombinant SP-C (Venticute) and lucinactant. Lucinactant is the only one that has been studied in neonates with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). It contains a 21-amino acid peptide, $\mathrm{KL}_4$, that reproduces the function of SP-B. While lucinactant has been shown to be safe and effective in reducing mortality associated with RDS, it was not found to be superior to animal-derived surfactants. $^{1-3}$

## 35. E. To deliver HFNV, a machine that provides high-frequency ventilation invasively can be used to alter the frequency and amplitude of pulsations.

High-frequency nasal ventilation (HFNV) is a form of noninvasive respiratory support where small tidal volumes are delivered at high frequency, eliminating the need for synchronization. Similar to continuous positive airway pressure, HFNV can be used as a primary mode of noninvasive respiratory support in spontaneously breathing neonates. During HFNV, a ventilator that provides invasive high-frequency ventilation is used, allowing for adjustments in frequency and amplitude of the pulsations, as well as base pressure, based on the neonate's needs. $^{1}$

In experimental lamb models, HFNV has been shown to support normal inspiratory dilator muscle activity without increasing inspiratory constrictor activity, which has been shown to occur during noninvasive positive pressure ventilation. $^{2,3}$

## 36. C. A randomized controlled trial has shown that caffeine therapy can reduce the risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

Methylxanthines inhibit adenosine receptors in the brain and are effective in the treatment of apnea of prematurity (AOP). The use of methylxanthines leads to

- Improved respiratory drive
- Increased minute ventilation and carbon dioxide sensitivity
- Decreased hypoxic ventilator depression
- Improved diaphragmatic contractility
- Improved lung compliance due to weak diuretic effect

Caffeine citrate has largely replaced theophylline because of broader therapeutic range and longer half-life. Caffeine therapy is recommended for all preterm neonates less than 28 to 32 weeks' gestation depending on center. $^{2,3}$ Caffeine has been shown to significantly decrease the incidence of bronchopulmonary dysplasia as well as the need for medical or surgical treatment of patent ductus arteriosus. $^{4}$

In addition to caffeine therapy, the use of noninvasive positive airway pressure support after extubation is recommended. Administration of positive pressures splints the airway and has been shown to decrease extubation failure and apnea. $^{5}$ This can be most effectively achieved using continuous positive airway pressure or noninvasive positive pressure ventilation. High-flow nasal cannula is also an option in larger

## 37. E. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a pathogen recovered from airway secretions in patients who have VAP by tracheal aspirate and bronchoalveolar lavage methods.

The use of tracheal aspirates to help establish the diagnosis of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is controversial. Tracheal aspirates do not allow for the distinction between colonization and pneumonia and have been shown to have low sensitivity, specificity, and positive predictive value for the diagnosis of VAP.¹ However, in neonates suspected of having VAP, the identification of the organisms colonizing the airway may be helpful in guiding antibiotic therapy.

In a cohort study, gram-negative organisms were identified in 94% of tracheal aspirates obtained in neonates diagnosed with VAP, with Staphylococcus aureus accounting for about 25% of cases.² Of note, multiple organisms were identified in 58% of patients. In contrast, when using bronchoalveolar lavage, Pseudomonas aeruginosa was identified in 62% of patients and multiple organisms were identified in only 16.7% of patients.³

## 38. A. If the lungs show overinflation, one or more of the following settings can be decreased: CPAP, peak inspiratory pressure of sinusoidal breaths, and/or pulsatile rate.

Similar to continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), high-frequency nasal ventilation (HFNV) can be used to support spontaneously breathing neonates noninvasively. During HFNV, small tidal volumes are delivered at high frequency by a ventilator that usually provides invasive high-frequency ventilation. Adjustments in frequency and amplitude of the pulsations, as well as base pressure, are made based on the neonates' needs. Based on multiple studies and clinical experience, the following guidelines for the use of HFNV have been developed:

- Typical CPAP level: 5 to 7 cm H₂O (can be titrated up to 10).
- Recommended rate: 300 to 480 breaths per minute. Lower frequencies should be considered in neonates with nonhomogeneous lung disease, with air-trapping, or for whom increase in amplitude fails to improve ventilation.
- Sinusoidal breaths: 6 to 12 breaths per minute.
- Peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) titrated to see chest wall movement.

In cases of lung overinflation, one or more of the following settings can be decreased: CPAP, the PIP of sinusoidal breaths, and/or pulsatile rate. Conversely, these parameters can be increased when underinflation of the lung is observed.

In neonates with fraction of inspired oxygen requirement greater than 0.4, an assessment of lung volume is recommended with subsequent increase in CPAP for suboptimal inflation or, conversely, decrease in CPAP if air trapping and overinflation is observed.¹

# 39. E. Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits sodium-potassium-chloride cotransporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle and the lungs. About 25% of tubular sodium reabsorption occurs in the ascending loop of Henle; hence, the administration of loop diuretics results in significant diuresis.¹,²

# 40. E. The volume of distribution of caffeine increases linearly with increasing weight.

Caffeine is commonly used in the neonatal intensive care unit and has been shown to be effective for the treatment of apnea of prematurity. Caffeine is metabolized in the liver via a N7-demethylation process that matures with increasing gestational age and postmenstrual age. In addition, caffeine metabolism has been shown to be higher in girls. In very low birth weight preterm infants, both caffeine clearance and the volume of distribution of caffeine are significantly lower, increasing linearly with increasing weight.¹,²

# 41. D. Type 2 malformations account for 20% of cases and are multicystic with cyst size greater than 2 cm.

Congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) occurs with an incidence of 1 in 10,000 and represent 40% of all congenital lung malformations. They more typically occur in the lower lobes and there is no right or left predilection. Most CPAMs are diagnosed prenatally.

The classic classification of CPAM includes 5 subtypes.

- Type 0 (rare): limited to the upper tracheobronchial tree
- Type 1 (70% of cases): macro-cystic (cyst size &gt;2 cm); may have a dominant single cyst or multiple cysts
- Type 2 (20%): multicystic with cyst size greater than 2 cm
- Type 3 (10%): microcystic adenomatoid solid without cystic elements; can be associated with other anomalies and carries a worse prognosis
- Type 4 (rare): hamartomatous malformation of the distal acini with peripheral cysts

Some authors recommend the use of a more clinically applicable classification into microcystic (&lt;5 mm cysts) or macro-cystic (≥5 mm cysts).¹

## 45. C. Octreotide can be administered along with a combination of medium-chain triglyceride formula and parenteral nutrition.

Chylothorax can complicate the postoperative course of neonates requiring cardiac surgery. The principles of management of neonatal chylothorax include drainage of the effusion for diagnosis and symptom relief, nutritional support, octreotide, and, in some cases, surgical management.¹,²

Nutritional management may involve periods of "NPO" to reduce lymphatic flow as well as the use of formula containing medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) that are directly absorbed. Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, is the most commonly used pharmacological agent in the management of chylothorax. Octreotide causes mild splanchnic vasoconstriction and decrease in hepatic blood flow, thereby decreasing lymphatic flow.² While it is commonly used, there are no randomized controlled trials to support its use in the neonatal population. Immune prophylaxis with intravenous immunoglobulin may be considered because of the high risk of nosocomial infections in neonates with chylothorax.³,⁴

A stepwise approach starting with an MCT formula and escalating to NPO with total parenteral nutrition and octreotide depending on response may be helpful in avoiding the need for surgery.² Response to medical management is typically observed for 2 to 4 weeks before considering surgical options.

## 46. C. These monitors have an inherent bias that can range from 2% to 5%.

Monitors measuring pulse oximetry (Spo₂, peripheral capillary oxygen saturation) are routinely used in clinical practice. These monitors display a percentage of hemoglobin saturated with oxygen that is calculated from the ratio between red wavelengths and infrared wavelengths. They have an inherent bias ranging from 2% to 5%. Monitors using signal extraction technology have a better sensitivity and specificity in addition to fewer missed events and alarms. Some monitors use more than 2 wavelengths, allowing for the measurements of hemoglobin, methemoglobin, and carboxyhemoglobin, in addition to Spo₂.¹,²

## 47. C. Continued use of caffeine is indicated if the infant is continuing to have events.

Caffeine citrate has been shown to be effective for the treatment of apnea of prematurity (AOP). Initiation of caffeine therapy is recommended in all preterm infants less than 28 to 32 weeks' gestation.¹,² While there are no clear guidelines on when to discontinue caffeine therapy, most clinicians discontinue caffeine

between 32 weeks' gestation and 34 weeks' gestation if the infant is no longer experiencing apneas requiring interventions over the previous 5 to 7 days.³ Recent data suggest that prolonged caffeine therapy decreases the intermittent hypoxemia burden in preterm infants 34 to 37 weeks' gestation. The long-term effect is unclear at this time.⁴

There is no conclusive evidence to support the use of anti-reflux medication in infants with AOP. Doxapram is another possible pharmacological intervention but is rarely used because of serious side effects including irritability, hypertension, and decreased cerebral blood flow. Other therapeutic options, such as red blood cell transfusion, increase inspiratory carbon dioxide concentration, and olfactory or mechanosensory stimulation requires further studies.

48. B. Preliminary studies suggest that neonates who received intratracheal administration of budesonide with surfactant (beractant) compared with surfactant alone required lower mean airway pressures for ventilation and had lower oxygen index and lower $\mathrm{PCO}_2$ during the first 24 to 48 hours.

Inhaled corticosteroids have been studied in the treatment and prevention of bronchopulmonary dysplasia in preterm neonates and infants because this route of therapy offers the theoretical advantage of high local delivery of the drug without the adverse effects observed with systemic administration. However, inconsistent and overall poor drug delivery to the lung has hampered progress in this area. As such, new methods of delivering inhaled corticosteroid using surfactant as a vehicle have been developed. Preliminary studies indicate that neonates who receive intratracheal budesonide with surfactant require lower mean airway pressure and have lower oxygen index and $\mathrm{PCO}_2$ 24 to 48 hours after administration compared with neonates who received surfactant alone. Further, neonates in the budesonide group were also more likely to be extubated in the first week and to survive without BPD (82% vs 58%). A transient increase in blood pressure was observed with budesonide administration, but the blood pressure remained within reference range for age. There was no effect of budesonide exposure on neurocognitive outcomes at age 2 years.¹²

49. E. Medications such as diuretics and inhalation agents are not currently recommended as standard therapy in the management of TTN.

Transient tachypnea of the newborn is caused by a delay in fetal lung fluid clearance. It is characterized by onset of symptoms shortly after birth including tachypnea, nasal flaring, grunting, and retraction and in some cases oxygen requirement (typically fraction of inspired oxygen is &lt; 0.4). Transient tachypnea of the newborn is a self-limiting disorder of delayed transition, and symptoms commonly resolve within 72 hours. Treatment is supportive. The use of diuretics, inhaled racemic epinephrine, and inhaled $\beta_2$-adrenergic agonists requires further study and is not recommended at this time.¹²

## 51. A. Tidal volume can vary with changes in lung compliance, particularly after surfactant administration, resulting in inadvertently large tidal volume delivery and lung injury.

Pressure-controlled ventilation is a commonly used mode of ventilation in neonates. In pressure-limited ventilation, the peak inspiratory pressure is set and the volume delivered to the lungs will vary depending on compliance. Advantages of pressure-limited ventilation include a decreased effect of endotracheal tube leak and improved intrapulmonary gas distribution because of decelerating flow patterns. Disadvantages of pressure-limited volume ventilation include variable tidal volume delivery with risks of hyperventilation in situations of improved compliance (ie, post-surfactant) and volutrauma. $^{1-3}$

## 52. D. Meta-analysis of the 4 main trials favored SI for the outcome of mechanical ventilation within 72 hours after birth.

The use of sustained inflation (SI) in the delivery room has been extensively studied in experimental models. Observational studies have indicated that SI is feasible and safe in neonates, and subsequent randomized clinical trials (RCTs) of SI compared with standard inflations have been published. In a meta-analysis of the 4 main RCTs, SI was found to decrease the need for mechanical ventilation at 72 hours but not rates of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) or death. Further, there was an increase in the number of neonates requiring treatment for patent ductus arteriosus who received SI. $^{1}$ However, results from a recent clinical trial have raised some concerns regarding the safety of SI in extremely preterm neonates. The trial was stopped early due to excess mortality among the SI group. $^{2}$ The most recent Cochrane review of SI versus standard inflation concluded that SI does not result in decreased mortality, need for intubation, need for or duration of respiratory support, or BPD. $^{3}$

## 53. D. 70% to 75%

While human fetuses develop in a relatively hypoxemic environment, fetal tissues are not hypoxic. The highest oxygen saturation $(\mathrm{SPO}_2)$ is measured in the umbilical vein and is between $70\%$ and $75\%$. This $\mathrm{SPO}_2$ decreases to $60\%$ prior to birth and can be as low as $30\%$ during labor. A gradual increase in $\mathrm{SPO}_2$ is observed after birth, with neonates born via cesarean delivery taking longer to reach $94\%$. Nomograms of expected $\mathrm{SPO}_2$ increase after birth have been published to assist clinicians with postnatal management and avoidance of hyperoxia. ## 54. C. In lymphoscintigraphy, a radioisotope is injected into the webs between a neonate’s fingers and toes, with the potential to identify aplasia, hypoplasia, and dysplasia of the lymphatic vessels.

Diagnostic imaging may be indicated in neonates with chylothorax to identify a cause and visualize the source of lymphatic leakage. Several imaging modalities are available.

- Conventional lymphography provides the best anatomical details of the lymphatic vessels but is technically challenging in neonates because it requires direct cannulation of the lymphatic vessels.¹
- Intranodal lymphography also provides good visualization of the lymphatic system but involves injection of ethiodized oil in a lymph node under ultrasonographic guidance and is typically performed under general anesthesia.²
- Magnetic resonance imaging lymphangiography, while noninvasive, is best at evaluating nodes and has poor resolution for the evaluation of the lymph vessels.³
- Lymphoscintigraphy is feasible in neonates but has a much lower resolution than conventional lymphography. It is performed by injecting a radioisotope into the webs between a neonate’s fingers and toes and may provide information on lymph vessels aplasia, hypoplasia, or dysplasia and can identify the lymphatic duct.⁴,⁵

These techniques require expertise and are generally not routinely available.

## 55. D. Lamellar bodies with eccentric dense inclusions

Inherited disorders of surfactant metabolism are caused by mutations in surfactant protein (SP) B, SP-C, adenosine triphosphate-binding cassette member A3 (ABCA3), and NKX2-1 genes.

Patients with ABCA3 deficiency have a variable clinical presentation ranging from acute neonatal respiratory distress to interstitial lung disease in infancy or childhood. Lamellar bodies with eccentric dense inclusions are characteristic of ABCA3 deficiency on histopathologic examination of the lung tissue. Nonspecific findings suggestive of a disorder of surfactant metabolism include diffuse alveolar type II cell hyperplasia, alveolar septal thickening, and alveolar proteinosis.¹,²

## 57. D. Inositol

Inositol is an essential nutrient that has been shown to promote surfactant maturation. To date, 4 small randomized controlled trials have been published investigating the efficacy and safety of inositol in preterm neonates with respiratory distress syndrome. A meta-analysis of these trials concluded that inositol significantly decreases neonatal death with a number needed to treat of 11. In addition, a decrease in severe retinopathy of prematurity and severe intraventricular hemorrhage was observed. A multicenter trial aiming to confirm these promising findings is ongoing. $^{1}$

## 59. B. Increases alveolar carbon dioxide elimination

Permissive hypercapnia is a ventilator strategy using low tidal volume and minute ventilation to decrease ventilator-induced lung injury. During permissive hypercapnia, higher $\mathrm{Paco}_2$ values are accepted.

During permissive hypercapnia, higher alveolar carbon dioxide level results in increased alveolar carbon dioxide elimination because carbon dioxide elimination is proportional to $\mathrm{Paco}_2$ and alveolar ventilation. Other beneficial effects of hypercapnia and hypercapnic acidosis include

- Improved ventilation-perfusion mismatch
- Increased unloading of oxygen to the tissue secondary to a right shift of the oxygen dissociation curve (Bohr effect)
- Stabilization of the respiratory drive with decrease in apnea events
- Increased cardiac output despite decrease in cardiac contractility
Hypercapnia also has some deleterious effects including
- Increase in pulmonary vascular resistance
- Small reduction in alveolar oxygen concentration $^{1}$

## 60. C. Distal convoluted tubule

Inhibition of sodium and chloride transport in the distal convoluted tubule represents the primary mechanism of action of thiazide diuretics. Because $90\%$ of filtered sodium is reabsorbed proximally to the distal convoluted tubule, thiazide diuretics only lead to moderate diuresis. A synergistic effect is observed when thiazide diuretics are administered with loop diuretics. $^{1,2}$

61. E. Continuous pulse oximetry should be used before weaning oxygen and can be modified to spot checks when weaning daytime oxygen.

Home oxygen therapy may be necessary for preterm infants with bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD). Typically, infants with BPD will go home on flows ranging from 0.1 to 0.5 L/min with a goal of maintaining oxygen saturation (SPO₂) at or greater than 95% to 98%. Infants on higher flows, or requiring sildenafil in addition to nasal cannula oxygen, are at high risk for right-sided heart failure dysfunction and hospital readmission. Continuous pulse oximetry is used to monitor SPO₂ before weaning oxygen and can be modified to spot checks when weaning daytime oxygen. Strategies used to wean home oxygen vary widely. In general, adherence to the following principles is recommended:

- Discontinuation of diuretics prior to nasal cannula wean, if applicable.
- Scheduled, slow wean of daytime nasal cannula flow (ie, 0.1 L/min every month), until discontinued.
- Once off daytime oxygen, wean nighttime oxygen using a similar strategy.²

62. D. Empiric treatment may include an antipseudomonal agent such as piperacillin-tazobactam.

Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is a common health care-associated infection in neonates. There are no consensus guidelines for the treatment of VAP in the neonatal population. Treatment guidelines have been largely derived from adult literature and include the recommendation to initiate empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic, ideally based on local bacterial colonization and antimicrobial sensitivity data. Such treatments may include an antipseudomonal agent such as piperacillin-tazobactam or ticarcillin-clavulanate to cover for gram-negative and gram-positive organisms.¹,²

63. A. This may be a presentation of severe transient tachypnea of the newborn with retained lung fluid, which may be associated with low surfactant levels.

Many factors contribute to the severity of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm neonates. Protective factors include administration of antenatal steroids as well as conditions that induce lung maturation such as chorioamnionitis.

Conversely, many factors can either contribute to the RDS picture or represent alternative causes of respiratory distress. Those include

- Variable degrees of lung hypoplasia, such as that observed in growth-restricted neonates.
- Pulmonary hypertension.
- Inflammation and infection.
- Retained fetal lung fluid. In experimental models, delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid has been shown to contribute to the severity of RDS in preterm monkeys.¹ In addition, low levels of surfactant have been found in neonates with severe transient tachypnea of the newborn.²
- Ventilator-induced lung injury.
- Failure of respiratory drive with apnea.³,⁴

65. A. Several trials of sustained inflation are ongoing and may provide further information on the potential effect of SI on outcomes and which methods may be most optimal.

The use of sustained inflation (SI) in the delivery room is not currently recommended for routine clinical practice. Results from the recently published Sustained Aeration for Infant Lungs trial have raised some concerns regarding the safety of SI in preterm neonates. This 18-center, international trial enrolled extremely preterm neonates (23–26 weeks’ gestation) and the intervention consisted of 2 SIs (maximal peak pressure of 25 cm H₂O and inflation time of 15 seconds). The trial was stopped early because of a significant increase in mortality at less than 48 hours after birth: 7.4% in the SI group versus 1.4% in the standard resuscitation group (adjusted risk difference, 5.6% [95% CI, 2.1% to 9.1%]; P = .002).¹

Three additional multicenter randomized controlled trials enrolling extremely preterm neonates are currently ongoing and may shed more light on the risks and benefits of SI in the delivery room.

66. D. Type II pneumocytes initiate surfactant production typically at around 26 weeks’ gestational age.

Congenital lung abnormalities have an estimated incidence of 1 in 10,000 and can occur throughout lung development. Lung development occurs in 5 stages.

- Embryonic stage (0–7 weeks): formation of the lung bud and conducting airways (trachea, lobar, and segmental and subsegmental bronchi)
- Pseudoglandular stage (7–17 weeks): branching morphogenesis with formation of 20 generations of airways, terminal bronchioles, and closure of the pleuroperitoneal folds
- The canalicular stage (16 to 23–27 weeks): terminal branching, respiratory bronchioles and establishment of the early air-blood interface, and differentiation of type II pneumocytes with emergence of lamellar bodies
- The saccular stage (24–28 to 36–38 weeks): saccule formation; surfactant production in type II pneumocytes at around 26 weeks’ gestation
- The alveolar stage (approximately 36 weeks–2 years): formation of the terminal alveoli, secondary inter-saccular, and inter-ductal septation with exponential increase in the lung surface area for gas exchange¹

## 68. E. Relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter

Caffeine has a wide therapeutic range, and dosing regimens vary by centers. The dosing regimen described in the vignette has been shown to lead to a therapeutic level in 70% of patients.¹ Caffeine decreases lower gastroesophageal sphincter pressure and increases reflux episodes, independently of plasma concentration.²,³

With increasing caffeine levels, signs of caffeine toxicity may include hypertonia, sweating, tachycardia, cardiac failure, pulmonary edema, metabolic acidosis, hyperglycemia, and creatine kinase elevation. Serious caffeine toxicity is not observed until levels reach 40 to 50 mg/L.⁴

## 69. B. Lipases

Surfactant is an important therapeutic consideration in the treatment of neonates with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). It is most effective when administered early, before the onset of lung injury. Lung injury can affect surfactant function via several mechanisms, including¹

- Inactivation by environmental exposure such as oxidants
- Degradation by lipases
- Conversion to inactive structural forms
- Inhibition of function by plasma proteins and lipids as well as inflammatory products
- Altered synthesis by alveolar type 2 cell secondary to circulating cytokines

## 70. A. An association between TTN and subsequent development of asthma has been described, with potential increased risk if the delivery was via cesarean.

Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a self-resolving disorder due to delay in fetal lung fluid clearance. Treatment is supportive and symptoms typically resolve within 48 to 72 hours. In rare cases, tachypnea persists for 1 week or more. Development of persistent pulmonary hypertension has also been described in severe cases, also called "malignant" TTN.

Studies have suggested a link between TTN and later risk of asthma, possibly due to underlying genetic predisposition. This risk is higher in neonates via cesarean.¹⁻³

## 71. B. Preterm neonates have enhanced sensitivity of the respiratory control system to inhibitory neurotransmitters, such as serotonin, that can lead to apnea.

Apnea of prematurity (AOP) is common and incidence is inversely correlated to gestational age, affecting 97% of neonates less than 28 weeks' gestation and about 20% of neonates at 34 weeks' gestation.¹ It can

---

<!-- Page 622 -->

Answers

persist beyond term and up to 44 weeks' gestation in some neonates.²³ Preterm neonates are at risk of AOP because of the developmental immaturity of several mechanisms involved in control of breathing and maintenance of airway patency.

While AOP is classically classified as central, obstructive, and mixed, it most likely represents a continuum of events, with central apnea having an obstructive component and vice versa. Pharyngeal wall instability, excessive neck flexion or extension, and nasal obstruction have been implicated in the pathophysiology of obstructive apnea. Central apnea is characterized by the absence of chest wall motion with no evidence of obstruction to airflow.⁴

The underlying mechanisms of central apnea include

- Enhanced sensitivity of the respiratory control system to inhibitory neurotransmitters
- Hypoxic ventilatory depression secondary to increased peripheral chemoreceptor sensitivity in the carotid bodies
- Impaired hypercapnic ventilatory response and apnea threshold only slightly below the eupnea threshold
- Exaggerated laryngeal chemoreflex that may result in apnea
- Increased amount of active sleep with associated generalized inhibition of skeletal muscle activity⁵⁶

## 72. A. Apnea is the main driver for IH in preterm infants.

Intermittent hypoxemia (IH), defined as episodic, brief desaturation events to hemoglobin oxygen saturation levels below 80%, is common in preterm infants. The main underlying mechanism of IH is apnea. The typical sequence of events progresses from apnea, followed by IH, and, if prolonged, bradycardia. It is important to note that in very preterm infants, IH can occur with apnea much shorter than the traditional definition of 15 to 20 seconds. With regard to an infant's well-being, both IH and bradycardia are more relevant outcome measures than apnea.

While apnea of prematurity is classically classified as central, obstructive, and mixed, it most likely represents a continuum of events, with central apnea having an obstructive component and vice versa.¹² Preterm infants are at increased for IH due to the combination of lung disease and immaturity with respiratory instability. The mechanisms underlying the pathophysiology of IH in preterm infants include

- Impaired hypercapnic response
- An apneic Pco₂ threshold only 1 to 2 mm Hg below the eupneic threshold
- Paradoxical ventilatory depression in response to hypoxia until about 35 weeks' gestation
- Hyperexcitable carotid bodies
- Immature laryngeal chemoreflex³⁻⁵

Lung immaturity and injury both lead to low pulmonary reserves and further compound the problem.

74. D. With $V_T$ as the primary control variable, inflation pressure will fall as lung compliance improves and result in weaning of pressure.

In volume-targeted ventilation (VTV), the peak inspiratory pressure varies (based on compliance) to deliver a set tidal volume ($V_T$). As shown in a Cochrane meta-analysis, this has the advantage of avoiding excessive $V_T$ and minimizes the risk of volutrauma. Volume-targeted ventilation significantly decreases the risk of death or bronchopulmonary dysplasia as well as the risk of pneumothorax when compared with pressure-limited ventilation.¹ In another meta-analysis, a decrease in the risk of severe intraventricular hemorrhage was also observed.² Results from these meta-analyses should be interpreted with caution because of the wide range of methodologies and outcomes reported. Importantly, VTV is critically dependent on accurate $V_T$ measurement. In neonates, volume guarantee is the only volume-targeted mode that has been shown to achieve stable $V_T$ delivery resulting in decreased risk of hypocapnia.

75. D. Infants born preterm with history of AOP have been noted to have higher baseline heart rates and lower heart rate variability in the first several months after birth, which is similar to findings in infants who died of SIDS.

Preterm infants with a history of apnea of prematurity (AOP) have higher baseline heart rates and lower heart rate variability in the first several months after birth.¹ While similar findings have been noted in infants who died of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS), there is no direct evidence that AOP is causally related to SIDS. Studies indicate that a history of AOP does not predict SIDS or the occurrence of clinically significant post-discharge events, and the need for readmission.² The use of home monitoring in this setting has not been shown to reduce SIDS. In addition, AOP typically resolves around 44 weeks’ gestational age, while the highest incidence of SIDS is around 47 weeks’ postmenstrual age. Based on this evidence, AOP and SIDS are not considered related disorders.²

Nasal intermittent positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) has been shown to decrease extubation failure in preterm neonates when compared with nasal continuous positive airway pressure.¹ In addition, with reports of decreased mortality and chronic lung disease,²,³ the use of NIPPV has increased in recent years.

One of the main disadvantages of NIPPV includes the lack of synchronization, which may lead to important adverse effects.

- Upper airway constrictor muscle activation⁴,⁵
- Increased mean airway pressure, oxygen requirements, and fluctuation in blood pressure and intracranial pressure⁶
- Gastric distention when breaths are delivered against a closed glottis⁷

With this in mind, newer methods of providing noninvasive ventilator support have been developed including noninvasive neurally adjusted ventilator assist and high-frequency nasal ventilation.

## 77. C. When CPAP is used in preterm newborns at birth, the increase in $\mathrm{SPO}_2$ occurs more rapidly than those in nomograms.

Monitoring oxygen saturation ($\mathrm{SPO}_2$) in the delivery room is standard of care and should optimally be measured from the right hand for preductal $\mathrm{SPO}_2$ monitoring. The left hand is another option in cases where the right hand is not available and is preductal in greater than 80% of patients. According to manufacturer recommendation, sensors should be applied to the palm and dorsum of the hand, not the radial artery.

Oxygen saturation monitoring after birth is important in assisting clinicians in avoiding hypoxemia and hyperoxemia. Studies indicate that hyperoxemia in the postnatal period, even for a short period, alters whole-genome expression and negatively affects outcomes including increased risk of leukemia and cancer in childhood.¹,² Nomograms of expected $\mathrm{SPO}_2$ increase after birth have been published.³ It is important to recognize that neonates receiving continuous positive airway pressure support experience a more rapid increase in their $\mathrm{SPO}_2$.⁴,⁵

## 78. B. Separate suctioning equipment should be used for tracheal and oral secretions.

Bundles to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) have been developed and many of the items beneficial in adults are not applicable to neonates. Neonatal VAP prevention bundles should include the following preventative strategies:

- Promote the use of noninvasive ventilation and assess daily for extubation readiness.
- Prevent unintentional extubation.
- Suction oropharynx prior to endotracheal tube adjustment.

## 79. D. Hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis

Chronic use of furosemide is associated with

- Electrolyte disarray including hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis. Hypochloremic alkalosis is very prevalent among preterm infants receiving furosemide due to ongoing maturational processes.
- Hyperuricemia.
- Metabolic alkalosis.
- Nephrocalcinosis secondary to increased urinary calcium losses.
- Osteopenia.

In addition, preterm infants exposed to furosemide have an increased risk of sensorineural hearing loss. The risk of furosemide-associated ototoxicity can be mitigated by slow administration of intravenous doses as well as twice daily dosing.¹,²

## 80. C. The presence of chorioamnionitis, even when asymptomatic, can potentially lead to early maturation of the lungs, including increased surfactant level.

Exposure to chorioamnionitis is common in preterm neonates born at less than 30 weeks’ gestation (50% of cases) and may be clinically silent.¹ The subsequent inflammation may result in early lung maturation, primarily via increased amounts of surfactant and ultimately decreased incidence of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).²

While exposure to RDS may lead to improved respiratory outcomes, it is also important to recognize the risk of diffuse pneumonia under these circumstances. Neonates with pneumonia are rarely recognized and rather are thought to have RDS. A poor response to exogenous surfactant may be a clue that an underlying pneumonia is confounding the RDS picture.

## 81. A. Congenital lobar emphysema is also known as congenital lobar hyperinflation and is caused by overdistension of one or more lobes, potentially causing severe respiratory compromise.

Congenital lobar emphysema (CLE), or congenital lobar hyperinflation, describes the overdistension of one or more lung lobes. Multiple etiologies have been implicated in the development of CLE, including dysplastic cartilage formation in the canalicular stage, or endoluminal obstruction resulting in ball-valve effect in the saccular and alveolar stages of lung development. Congenital lobal emphysema is more common in the upper lobes and affects the left upper lobe in 40% to 50% of patients. The next most common location is the right middle lobe (30%–40% of cases). Congenital lobal emphysema can lead to significant respiratory compromise.

---

<!-- Page 626 -->

Answers

In contrast, congenital pulmonary airway malformations are more common in the lower lobes and do not have a right or left predilection. They are the most common type of congenital pulmonary abnormalities, representing 40% of all cases.

Bronchopulmonary sequestration is classified as intralobar (75% of cases) or extralobar and is characterized by anomalous systemic arterial blood supply (rather than pulmonary). It does not communicate with the tracheobronchial tree, has a pleural covering, and occurs most commonly in the lower lobes, particularly the left lower lobe.

Bronchogenic cysts occur in the mediastinum in 85% of patients. When they occur in the lung, they are typically located in the lower lobes with no right or left predilection. Bronchogenic cysts are thin-walled cysts with a bronchial epithelial lining, and they do not communicate with the bronchial tree.¹⁻³

## 82. A. Angiotensin-converting enzyme

While the etiology of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is multifactorial, genetic factors have been shown to account for 53% of the variance in the susceptibility for BPD.¹ Multiple candidate genes regulating inflammation, oxygen toxicity, cell injury and death, tissue repair, and infection have been studied in this context. Among those, the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) gene is of particular interest because increased ACE activity leads to fluid retention and may increase the risk of BPD. Angiotensin-converting enzyme gene polymorphism, consisting of the presence (insertion, I) or absence (deletion, D) of a 287-bp Alu repeat in intron 16, leads to variable ACE activity with the D allele having increased activity. Kazzi and Quasney found that the presence of the D allele of ACE was associated with increased risk (47% vs 22%, P = .025) as well as increased severity of BPD in 120 neonates 1,250 g or less at birth and who survived to 36 weeks' postmenstrual age.² This finding was not, however, replicated in a study of 245 mechanically ventilated preterm neonates less than 1,250 g at birth. In this study, the ACE I/D polymorphism was not found to affect the development of BPD at 36 weeks' postconceptional age.³
