## 83. A. It is likely that periods of hypoxia (ie, low tissue oxygenation) may lead to decreased respiratory drive in this infant, with reduced respiratory rate during those episodes.

Preterm infants are at increased for intermittent hypoxemia (IH) because of low pulmonary reserves, particularly low functional residual capacity (FRC), secondary to lung immaturity and/or injury. Functional residual capacity is inversely correlated with IH, with more rapid IH occurring in infants with lower FRC.¹ Periodic breathing and periodic apnea have been shown to be associated with higher frequency and severity of IH, likely secondary to progressive decrease in FRC volume. While inflammation can lead to respiratory depression because of increased prostaglandin production, IH itself may in turn be proinflammatory, resulting in a positive feedback loop.²,³

In addition, immaturity of the respiratory reflexes and responses further compounds the problem.

- Preterm infants demonstrate an impaired hypercapnic response, whereby the response to changes in Pco₂ is flat compared with older patients. In addition, the apneic Pco₂ threshold is only 1 to 2 mm Hg below the eupneic threshold, resulting in increased likelihood of IH.¹
- Preterm infants also have a paradoxical ventilatory depression in response to hypoxia, whereby hypoxemia results in decreased respiratory rate and decreased minute ventilation. Hypoxic ventilator depression persists until about 35 weeks' gestation.⁴,⁵
- Preterm infants also have hyperexcitable carotid bodies, which can lead to hyperventilation, decreased Pco₂ and apnea, and an immature laryngeal chemoreflex.⁶

## 84. E. In the CAP trial, there were lower rates of severe retinopathy of prematurity among the caffeine-treated group compared with the placebo group.

The Caffeine for Apnea of Prematurity (CAP) trial is a large randomized placebo-controlled trial that investigated caffeine therapy for apnea of prematurity in 2,006 preterm neonates 500 to 1,250 g birth weight.¹ Results from this trial demonstrated that caffeine therapy is safe in preterm neonates and results in

- Improved respiratory outcomes including the durations of endotracheal intubation, positive pressure ventilation, and supplemental oxygen use. Neonates who received caffeine were less likely to be prescribed postnatal corticosteroids. In addition, the rate of bronchopulmonary dysplasia decreased from 46.9% to 36.3%. Benefits were most significant with early initiation of caffeine (within the first 72 hours after birth).
- Decreased need for pharmacological or surgical interventions for a patent ductus arteriosus.
- Decrease in the primary outcome of death or survival with major disability at 18 months' postmenstrual age. While this was no longer significant at the 5-year follow-up, neonates who received caffeine had improved motor coordination and visual perception.
- Decrease in the incidence of severe retinopathy of prematurity.
- Temporary slowing of weight gain with no difference after 4 weeks of therapy.¹⁻³

# 87. A. Assisted ventilation to optimize airway and alveolar patency

Exogenous surfactant administration is an effective therapy in the treatment of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). A key to the success of surfactant therapy is homogeneous distribution over a large surface area of the lung. To optimize surfactant distribution, the factors should be considered.

- Volume of dose (Larger is better.)
- Rate of administration (Faster is better.)
- Ventilator assistance (to facilitate airway clearance and alveolar patency)
- Presence of lung liquid (to improve distribution)
- Positional maneuvers (to combat the effects of gravity)

# 88. A. Airway obstruction

Aspiration of meconium can lead to significant respiratory distress at birth because of multiple mechanisms, including

- Airway obstruction, either partially or completely, resulting in overdistention and atelectasis of the affected respiratory unit. This mechanism is prominent early in the course of the disease.
- Pulmonary vasoconstriction and persistent pulmonary hypertension, typically improving within 3 to 4 days. Pulmonary hypertension can occur because of chronic uterine hypoxia and post-acinar capillary hypertrophy or be secondary to hypoxia, hypercarbia, acidosis, and/or lung inflammation.
- Surfactant dysfunction, typically in the subacute and late phases of the disease.
- Chemical pneumonitis secondary to low meconium pH (7.1-7.2) as well as presence of enzymes and bile salts.
- Secondary infection. $^{1-3}$

# 89. C. Intubation followed by surfactant treatment has been shown to alter cerebral perfusion and electroencephalographic activity.

Direct instillation to the lungs of exogenous surfactant was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in 1989. Studies indicate that intubation and surfactant administration result in cerebral perfusion alterations as well as suppression of electroencephalographic activity. $^{1}$ Further, rapid changes in systemic blood flow are also observed. $^{2}$

With the success of noninvasive modes of respiratory support in preterm neonates, there has been an increasing interest in the development of minimally invasive methods of surfactant administration. These include administration of surfactant via

- A laryngeal airway mask. This technique is limited to neonates greater than $1,200\mathrm{g}$ and research on this technique is growing.
- Brief tracheal intubation using a thin catheter in spontaneously breathing neonates. A laryngoscope is used for direct visualization of the airway.
- Aerosolization. Studies are ongoing to determine the efficacy of nebulized surfactant.

Multiple types of surfactant are available for use in the United States, including animal-derived and third-generation synthetic surfactants. Lucinactant (Surfaxin) is the only synthetic surfactant studied in neonates. It contains a 21-amino acid peptide, $\mathrm{KL}_4$, that reproduces the function of surfactant protein B. While lucinactant has been shown to be safe and effective in reducing mortality associated with RDS, it was not found to be superior to animal-derived surfactants. $^{3-5}$

## 90. C. When attempted, the LISA procedure was able to be achieved in 94% of neonates without needing intubation.

The less invasive surfactant administration (LISA) procedure was performed in 224 neonates 23 to 27 weeks' gestation born between 2009 and 2011 at the Medical University of Vienna. The LISA procedure is based on the technique described by Kribs and colleagues, where brief tracheal intubation with a thin feeding catheter is performed under direct visualization using Magill forceps.¹ The procedure was performed at about 30 minutes after birth, in newborns on high-flow continuous positive airway pressure of 10 to 15 cm H₂O via a face mask, and after premedication with caffeine. The procedure was successful in 94% of neonates. In this cohort of patients, intubation was avoided in the first week in 65% of neonates, and 41% of these neonates were never intubated. Compared to historical control participants, neonates treated using the LISA method had²

- Increased survival (76% vs 64%, P &lt; .002)
- Decreased incidence of severe intraventricular hemorrhage and cystic periventricular leukomalacia
- Decreased need for supplementary oxygen at 28 days
- Higher incidence of patent ductus arteriosus and retinopathy of prematurity

## 91. D. A pressure pop-off valve is an important component of an HFNC system, to avoid excessive pressures.

High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is defined as flow rates greater than 1 L/min. Devices delivering HFNC include an oxygen blender, a gas heater, a humidifier, and a pop-off valve. The pop-off valve is a critically important safety feature, as supraphysiological distending pressures can occur at high-flow rates.¹ The pressure delivered via HFNC is less reliable than that delivered via continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and depends on the following factors:

- Size of the nasal prongs and degree of nares occlusion.²
- Whether or not the mouth is open.
- Flow rate. There is a linear relationship between flow rate and distending pressure.³ Wilkinson and colleagues determined that there is on average an increase of 0.8 cm H₂O for each increase in flow of 1 L/min if no leak is present.⁴

The use of heated, humidified HFNC has been studied as an initial mode of respiratory support and mostly as post-extubation support in preterm neonates. A recent meta-analysis of published trials indicates that HFNC has similar efficacy in preventing initial treatment failure as CPAP. As a post-extubation method, CPAP had fewer treatment failure than HFNC but was associated with more nasal trauma and pneumothoraxes. Data are lacking on the applicability of heated, humidified HFNC in extremely preterm neonates.⁵

## 92. C. Assist/control mode ventilation.

Assist/control (A/C) mode ventilation is a time-cycled, pressure-limited mode of ventilation where all spontaneous breaths are fully supported by the ventilator. In this mode of ventilation, the neonate controls the ventilator rate, and weaning is achieved by weaning the peak inspiratory pressure. A backup rate is generally set just below the neonate's spontaneous breathing rate in case of apnea. In A/C mode, tidal volume delivery is more uniform and work of breathing is lower.¹

## 93. E. The effect of lower Spo₂ targets on influencing IH events is most pronounced during the early postnatal period, before 2 weeks after birth.

Preterm neonates are at increased risk of intermittent hypoxemia (IH) secondary to lung immaturity/injury and respiratory instability. Intermittent hypoxemia has been shown to have a cumulative adverse effect of retinopathy of prematurity, neurodevelopmental impairments, and mortality. In addition to the goal of limiting IH, the following factors should be considered when deciding on hemoglobin oxygen saturation (Spo₂) targets:

- Low Spo₂ targets (ie, 85%–89%) result in increased short and long events, particularly in the first 2 weeks after birth.¹
- The pulse oximeter averaging time affects the number of events detected.² Averaging times longer than 2 seconds underestimate IH events of short duration and overestimate IH of long duration. Of note, the typical averaging times used in clinical oximeter are between 8 and 10 seconds to decrease alarm fatigue.

In addition, multiple studies have shown that health care professionals grossly underestimate the burden of events when compared with automated detection systems. In one study, health care professionals documented only 29% and 35% of events lasting more than 10 seconds and 20 seconds, respectively.³

## 94. A. Caffeine is likely to have reduced the frequency of apnea events in this patient compared to if she had received no treatment.

Caffeine therapy has been shown to be effective in reducing the frequency of apnea events in preterm infants.¹ Caffeine exerts its effect by blocking adenosine A1 and A2 receptors and acts both centrally and peripherally to stimulate the medullary respiratory centers, increases carbon dioxide sensitivity, induces bronchodilation, and enhances diaphragmatic function.²,³

In addition, data from the Caffeine for Apnea of Prematurity trial indicate that caffeine is safe and results in

- Improved respiratory outcomes with reductions in duration of mechanical ventilation and rates of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (from 46.9%–36.3%).
- Decrease in the combined outcome of death or survival with major disability at 18 months' postmenstrual age. At the 5-year follow-up, children in the caffeine group had improved motor coordination and visual perception.⁴⁻⁶

96. C. Opiate treatment for sedation has been associated with increased risk of VAP.

Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is a serious complication of mechanical ventilation in neonates. Diagnostic criteria in the neonatal population overlap with other conditions, and as a result, the diagnosis of VAP is subjective in many cases.¹ The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) criteria for the diagnosis of VAP in neonates include²

- Radiographic criteria: new or progressive infiltrate and persistent infiltrate, consolidation, cavitation, or pneumatoceles
- Clinical criteria of worsening gas exchange
- At least 3 of the following items: temperature instability; leukopenia, leukocytosis, or left shift; changes in the secretion pattern; apnea or increase in work of breathing; abnormal lung auscultation; and bradycardia or tachycardia

Of note, in its most current recommendations, the CDC defines ventilator-associated events as increase in fraction of inspired oxygen 0.25 or greater or mean airway pressure 4 cm H₂O or greater over baseline for at least 2 days.

The following risk factors have been found to be associated with the development of VAP³,⁴:

- Low birth weight
- Need for prolonged mechanical ventilation
- Sedation with opiates
- Frequent suctioning and reintubation
- A history of bloodstream infection
- Steroid use

97. B. One consideration for surgical repair, even in asymptomatic patients, is that complications including pneumonia or infection of the cystic elements may occur.

The treatment of congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) depends on whether or not the patient is symptomatic. Patients with antenatal presentations complicated by hydrops or very large CPAM should be referred to centers that can provide fetal surgery and/or have expertise with the postnatal evaluation and management of CPAM. Acutely symptomatic patients require surgical intervention in the newborn period. Asymptomatic patients can be treated expectantly with plan for elective diagnostic study (chest tomography with contrast) for surgical planning. Resection of the lesion is most commonly performed during the first year after birth. Observation alone in asymptomatic patients remains controversial because of the risk of infection, air leak, and malignancy. Open resection using a thoracotomy or thoracoscopic lobectomy are both an option in the surgical treatment of these patients.¹⁻³

98. D. Small and large for gestational age neonates are at increased risk of developing TTN.

Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a common cause of neonatal respiratory distress. It affects 10% of neonates born at 33 to 34 weeks' gestation, 5% of neonates born at 35 to 36 weeks' gestation, and less than 1% of all term neonates. Risk factors for TTN include¹

- Cesarean delivery without labor
- Preterm birth
- Male sex

100. B. Spontaneous breaths in excess of 32 breaths per minute will not be supported by the ventilator.

Synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV) is a time-cycled, pressure-limited mode. In SIMV mode, a set number of synchronized breaths are delivered by the ventilator (ie, 32 breaths per minute in this vignette). The tidal volume (V_T) delivered will vary based on compliance. Spontaneous breaths above the set rate are not supported, which can result in uneven V_T delivery (lower during spontaneous breaths) and may lead to increase in work of breathing during weaning. In addition, there is concern of rebreathing of dead space and subsequent inadequate alveolar ventilation (alveolar ventilation = minute ventilation - dead space).¹ However, the routine use of pressure support ventilation in combination with SIMV mitigates this problem.²

## 102. A. Bubble CPAP generates a variable distending pressure.

Bubble continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is characterized by variable distending pressure due to its unique design where the distending pressure is generated by submerging the expiratory limb in water.¹ This system can be readily translated to low-resource areas at a low cost. With bubble CPAP, the intraprong pressure may be higher than expected and is higher with higher flow rates.²,³

In a randomized controlled trial, the duration of CPAP support was decreased by 50% for preterm neonates 24 to 29 weeks' gestation in the bubble CPAP group compared with those in the ventilator-derived CPAP group. Further, there was a decrease in extubation failure in neonates ventilated for fewer than 14 days.⁴ In addition, units who use bubble CPAP as their primary mode of respiratory support in preterm neonates have reported sustained low rates of bronchopulmonary dysplasia.⁵

## 103. E. The leak around the endotracheal tube may vary from moment to moment depending on the positioning of the neonate's head or changes in tension on the tube.

Multiple aspects of mechanical ventilation are unique to the neonatal population, including

- Lung mechanics characterized by poor compliance, thereby predicting very short time constant, and the need for rapid respiratory rates.
- Limited muscle strength and ability to generate strong inspiratory flow or pressure, which may lead to triggering challenges and asynchrony.
- The use of uncuffed endotracheal tubes resulting in variable leak based on head position and tension of the tube. The leak is typically greater in inflation, emphasizing the need to measure inspired and expired tidal volume (V_T) in this population.
- Low V_T requirements (ie, 2–5 mL for neonates 400–1,000 g) leading to significant challenges in measuring V_T accurately. In neonates, standard measurements at the ventilator result in grossly inaccurate V_T because of loss of volume to the circuit. Because accurate V_T measurement is critical to successful volume-controlled or volume-targeted ventilation, attention to where the V_T is measured is necessary.¹

## 104. D. Caffeine treatment has been associated with a decreased likelihood of patent ductus arteriosus requiring treatment.

The effects of caffeine on the cardiovascular system include the following:

- Increased in heart rate. Of note tachycardia alone is not helpful in predicting toxic caffeine levels.¹

## 105. A. Bronchiolitis obliterans

The 5-year survival after lung transplantation in infants and children is 50%. Short-term morbidities are largely secondary to infections. Bronchiolitis obliterans and infections represent the most common long-term morbidities, in 57% of patients and 43% of patients, respectively. Other long-term morbidities include malignancy, gastroenteritis/dehydration, acute rejection, and posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder.¹

## 106. B. Canalicular phase

Lung development occurs in 5 overlapping stages.¹,²

- The embryonic stage (0–7 weeks), with formation of the lung bud and conducting airways (trachea, lobar, and segmental and subsegmental bronchi).
- The pseudoglandular stage (7–17 weeks), characterized by branching morphogenesis and formation of the conducting airways and terminal bronchioles. Type II pneumocyte are undifferentiated and pleuroperitoneal folds close during that stage of lung development.
- The canalicular stage (16 to 23–27 weeks), during which terminal branching occurs resulting in the formation of respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and primitive alveoli. Differentiation of type II pneumocytes with emergence of lamellar bodies occurs during this stage of lung development.
- The saccular stage (26–28 to 36–38 weeks) is characterized by enlargement of the peripheral airways, saccule formation with thinning of the alveolar wall, and surfactant production in type II pneumocytes.
- The alveolar stage (approximately 36 weeks–2 years) is characterized by further thinning of the alveolar wall, secondary septation, and formation of the definitive alveoli resulting in exponential increase in the lung surface area for gas exchange.

## 107. A. Ventilated patients pose particular problems in effective administration of aerosol because large amounts of aerosol are deposited in ventilated tubing and proximal airways without reaching peripheral airways.

Inhaled corticosteroids are an attractive option for the treatment and prevention of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) because of the theoretical advantage of high local drug delivery without the adverse effects observed with systemic administration. However, the delivery of inhaled steroid in intubated preterm neonates is complicated by large amounts of aerosol deposited in the ventilator tubing and proximal airways with very little drug delivered to the lungs. In an animal model, only 1% to 2% of the aerosolized drug was delivered to the lung using the metered-dose inhaler technique.¹ Because of this, the use of surfactant as a vehicle for inhaled corticosteroid delivery has been studied in a pilot trial with promising results.² In this pilot trial, 116 very low birth weight neonates requiring mechanical ventilation and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO₂) 0.6 or greater shortly after birth were randomized to budesonide and beractant (Survanta) or beractant alone every 8 hours until FiO₂ less than 0.4 or extubation. Neonates who received budesonide required lower mean airway pressure and had lower Paco₂ and FiO₂ requirements during the first 3 days. In addition, the combined primary outcome of death or BPD was lower in the budesonide group.

## 108. C. A sterile tracheal aspirate culture has a high negative predictive value for VAP.

The diagnosis of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is complex in neonates because obtaining non-contaminated specimens (ie, from a bronchoscopy-guided bronchoalveolar lavage) is challenging in this population. As such, diagnostic criteria from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) include a combination of clinical factors (worsening gas exchange, changes in secretions, temperature instability, abnormal white blood cell count, apnea or increased work of breathing, abnormal lung auscultation, and bradycardia or tachycardia) as well as radiographic findings to establish the diagnosis of VAP.¹ However, these criteria are nonspecific, occurring in other common neonatal conditions, and as a result the diagnosis of VAP is often subjective.² In its most current recommendations, the CDC defines ventilator-associated events as increase in fraction of inspired oxygen 0.25 or greater or mean airway pressure 4 cm H₂O or more over baseline for at least 2 days.¹

Tracheal aspirates have overall low sensitivity, specificity, and positive predictive value for the diagnosis of VAP. They may, however, be helpful in identifying colonization organisms and guide antibiotic therapy in neonates diagnosed with VAP.³ Because of these limitations, investigators have studied the utility of sterile tracheal aspirate cultures in the neonatal population and have reported high negative predictive value of this technique.⁴

## 109. D. There are multiple acceptable options regarding timing of surfactant administration, as treatment does not benefit neonates who do not have RDS but delay in treatment for a patient with RDS could lead to complications.

Surfactant is an important therapeutic option in neonates with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Some neonates with RDS can be managed successfully on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) or noninvasive positive pressure ventilation and avoid intubation and mechanical ventilation altogether. However, some neonates will have progressive RDS and proceed to require intubation and surfactant administration.

As such, the decision to proceed with surfactant administration is complex and should weigh the following considerations carefully:

- Gestational age of the neonate. The risk of CPAP failure increases at lower gestational ages.
- Age of the neonate. In neonates with RDS requiring assisted ventilation, earlier surfactant administration, within 1 to 2 hours of birth, is preferable to late-rescue surfactant and has been shown to decrease the risk of mortality, air leaks, and bronchopulmonary dysplasia.¹²
- Severity and progression of RDS. While fraction of inspired oxygen thresholds are used in the decision to administer surfactant in non-intubated neonates, there is no consensus on what parameters should be considered and wide variability in clinical practice exist. The European consensus guidelines for the management of RDS suggest a threshold of 30% for neonates younger than 26 weeks' gestation and 40% for older infants.³ While the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends earlier (within 2 hours) surfactant administration, the consensus statement does not provide specific guidelines on when to administer surfactant in spontaneously breathing neonates receiving noninvasive respiratory support.²

## 110. D. Several studies have shown an association of frequent IH events and more severe retinopathy of prematurity.

Preclinical and clinical evidence support the concept that intermittent hypoxemia (IH) episodes have a cumulative effect on mortality and morbidity. Data from experimental models indicate that IH increases oxidative stress and inflammation and leads to increase in white matter injury as well as neurofunctional deficits.¹

In preterm infants, longer and more variable IH events as well as higher percentage of time spent with oxygen saturation below 80% have been linked to increased risk of retinopathy of prematurity.²,³ In addition, an increase in IH events is also correlated with adverse neurodevelopmental impairments at 18 months, as well as late mortality.³ In a post hoc analysis, small for gestational age infants with increased IH in the first 3 days after birth were found to have increased 90-day mortality compared with appropriate for gestational age infants.²

## 112. C. One gram of hemoglobin carries about 1.34 mL of oxygen when fully saturated.

Because oxygen is very insoluble, it is transported by hemoglobin. The maximum oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin is 1.34 mL of oxygen per gram of hemoglobin. When all available hemoglobin sites are saturated with oxygen, the oxygen saturation is 100%, regardless of the hemoglobin level. Together hemoglobin and arterial oxygen saturation are the major determinant of arterial oxygen content (Cao₂). The contribution of dissolved oxygen is minimal (0.003 mL of oxygen per millimeter of mercury) and can typically be ignored. Taking the example of the newborns described in the vignette,

---

<!-- Page 637 -->

Respiratory
629

- Twin A (oxygen saturation 100%, hemoglobin 20 g/dL) has a Cao₂ of 26.8 mL/dL (20 × 1.34).
- Twin B (oxygen saturation 100%, hemoglobin 8 g/dL) has a Cao₂ of 10.7 (8 × 1.34).

This emphasizes the major effect of anemia on Cao₂. Even if Twin A's oxygen saturation dropped to 90% (ie, 90% of hemoglobin-binding sites are occupied), the Cao₂ would remain much higher than that of Twin B (24.1 mL/dL). This explains why tissue hypoxia may occur in severely anemic patients despite oxygen saturation of 100%.

## 113. B. Phosphatidylcholine

Lipids constitute 90% of surfactant and include phospholipids and neutral lipids. Phosphatidylcholine, particularly in its desaturated form dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine, is the main phospholipid responsible for lowering surface tension. Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine represents about 50% of surfactant by weight. In addition to lipids, surfactant also contains surfactant proteins that facilitate absorption and spreading of the phospholipid monolayer and are essential for the optimal dynamic behavior and function of surfactant.¹,²

Multiple drugs that are substrates of cytochrome P450 1A2, the major enzyme involved in caffeine metabolism, can lead to increase or decrease in caffeine elimination and may require dosing adjustments. ## 115. A. Arrested alveolar septation

Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) was first described by Northway and colleagues in 1967. Classic, or "old," BPD describes neonates with chronic respiratory failure associated with characteristic radiographic sequelae from prolonged mechanical ventilation and oxygen toxicity, in the pre-surfactant era. In these neonates, lung injury is characterized by airway injury, smooth muscle hypertrophy, and marked inflammation, as well as areas of parenchymal lung fibrosis alternating with areas of hyperinflation.¹

The hallmark of new BPD is arrest of normal alveolar septation and microvascular development resulting in diffuse alveolar/capillary hypoplasia and marked decrease in surface area for gas exchange. In contrast to classic BPD, airway injury, inflammation, and fibrosis are usually milder.²,³

1. C. Cost-effectiveness analysis

Economic evaluations in health care may use similar methods in determining costs but differ in assessing the intervention's effectiveness. The most common type of economic evaluation, which may use data from randomized controlled trials, is a cost-effectiveness analysis.¹,² In these studies, effectiveness is expressed as a change in a clinical outcome, such as the change in bronchopulmonary dysplasia, mortality, or neurodevelopmental outcome. In a cost-utility analysis, which is a specific type of cost-effectiveness analysis, clinical outcomes are weighted according to individuals' preferences, or utilities, and then are converted to quality-adjusted life years or disability-adjusted life years.

16. E. The negative predictive value of this test will depend on the prevalence of sepsis in the tested population, with higher disease prevalence leading to decreased negative predictive value.

Diagnostic tests are characterized by the following parameters:

- Sensitivity: the proportion of subjects with the disease in whom the test gives the correct answer (true-positive result)
- Specificity: the proportion of subjects without the disease in whom the test gives the right answer (true-negative result)
- Positive predictive value: the proportion of subjects with positive tests who have the disease, as calculated by true-positive results ÷ (true-positive results + false-positive results)
- Negative predictive value: the proportion of subjects with negative tests who do not have the disease, as calculated by true-negative results ÷ (false-negative results + true-negative results)

For a given test, when there is increased prevalence of disease, the positive predictive value will increase and the negative predictive value will decrease. Sensitivity and specificity are independent of prevalence.¹

1. Norman GR, Streiner DL. Biostatistics: The Bare Essentials. Hamilton, ON: B.C. Decker; 2008

## 21. B. Dose-response relationship: mothers who used more marijuana had neonates with even lower birth weight than did mothers who used smaller amounts of marijuana

In a classic essay entitled, “The Environment and Disease: Association or Causation,” the British epidemiologist Sir Austin Bradford Hill described the criteria for causation (Hill’s criteria for causation).¹ While there are slight modifications in various versions that cite Hill’s criteria, the following summarizes the core principles:

- Temporal relationship: exposure occurs before the occurrence of disease (outcome)
- Strength of the association: measured by relative risk or odds ratio
- Specificity of the association: a specific exposure is associated with only 1 disease
- Dose-response relationship: increasing dose of exposure leads to increasing risk of disease
- Biological plausibility: the relationship is in agreement with the body of biological knowledge
- Replication of findings: replication in different populations and different studies
- Cessation of exposure: the risk of disease decreases with decreasing or removing the exposure
- Consistency with other knowledge: association is found in different subgroups, such as in both men and women
- Consideration of alternate explanations: if alternate explanations are excluded, likelihood of causation increases

## References

1. Hill AB. The environment and disease: association or causation? Proc R Soc Med. 1965;58(5):295–300

## 22. C. Study design

Studies considered in a given systematic review often have differences. This variability among studies in a systematic review is termed heterogeneity. Clinical heterogeneity refers to variability in the participants, interventions, and outcomes considered. Methodological heterogeneity refers to variability in the study design. Clinical or methodological heterogeneity may contribute to measurable statistical heterogeneity. Methods have been developed for quantifying inconsistency across studies that move the focus away from testing whether heterogeneity is present (which is almost inevitable) to assessing the effect of heterogeneity on the meta-analysis. The $I^2$ statistic is used to evaluate whether substantial heterogeneity is present in a meta-analysis and may influence its interpretation.¹

## References

1. Higgins JPT, Green S, eds. Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions Version 5.0.2. Oxford, United Kingdom: The Cochrane Collaboration; 2009

## 23. D. Presymptomatic state: this screening is a form of secondary prevention, allowing for detection of the condition at an earlier point in the natural history of the disease

The rationale for implementing a screening test depends on several factors:

- Prevalence: The prevalence of the detectable preclinical phase of the disease should be reasonably high among the population screened.
- Accuracy: The test should have a high ability to detect true disease and to distinguish between who has a disease and who does not. A screening test ideally should be highly sensitive and reasonably specific to detect disease but also not lead to too many false-positive results.
- Risk-benefit ratio: The costs, benefits, and risks should be considered for both those affected by the disease and those who may have positive results even though they do not have the disease.
- Presymptomatic state: The test should be available to detect the condition before the onset of symptoms or at least early in the disease course. Once a patient has symptoms, the natural history of a disease may continue to progress to a critical point beyond which an appropriate treatment is less effective or more difficult to administer.

The rationale for pulse oximetry for congenital heart disease screening has been established based on these factors.¹²

1. Mahle W, Koppel R. Screening with pulse oximetry for congenital heart disease. Lancet. 2011;378(9793):749-750

- Respect for persons: individuals should be treated as autonomous agents; persons with diminished autonomy are entitled to protection
- Beneficence: do no harm; maximize possible benefits and minimize possible harm; consider the risks and benefits to society or particular populations, as well as to the individual subject
- Justice: distribute the burdens and benefits of research equitably such that potential subjects (or populations) are not targeted disproportionately to bear the brunt of the risk or excluded when they benefit from participation

## 35. E. Greater than 0.9

Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves are created by plotting the sensitivity at a specific threshold on the y-axis, with 1 – specificity of the same test at the same threshold plotted on the x-axis.¹ The diagnostic performance of the test is plotted at multiple thresholds to create a curve. The area under the curve (AUC) is a summary statistic that describes the accuracy of the test. When the optimal cutoff for a quantitative test moves closer to (0,1), the AUC increases. A test that is only as good as chance has an AUC of 0.5, whereas a perfect test would have an AUC of 1.0.
